HEADLINE: Art and Money

 BODY:
The arts are headed for trouble. Public funding is shrinking as legislators cut programs for ideological or budgetary reasons. Private funding, which some hope will fill the gap, is also tightening as foundations and individuals struggle to meet expanding needs in an uncertain economy.
The potential for harm is dismaying. The marriage of public and private funds has sustained a remarkable diversity of organizations and made the arts an important, accessible part of American life. You do not have to live in a great urban center or travel hundreds of miles to see a great dance company or a great painting anymore. In the 30 years since the National Endowment for the Arts was established, for instance, the number of professional orchestras in this country has increased from 110 to 230, dance companies from 37 to 450 and opera companies from 27 to 120. 
 According to a new Rockefeller Foundation report, "Looking Ahead, Private Sector Giving to the Arts and the Humanities," public-private financial support for the arts is diminishing just when Americans are showing a powerful enthusiasm for them. Total private giving to the arts (from individuals, corporations and foundations) was $9.57 billion in 1993 and $9.68 billion in 1994. Adjust the figures for inflation and the result is actually a 2 percent drop in giving. That drop is almost certain to continue, given the increased competition for private support from various social and community groups suffering government cutbacks.
The slackening of support for the arts may have economic as well as cultural consequences. Many states and localities have discovered that the arts are considerably more than enliveners of the human spirit. They also generate tourist dollars.
If the N.E.A.'s commitment to decentralizing the arts was not wholly responsible for the cultural buttering of America, it was certainly a catalyst. But the N.E.A.'s funding has already been cut and is scheduled to take a bigger hit -- 39 percent -- next year.
Foundations, the report warns, are in no position to take up the slack. Many have even shifted some money that once would have gone to the arts to human services. Furthermore, there has been a decline in the willingness of Americans to support charitable giving in general, and arts giving in particular. The same percentage of households continues to contribute but on a much smaller scale -- a shift paralleled by the increase in the percentage of people worried about their own economic futures. Corporate giving, which had sunk steadily since 1987, is slowly rising, but not to its 1980's levels.
Money for new projects and new artists and an ability to leverage private funding are not all that the N.E.A. has contributed to the cultural scene. Its size has allowed for long-range planning and innovation. It constitutes, in effect, a national knowledge bank on the arts and arts organizations.
The recently formed Center for Arts and Culture, established by a dozen or so foundations -- Rockefeller among them -- to study the state of cultural policy in the United States, can help fill the gap, at least as an educator and disseminator of information. But it cannot possibly replace a Federal agency's reach and scope. Cities and regions that recognize the potential revenues in cultural tourism will have to provide more of their own funding. Struggling arts organizations everywhere will have no choice but to scratch harder for support.

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Tuesday
The Federal Open Market Committee meets to discuss the state of the economy and to determine monetary policy for the next six weeks. There is no clear consensus among economists and Fed watchers as to whether interest rates will be cut, despite a slew of data indicating that the economy has slowed.
 
The Commerce Department reports final numbers for gross domestic product in the third quarter. Growth of about 4.4 percent is expected.
 
The Commerce Department reports on November housing starts. After declines in September and October, an increase of less than 1 percent is expected.
 
The Senate is expected to approve a $275 billion military spending bill that President Clinton has said he will veto because of the costly anti-missile defense system it includes. The bill, which includes $7 billion more than the President sought for the military, was approved by the House on Friday -- but not by the two-thirds majority that would be needed to override a veto.
 
The Bank of Mexico will offer short-term Treasury notes with terms of 28, 90, and 182 days, with a total value of 2.7 billion pesos, about $347 million.
 
The Johnson Redbook research service will issue its weekly survey of sales at department, discount and chain stores. All the indications are that it has not been a happy holiday season for most retailers.
 
Wednesday
 
Shareholders of the Union Electric Company of St. Louis are expected to approve a $1.2 billion merger offer from Cipsco.
 
The Commerce Department reports on merchandise trade for October. A deficit of $8.7 billion is expected, with import growth likely to be stronger than export growth. The monthly deficit was $8.4 billion in both September and October.
 
The Energy Department issues its weekly report on petroleum stocks, production, imports and refinery use, while the American Gas Association releases its weekly report on natural gas inventory.
 
Thursday
 
The Treasury Department releases its November budget statement. A deficit of $29.2 billion is expected, up sharply from $22.8 billion in October.
 
The Commerce Department reports on personal income and spending in October. Income is expected to rise one-tenth of 1 percent.
 
Friday
 
The University of Michigan releases its monthly report on consumer sentiment. In October, the index of consumer confidence dropped to 88.2 from 90.2, which was lower than expected.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

THE NETWORKS
 
An Active Week for NBC
Persuading the International Olympic Committee to abandon competitive bidding, NBC agreed to pay $2.3 billion for the broadcast and cable rights to the 2004 and 2008 Summer Olympics and the 2006 Winter Olympics, even though where those games will be held -- and significantly for broadcasters, in what time zone -- has not been decided. The committee went along with NBC's pre-emptive strike in return for the promise of a cut of the advertising revenues if they exceed certain levels. NBC had previously won the rights to the Summer Games in Sydney, Australia, in 2000 and the Winter Games in Salt Lake City in 2002.
Then, gaining what could be an enormous advantage over ABC, which has announced plans for an all-news cable channel, NBC said Microsoft would pay $220 million for a 50 percent interest in NBC's America's Talking cable channel and help convert it to an all-news operation. The big question is whether the audience for all-news programming is big enough to sustain a rival to CNN. The companies will also cooperate in providing news to computer users through an on-line service.
 
DEVELOPMENT
 
E.P.A. Veto Power at Risk
Buried deep in a spending bill now before Congress is a provision that would strip the Environmental Protection Agency of a major tool for protecting the wetlands: its veto over permits that the Army Corps of Engineers issues for wetlands development projects. One interesting footnote: Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri and the author of the provision, said he had "no idea" what projects might be affected by the change.
 
BANKING
 
Addition, Then Subtraction
The Bank of Boston said it would pay $2 billion for Baybanks, the leading consumer bank in New England, in a deal that would create the 15th-largest bank in the country. The banks said they would close 85 of their combined 400 branches and eliminate 2,000 of their 24,500 jobs.
 
TRADE
 
Renewed Concerns on China
While standing by its policy of not linking trade relations with human rights, the White House made clear that China's increasingly belligerent positions on both fronts had made it politically impossible to support Beijing's admission to the World Trade Organization.
 
MANAGEMENT
 
Arrivederci, Agnelli
After 30 years as head of Fiat, Italy's largest employer, Giovanni Agnelli said he would step down soon as chairman and be succeeded by the managing director, Cesare Romiti. That will allow more time to season Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, 31, the eventual replacement for his uncle. Fiat, an acronym for Fabbrica Italiana di Automobili Torino, was founded in 1899 by the grandfather of the retiring chairman.
 
AIR SAFETY
 
Cockpit Time, Sack Time
Asserting that pilot fatigue contributes to crashes, the F.A.A. proposed limiting pilots to a 14-hour shift followed by 10 hours of rest, down from the current 16-hour shift and an 8- or 9-hour break. The Airline Transport Association, an industry group, objects to the proposals. The agency also put into force rules for commuter aircraft that are intended to make them as safe as larger airliners.
 
COSMETICS
 
A Makeover for Maybelline
L'Oreal, based in France and the world's largest cosmetics company, agreed to buy Maybelline, broadening its line and its reach in the United States. Maybelline's strength is modestly priced products sold in discount and drug stores, L'Oreal's Cosmair unit makes Lancome, Ralph Lauren, Giorgio Armani and other prestige lines.
 
RETAILING
 
Does Staff Morale Affect Sales?
Sales staff at 15 Macy's stores, most in the New York suburbs, have been told they will receive a sales commission of 3.96 percent, a steep cut from the 6 percent they have received until now. Unionized employees at the flagship store in Herald Square and three others are not affected by the cut, which Macy's executives said was but another attempt to reduce operating costs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: LABOR -- Back to Work at Boeing -- Approving a contract that gave them much of what they sought, machinists to work after a 69-day strike at Boeing, the world's largest aircraft maker. Under pressure from airlines whose orders for planes were in jeopardy, Boeing retreated from its demands, including one that workers pay more for health care insurance. The company also agreed to retrain and retain any worker whose job was eliminated because of subcontracting to nonunion plants in the United States or cheaper foreign manufacturers. On their first day back at work, Irv Sensel, above left, and Matt Bauermeister, work on an engine on a 777 jetliner. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Mexican Collapse

BYLINE: By Timothy Golden; Tim Golden, who was Mexico City bureau chief for The New York Times from 1991 to 1995, is on leave as a Neiman Fellow at Harvard University.

 BODY:

THE MEXICAN SHOCK
Its Meaning for the United States.
By Jorge G. Castaneda.
254 pp. New York: The New Press. $23.
MEXICO'S violent awakening from the first-world dreams it entertained during the presidency of Carlos Salinas de Gortari has been a boon to the country's publishers. The struggle to explain what happened -- the peasant uprising, the political assassinations, the anticlimactic election and the economic collapse -- has become a melee of memoirs, exposes and campaign year kiss-and-tells. Book parties in Mexico City are often no parties at all, but political events attended by hundreds of people and by great debate about who did what to whom. 
 Jorge G. Castaneda, a political scientist at the National Autonomous University of Mexico and a longtime critic of the Salinas Government, is among the first to produce a book-length study of the country's recent turmoil for readers in English. The effort already seems overdue. A new relationship with the United States was central to the bright future that Mr. Salinas promised; the image of a new Mexico that he appeared to embody helped win approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement in Washington. The Clinton Administration and Republicans on Capitol Hill shared the shock when Mr. Salinas's chosen successor, Ernesto Zedillo, botched a long-postponed devaluation of the peso and needed commitments of almost $50 billion in foreign loans to save the economy from collapse.
As Mr. Castaneda sees it, the Americans had it coming. Politicians, scholars, businessmen and the media all fell blindly in love with Mr. Salinas and his band of young, English-speaking technocrats, he asserts; thrilled with the Salinastas' faith in free markets and free trade, most of the gringos chose to ignore the undemocratic politics and unequal distribution of wealth that went along with them. "No one, it seems, was willing to analyze the overwhelming evidence of abuses and financial mismanagement in Mexico since 1988," Mr. Castaneda writes in "The Mexican Shock." "Those surprised by the economic collapse and the stench of it all had simply neglected to open their eyes."
The steadiness of Mr. Castaneda's own skepticism cannot be faulted. When others praised the renegotiation of Mexico's huge foreign debt in 1990, he warned that the terms could condemn the country to indentured servitude. While most Mexicans welcomed the trade accord, he saw another raw deal: uncompetitive Mexican industries left to perish, wrongheaded American immigration policies left intact. Mr. Castaneda, who sometimes advised leaders of the country's main leftist political party, states proudly that his lens is one of "systematic, virtually across-the-board criticism of the Salinas administration's program and the authoritarian political system upon which it rested."
His indictment is handed up in a series of essays written since mid-1993 for audiences ranging from Inter-American Dialogue to The Atlantic Monthly's. The concerns of this somewhat disparate compilation have to do with the shortcomings of Mexico's economic model, the breakdown of the political system and the dangers looming for the United States should it fail to grasp Mexico's predicament. If there is a central argument, it is perhaps that a successful transformation of the heavily protected and state-dominated economy was impossible without deeper political change. Mr. Castaneda contends that the failure of a flawed economic strategy was predictable, even inevitable so long as the Government's authoritarian controls allowed it to ignore pressures for moderation, from a slower opening to foreign trade to adjusting the exchange rate.
Mr. Castaneda's complaints about the refusal of the Salinas Government to adopt some sort of industrial policy and build domestic savings sound even more valid now, as the Zedillo administration gropes for a way to absorb the growing millions of unemployed. Some analysts will quarrel with his dismissal of the possibility that Mr. Salinas might have succeeded in his gamble to balance huge deficits in Mexico's trade and debt accounts with foreign investment, but the case is at least clearly argued. Readers will probably have more trouble sorting out what Mr. Castaneda means to say about Mexican politics. At one point, he explains the violence that racked the country in 1993 and 1994 as a national equivalent of what French psychoanalysts call "the return of the repressed" -- "indirect results, consequences indecipherable in their precise mechanism, of a problem left unresolved or buried in the national unconscious." Farther on, he attributes the killings of a Roman Catholic cardinal and two governing-party leaders to the partial dismantling of the patronage system that traditionally resolved disputes within the ruling elite. The problem with this idea is not simply that it is still rather speculative -- Government investigations have yet to show any clear tie between the various crimes and continuing struggles within the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party -- but that makes it harder to understand the party's resilience now.
MR. CASTANEDA wonders whether the current chaotic state of affairs might not in fact represent a kind of status quo. But while that notion represents a noteworthy break from the prevailing faith among Mexican intellectuals that the PRI, as the governing party is called, will disintegrate any day now, readers unschooled in Mexican politics may be hard pressed to understand from the preceding discussion how Mr. Zedillo ever got elected and why he hasn't been overthrown. Mr. Castaneda emphasizes the fears of an opposition victory that the Government worked hard to build, particularly among the poor. Still, his triumphal focus on the evils of the Salinas regime tends to obscure other sources of the country's difficulties: the weakness of demands for political change among ordinary Mexicans, the failure of opposition leaders to articulate convincing alternatives, the remarkable (if largely superficial) adaptation of traditional ruling-party bosses to changing rules of the game.
Admirers of Mr. Castaneda's 1993 study of the political left in Latin America, "Utopia Unarmed," may wish that he had sat down and written a whole book about Mexico's moment, instead of patching one together from earlier writings. The sort of profile sketches that made "Utopia Unarmed" more readable are missed here: Mexican political figures drop into the narrative like strange guests and then quickly disappear, while others are mentioned but never identified, and the same statistics and ideas are sometimes marshaled more than once in slightly different form. An essay written in mid-1993 makes clear what political consequences Mr. Castaneda foresaw for the free trade agreement before it passed, but it does not make for an irresistible read now. Throughout "The Mexican Shock," Mr. Castaneda makes a strong case for Americans' need to understand his country better. This time, however, he contributes less to that cause than he might.

HEADLINE: Displaced Persons

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe; Alan Wolfe teaches sociology at Boston University. He is writing a book about middle-class morality.

 BODY:

FRESH BLOOD
The New American Immigrants.
By Sanford J. Ungar.
399 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $25.
 
AMERICAN DREAMING
Immigrant Life on the Margins.
By Sarah J. Mahler.
Illustrated. 268 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press.
Cloth, $49.50. Paper, $15.95.
SANFORD J. UNGAR and Sarah J. Mahler recount the human tales that are ignored when Americans, and their politicians, turn their anger against immigrants. If we appreciated the difficulties recent arrivals face, both authors maintain, we would be less likely to blame them for problems of our own making. 
In "Fresh Blood," Mr. Ungar, the dean of the School of Communications at American University, talks to immigrants everywhere, but he concentrates on such relatively unknown groups as the Laotian Hmong in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area; the Mashadi Jews of Iran, now living in Queens; Washington's Ethiopians and Eritreans; and "second wave" Poles and Irish migrating to already well-established ethnic neighborhoods in Chicago and Boston. Through his eyes we experience the conflicts felt by nearly all immigrants between group loyalty and the seductions of assimilation, the benefits of having karate lessons or Alcoholics Anonymous meetings in one's native language, and the tensions within ethnic categories that most Americans view as homogeneous.
"Fresh Blood" humanizes the people it depicts. Christopher Thao, one of 11 children of illiterate Hmong parents, came alone from Laos to Jasper, Ark., at the age of 18 and is now a lawyer in a major St. Paul firm. Sophia Kim, who is married to an Ethiopian, is proud that her children "may be the only Korean-Ethiopians in the United States." But Mr. Ungar's fine book is not simply a collection of success stories. He favors expansive welcoming policies but is unsure whether they demand an appreciation of "adaptation gone awry," or a recognition that "immigrants help renew, enrich and rediscover the values of America." As if in acknowledgment of the complexities of the matter, his policy proposals are modest, his opinions muted.
In this he is worlds apart from Ms. Mahler, an anthropologist at the University of Vermont who, in "American Dreaming," focuses on illegal immigrants on Long Island. Her subjects -- poor Salvadorans and primarily middle-class South Americans from Peru, Chile and Colombia -- have fascinating stories to tell. At home there was little but horror: a nun speaks of her rape and subsequent pregnancy, other people of being caught between left-wing guerrillas and right-wing terrorists, and most tell of a subsistence existence unimaginable to the majority of Americans. The passage from that world to this one is filled with anxiety: near-starvation on the journey through Mexico, possible betrayal from the "coyotes" who act as brokers of human freedom, the uncertainties of the border crossing itself. Once the immigrants are here, their jobs pay well compared to those at home, but the cost of living is unexpectedly higher. For Ms. Mahler, the life of illegals is filled with "deceit, dejection, marginalization and exploitation."
Ms. Mahler's narrative skills bring these people to life, which makes it a shame that her didactic intrusions and overweening political opinions squeeze the life right back out of them. Juanita is overcharged by fellow Hispanics for housing, but, Ms. Mahler laments, "she never mentions the structural causes of the crisis." Some people proudly manifest their success by wearing gold chains and fancy clothing, but, Ms. Mahler editorializes, "more substantial success remains elusive." The Salvadorans and Ms. Mahler speak different languages: she wants them to talk about injustice, discrimination and alienation, they want to talk about their accomplishments, their disdain for African-Americans and their in-group bickerings. They drive cars; she complains about the costs of automobile insurance and the design of the Long Island Expressway.
Both authors believe that to like immigration it helps to like immigrants. But this is just as fallacious as the notion, common on the right, that to dislike immigration one must dislike immigrants. Most immigrants are just trying to get by. Personalizing their stories, as important as that may be, runs risks in the debate over immigration that neither author fully appreciates.
For one thing, the personal experiences of the immigrants themselves are not the crucial factor in judging the morality of immigration policy. Even if life on the margins in the United States is as awful as Ms. Mahler maintains, most would still choose it if it offered the possibility of a better life for their children.
In addition, tales of woe raise the inevitable question, which personal stories can never answer, of whether there exists a means of comparing suffering. Yes, immigrants find life difficult in America. But so do native-born Americans. Mr. Ungar dutifully records stories about immigrant children having racial epithets thrown in their faces, while Ms. Mahler explains the many ways in which illegal immigrants can be paid too little or charged too much. Yet surely some perspective is required before the moral books are closed. The obvious reason these authors lack perspective is that Mr. Ungar, and to a much greater degree Ms. Mahler, want Americans to feel guilty for the way they treat the immigrants in their midst. But one can also feel proud to belong to a country that offers immigrants a chance.
FINALLY, personalized accounts of immigration are of little help for policy makers. Since we can never open our borders to everyone, we have to make distinctions among different categories of claimants, all of whom have some justice on their side. The most important one we make is between political and economic refugees. Mr. Ungar is uncomfortable with that distinction, while Ms. Mahler snorts with contempt over its absurdity. Indeed it can be blunt. Yet something much like it is essential if we are to preserve a humanitarian immigration policy. Sometimes justice to those we do not yet know requires harshness to those in front of our faces. And that remains true even if we hear their stories and come to know them as people.
The most illustrative story in either book is told by Rafael Ramirez, a Peruvian described by Ms. Mahler. His journey to the United States was oppressive, his employment in this country sporadic. His family remained behind. Injured at work one day, he was awarded $40,000 and returned home to Callao. "I spent the first month drinking beers with everyone I knew," he told Ms. Mahler. "But I got bored. I had bought a house and furniture for it and everything, but I knew that I could no longer stay. So my wife and I decided to come back to the United States and we snuck over the border." Figure out the rights and wrongs in that one, and you may have an answer to the immigration question the rest of us lack.

HEADLINE: A Science of Contrasts

BYLINE: By Malcolm W. Browne; Malcolm W. Browne is a science reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE SAME AND NOT THE SAME
By Roald Hoffmann.
Illustrated. 294 pp. New York:
Columbia University Press.
$29.95.
TO savor the beauty of objects far too small to see or feel or taste requires a special sense -- one that develops in people who have a deep understanding of chemistry and its wondrous transformations. Most of us cannot share this sense, and we may consider the delight chemists claim to take in the contemplation of molecular beauty a mere affectation. 
 We are wrong, though, to scorn the chemist's vision of beauty; chemistry may seem smelly, violent and dangerous, but to its practitioners a molecule may really be a thing of beauty -- a beauty inaccessible to outsiders, cut off as we are by barriers between the languages of science and ordinary discourse.
Most of the high priests of chemistry eventually give up trying to explain to others what they do and why they relish their work. Arguably, chemistry is the most difficult of all the fundamental sciences, and to translate its quasi-mathematical nouns and verbs into spoken language is beyond the ability of most scientists. Even the ingenious metaphors writers invent to describe chemical processes -- devices the physicist Leon Lederman calls "tap-dancing" -- generally fall far short of expressing the reality of chemistry, much less its underlying beauty.
But Roald Hoffmann of Cornell University is a poet as well as a winner of the 1981 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, and he has never given up his lifelong campaign to illuminate the beauties of chemistry for the unenlightened. His latest book, "The Same and Not the Same," consists of roughly equal parts art and science, and its relaxed style, uncomplicated explanations and clever illustrations could qualify it as a primer for chemistry haters.
Despite his passionate love of the science, Mr. Hoffmann is no defender of the chemical industry or of suggestions that important policy issues involving science should be decided by scientists. It is perfectly proper, he believes, for ordinary people to favor words like "natural" and "organic" over "chemical" and "synthetic," even though the popular meanings of these words differ wildly from the chemist's understanding of them. Chemistry, like everything else, should be an element of democratic society, accessible to all and under the control of ordinary people, he says. And he contends that the tragedy of thalidomide -- which resulted in the birth of thousands of deformed infants -- could have been avoided by more effective social supervision of the chemical industry.
At the same time, Mr. Hoffmann is acutely aware that many people fear and dislike chemistry. He even seems to feel a certain isolation imposed by his calling. A Jewish survivor of the Holocaust whose father died in a Nazi concentration camp, Mr. Hoffmann writes:
"Chemists encounter frustratingly conflicting signals from society -- economic dependence and reward, coupled with an attitude from the media and some intellectuals that is abusive. I wonder if there are some parallels to the attitudes toward Jewish moneylenders in Europe in the Middle Ages."
Mr. Hoffmann cites the story of Fritz Haber, one of the greatest synthesis chemists of the 20th century, as illustration of the ambiguities inherent in the popular image of chemistry. Haber, an ardent German nationalist, was one of the inventors of a cheap and efficient process for making ammonia out of hydrogen and nitrogen. The process was ready when Germany went to war in 1914, providing not only fertilizer ("making bread out of air," as German propagandists called it) but munitions. In 1918 Haber was awarded the Nobel Prize for his synthesis of ammonia.
Haber also gave Germany one of the most horrible of weapons: poison gas. The German high command first put Haber's gases to work at Ypres in 1915, beginning the scourge that killed or maimed many thousands. But when the Nazis came to power in 1933, Haber, a Jew, was forced out of his university job and into exile in Switzerland, where he died an embittered man.
While Mr. Hoffmann's breezy style makes the synthesis of ammonia by the Haber process easily understood, he also offers a few samples of chemistry at its most impenetrable. Even with his great skill, he is occasionally reduced to hand-waving in place of real explanations of, say, the electronic orbitals that bind atoms together into molecules.
But a central theme of "The Same and Not the Same" is easily grasped: chemistry is strongly influenced by yin-yang symmetries and complementarities. It is a science of contrasts. For example, many molecules exist as pairs of mirror-image forms, each containing exactly the same atoms as the other but each differing radically from the other in its properties. The "left-handed" versions of some molecules may cure disease, while their "right-handed" mirror images may be deadly; they may differ as greatly from each other as did Stevenson's Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.
The final chapter sums up by alluding to the author's mythological hero, Cheiron the centaur. Cheiron, Mr. Hoffmann tells us, was "man and beast, not whole human, not wild beast. Stationary and fleet, a tenser, complex yet integrated being. Capable of harm, seeking for the good. Like chemistry."

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

WHERE THE SUCKERS MOON: The Life and Death of an Advertising Campaign
By Randall Rothenberg. Vintage, $14.
 The account was Subaru (stodgy), the agency was Wieden & Kennedy (young and hip), and the author, a former advertising columnist for The New York Times, had good reason to be skeptical of the union. This is the story of how the marriage unraveled, and it is "a delicious, subtly subversive fly-on-the-wall exploration," Joseph Nocera said here last year.
 
WHAT REMAINS AND OTHER STORIES
By Christa Wolf. Translated by Heike Schwarzbauer and Rick Takvorian. University of Chicago, $14.95. 
 Once an ardent East German Communist, the author grew to criticize her Government while also being its ostensible ally. These pieces of fiction articulate her uncomfortable position in narratives that are frequently autobiographical, evoking her feelings at the fall of Berlin to the Allies in 1945 and at being watched by her country's secret police as a mature woman. In 1993 our reviewer, Peter Demetz, wrote, "They provide an illuminating chance to enter Ms. Wolf's changing world . . . and to come closer to a consciousness increasingly pained by the creeping loss of what utopia had promised so easily." The University of Chicago has also reissued THE AUTHOR'S DIMENSION: Selected Essays, edited by Alexander Stephan, translated by Jan Van Heurck ($14.95), a collection that spans more than 25 years, in which Ms. Wolf reflects on subjects from the art of reading to the art of governing. Her "few speeches and essays after the fall of the Berlin wall are astonishingly accurate . . . in them, she has ceased to play ideological poker," Mr. Demetz said in the same review. The work of another contemporary German writer, this one from the West, is gathered in THE SELECTED STORIES OF SIEGFRIED LENZ, edited and translated by Breon Mitchell (Hydra Books/Northwestern University, $15.95). Also quietly critical of history, Mr. Lenz writes fiction that examines life during World War II and Germany's later "economic miracle." In 1989 Mr. Demetz wrote in these pages that the author's "voice has remained as sober, steady and sympathisch as ever."
 
WISHING ON THE MOON: The Life and Times of Billie Holiday
By Donald Clarke. Penguin, $13.95.
 This biography examines the often harsh circumstances that led to Billie Holiday's dual addictions to heroin and abusive men; it also lauds the singer's fine musicianship. The author "has written what may be the most thorough and valuable of the many books on Holiday," Francis Davis wrote here in 1994. The legacy of another jazz artist is explored in ASCENSION: John Coltrane and His Quest, by Eric Nisenson (Da Capo, $13.95), which combines the saxophonist's life story with a guide to his recordings. Last year our reviewer, David Royko, said the author brings "to life Coltrane's inner world by viewing music of today through the prism of his accomplishments." Da Capo has also reissued LISTEN TO THE BLUES, by Bruce Cook ($13.95), a study of a musical form many find hard to define. Published with a new introduction and discography, it offers insights "both valuable and fascinating," Frank Conroy wrote in the Book Review in 1974.
 
THE WAY TO THE CATS
By Yehoshua Kenaz. Translated by Dalya Bilu.
Steerforth Press, $14.
 This Israeli novel presents old age with all its ravages. Yolanda Moscowitz, 76, is recuperating from a broken leg in a rehabilitation center in Tel Aviv, where she hopes that her dignity won't go the way of her beauty. "Mr. Kenaz captures in sharp close-up the disjunction between one's self-image and the grim actuality," Lore Dickstein said in these pages last year.
 
IMPERIUM
By Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated by Klara
Glowczewska. Vintage International, $13.
 These essays form a highly personal account of the functioning and ultimate decline of the Soviet Union as seen by a Polish correspondent who until recently was the state's subject as much as its chronicler. Because the author "is such a keen observer, there are treasures in this book," our reviewer, Bill Keller, wrote in 1994. There is more about what it means to be Central European in A YEAR OF THE HUNTER, by Czeslaw Milosz, translated by Madeline G. Levine (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12). This Nobel laureate's journal of 1987-88 examines his identity as a poet and as a Pole. "It seems on first reading indigestible only because so many alternative 'digests' can be made of its chastening wisdom," Donald Davie said here last year.
 
FACE OF AN ANGEL
By Denise Chavez. Warner, $11.99.
 The narrator, Sovieda Dosamantes, is a Chicano woman growing up in a rural New Mexican town, where she ultimately weathers trials ranging from waitressing to widowhood. Last year our reviewer, Robert Houston, said the author "is at her best . . . working her way through one of her tour de force comic scenes." PARADISE, by Elena Castedo (Grove, $13), also features a feisty heroine coming of age in an inhospitable New World. Solita, a refugee from Franco's Spain, finds herself at a Latin American hacienda, which her mother says will be paradise, but which proves quite the opposite. "Ms. Castedo's language is exuberant," Lyll Becerra de Jenkins said here in 1990.
 
THE PRESIDENT'S DAUGHTER
By Barbara Chase-Riboud. Ballantine, $12.
 The author of "Sally Hemings" has written another novel about the consequences of Thomas Jefferson's purported love affair with a slave. Here, Harriet Hemings, the child of that union, finds freedom in Philadelphia, where she passes for white. "With intelligence and immediacy, 'The President's Daughter' illuminates the brutal politics of slavery," Kiki Olson wrote in the Book Review last year. LAUREL GRAEBER
