HEADLINE: STOCKS AND BONDS IN SHARP RETREAT

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
In what analysts called a resoundingly negative reaction to the failure of Congress and the White House to resolve their budget impasse, Wall Street sent stock and bond prices down sharply yesterday, a day before the Federal Reserve's policy-making panel meets to consider a second cut this year in short-term interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 101.52 points, or 1.96 percent, to 5,075.21, its largest percentage decline in more than a year. Even sharper declines were felt in the Nasdaq composite index, which is rich with the technology companies that have fueled much of the broad market's gains this year. As bond prices plunged, the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond jumped to 6.20 percent, from 6.09 percent on Friday. [Page D20.] 
 In recent weeks, hopes that Federal Reserve policy makers would move to cut short-term interest rates and that Congress and the White House could agree on a plan to balance the budget in seven years helped push the markets higher. The Dow industrial average climbed above the 5,200 level and just last Wednesday set its 69th record closing high of the year, while the yield on long-term Treasury bonds fell to its lowest level in two years.
But the hope for an interest rate cut apparently all but dissipated by yesterday morning. And as the Government formally shut down and many Federal workers were furloughed for a second time this year, the outlook for a quick budget compromise dimmed.
Adding to Wall Street's consternation, a computer glitch at the New York Stock Exchange delayed trading for an hour at the outset, and some traders said that the pent-up demand to sell stocks compounded what had been expected to be an opening decline in market indexes. Another set of disappointing earnings forecasts from technology companies helped to pull the market down further.
Whether the markets recover before the end of the year will depend first on the Federal Reserve's action today. Analysts said it would be hard for the markets to rebound if the Fed did not trim short-term rates.
A recovery will also depend on the reaction of individual investors, who, in the last few years, have learned to take advantage of steep market declines to buy stocks and mutual funds.
"People have learned to buy the dips, but everybody knows that strategy is not going to work forever," said Byron R. Wien, a managing director and strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "This one has a somewhat eerie feeling to it."
Mr. Wien said he expected the rest of this year to be a rocky one for the stock market, but he foresaw higher prices early in 1996. Not all market strategists agree, however. Charles I. Clough Jr., who fills the role for Merrill Lynch, said that yesterday's activity could be "a shot across the bow" warning that "the first part of 1996 might be a lot rougher."
Yesterday's selloff hit technology stocks particularly hard, pushing the Nasdaq composite index down 27.92 points, or 2.71 percent, to 1,002.56, where it was in October. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 9.53 points, or 1.55 percent, to 606.81.
"There have been a lot of big bets made going into the end of the year that Washington would reach a budget compromise and that the Fed will cut rates," said Jack Baker, head of equity trading at Furman Selz Inc.
"Many people have been expecting and waiting for a rally to sell into," he said. "Now, if you want to nail down profits before the end of the year, you have to sell. There is no support for stepping up to the plate to buy stocks here."
If the budget and interest rate worries were not enough to unnerve an increasingly skittish stock market, the New York Stock Exchange announced at 9:15 A.M. that trading would be delayed because a computer software foul-up had closed the electronic system that accepts orders for program trades and individual investor transactions.
Officials of the exchange and the Securities Industry Automation Corporation, a majority-owned subsidiary of the Big Board that operates its computer systems, said that the problem was not related to Friday's record trading volume, when 653.2 million shares changed hands. The only previous times that Big Board volume exceeded 600 million shares were Oct. 19 and 20, 1987, when the market crashed and then began to recover.
While computer problems have halted trading on the New York and other stock exchanges at various times, yesterday was the first time since December 1990 that the Big Board's opening was postponed. Shortly after that incident, the Dow industrials began a rally that has now lasted nearly five years.
In yesterday's shortened session, more than 426 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, and exchange officials said they expected no further computer problems today.
Mr. Baker and other traders yesterday questioned the New York Stock Exchange's decision not to inform the public of the possibility of a delayed opening until shortly before trading was scheduled to begin. "That definitely added fuel to the fire," he said. "If the exchange had opened at 9:30, I think the market would have settled down at midday 40 to 50 points lower."
Richard A. Edgar, an executive vice president of the exchange, said that while the software problem was detected at about 4:30 A.M., the exchange and its software unit held out hope that the problem would be fixed and that trading would begin as scheduled. But at 9:15 A.M., the possibility evaporated.
Stock prices fell precipitously once trading began at 10:30. The Dow industrials fell 50 points in the first 11 minutes of trading, setting off the first of the New York Stock Exchange's circuit breakers, intended to prevent the market from going into a free fall.
Stock prices stabilized at about 11 A.M., but headed lower again in the late afternoon. The Dow industrials did not breach the 100-point loss mark until the final hour of trading and finished with their biggest daily point decline in four years.
The breadth of the decline in stock prices was strong as well. Of the 30 stocks in the Dow industrials, 27 declined. Only 54 of the stocks in the S.& P. 500 rose, while 416 fell.
Among the most active stocks, Intel fell 1, to 57 1/4; Cisco Systems fell 3 1/8, to 70 7/8, and Micron Technology lost 1 5/8, to 43 1/4.
Even several merger and acquisition moves announced yesterday did not add much support. Cobra Golf, which agreed to be acquired by American Brands, was the lone gainer among the 10 most actively traded stocks yesterday, rising 7 7/8, to 35 1/2.
The Steris Corporation, a maker of devices to sterilize medical equipment, agreed to acquire Amsco International, a competitor. But the market did not view the deal very kindly, as Steris shares declined 9 3/4, or 23 percent, to 32 1/2, and Amsco fell 2 5/8, to 15 1/8.
The negative tone was set early in the day by the latest in a series of disappointing earnings announcements from a technology company. Advanced Micro Devices said lower-than-expected shipments of its 486 line of semiconductors would cause profits to fall below the previous quarter; the company's shares fell 1 1/8, to 17 1/8, the lowest level in three years.
Information Storage Devices, which makes semiconductors for telephone answering machines, similarly said fourth-quarter revenues would be below expectations. Its shares fell 3 1/2, to 9 1/2; the company went public in February at $15 a share.
But the disappointments were not limited to the high-tech sector. The James River Corporation, a leading paper producer, said weaker demand and lower prices would cause fourth-quarter profits to fall below expectations. James River shares fell 6 1/8, to 25 1/4.
But Advantage Health rose 8 1/4, to 45, after it agreed to be acquired by Healthsouth for $325 million in stock. Healthsouth fell 3/8, to 30 1/2.
Manhattan Bagel shares fell 5 7/8, to 15 1/8; the company was the subject of a column in Sunday's Money and Business section of The New York Times, which said that two executives of the bagel chain had been indicted on criminal charges in California.

HEADLINE: 2 More Spending Bills Vetoed, But Clinton Offers to Negotiate

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
With a sizable chunk of the Government shut down over stalemated negotiations on a balanced budget, President Clinton used both carrot and stick on Congressional Republicans today by vetoing two more spending bills but then holding out the possibility of renewed face-to-face talks and compromise.
The second partial Government closing in a month idled about 260,000 Federal employees, who were sent home around the nation because the temporary spending measure that had financed their offices expired at midnight Friday. The resulting uncertainty helped send the stock market skidding more than 100 points. 
 After once again denouncing the Republicans, in his veto message, as too eager to cut programs for health, education and the environment, Mr. Clinton offered a private olive branch at midafternoon. In separate telephone calls to Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, the President proposed two alternatives to end the standoff, White House aides said.
By evening, the two leaders had formally accepted neither but said they wanted to go to the White House on Tuesday for talks with the President alone. White House aides said no meeting was yet scheduled but suggested that one was likely.
In his phone call, aides said, Mr. Clinton proposed that if the Republicans agreed to drop their insistence on using Congressional Budget Office estimates to balance the budget in seven years, he would agree to join the talks personally, with no preconditions and everything negotiable. Or, if the Republicans insisted on using the Congressional estimates, aides said, Mr. Clinton would demand that they drop their proposed cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid spending in favor of his own, smaller reductions before negotiations could resume with senior White House aides.
The Republicans' initial response was circumspect enough to suggest that serious talks might be in the offing.
"There will be a 30-minute private conversation, just the three of us," Mr. Gingrich said tonight after a meeting of the Republican leadership. "We're not discussing either option. We're going down there."
Later, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole issued a joint statement saying: "We have asked to meet with President Clinton tomorrow to discuss fulfillment of the commitment he made 29 days ago to enact a 7-year balanced budget using nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimates. We do not view this as a negotiating session but as an opportunity to discuss face-to-face the importance of getting a balanced budget agreement this year, and how we might achieve that goal."
After the President's phone call Mr. Dole said, "The President's call does demonstrate that he has at least heard our pleas over the weekend, and indicates a willingness to talk about a balanced budget over seven years using C.B.O. figures."
For weeks, negotiations over balancing the budget have been tangled up in disputes over the assumptions about national economic performance that would underlie any spending projections. Republicans have insisted on using the figures of the Congressional Budget Office, which are only slightly more conservative than the Administration's, but which translate into multibillion-dollar differences over seven years.
Last month, to re-open the Government after a six-day shutdown, Mr. Clinton agreed to balance the budget in seven years with Congressional assumptions, but only if doing so protected his own spending priorities. White House aides said that his second proposal to Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich today was merely meant to enforce the second half of the earlier agreement, by insisting that they accept his original proposed cuts of $124 billion in Medicare spending and $54 billion in Medicaid spending -- less than half the size of their own.
Speaking on condition of anonymity, senior White House aides said the Republicans had seemed more sympathetic to the President's offer to join the talks personally with no preconditions, since any budget must eventually be based on the Congressional Budget Office's assumptions. The aides said a meeting could come as soon as Tuesday.
With the Christmas holiday fast approaching, both sides faced growing pressure to find a solution. Republicans and conservative Democrats sponsored a nonbinding resolution in the House calling for a balanced budget in seven years using Congressional estimates, and it passed overwhelmingly on a bipartisan vote of 351 to 40.
"This shows a growing bipartisan movement for everyone to get in the box of seven years and then fight it out," said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is the chairman of the House Budget Committee. "The earth is shifting under the White House now."
But Mr. Clinton began the day by standing his ground, and the oratory on both sides was hot.
"It is wrong for the Congress to shut the Government down just to make a political point a week before Christmas," Mr. Clinton said in a brief Oval Office ceremony where he vetoed bills that would have financed the Departments of Housing and Urban Development, Interior and Veterans Affairs, and the Environmental Protection Agency. He is to veto a bill to provide funds for the Departments of State, Justice and Commerce, and for the Federal judiciary on Tuesday, the White House said.
Republicans were quick to blame the President for the shutdown.
"The bills are on his desk; the burden is on him," Mr. Gingrich told reporters at a fund-raising breakfast in Richmond.
Speaking on the Senate floor moments after the President's veto, Mr. Dole said: "He had it in the stroke of a pen -- all of these Federal employees employees could have been back to work today," and added: "It's the same old deception -- scare the American people, scare the children, scare the senior citizens, scare the veterans. Tell everybody the sky is falling in."
But Mr. Clinton insisted that the price of the spending bills was too high, and he had threatened for weeks to veto them. His main objections included cuts in spending for environmental enforcement, elimination of his Americorps national service program and provisions on the use of public lands that the White House says favor developers.
In the meantime, the shutdown moved into its first regular workday, with 260,000 employees, about 13 percent of the nonmilitary Federal work force, either sent home today or off the job since Saturday.
"For agencies affected by the shutdown, the only work being done is of an emergency nature related to imminent threats to life and property," said Lawrence Haas, spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget.
Among the departments and agencies still without regular appropriations are Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Commerce, Justice, State, Interior, Veterans Affairs, Housing and Urban Development, the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Small Business Administration.
Federal museums, parks and monuments were closed as were passport offices, for all but emergency applications.
The idled workers were many fewer than the 800,000 affected by the six-day closing in November, since civilian employees of the armed forces and Internal Revenue Service workers are on the job because the President signed appropriation bills for their agencies last month.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton spoke to Republican leaders yesterday about ways to break the deadlock in budget talks, and he vetoed two spending bills, as Vice President Al Gore and local schoolchildren watched. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. B11)

HEADLINE: California Economy Shakes Off Doldrums

 BODY:
The California economy is showing signs of a vigorous revival after five years of decline.
Job growth is running better than 2.3 percent a year, about 50 percent faster than growth nationwide. The entertainment, technology and international trade sectors are leading the way. 
 By early next year, economists say, most of the 525,000 jobs lost in the recession, mostly in the still-depressed construction, aerospace and military industries will be replaced.
The migration to other states has slowed while an increasing number of people are moving in. The recovery is going so strong that state taxes are 3 percent ahead of estimates.
Article, page B12.

HEADLINE: Communication Legislation Stirs Talk of Mergers By Baby Bells

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
With Congress on the verge of sweeping away six decades of communications laws, the nation's telephone companies are jockeying furiously in preparation for a wide-open race for customers and profit.
Two regional Bell telephone companies, Nynex and Bell Atlantic, are reportedly exploring a merger that would create the second-largest telephone company in the United States. Only AT&T, the largest long-distance provider, would have more customer lines. 
 At the same time, Wall Street executives said that a third regional Bell, the Pacific Telesis Group, was trying to negotiate deals with several phone companies, including Nynex and Bell Atlantic.
Investment bankers and communications executives floated an array of other potential deals yesterday that would pair local phone companies with long-distance carriers or overseas phone companies.
These days, picking up a rumor about a telecommunications deal is about as easy as picking up the phone. "With the starting gate going up, the Bells are going to have AT&T in their business tomorrow," said Robert Waldman, corporate bond research chief at Salomon Brothers, "They want people to know that they can potentially serve far more customers, too."
For Wall Street, a frenzy of deals would be a bonanza. For many consumers, though, the activity is unlikely to make much difference in the price or quality of their phone service. Only in metropolitan areas, where the lure of lucrative markets might intensify competition, could the small customer hope to see much benefit.
Congress has yet to pass the telecommunications bill, which would allow the local and long-distance carriers to compete in each other's markets. But a House-Senate conference has nearly completed a compromise measure. And if a bill does not make it to the White House before the end of the year, many industry executives and lawmakers expect it to do so early next year.
A report of discussions between Nynex and Bell Atlantic, something long assumed in the industry and the subject of a Wall Street Journal article yesterday, caused little stir in Washington, where the conference did not hold a meeting.
But Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, who has harshly criticized the monopoly power of the regional Bells companies, threatened to mount a filibuster against the bill when it reaches the Senate floor. "This is a signal of where the industry is going after the legislation," he said, "and it is toward greater concentration."
Industry consolidation, though, may be a fact of the future, with or without a law, as companies seek the advantages that size and economies of scale can bring. The antitrust consent decree, the court-supervised settlement that has governed the seven so-called Baby Bells since they were spun off from AT&T in 1984, does not prohibit two of these companies from merging. Nor does it prohibit a long-distance company other than AT&T from acquiring or merging with a Baby Bell.
Although telephone executives are still treading lightly around regulators for fear of derailing the bill, most are scrambling behind the scenes to line up partners and allies to help them compete.
And in a public gesture, AT&T announced a move yesterday to further distance itself from the local phone companies with which it expects to soon be competing. It said it would begin billing some customers in Florida, Texas and California directly for long-distance service. Until now, AT&T has generally paid local phone companies to add its charges to their monthly bills.
A merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic has been talked about in recent months as increasingly likely, a powerful local-phone franchise stretching from Maine to Virginia. The companies have merged their cellular properties, and they are partners with Pacific Telesis in a television programming venture, Tele-TV.
Nynex and Bell Atlantic declined to comment on the talks yesterday. And an investment banker familiar with the discussions cautioned that the two were at least weeks away from any deal.
Ivan G. Seidenberg, chairman and chief executive of Nynex, said in an interview yesterday that his company was exploring a broad range of relationships with other phone companies, ranging from joint ventures to marketing alliances.
"This industry is so dynamic that we have to be flexible," Mr. Seidenberg said. "We have explored any number of options to do that, and we will continue to do so. But any discussion that we've had with any company is inappropriate to comment on."
He noted that Nynex had not waited for telecommunications legislation to strike several of its deals. But he acknowledged that the bill, if it became law, would open the door to new relationships. Mr. Seidenberg said Nynex would try to gain some share of the huge number of international calls in and out of New York City. To do that, analysts said, Nynex could conceivably form an alliance with an overseas carrier.
In seeking to compete against AT&T in the domestic market, analysts said Nynex and Bell Atlantic would each benefit by consolidating their local-phone franchise on the Eastern Seaboard. "What you need to have is a large footprint to reach more customers with one network," Mr. Waldman said, "There's no reason on God's earth why you have to have seven Bell companies."
If a merger would help both companies, most analysts said that on balance, it would be more beneficial to Nynex. Mr. Waldman said Bell Atlantic -- which covers the area from New Jersey to Virginia -- had better debt ratings and was viewed as one of the best run of the regional Bell companies. Though Nynex, serving New England and New York, had improved its reputation under Mr. Seidenberg, it was viewed as the weaker of the two.
Nynex shares bucked a sharp stock-market decline yesterday, rising 25 cents, to $49.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Bell Atlantic shares dropped $1.625, to $67.
Regional Bell companies are not the only candidates for deals. Several analysts said MCI Communications was an obvious partner for a local phone company because it could gain access to local customers while offering access to its long-distance network in return.
Analysts regard GTE as another natural candidate for a deal because it controlled local markets throughout the country. Indeed, an investment banker said Pacific Telesis had expressed interest in merging with GTE because the two companies both controlled lucrative local phone markets in California.
Consumer advocates, however, were alarmed by a linkup of regional Bell companies. "In a merger like this, you're talking about two companies that border each other," said Bradley Stillman, director of telecommunications policy at the Consumer Federation of America. "This assures that they will never compete in each other's markets."
Critics of the legislation, including Senator Kerrey and Mr. Stillman, want the Justice Department to help determine whether there is adequate competition in the local phone business before the regional Bells are let loose in the long-distance business.

HEADLINE: A Rail Union That Could

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The hope was that Paris and the rest of France would limp back to normal this week after a paralyzing national rail strike and a struggle between public-sector labor unions and the Government over austerity measures to reduce the federal deficit.
But after three weeks in which many hundreds of thousands marched to support the strikers, it seems clear that it will take a long time to heal the wounds. 
 The strikes revealed a deep gulf between technocrats like Prime Minister Alain Juppe who tell the nation that it has to tighten its belt to insure France's place in a more competitive European economy, and French workers who have not been convinced they should have to make sacrifices to allow public and private enterprises to flourish.
In the short run, the railway workers who closed down the national rail network on Nov. 25 and who were still blocking trains to the Channel Tunnel today were clear winners.
Led by Marc Blondel, a cigar-smoking 57-year-old career union official whose like has all but disappeared from Britain and the United States, the workers forced Mr. Juppe to promise in writing not to touch their special pension rules. These allow some locomotive engineers to retire at 50 on pensions based on their last six months' average earnings. Mr. Juppe was also persuaded to shelve a five-year plan that would close 3,750 miles of unprofitable railroad branch lines.
Thousands of civil servants, now permitted to retire after 37.5 years' work instead of the 40 years common in the private sector, closed schools and post offices, and they, too, forced Mr. Juppe to withdraw proposals to curtail their benefits.
In a television interview on Sunday night, Mr. Juppe said nobody understood his proposals. But backed by President Jacques Chirac and the strong conservative majority in Parliament, he is still hoping to convince union leaders of the need for changes in the comprehensive French health insurance system, which has fallen $46 billion into the red during the last three years.
Neither Mr. Chirac nor Mr. Juppe ever came right out and said that the speeded-up deficit reduction was necessary for France to qualify to join Germany and other countries in a common European currency at the end of the decade. But under rules agreed to by the European Union four years ago, France will have to reduce its deficit from $59.3 billion, or 5 percent of its gross national product this year, to 3 percent of its G.N.P. by 1997 in order to qualify.
Meeting in Madrid late last week, Mr. Chirac and other European leaders did not even suggest the possibility of stretching out the timetable, a request Mr. Chirac would see as a humiliating sign of weakness. And none of the European leaders want to attract domestic public opposition to a common currency that most portray as a way to insure the continuation of Europeans' comfortable life in the future.
Mr. Chirac's thinking is that a strong euro, the name given to the future currency, could stand up to the dollar and the yen better than the franc could, but only if the new money is as sound as the German mark.
What played itself out here during the last three weeks is a French domestic struggle over austerity measures, not a Franco-German struggle. The problem is that French governments, afraid of stirring opposition, have never adequately explained to the electorate why they cannot just go on running up deficits to keep paying benefits.
Pierre Laroque, the 88-year-old former Resistance leader who put the health insurance and pension system in place in 1945, said recently that the core of it was a feeling of solidarity born of the war: the sense that those holding jobs in a full-employment economy would make the financial contributions, through health insurance and pension premiums, to enable older people to live in dignity in retirement and to allow all to enjoy modern medical benefits.
But the system was never intended to support three million people without jobs. Mr. Juppe's plan for the health system would keep its benefits intact. He rejected raising out-of-pocket costs for hospital stays, which now are $10 a day.
But the Prime Minister did not explain the plan that way when he introduced it in Parliament. Many people were baffled and angered by portions of the plan, including a new 0.5 percent tax on income to pay off the accumulated deficit and tighter controls over prescriptions.
What a humbled Mr. Juppe appears to be planning to do is to start a long process of public education on the effects of the welfare-state on jobs and economies.
It is not a task that comes easily to French bureaucrats, but Mr. Juppe will start by meeting with union leaders on Thursday. Some think he should have started much earlier.

HEADLINE: Latest Shutdown Disrupts Services

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Cold impersonal numbers were translated into blunt reality yesterday when the executive branch of the United States Government furloughed an estimated 260,000 of its two million nonuniformed workers in the continuing Congressional budget battle.
On an average day in December, according to the Office of Management and Budget, 383,000 people visit national parks, monuments and historic sites. 
 But with the National Park Service shut down yesterday, Marcelo Tillen, 26, a civil engineer from Sao Paulo, Brazil, stood despairing near the ferry landing that serves the Statue of Liberty. "I don't know if I'll be able to see the statue again," he said. "I don't know if I'll be able to return to New York again."
He added, "I think that it's ridiculous because the normal people don't have to suffer just because of discussions going on between politicians."
Across the country, from Liberty Island in New York Harbor to Alcatraz Island off San Francisco, Government workers deemed nonessential were, in the parlance of the day, furloughed. As they left their jobs, the impact rippled through museums, the passport agency, the Federal Housing Administration and beyond.
Workplace safety complaints went unanswered at the Labor Department, the 20,000 students and parents who would be expected to apply for Federal grants and loans at this time of year found that they would have to wait for a chance at college aid, and there was no one to hear the 100 complaints of discrimination in the schools that would be expected this week at the Education Department.
Outside 26 Federal Plaza in Manhattan, a civil rights investigator, Ronald A. Thomson, 65, of Ridge, L.I., expressed resentment at being furloughed. "To be told you're not essential when you're dealing with people's civil rights, which affects their lives and well-being, really bothers me," he said.
No one was handling the telephone lines where the Environmental Protection Agency receives 240 calls a day reporting contamination of drinking water. And farmers seeking emergency exemptions from the agency to use restricted pesticides to fight pest outbreaks had no one to turn to for authorization and faced the prospect of severe crop damage and loss of income.
In South Dakota, the services of the Pine Ridge Reservation office of the Bureau of Indian Affairs are vital to the Oglala Sioux; the reservation includes one of the poorest counties in the United States. But only 5 of the 75 regular employees remained at work there yesterday afternoon.
Because the shutdown was anticipated, arrangements had been made through the bureau's Aberdeen office to send payments to welfare recipients in the Oglala and 15 other tribes through the end of the month to spare them hardship during the holidays.
"Federal workers want to work," said Steve Walanka, a general counsel for the Department of Labor in Chicago. "Maybe the public doesn't believe that, but we do. This is a terrible disruption."
Karen Vaughan, an administrator in Chicago for the General Services Administration, an agency that escaped the furloughs, said: "We can barely keep up as it is with all the paper work. The furloughs and the shutdowns make it that much more impossible. Then people complain about Government service.
"Believe me, we're trying," she added. "But many of the offices that serve the public, like the I.R.S. and the Social Security offices, they've never caught up from the last shutdown."
Dianne H. Pilgrim, director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in Manhattan, part of the Smithsonian Institution, said that she was annoyed by perceptions that the second round of furloughs in a month was less serious than the first and that it affected mainly national parks, monuments and museums.
"It's putting us down as if we're not important," she said. "We are an educational institution, and it's tourist time."
On an average day, the Federal Housing Administration processes 2,500 loans for home buyers and refinancings, a total of $200 million worth of mortgage loans. But it did no business yesterday.
In Los Angeles, at the western regional office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the spokesman, Ron Rogers, was hopeful that the public would be shielded from the shutdown as long as possible. Most employees sent home from that office yesterday were support staff, individuals who handle budget, payroll and computer services.
But Mr. Rogers said: "If this were to last any significant time, services would start to erode. We've got people out there servicing the public, but it's like driving a car. When you run out of fuel, and there's no one to refuel you, there's a problem."
But the ill wind that blew through the Government yesterday did some good for some people.
A few furloughed workers welcomed the extra time for Christmas shopping. And the Federal Parent Locator Service, which receives 20,000 cases a day, was closed yesterday, making it, in effect, a national holiday for deadbeat dads.
At passport offices, though, life and death were the order of the day. On an average day, the State Department gets 23,000 passport applications. It also issues 20,000 visas for visitors, who each spend an average of $3,000 a trip, pumping $60 million into the United States economy.
But only emergency service was available yesterday, and not much of that.
In Chicago, Linda Graham Reichert, whose brother died on Sunday in Iceland, waited forlornly on a bench inside the Federal Building while her husband, John, waved itineraries and tickets in front of guards and shrugging Federal officials.
"I have to get a passport," Mrs. Reichert said quietly. "This is a nightmare. I understand politics. But why should it have to end like this, in this kind of mess?"
After a while, Mr. Reichert told his wife that the sole remaining employee in the passport office said he would call Washington to see what could be done.
"I have one thing to say about all this," he said. "Throw the bums out. That's the lesson I learned today."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Mexico Postpone Nafta on Truck Crossings

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration and the Mexican Government backed away from a politically volatile and highly symbolic provision of the North American Free Trade agreement today, indefinitely delaying the day when Mexican trucks can move freely through much of the Southwest.
The action came after days of round-the-clock talks in which the Administration sought to forestall the border opening, which was supposed to begin today. Under pressure from labor unions and officials in the border states, the Administration complained that Mexican authorities have done far too little to improve the safety standards of its long-haul trucks. The United States wants Mexico to be tougher on the training and licensing of drivers and to increase enforcement of drug laws to prevent the trucks from becoming a conduit for traffickers. 
 The trade agreement calls for the trucks to move without restrictions in Arizona, California, New Mexico and Texas after a brief registration process that was supposed to begin this month; American trucks would have reciprocal rights south of the border. Currently, trucks from both nations are limited to a commercial zone that is as wide as 26 miles in some places near the border.
At a news conference today, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena portrayed the action as a minor delay while Mexican officials and the Administration "continue consultations to place an even greater emphasis on safety and security."
In the interim, Mr. Pena said, the Interstate Commerce Commission, which is slated for elimination in the budget for this fiscal year, would receive applications from Mexican companies seeking to send their trucks over the border, but would not certify any of them to do so.
But other Administration officials said it would probably take months and perhaps far longer before Mexico would be able to meet the new requirements.
Despite the delay in the agreement, Federal and state officials began a scheduled program of tougher inspections they had planned for the new phase. Agents pulled over trucks heading north into the commercial zone, conducting the new safety inspections and sending sniffer dogs to detect hidden caches of drugs.
Past surveys have found that roughly 1 in 4 Mexican trucks entering the country do not comply with American safety regulations. Many trucks regularly haul toxic chemicals, corrosives and waste, and they will be operating on highways that, as of last week, are no longer subject to the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit.
The action today was the first in which the two countries worked together to slow the Nafta accord, a telling reversal of their effort two years ago, when both Washington and Mexico City were rushing to approve the accord, which had faced considerable domestic opposition.
And the suspension of this phase calls into question whether Administration officials and their Mexican counterparts were too optimistic two years ago when they spoke of the speed with which Nafta would spur the integration of two very different economies, bring their environmental, safety and highway rules into rough equilibrium.
While both Governments portrayed the issue as simply a matter of safety, politics was also clearly a factor on both sides of the border.
Texas and California are key states in the Presidential race, and Mr. Clinton's advisers are clearly concerned that a serious accident, a toxic-waste spill or influx of drugs would be linked to one of his signature accomplishments: the passage of Nafta, the most far-reaching trade pact in North American history.
Mexican business interests, which initially embraced the accord, have become equally reluctant. With the Mexican economy mired in a deep recession, trucking companies in Mexico feared an influx of American competition. By delaying the opening, President Ernesto Zedillo can insulate a key part of the Mexican economy from going head-to-head with more efficient delivery services based in the United States.
"This is a case where everyone wanted a time-out," a senior Administration official said today. It is unclear how the delay would affect the agreement's next big milestone on transportation, in the year 2000, when Mexican trucks are to be allowed to go anywhere in the country.
Integrating the two economies has turned out to be far more difficult than simply reducing tariffs and eliminating other government-created trade barriers. American officials, while insisting that the agreement has created jobs in the United States and increased American exports to both Mexico and Canada, the other signatory of the tripartite agreement, say that Mexican compliance with safety and environmental rules has been scanty at best.
"We needed to wake them up," one official here dealing with the trucking issue said the other day.
Mr. Pena and the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, insisted today that the action was not a setback for the accord.
"It will only help Nafta to underscore how serious we are being," Mr. Kantor, who played the central role in negotiating the agreement at its final stages in 1993, said today. "We need to show an abundance of caution and responsibility."
At the White House, Mr. Clinton's political advisers said they were trying to handle the issue with particular care because two of its most vocal and frequently disappointed constituencies, unions and environmentalists, were strongly opposed to the broader opening of the border.
The teamsters union went to court last week in Washington seeking a delay in the opening of the border, though the Administration acted today before the first court hearing on the subject could be held. On the other hand, lobbyists representing American trucking interests wanted the opening to go ahead, so that they could get a better foothold in the Mexican market. Under the accord, however, they can begin to invest in Mexican trucking companies.
Bill Bronrott, a spokesman for Citizens for Reliable and Safe Highways, a consumer group that has been critical of lax standards for trucks, said today, "Delay is good if it is used as a real moment to look at safety and environmental issues."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Teamsters union members protest the Mexican trucks crossing the border at San Diego yesterday. A new phase of the trade pact between the United States and Mexico to allow more access for Mexican trucks was delayed. The union says the trucks do not meet American safety standards. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Counting the Wealth of Nations;
G.D.P.'s Accuracy Is Under Attack From All Sides

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Jean Brown is an energetic widow who works nine hours a day, four days a week doing clerical work and sometimes pushing the toiletries-laden "comfort cart" at the veterans hospital in downtown Baltimore. Her pay? Nothing, unless you count a parking space, a $4 lunch chit or the offer of a free flu shot.
The V.A. hospital estimates that the work done by hundreds of volunteers like Mrs. Brown is worth at least $350,000 a year. But none of it registers on the gauge most widely used to assess the nation's well-being -- the gross domestic product -- which represents the estimated total of goods and services produced in the American marketplace. 
 No other statistic plays as influential a role in the nation's economic and political life as the G.D.P. does. These days momentous Federal budget negotiations hang on impossibly precise projections of economic growth over the next seven years. As the Presidential campaign hits full stride, politicians with next to no idea of how the gross domestic product is compiled will soon be invoking it as evidence of how well or poorly the country has done in recent years.
But within economic circles, the compilation of the gross domestic product is coming under increasing attack from all sides. Environmentalists argue that it overstates the health of society by ignoring the drain on natural resources and the cost of ecological damage.
On the other side, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is among economists who argue that it understates the strength of economic growth by overlooking much of the productivity and quality improvements technology brings.
And analysts from various spots on the political spectrum note that volunteer work, child care and other work at home are ignored, while the figures include the cost of building prisons and the fees of divorce lawyers -- items that could more properly be deemed a reflection of social breakdown, not economic advance.
The G.D.P. "isn't really a measure of economic welfare," said Gail D. Fosler, economist at the Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group in New York.
Indeed, close scrutiny helps explain one of the central mysteries of the day -- how total output can grow at a brisk rate while much of the population believes it is losing ground. A lot of the reported growth of the last 20 or 30 years has come from Americans working longer and harder rather than smarter. The gross domestic product has grown, but often only because some activity like child care has been shifted from the home into the paid sector -- where quality might well be inferior.
The Government itself has long recognized that the statistic is flawed. Starting with the newest figures for the third quarter, which were scheduled to be released today and now will be available as soon as the partial Government shutdown ends, the Commerce Department will switch primary emphasis to a calculation method known as the chain-weighted system from the traditional fixed-weight system. The new method, which has been used as a backup measure for several years, will lead to calculations showing a slower pace of economic growth.
But rather than satisfying the critics, the new accounting system is likely to widen the debate over the appropriateness of the G.D.P. as a measure of whether Americans are actually living better.
In simplest terms, the statistic is designed to measure the sum total within the borders of the United States of consumer spending, business investment, government purchases and foreign trade. But nothing is simple about the calculations that go into it.
Analysts say the figure, while still probably the best single gauge of the overall pulse of the economy, no longer accurately reflects the changing dynamics of an increasingly service-oriented society. Its conceptual deficiencies, they say, are grounded in the statistic's roots as a World War II-era tool for judging military-industrial potential.
Nor is gross domestic product viewed as simply a neutral judgment of the economy. The fiercest criticism comes from environmental groups and others fearful that their interests are being swamped by an all-consuming attention to sheer output.
"The G.D.P. was never intended to be a yardstick of economic progress," said a report by Redefining Progress, a public policy institute in San Francisco. "It says nothing about the impacts of current modes of production upon the nation's health and well-being. Yet economic analysts and the media accord the G.D.P. a totemic stature and regard its growth as the ultimate measure of economic success."
The group has begun to publish an alternative version that takes the Commerce Department's tally of economic activity and adjusts it, among other ways, to include unpaid work and exclude social and environmental costs. The difference is striking. The group's so-called Genuine Progress Indicator shows almost uninterrupted decline since 1969, with the measure slumping at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in the third quarter of 1995. That contrasts sharply with the Government's estimate of a 4.2 percent rate of expansion during that period.
The Commerce Department, encouraged by Clinton appointees, published data in spring 1994 that sought to account for the depletion of oil and other nonrenewable resources. The department hoped to eventually include factors like the use of forests and changes in air quality. But further development of the measure has stalled because some members of Congress worry that such data might be used against the oil and mining industries.
In contrast to these criticisms, which suggest that the G.D.P. exaggerates national well-being, some important economists believe the G.D.P. errs in the other direction. They say the economy -- at least in terms of material prosperity -- is actually considerably stronger than the official figures show. Mr. Greenspan, a leader in this camp, said recently in a Chicago speech that the G.D.P. "increasingly underestimates the market value of goods and services," primarily because advances in technology have improved life and bolstered productivity in ways statistics fail to capture.
That view is shared by private economists like Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley and Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch.
"If properly measured, real G.D.P. growth was probably stronger during the 1990's than currently reported, rather than weaker," Mr. Steinberg told clients.
The Government revision is part of a longstanding effort to keep this gauge up to date and realistic -- an effort that one official compared to trying to fit someone running a 100-yard dash for new clothes.
The goal is to halt a systematic overstatement of G.D.P. caused primarily by the sharp drop in computer prices since 1987, the base year. The widespread use of personal computers has swelled G.D.P. more than thought appropriate because the formulas assume that a unit of computing power -- such as the ability of a central processing unit to crunch numbers and manipulate data -- still costs as much as it did eight years ago. In fact, it is many times cheaper. The distortion becomes greater over time.
The department will now use a combination of preceding-year and current prices for a range of products and services, with G.D.P. reported as an index whose individual components -- consumption, investment, government purchases and net exports -- will no longer add to total G.D.P.
The result, economists believe, will be that the chain-weighted figure will be about a percentage point lower than the fixed-weight calculation for the last three years. While only the method of measurement has changed, that may well have a negative effect on the way many people view the economy.
Many specialists insist the changes only scratch the surface.
"They're only working on the input side, not on the output side," said Joseph W. Duncan, formerly a top-ranking Commerce Department statistician and now chief economist for Dun & Bradstreet. By this he means that the G.D.P. will still not pick up hard-to-measure changes in the quality and convenience of services, such as education, computer software or banking.
And since the components no longer add up, economists say it will be even harder to construct meaningful forecasts and provide readily understandable data for policy makers.
Indeed, some critics say it is time to start over with entirely different measures. Richard M. Salsman, an economist at H. C. Wainwright Economics in Boston, disparages the G.D.P. accounts as based on an era when most economists believed that consumption was the driving force of the economy. He argues that the statistic undervalues business investment, does not capture the dynamism of new inventions and fails to account correctly for transactions that take place among companies.
"It's a kind of tweaking of a system that is so horrible to begin with that it's almost comical," Mr. Salsman said. "It excludes the bulk of activity that goes on."
Others complain that the G.D.P., in looking at only measurable things, holds a distorted mirror to daily life. William R. Mattox Jr., vice president for policy at the Family Research Council in Washington, argues that the gauge needs to be put in perspective.
"If we hold it up to exalted status," he said, "and ignore families and volunteers, including the church, we run the risk of creating the false impression of great health while experiencing cultural collapse."
As for Mrs. Brown, the 71-year-old volunteer at the V.A. hospital and the widow of a World War II veteran plans to keep on contributing to the well-being of the community even if it never shows up on the bottom line.
"I'm giving back to the country," she said, "and the men who were with my husband."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Impasse Takes A Toll on Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The yield on the long bond surged to its highest level in nearly three weeks yesterday, as prices fell, reflecting both traders' anxiety about the stalemated budget negotiations in Washington and their fear that as a result of the Government shutdown, the Federal Reserve will not cut interest rates today.
The 30-year benchmark issue dropped 117/32 , to a price of 1095/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose 11 basis points, to 6.20 percent, the highest since Nov. 28, when it was 6.23 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Also weighing on prices was a weak dollar; the potential for currency translation losses caused foreign investors to shy away from buying American securities.
When the Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee meets today to decide whether to cut interest rates, it may not have all the data it needs for the decision, lessening the possibility of a cut.
The Commerce Department said yesterday that it was postponing the release, scheduled for today, of both the revised gross domestic product report for the third quarter and for November housing starts. It also warned that should the shutdown continued, it could also force the postponement of the scheduled release tomorrow of trade data for October and the scheduled Thursday release of personal income figures for October and November.
Traders are also uncertain about investor demand for this week's sale of Treasury notes, starting with today's $19.25 billion auction of a new two-year maturity, followed by tomorrow's $12 billion of new five-year notes. If the auctions are less than successful, interest rates would have to rise to attract buyers.
In when-issued trading ahead of today's auction, two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 5.39 percent, and the five-year notes at a price to yield 5.62 percent.
At the regular weekly bill auction yesterday, rates declined to September levels, with the average rate for both three-month and six-month bills down to 5.15 percent. Last week they were 5.30 percent and 5.20 percent, respectively.
In what is now becoming a norm at these auctions, the Government, to remain under its debt limit, again prohibited foreign central banks from buying any bills exceeding the maturity of bills they already hold.
Anthony Chan, chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said that everyone knew that some budget deal would eventually be reached, but that the uncertainty as to the details of such a deal appeared to worry the market.
There is concern that a deal would favor higher expenditures, which would mean higher interest rates, instead of greater debt reduction, which would lower rates.
Mr. Chan put the odds of a Fed easing today at about 40 percent: "We believe the negative market reaction to the collapse of budget negotiations has tilted the balance in favor of no change in policy."
Dana Johnson, managing director for research at First Chicago Capital Markets, said of the budget impasse: "Until now the markets had done a pretty good jop of ignoring the posturing. Now we are in this crucial period, and people are beginning to realize that the impasse is real."
He added that the market "is really concerned that Government is going to be a more lasting competitor for borrowing in the capital markets."
Mr. Johnson saw yesterday's market reaction as just the start of a response that would grow if Government negotiations continued to stall. "The bond market, stock market and dollar are all reacting as one to the budget negotiations, or lack of," he said. "I think the economy is O.K. and see no sense of urgency of the part of the Fed toward an easing."
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, noted the widening of the yield spread between short and long maturities and said: "On Friday there were high hopes; now both sides are not even talking numbers, but ideology. The market does not see the signs of progress it would like to see, and there is concern on how the Fed will react. I don't think the Fed will be forced into adjusting interest rates just because of the financial markets."

HEADLINE: Mr. Pataki's Block Grants

 BODY:
The welfare and Medicaid proposals made by Gov. George Pataki last week would apply to those New York State programs the same misguided reform principle that Congressional Republicans are using to refashion Federal poverty programs. In his own variation of a block-grant system, the Governor would turn over parts of Medicaid and welfare to counties to run with fixed allotments of state money that would not change as local poverty rolls changed.
Block grants would make for bad Federal policy -- and even worse state policy, encouraging counties to skimp on New York's neediest families. Specifically, Mr. Pataki would turn over home-care and Medicaid coverage of able-bodied single adults to the counties. He would have counties run employment and other non-cash assistance programs for welfare recipients and give counties the option of taking over cash assistance for the poor. 
 The cruelty of this idea would be obvious the next time a recession hits. Counties would have to handle burgeoning caseloads either by cutting benefits, dropping enrollees or raising revenues through higher taxes, hardly likely in a recession.
Even in ordinary times, counties will be tempted to cut poverty programs, including Medicaid coverage, and pass along the savings in the form of tax cuts to businesses and families. That way counties can discourage needy people from moving in and encourage their own poor citizens to move out. Because family migration across county lines is potentially great, the incentive for counties to slash poverty benefits will also be great.
The tone of the Pataki budget plans is unfair. It rails against paying for training residents at teaching hospitals under Medicaid even though many health-care experts say the system has provided relatively high-quality, low-cost care to the hospitals' indigent and other patients. The administration accuses Medicaid of helping teaching hospitals add unnecessary layers of residents, even though the state system scrupulously avoids paying more to hospitals that hire additional residents.
New York does pay too much for Medicaid. Some of the Governor's reforms, such as placing recipients in managed care, make sense. But the excess should be put in perspective. For example, state Medicaid spending on children is only about 13 percent higher per recipient than in other Middle Atlantic states.
Some of the gap between New York and other states can be explained by New York's high cost of living. New York includes under Medicaid benefits such things as hospital coverage for able-bodied single adults that other states provide under separate programs. That way the Federal Government picks up half the tab, hardly something the Governor should be attacking. The gap that is left, after putting the accounting systems on the same basis, would not be gigantic.
Medicaid and welfare can no doubt be pruned without doing injustice. But the huge cuts proposed by Mr. Pataki and the perverse incentives that would be unleashed by the block-grant reform are attacks aimed primarily at counties and cities, like New York City, that care for the state's poor.

HEADLINE: With Cheap Fixes Completed, the Cost of Clean Air May Exceed the Benefits

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The retreat sounded by California last week from its commitment to a tough mandate for electric cars reflects the larger quandary facing the officials who must grapple with the increasingly stringent demands of the Federal Clean Air Act. The problem with the effort to reduce air pollution further is that most of the relatively cheap fixes have already been made, economists argue, and the expensive ones may not be worth the price.
The very premise of the cleanup -- that smog can be reduced to such low levels that it no longer poses any health risk at all -- is now being questioned by serious academics as well as industry. "The technology now available will not meet the legal standard," argues Ted Russell, an environmental engineer at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. 
 Just how the underlying conflict between the dictates of law and economics will be resolved is far from certain. The Environmental Protection Agency -- or the courts -- may reinterpret the law to allow all but a few cities off the hook. Congress may link enforcement to evidence that the benefits exceed the costs.
Some conservative analysts want to limit Washington's role altogether. "In the end, communities should decide whether improvements in air quality are more important than, say, schools or parks," suggests Jonathan Adler, the director of environmental studies at the Competitive Enterprise Institute in Washington.
The Clean Air Act requires Washington to set standards for ground-level ozone -- the key pollutant in smog -- that provide "an adequate margin of safety" against "any adverse health effects," without reference to cost. And in 1993 the agency set the standard at a maximum of 12 parts ozone per billion, averaged over a one-hour period at any one of dozens of monitors in each metropolitan area.
One bad day is to be ignored. But once a city exceeds the standard at least one day a year over a three- year period, a sliding scale of remedies -- from modest policing of large- scale polluters to the reformulation of consumer products for "extreme" and "severe" ozone areas -- is supposed to apply automatically.
Ground-level ozone is formed by reactions between nitrogen oxides (NOX) and carbon-based vapors called volatile organic compounds (VOC) in the presence of bright sunlight. It builds to dangerous levels in summer, particularly where winds do not clear the air. Los Angeles has the highest concentrations and most frequent violations in the country. Sacramento, San Diego, Houston and Chicago have serious problems, too. And many cities in the Northeast -- notably New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Hartford -- are not far behind.
Virtually all gains in the war on ozone have been achieved by reducing auto emissions. And apart from a few hot summers that cloud the figures, those gains have been heartening. Outside of California, calculates Kay Howard Jones, a former E.P.A. official who is now an environmental consultant, violations have been cut in half since 1985.
But these gains have come at substantial cost. Paul Portney and Winston Harrington, researchers at the nonprofit Resources for the Future in Washington, estimate that roughly $13 billion was spent in 1994 to clean up the air. And once the additional controls on power plants, new cars, consumer products, commuting habits and vehicle maintenance kick in, Mr. Portney expects the annual bill to double.
Will Americans get their money's worth?
Along with Alan Krupnick, Mr. Portney calculated that the value of reduced incidence of asthma and other lung disorders, as measured by surveys of how willing the afflicted were to pay to alleviate the damage, was more than $1 billion a year, far short of the cost. And the disparity may only get worse over time. "There are only so many times you can go back to the well and expect a full bucket," said Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute.
Take autos. By 1994, the tailpipe pollution standard reduced the uncontrolled exhaust of VOC pollutants by 98 percent. Getting the figure down to 99.5 percent will at least double the cost. And producing zero-emissions electric vehicles with the range and performance of today's cars would take another technological revolution. "People are appalled when they actually understand how little they get," Mr. Jones argues.
There may be some technical fixes but they do not go to the core of the quandary. Relying on more current data, adjusting the standard slightly and averaging it over an eight-hour period and allowing an average of three days of excessive pollution per year rather than just one would move every non-California city except Houston within spitting distance of compliance. In the same spirit, Mr. Krupnick would average ozone readings over all monitors in an area rather than simply recording the worst case.
Neither approach is likely to pass legal muster, though. For one thing, there is evidence that the damage from superfine chemical particles produced in smog along with the ozone may exacerbate lung disease. For another, the health effects of ozone have been observed at very low exposure levels. "There is no obvious place to stop," Mr. Krupnick concedes.
A straightforward alternative to fudging the health standard would be to subject it to a formal test of costs and benefits. That's the approach advocated by Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, who is a leading Republican candidate for President. But Ron White of the American Lung Association touches a popular chord of resistance to such bloodless calculations. "People have a right to breath healthful air," he said flatly.
A third approach would catch the fashionable wave of governmental decentralization. If states can set their own welfare policies, as many in Washington now favor, why not let them set their own air quality policies?
One reason is that big business is quietly -- but strongly -- opposed. Auto makers are already lobbying for a 49-state emissions standard for cars (California has its own) that would wrap the Northeast states up with the rest of the country. And consumer product manufacturers support national standards for everything from hair spray to lighter fluid: they fear the Balkanization of markets more than the chance to play one state regulator off against another. Decentralization of regulation will also be resisted by environmental groups, which are better able to influence national legislation and lack the resources to fight state-by-state battles.
However the issue plays out, the battle of electric cars in California is only one of many signs that the time of easy fixes is over. Last week California outlined three proposals that would gut the mandate that 2 percent of all vehicles sold in the state by 1998 be emission-free. Among the proposals is one that would call for voluntary electric-car production. And in New Jersey and other states, initial attempts to tighten state auto inspection programs and to mandate "trip reduction" programs for commuters in the most heavily polluted areas have already met with bitter protest. For now, the E.P.A. -- worried that it might lose the war if it attempts to fight every early battle -- has held its fire.
But the showdown cannot be postponed for long. "As cities struggle to come into compliance with virtually unattainable goals," Mr. Krupnick said, "something's got to give."

HEADLINE: The Communist Comeback

 BODY:
Less than five years ago as Communist Party leaders fled their Moscow offices, frantically destroying files as they went, the very survival of the party seemed in doubt. Sadly, Sunday's parliamentary election erased that doubt. Though a final count will not be available for several days, the Communist Party seems likely to finish with better than 20 percent of the vote, double the nearest rival. That makes it the strongest political force in Russia.
Together with the robust showing by the ultra-nationalist Liberal Democratic Party, led by the firebrand Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the election was a reversal for the forces of reform, and an undeniable rebuff to President Boris Yeltsin. His party is running third, with about 10 percent of the vote. 
 Many Russians, disillusioned by disorder and economic dislocation, plainly want stability and greater financial security. But whether they want the new Russian empire cavalierly promised by the Communists is doubtful.
The Communist resurgence is disheartening, but not calamitous. Political and economic reform in Russia have advanced too far to be brought to a dead stop by this election. The new State Duma, or lower house of Parliament, will be more conservative than the old, but not much more unified. Unequal in power to the presidency, it cannot force a drastic change in direction unless an opposition coalition can put together a two-thirds majority to overturn Yeltsin vetoes, which seems unlikely.
What it can do is slow reform. Through obstruction more than action, the new legislature can force Mr. Yeltsin to continue a drift toward more conservative policies that he began after the last parliamentary election two years ago.
Russians, taught by their own history to expect the worst, are already talking darkly of civil conflict and a return to the violent confrontations between the President and Parliament that shook Moscow in October 1993. Speculation is high that Mr. Yeltsin will cancel next June's presidential election. The same prophets predicted earlier this year that he would cancel the parliamentary election.
Russia has certainly proved itself capable of political deformity over the centuries, and there is no guarantee against new turbulence. But several points ought to be kept in mind in Moscow and Washington in the days ahead that suggest this election was a warning, but not necessarily a prelude to the end of reform.
To begin with, this was a democratic election, one of the largest in history. More than 60 percent of eligible voters, or about 60 million Russians, cast ballots. Whatever their doubts about the future, they showed their commitment to democracy. When the Bolsheviks, an earlier incarnation of the Russian Communists, came back from near-extinction in 1917, their popularity was hardly put to a vote. Nor did the Soviet Communists ever need to assemble a legislative coalition to pass a law.
While moderates remain divided, and at least one reform party lost ground, the threat of a united front of neo-Communists and nationalists seems premature. The Communist leader, Gennadi Zyuganov, an obscure official in the Soviet era, will find it no easier than other politicians to work with the mercurial Mr. Zhirinovsky.
Both men have made promises they cannot keep. Russia lacks the military and economic muscle to rebuild its empire, no matter how much the two men may like to talk about it. The Russian economy, just coming out of a tailspin, cannot be forced back under state control without crashing.
Mr. Yeltsin, for his part, must resist the temptation to resort to authoritarian rule as he deals with a quarrelsome legislature and looks ahead to a presidential election that could put a Communist or nationalist in his Kremlin office. Russians clearly relish the exercise of their voting rights, something their political leaders will have to accept.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The American Way

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Russell Baker is on vacation.

 BODY:
Americans really have to feel sorry for the French. They just don't have a clue how to run a country during a budget crisis. Over there the people, millions of them, go on strike against the Government. The American way is that the Government goes on strike against the people.
Our way is far better, anybody can see that. First, it takes only a handful of people, politicians in Congress and the White House, to get the job of shutting down the Government done. 
 Second, the streets don't get all clogged and messy, so there is no garbage to clean up.
Third, not too many people get hurt to make it very risky for politicians. Tourists, who can't get into museums or national parks, should be at home anyway, watching a football game or something.
The Federal employees who lose paychecks can go see the President's Christmas tree, and get all snuggly at the idea that he is paying for the electricity himself.
Maybe if the shutdown goes on he will consider paying rent for his family's personal quarters. Maybe members of Congress will charge themselves for office space. Maybe they will all evict themselves if they cannot get up the cash. That would be excellent burden-sharing.
And here is the beautiful part of doing it the American way: In a relatively short time and without having to call out the cops or the garbage collectors, the Government strike against the people will have accomplished its purpose.
Breathes there an American with mind so dead as not to understand what is going on: shutting the Government to make the other side look mean, stupid and the enemy of the people as the Presidential election campaign is really getting going?
Of course not. We know the Government was shut down not because of money or deep principle left unsettled but for political advantage.
Money: There is a gap of about $300 billion over seven years between the hardest Republican position and the official Clinton response, which is not chewing gum. But Washington knows that the gap will narrow after the Government shutdown.
As for principle the President, turning this way and that, has wound up giving the Republicans much of what they wanted: a balanced budget with a deadline, the surrender to the states of control over welfare and other parts of the budget, tax cuts and recognition of the need for Medicare change.
Now he is left with the matter of Medicaid. If he surrenders on the need and right of poor people -- just plain poor, you understand, not immigrants, welfare recipients or other such miserable specimens of humanity -- he will have jettisoned not just the poor but his own political honor.
But about the shutdown, Congress and the President are not talking either bottom-line money or unshakable principle. There is no end of legislative devices that would allow them to do the sensible thing: arrange for funds to keep the Government going while they argue over money and principle.
That approach, in case you forgot, is known as democracy, problem-solving, conciliation, common sense, judgment, words like that.
Many of them are taught, I believe, in schools that still have courses in civics, excuse the expression. And for a couple of hundred dollars a day the Government could hire a mediation expert to do the job, maybe one of the non-essential people who have been shut out of their Federal jobs.
Now: Breathes there an American with soul so dead as not to boil with rage against Congress and the White House for making such a clown out of the American government system?
Obviously yes, tens of millions of us.
Otherwise the fortunes that politicians spend for polls to keep their sticky fingers on our political pulse would have told them to watch out, that Americans would turn hard against the party that squeezes the last drop of dignity out of government, and give their votes to the party that shows any sign of political adulthood.
If I were a foreign correspondent in the United States, I would write about this Government's strike against its people, not as an economic story but a kind of style piece, the latest happening in the growing American passion for self-mutilation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Suffers From Stalemate Over the Budget in Washington

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar kept pace with the sliding stock and bond markets yesterday as the stalemate over the Federal budget made currency traders nervous.
In early trading in Europe, the dollar was hurt as traders sought out the Swiss franc as a safe currency after gains by Communists and nationalists in Russian elections. Later drops in the United States bond and stock markets kept investors away from the dollar, as did the budget fracas, which sent some Government workers home for the second time this fall. 
 The dollar's weakness against European currencies helped bring it lower against the Japanese yen. "The dollar is closing out on a soggy note," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4290 German marks, down from 1.4432 late Friday. The dollar was also changing hands in New York at 101.52 yen, down from 102.
Meanwhile, the dollar dropped to 1.1465 Swiss francs from 1.1638 francs. During trading, the dollar hit 1.1455 Swiss francs, a level not seen since Nov. 27, when the dollar touched 1.1385 Swiss francs.
The German mark, typically a safe haven in Europe, lost some of its appeal because of its close economic ties to Russia.
European investors are also not sure if the political problems in Italy and France will allow those countries to remain committed to European unity and a single currency, which is another plus for Swiss assets.
Once trading opened in the United States, attention shifted to traders' displeasure with the stalemate over the budget. "It's like little kids, I think," said Margaret Kudarauskas, a senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
Currency traders were unsure whether the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee would lower interest rates today and were equally uncertain about what effect a rate cut would have on the dollar.
The stock and bond markets were equally uncertain, with the price of a 30-year bond dropping more than a point during trading and the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 101.52 points.
"With such a sharp decline in stocks and bonds, the few participants in the markets got spooked and squared" their positions, Ms. Kudarauskas said.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, were: 4.9200 French francs, down from 4.9620; 1,595 Italian lire, down from 1,597, and 1.3776 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3740.
The British pound was quoted at 1.5403, down from 1.5360 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Moderate Growth Is Seen by Economists

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The economy is expected to grow moderately in the short run with inflation easing, a semiannual survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported today.
It said inflation forecasts among the 56 economists polled were lower than its last survey, in June. The Consumer Price Index is expected to grow at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the first half of 1996, compared with projections of 3.5 percent in the last survey. 
 The gross domestic product is expected to grow at an annual rate of 2.5 percent in 1996, compared with an expected rate of 2.1 percent in the current quarter.
The survey also said the economists projected that the Consumer Price Index would rise at 3 percent annually for the next decade, far lower than the 3.4 percent of the last two surveys.
