HEADLINE: World of Ancient Iceman Comes Into Focus

BYLINE: By BRENDA FOWLER 

 BODY:
IT was four years ago that a vacationing German couple happened across a well-preserved body lying face-down in a slushy pocket of glacier in the Italian Alps. Since this chance discovery of what turned out to be a 5,300-year-old corpse, the world's oldest known human-flesh remains, scientists and archeologists have teased out remarkable information on the man and his environment from the equipment and clothing found with him.
A bit of ember he carried to restart his campfire was from a tree likely to have grown south of the spot where he died. That evidence suggested he was on his way from the fertile Venosta Valley in northern Italy and had probably made his home there. A grain of domesticated wheat clinging to his fur clothing indicated that he had had contact with civilization, which in those days and parts would have been a small farming village. 
 In the last year, studies of the Iceman, as the body is known, have moved beyond his accouterments to his flesh. His guardians at the University of Innsbruck in Austria, where he is being preserved at glacial temperature and humidity, have at last opened up the corpse itself to research. Using specially designed titanium instruments that leave no trace elements, doctors have snipped off tiny samples from the man's shrunken organs and tissues and delivered them to scientists in Europe and the United States for studies that are slowly building answers to the questions about the man's life and death.
In September, Dr. Werner Platzer, the Innsbruck anatomist who oversees research on the body, announced that preliminary findings showed the man's stomach was empty when he died. But his large intestine contained considerable amounts of material.
"That means he had probably not eaten for eight hours," Dr. Platzer said in a telephone interview, adding that the contents of the large intestine were being investigated now. The finding, which had been predicted by radiologists' interpretations of CAT scans, hinted that the man may have been hungry and weak when he died. A hypothesis that has strong support among scientists is that he died of hypothermia after being surprised by one of the sudden snowstorms that come up on the Hauslabjoch, the 10,500-foot pass over the main ridge where he was found.
Other new findings suggest that the man had not been in perfect health. Dr. Andrew Jones, an environmental archeologist at the Archaeological Resource Centre in York, England, identified the eggs of a parasitic whipworm in a small sample from the man's colon. The preliminary results do not reveal how severe the infestation was, and Dr. Jones could not say whether the parasites caused the man any discomfort. Light cases often go unnoticed , but severe infestations carry severe symptoms, Dr. Jones said, and even a moderate infestation may have weakened the man.
Another potential vulnerability appeared in the man's lungs, where Dr. Raul J. Cano, a microbiologist at the California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo, recently found a fungus called Aspergillus, most likely the species fumigatus.
"I know that Aspergillus has been associated with lung disease, but we have no reason to believe he died of anything other than natural causes," said Dr. Cano, who isolated the DNA of the fungus. And last year doctors found that the lungs were as black as a smoker's, probably a result of living in a shelter with an open hearth.
Discussion of what caused the man's death has been complicated from the start by X-rays that show five broken ribs on his right side. Radiologists are unable to determine whether these fractures occurred before the man's death, under the weight of the glacier or during the rough recovery.
"There are so many rib fractures, they're angled, the chest is severely decreased in diameter, and the posterior ribs are dislocated from the spine," said Dr. William A. Murphy Jr., the head of diagnostic imaging at the University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston and one of the radiologists who has studied the thousands of X-rays and CAT scans of the body. "It's my opinion that it would take significant force to do that, and I can imagine that force from the weight of ice."
But neither he nor Dr. Dieter zur Nedden, his Austrian colleague, believes the question will soon be laid to rest. That keeps alive the theory of Dr. Konrad Spindler, the University of Innsbruck prehistorian who proposed that the man had been involved in a fight in his village then fled into the mountains, where he succumbed to his injuries.
There are, indeed, signs that the man's life had not been easy. Dr. Horst Seidler, an anthropologist at the University of Vienna, said the man may have lived through episodes of extreme hunger, illness or metal poisoning that arrested his growth. Examining X-rays of the man's shinbone, Dr. Seidler and his colleagues found 17 Harris lines, thin layers of bony material that form in the hollow of a bone when growth stops. They calculated that severe disturbances occurred in the man's 9th, 15th and 16th years.
"Possibly this had to do with periods of hunger in the transition between seasons," Dr. Seidler said.
One of Dr. Seidler's next projects is to compare tissue samples from the Iceman with those of the 500-year-old Peruvian girl whose discovery on an Andes mountain was announced in October.
"These two finds were conserved in the same condition," said Dr. Seidler, who was recently in Peru. "This is the first time we've had material with which to compare him."
Other findings illuminate the man's activities during his life. In September, Dr. Don Brothwell, an archeologist at the University of York in England, announced that his team had detected unusually large amounts of copper on the surface of the man's hair. In a telephone interview Dr. Brothwell suggested that the prehistoric man, who was found with a copper ax, may have been involved in the processing of copper, the first metal smelted.
"What I'm hoping to do is check out if there is copper on the fingers and in the lungs," Dr. Brothwell said, noting that if the man were smelting he would have been breathing in copper particles.
In the Copper Age, a period that may have begun as early as 3,000 B.C. in the Alpine region, people searched for malachite, a copper carbonate that appears naturally as a bluish-green efflorescence on rock and cliff sides. They scraped and flaked off the malachite and then smelted it in a crucible in a campfire. They increased the fire's temperature by blowing oxygen into it through bellows. The nearly pure copper would then be poured into a stone mold, for an ax, for example. Some prehistorians have wondered whether the man was in the mountains looking for malachite, though he was not found with digging tools..
"We can only speculate about how metal production was organized," said Dr. Lawrence Barfield, an archeologist at the University of Birmingham in England who studies the Copper Age in northern Italy. "We don't know whether there were specialists doing it or whether it was something that anybody could do."
But even if the man did not make his copper ax, he still had to polish and sharpen it, and that process, too, could have left dust on his hands that he then rubbed into his hair, said Dr. Markus Egg at the Roman-Germanic Central Museum in Mainz, Germany, where the equipment and clothing have been conserved and studied.
While much of the remaining research is in the court of doctors and scientists, archeologists, too, are still intrigued with the find. Archeologists in Italy and Austria have spent the last three summers looking for more signs of prehistoric human activity in the high valleys below the Hauslabjoch, and recent excavations have turned up several sites where hunters who lived millennia before the Iceman stopped to camp overnight, built a fire and left a few flint tools and flakes behind.
At least three of these sites were found along a path over which local shepherds still guide their sheep to summer pastures, and the Iceman was also found on this route, said Dr. Annaluisa Pedrotti, an archeologist at the University of Trient in Italy.
At that time, Dr. Pedrotti pointed out, a person would not climb to such altitudes without sound economic or, possibly, religious reasons. Like most prehistorians involved in the project, both she and Dr. Egg think the man was probably a farmer or shepherd on his way to or from the summer pastures nearby. Yet even this interpretation has problems.
"We still don't have any typical shepherd equipment with him," Dr. Butterfield said. "Where is his walking stick? Why isn't he wearing anything made of sheepskin?"

HEADLINE: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;
Digital Outlets for Your Holiday Generosity

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
BEFORE hyperlinking directly to the traditional roundup of last-minute holiday computer gift suggestions, it seems appropriate to switch the computer off for a moment to consider gifts that cannot be measured in megabytes or dollars.
The headlong rush to the Internet and the Information Age has left many people behind, and others befuddled. True, many people have no desire to log on and get sucked into what they consider cybernonsense, but others are worried that they will be at a social and economic disadvantage in years to come if they do not learn to surf the Internet and the World Wide Web. 
 In a world that has increasingly come to value nanoseconds and megahertz, one of the greatest gifts one can give is time. Many readers of this column are experienced computer users and cybernauts, and there are unlimited opportunities to share their skills and insights with the information-needy at schools, nursing homes, community centers, houses of worship and neighbors' homes.
The assistance can be as simple as helping a harried elementary teacher who is trying to multitask 25 second-graders in the computer lab or taking over the task of troubleshooting the printer connection.
Thanks to America Online's aggressive mailing campaigns, dumping a steady stream of trial diskettes in everyone's mailboxes, many of us have stacks of perfectly good but unwanted diskettes that a church or community center can put to good use. The same goes for old equipment and retired software.
Someone with a laptop and modem might find it rewarding to take the folks at a local retirement center on a surfing safari on the Internet.
They may be surprised, as I was recently at one retirement facility, that the questions are not "What's a modem?" but rather, "Our global positioning satellite system on the roof is malfunctioning; can you help?" (Sorry, no.)
Our senior citizens, it turns out, are just as likely as our young school children to be interested in and experienced with computers and on-line technology.
Thomas E. Miller, publisher of Interactive Consumers, a monthly report from the research firm Find/ SVP, said a recent survey "poked some holes in the cybernaut image." The heaviest Internet and on-line use among teen-agers occurs at college, he said.
"Once you break through the stereotype of the teen hacker, you find most kids don't know much about it," Mr. Miller said. "We found more adults were on line, and stayed on line longer, than kids. The average age of the modem user is in the 40's."
For seniors who are physically isolated, the Internet allows them to continue an education or connect with someone, somewhere, with whom they share an interest, Mr. Miller said. For others, the attraction might be the electronic mail that reconnects them to children, grandchildren and friends who are far away.
For reasons not fully understood, it seems easier to write or reply to electronic mail than to pick up a phone or type a physical letter.
For those with dollars to spend, as always there is no shortage of computer-related things to buy.
One often-overlooked possibility for computer-related holiday giving is a second phone line. The cliche of the next decade may be the teen-ager who is exasperated because Mom and Dad are tying up the phone for hours, doing their stupid modem chat sessions and electronic banking.
Another gift favorite is a CD-ROM drive. Almost all of the really cool software arriving in this office in the last six months (indeed, more than 75 percent of all software, interesting or not) came on laser-pitted CD-ROM disks.
A quad-speed, or 4X, drive is the current standard and is likely to remain so until the new generation of digital video (or maybe versatile) disks arrive late next year. I am distrustful of the newer 6X drives, which recall the fiasco of the 3X drives that were in vogue for about 10 minutes during the transition from double-speeds to quad-speeds.
Okay, now for some Macintosh software picks, all in the $50 range. Nick, a 13-year-old beta tester, wants Santa to know that games are intrinsically more valuable and fun than educational software or personal productivity applications. As a guide, he offered us his top picks of the year and some pithy comments:
1. A-10 Attack!, from ParSoft, telephone (214) 479-1340. "Simply the best flight simulator," based on the ugly but effective A-10A Thunderbolt II Warthog that chewed up Iraqi airfields in the last war. May see action in Bosnia.
2. Wing Commander III, from Origin Systems, (512) 434-4263. "Just incredible, lots of video, and a plot." Not just a plot, a whole screenplay. Origin spent several million dollars making this one, and it shows.
3. Dark Forces, from LucasArts, (415) 472-3400. "By far the best first-person virtual shoot-'em-up." Very similar to Doom, except that it has more plot and fewer internal organs splattered on the walls.
4. Havoc, from Reality Bytes, (617) 261-2581. "The polygon graphics are great." Essentially, a flight simulator in which alien bad guys shoot back over a surreal landscape.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Financial Markets Plunge On the Budget Impasse
Financial markets tumbled in what analysts called a resoundingly negative reaction to the failure of Congress and the White House to resolve the budget impasse. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 101.52 points, or 1.96 percent, to 5,075.21, its largest percentage decline in more than a year. The Nasdaq composite index, which is rich with the technology companies that have fueled much of the broad market's gains this year, slid 27.92 points, or 2.71 percent, to 1,002.56. [Page A1.]
 
The yield on the long bond surged to its highest level in nearly three weeks, 6.20 percent, up from 6.09 percent on Friday, as prices in the credit markets slid. [D20.]
 
The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is to consider today whether to cut rates for the second time this year, a tough decision with so much of the Government closed and economic data delayed. [D2.]
 
Clinton Vetoes Two Spending Bills
President Clinton used both carrot and stick on Congressional Republicans, vetoing two more spending bills but holding out the possibility of renewed face-to-face talks to compromise on budget balancing. The second partial Government shutdown in a month idled about 260,000 Federal employees. [A1.]
 
 
Advanced Micro Sees Profit Slide
Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said its fourth-quarter earnings would be lower than last quarter's, which would also be earnings below the consensus estimate of Wall Street analysts, because it has not yet been able to produce a chip to compete with Intel's Pentium. The announcement sent its stock down $1.125, to $17.125, and helped fuel a broad selloff in technology shares. [D5.]
 
Encyclopaedia Britannica to Be Sold
Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc., the troubled publisher of the venerable encyclopedia, said that the company would be sold for an undisclosed amount to an investment group led by Jacob E. Safra, a financier based in Switzerland. [D2.]
 
A Merger in Surgical Equipment
Two companies that make surgical sterilization equipment, Steris and Amsco International, agreed to merge yesterday in a stock swap initially valued at about $660 million; the value of the deal plunged to $505 million in later trading. [D4.]
 
Healthsouth, which provides surgical and rehabilitation services on an outpatient basis, agreed to buy Advantage Health for stock worth about $325 million. [D4.]
 
American Brands
To Buy Cobra Golf
Cobra Golf Inc., a maker of premium clubs, said that it had agreed to be acquired by American Brands Inc. for $700 million, sending its stock up $7.875, to $35.50, in afternoon trading on the Nasdaq market, just under American Brands' offer of $36 a share. [D4.]
 
Con Ed Accused of Intimidation
A Federal monitor criticized Consolidated Edison, saying it had punished several employees for reporting environmental problems. The monitor was appointed after the utility failed to report asbestos was released in the 1989 explosion of a steam pipe, for which it was ordered to pay a $2 million fine. The company defended its efforts to improve its environmental practices. [B1.]
 
Trade Provision Postponed
The Clinton Administration and the Mexican Government delayed the day when Mexican trucks can move freely through much of the Southwest, backing away from a politically volatile provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement. [B10.]
 
Arch Agrees to Buy Westlink
Arch Communications agreed to acquire the privately owned Westlink Holdings for $340 million. After the deal, Arch would have almost 2.5 million subscribers. [D7.]
 
 
California Economy on the Mend
California is beginning to recover its standing as the nation's most powerful economy, after its worst economic slump since the Depression. Fueled by the entertainment and technology industries and international trade, job growth in the state is now running above 2.3 percent annually, about half again the national rate of 1.5 percent. [B12.]

HEADLINE: Down for 5 Years, California Economy Shows Signs of Regaining Its Glitter

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Battered for five years by Mother Nature and the worst recession since the Depression, California is finally beginning to recover its standing as the nation's most powerful economic machine.
Job growth in the state is now running better than 2.3 percent annually, about half again the national rate of 1.5, thanks to an employment explosion in the entertainment industry, advanced technology manufacturing and international trade -- the new Big 3 of the California economy. 
 By early next year, economists say, most of the 525,000 jobs lost in the five-year recession will have been replaced -- significantly without any real recovery in the construction, aerospace and military industries, the old Big 3 whose collapse led the state into its grinding downturn.
"California is back!" Gov. Pete Wilson now boasts, prompting his aides to order him a limousine license plate that sports that happy proclamation.
The great exodus of people fleeing to other states to escape California's fires, floods, earthquakes, riots and economic cave-ins, including the Orange County bankruptcy debacle, has sharply slowed, as much as 20 percent, according to real estate agents and driving permit bureaus in some of those states.
Conversely, housing agents and driving bureau officials in California say that the migration rate this year to California from other states is running more than 15 percent ahead of last year's.
Demographers report that California -- still the nation's most populous state, with almost 33 million people -- is again becoming a magnet for the young, adventurous, entrepreneurial types who have flocked here for more than 150 years.
Based on current trends, demographers say, in the coming decade California's population will increase 1.6 percent a year, almost twice the nine-tenths of 1 percent annual increase estimated for the nation as a whole.
Indeed, California's recovery is proceeding so rapidly that state tax receipts are running close to 3 percent above original estimates for the current fiscal year, a budgetary miscalculation that works out to a yearly windfall of more than $1 billion. And the pulling and tugging over this windfall is already under way at the Capitol in Sacramento over whether to spend the surplus on schools or prisons, or to use it to cut taxes.
Before the state's economy collapsed, the total value of California's annual output of goods and services was about $750 billion, enough to rank it not only as the biggest economy in the United States, but also as the eighth largest among all the economies of the world. With its gross product now close to $900 billion, California has regained that economic status and, indeed, now ranks seventh among the world's economies.
"It's been an impressive bounce back from a really tough place," said David Hensley, a specialist on the California economy for Salomon Brothers Inc., the New York financial concern.
"The old California energy is back in the air," Mr. Hensley continued. "There's the old churning and dreaming and business adventurism.
"There's also the old determined optimism that sees opportunity in the ashes of recession, earthquakes and fire. I'm definitely bullish on California."
Howard Flagg, president of PairGain, a manufacturer of advanced technology telecommunications equipment in the Los Angeles area, was one of those who saw opportunity in the depths of adversity and helped turn the state's economy around. His company has increased gross sales tenfold in the last three years, to more than $100 million annually.
"We decided to expand right when things were at the worst in the state," Mr. Flagg said. "We never lost faith in California or cutting-edge industries like ours that we're convinced are the state's future. We were positioned right and the time was right and we moved, even while others were still sinking. It's the old California success story."
But there are some qualifiers.
Despite all the favorable economic indicators, the state's unemployment rate in recent months has been hovering stubbornly around 8 percent, at least two percentage points above the national rate. As much as anything, that high figure reflects just how low California's economy fell during the recession and how far it still has to go to fully recover.
Moreover, the most recent figures from the United States Labor Department indicate that California's unemployment rate could be as much as three points above the national rate, though many employment experts question that estimate, saying the recovery is moving so fast that labor surveys cannot accurately follow it.
Also, the California housing market, once the most overheated in the nation, remains in the economic doldrums, as does the residential construction industry. Many houses -- those few that are selling -- are going for 30 percent to 40 percent less than they might have brought at the turn of the decade.
Nor is there any sign that the aerospace and defense industries will soon make an economic comeback, given the big national cutbacks in both fields.
And if California has to contend with another natural disaster or if the national economy falters, the state's economy might again find itself in big trouble.
But for the moment, most businesses here are doing very well, and expectations are again running high.
"The pluses far outweigh the minuses," said Stephen Levy, director of the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy, a Palo Alto firm that supplies analysis to private companies and public institutions, "and they are especially dramatic because many trace their roots to the depths of the recession, when everything else seemed headed down the tubes."
From 1990 to 1995, for example, international trade grew so rapidly in California -- 70 percent over all -- that the twin ports of Long Beach and Los Angeles overtook the ports of New York City and northern New Jersey as the nation's busiest. The value of goods going across the California docks is nearing $150 billion a year, compared with about $140 billion for the docks in the New York area.
Equally striking -- and equally unheralded until recently -- while the recession and cutbacks in military spending slashed employment in the state's defense industries to 150,000 workers, from a high of more than 400,000, employment in the film and television industry was almost doubling.
At the start of the recession, "Hollywood" employed about 85,000 people. Today, according to the California Employment Development Department, the entertainment industry employs at least as many people as hold jobs in what is left of the defense industry.
The ultimate economic metaphor for this switch may have been the site recently chosen for building the newest high-tech California studio, DreamWorks. It is a hangar once used to build military aircraft, including Howard Hughes's experimental Spruce Goose, a 2,000-ton seaplane built almost entirely of wood. The plane, designed to ferry soldiers and tanks in World War II, made its only flight on Nov. 2, 1947.
Along with DreamWorks, nearly 43,000 new businesses have been incorporated in California in the last year, a 7 percent increase. For the nation as a whole, the rate was 5 percent.
"At almost every important turn," Mr. Levy said, "you find that California once again is outstripping the national average."
Many of the new businesses that were incorporated were in entertainment, advanced technology and international trade, industries that have now fully replaced the aerospace, military contracting and construction industries as the economic pillars of California.
And the new companies tend to pay higher salaries than the older industries, thus raising average earnings in the state.
Twenty-two percent of California households now have annual incomes of more than $75,000, compared with 17 percent nationally.
"This is a recovery like no other, in a state that has had its full share of boom and bust over the years -- the gold rush, the oil gush, the house craze, aerospace and defense contracting," said Joel Kotkin, an analyst at Pepperdine University in Malibu who specializes in West Coast business trends and public policy. "The fundamental economic mix has changed hugely, and it's the kind of change that is positioning the state extremely well for the 21st century."
Mr. Kotkin added: "While it's true that high-paying, cutting-edge technologies, new-age television and film and expanding Pacific Rim trade were all present in California before the recession started, each of these industries happened to really boom and come fully into its own in the middle of it. Now they're leading our way to the new future."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
After Many Selloffs, a Rally. And Now?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Once again, Wall Street has thrown a small panic. Now the question is whether individual investors will once again throw money into the market to combat weakness. Recent history suggests they will.
Yesterday's plunge of the Dow Jones industrial average, in which it lost 101.52 points, or 1.96 percent, closing at 5,075.21, was the worst for the index in more than a year, and was the eighth worst day since the start of 1991. That period has been remarkable for being the longest stretch in history in which the index has not had a 10 percent correction. 
 With technology stocks hit especially hard, the Nasdaq composite index turned in an even worse performance, falling 27.92 points, or 2.71 percent, to 1,002.56.
Explanations for the fall ranged from concerns over 1996 profits to the continued budget stalemate in Washington. That dispute had heretofore been deemed irrelevant except as poor theater by most investors, who assumed a deal would be reached eventually.
But for the first time, Wall Street seemed to have something immediate at stake in the budget battle. The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meets today, and it has widely been expected to cut short-term interest rates. Indeed, the bond market has rallied so strongly that it was clear a cut was expected. But there is fear that the Fed may defer any action until a budget deal is cut, and that sparked selling in the bond market yesterday, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rising to 6.20 percent from 6.09 percent.
A cynic might even suspect that in selling off just before the meeting, the markets were sending a message to Washington that the Fed had better ease credit if it did not want a continued slide in prices.
It could also be argued that by some traditional methods of valuation -- notably the level of dividends -- the stock market is overvalued, but that has been true for months, without bothering investors very much. Quantitative types have taken refuge in rapidly rising profits and falling interest rates, both of which have tended to indicate that stocks were not ridiculously high. Were either or both of those to come into question, stocks could be vulnerable.
But since the 1987 crash -- which proved to be a wonderful buying opportunity -- and especially since the end of the 1990 correction, one of the saving graces of the market has been that mutual fund investors were willing to throw money at stocks at any sign of weakness. They have generally been right to do so, at least so far, as prices have generally rallied quickly.
The willingness of mutual fund buyers to leap in at any sign of weakness has, in fact, helped to produce remarkably few days this year that closed with significant losses. Many days that started badly have seen rallies -- brought on in part by mutual fund buying -- that pared the dips by the end of the sessions.
Yesterday was, in fact, only the sixth day of 1995 in which the Dow fell at least 1 percent. By contrast, there were 18 such days in 1994.
Among the other nine days on the 10 worst list for 1991-95, the Dow has rallied the following day in seven instances. Only twice did it take as much as a month for the index to completely recover its losses from the bad day. On the worst day of the period -- Nov. 15, 1991, when the index fell 3.93 percent in part due to drops in biotechnology stocks, that year's high fliers -- it took six weeks, until Dec. 26, for prices to totally make up the loss.
And -- the precedent that might be most bothersome if yesterday's bond market weakness were to continue -- the 2.42 percent plunge on Feb. 4, 1994, coming as the Fed tightened credit, set off a weak market that endured for months. Not until Sept. 8, 1994 did the Dow return to the level it was at the day before the big drop.

 Otherwise, though, it has generally been clear sailing. In one case, the Dow tumbled 2.36 percent on Aug. 19, 1991. Two days later, it had wiped out that entire fall.
Will it happen again? There was no immediate sign of panic among mutual fund investors yesterday, reported Steve Norwitz, a spokesman for T. Rowe Price, who said there were many more questions about end-of-year tax issues than about the falling market.
Charles Biderman, the publisher of Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, a newsletter that compiles figures on fund cash flows, said that two weeks ago the flow of cash into stock funds was the highest ever, and that while it was down last week, the figure was still very strong. He said he expected prices to reverse by tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Pressure on Fed Grows With Budget Standoff

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
When the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy committee meets on Tuesday, nervous budget negotiators and nervous financial markets will be watching closely. And that makes the Fed itself nervous.
The recent record-setting climbs on Wall Street have been based in part on interlocking assumptions about what would happen in Washington: that President Clinton and Congress would strike a deal to balance the budget, and that the Fed would give its blessing in the form of an interest rate cut that would allow the markets to continue their climb. 
 Today's 101-point fall by the Dow Jones industrial average reflected investors' worries that since the politicians show no sign of delivering on their part of the equation, the Fed will not deliver on its.
The Fed, which loves to see itself as above the political and market fray, hates outside pressure. Yet to an unusual degree, it finds itself in a pickle of its own making.
While the central bank has customarily kept a low profile in budget battles, Alan Greenspan, its chairman, has been more vocal this year in pushing for a balanced budget.
Of all the Washington officials who welcomed the prospect of a Republican Congress producing a balanced budget, few were as optimistic as those at the Federal Reserve. And within the Fed's chambers, few were as enthusiastic as Mr. Greenspan.
In January, he volunteered to the House and Senate Budget Committees a quick way to save up to $50 billion a year: reduce the inflation adjustments for many tax and spending programs. In February, he predicted that the Fed would cut interest rates if Republicans cut the budget so deeply that the economy slowed. And in the months since then, he has repeatedly called for a credible plan matching Federal spending with Federal revenue.
Mr. Greenspan has said that a credible deal to reduce the budget deficit would produce a drop in market interest rates, as demand for credit diminished, and that the Fed would likely accommodate that fall, presumably by reducing the short-term interest rates it controls.
Fed officials have justified Mr. Greenspan's role by pointing to his background as a budget expert. And they have emphasized the long tradition among central banks of pushing for balanced budgets, which tend to reduce inflation pressures.
As evidence increases that the economy is slowing while inflation remains under control, the question now is whether the Federal Reserve is willing to cut interest rates without waiting for a budget deal. By coincidence, Fed officials will be meeting for a second time during a partial shutdown of the Government.
Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman and a Clinton appointee who has often differed with Mr. Greenspan, is increasingly critical of linking interest-rate policy and the budget. "The idea that we should or would reward or punish the budget deal is pernicious," he said in a recent interview.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, another Fed governor, sided with Mr. Greenspan in contending during a recent interview that the central bank should pay close attention to budget policy because Federal spending accounts for nearly a quarter of the nation's economic activity.
A growing number of Wall Street analysts and former Fed officials say the central bank may decide to put aside the uncertainty about the budget and focus on the economy's strengths and weaknesses. While the Fed may not know the overall shape of the deal, they point out that many of the outlines are becoming clear.
President Clinton has already signed seven of the 13 spending bills for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. Even if all 13 bills are passed in the form Republicans want, they would only cut spending by $23 billion, or three-tenths of 1 percent of the nation's economic output. And while some of the spending cuts in the budget reconciliation bill are ambitious, many would not take effect this fiscal year.
"The budget deal is really not going to factor into their thinking to any significant degree," said Lyle E. Gramley, a former Fed governor who thought the central bank would leave rates unchanged. "Their discussion is going to be focused primarily on how fast or how slow the economy is going to be growing in the second half of next year, and the signals are really hard to decipher."
Evidence that the economy may be slowing includes weakening demand for new factory equipment, a slow start in October to the Christmas retail season, lackluster car sales, the absence of consumer inflation in November, and the growing number of Americans who are behind on personal debts. But evidence that the economy is still fairly strong includes shortages of skilled workers in Midwest cities, strengthening commercial real estate construction, rising bank loans, a rise in producer prices in November, and a recent rebound in most retail sales.
The Federal Reserve's situation is complicated by the approaching Presidential primary season and the expiration on March 2 of Mr. Greenspan's term as chairman. As the Administration's decision on Mr. Greenspan's reappointment draws near, the Fed's decisions are seen in an increasingly political light.

HEADLINE: U.S. Responds Calmly to Communist Gains in Russian Vote

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration responded with equanimity today to the preliminary outcome of parliamentary elections in Russia, despite the revival at the polls of the once-moribund Communist Party.
"I think there's a sense of calm and perspective about this election," said Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman. 
 Mr. Burns said the outcome, which was largely expected, was inconclusive in the fractured political environment of 43 parties, even though the Communists have gained more than 20 percent of the votes reported when today's round of counting ended.
The results so far indicate that the Communists are replacing the nationalist party of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky as the leading anti-reform element in the lower house of Parliament. But Administration officials said they did not see any need to adjust Washington's policy toward Russia and the Government of Boris N. Yeltsin.
Even the apparent plurality achieved by the Communists leaves them well short of a working majority, said Administration officials, who concluded that more than three in four Russian voters did not support a return to the past. They noted that the Communist surge was offset by a decline in support for Mr. Zhirinovsky's nationalists, which meant that the coalition of forces opposing President Yeltsin's liberalization policies had not really increased.
"At this point, I think it seems likely that the new Duma that was elected yesterday will not be strikingly different than the Duma that has been in session for the last few years," Mr. Burns said today, referring to the lower house of the Parliament. In essence, he said, the results mean that one-third of the legislators would oppose economic reform, another third would support it and the rest would be in the middle.
The votes reported so far apply to seats allocated to political parties, which account for only half of the 450 seats in the lower house. The results for remaining seats will not be known for some days. Those seats are elected from among individual candidates who represent themselves and are expected to hew more closely to the center because they will be elected foremost on the basis of local issues.
Because the lower house of Parliament is constitutionally much weaker than the presidency, Administration officials are also treating yesterday's elections as a kind of rehearsal for the presidential elections next June that will determine Mr. Yeltsin's political survival.
It also seems likely that the Administration has been looking beyond President Yeltsin, who is not only politically unpopular at home but also suffered a heart attack recently, to identify younger, more vigorous Russian politicians who support economic reform.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said, "What remains clear after the election is that the political culture of Russia is still multi-faceted and quite dynamic, with a lot of different participants, a lot of different factions, a lot of different points of view of what Russia's political future should hold."
While conceding that the Communists had made a strong showing, Mr. McCurry said, "We also believe that there is a strong presence in the newly elected Duma of reformers and those committed to democracy and market economics."
Even so, Administration officials acknowledge some discomfort with the new prominence of the Communists, whose leader, Gennadi Zyuganov, has spoken of reconstituting the Soviet Union.
"It certainly doesn't hearten those of us who believe in democracy and reform," Mr. Burns said at today's State Department briefing.
But another senior Administration official observed that it would be hard to put the Soviet Union back together because Russia, like the West, recognizes the sovereignty of the other former Soviet republics.
"Russians are looking to the future, not looking to turn back the clock, but they have very different ideas of what the future should be," he said.
The official observed that foreign policy issues had not figured in the recent political campaign, which focused far more on the debate over Russia's troubled transition to a market economy.
The final composition of the lower house, and its variance with President Yeltsin, will not become clear until it is known how many political parties garner 5 percent or more of the total vote, which is the threshhold for inclusion in the legislature.
Dr. Harvey D. Balzer, director of the Center for Eurasian, Russian and East European Studies at Georgetown University, agreed that the outcome so far did not pose a threat to the Administration's relationship with Moscow. "Overall, it probably deserves a sigh of relief," he said.
Mr. Burns, who previously served as a Russian affairs specialist in the National Security Council, offered another reason for the relative calm with which the Administration accepted the election news. When the nationalists under Mr. Zhirinovsky made gains in the first parliamentary elections in 1993, Mr. Burns recalled, "there was pretty much shock" inside the White House. This time around, he said, it was expected that perhaps a third of the Russians would not be reconciled to change.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: CLINTON, GINGRICH AND DOLE PLEDGE A DEAL ON BUDGET

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
In the first sign of a break in the budget impasse, President Clinton and the Republican leaders of Congress agreed today that they would personally negotiate an agreement to balance the Federal budget in seven years. After the White House made a concession the Republicans had sought, the Congressional leaders said they hoped to reach the agreement before the new year.
Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said they would meet with Mr. Clinton on Wednesday to try to work out the framework of an agreement for balancing the budget. "It's a big step," Mr. Dole said. "We're serious about this now." 
 Mr. Gingrich said that if further progress occurred in Wednesday's meeting, Congress would consider a temporary spending bill to end the partial Government shutdown that left 260,000 Federal workers idled for a second day today. And the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, made clear tonight that negotiators were trying to pave the way for such a bill to be passed on Wednesday.
Mr. Dole said that such a measure could finance the Government through Dec. 27 or 28, putting off the possibility of any further upheaval at least until after Christmas.
The Republican leaders painted Mr. Clinton's pledge of personal involvement as an important turn in the yearlong budget dispute. "We know there are some major decisions that the President, the Speaker, the majority leader are going to have to make," Mr. Dole said.
Yet, despite the optimistic talk, it was not clear that the two sides had reached any substantive understanding on the issues that divided them and there was even some initial confusion between the White House and the Republican leaders over what occurred in the two-hour meeting today.
Mr. Gingrich said the President had agreed to use the economic assumptions of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office in the negotiations, a concession that the Republicans had been seeking. Those forecasts are less optimistic than the White House projections and would require deeper cuts to reach a balanced budget. Mr. Gingrich also said that the two sides had pledged to try to conclude a budget agreement by New Year's Day.
But Vice President Al Gore, who attended the Oval Office session, said that there was a "slight misunderstanding" and that there had been no pledge to use the Congressional Budget Office's assumptions. He also said no timetable had been set for an agreement.
"If it is possible to do that by the end of the year, we'll do that," he said. But minutes later, Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, amended Mr. Gore's remarks and said that the President had agreed that when any individual part of the budget was discussed, the parties would use Congressional Budget Office estimates of how much it would save or cost.
The meeting was the first time that the President and the Republican leaders had sat together since mid-November, when they made an unsuccessful effort to avert the first partial Government shutdown, which lasted six days.
Mr. Panetta met tonight with Congressional budget negotiators to develop a framework for Wednesday's talks. Leaving Capitol Hill midevening, he said the group was "making good progress."
Mr. Panetta said the President would not put forth a new budget proposal to Congressional leaders on Wednesday, but that a range of proposals would be examined.
Besides the competing budget plans already drawn up by Mr. Clinton and by Congressional Republicans, plans have been drafted by conservative Democrats, by Senate Democrats and by a bipartisan group of Senators.
In addition, the White House and a task force of Congressional Democrats have been working behind the scenes for days to draw up a plan that could hold the allegiance of both liberal and conservative Democrats.
Senate Democrats said today that that plan would hold firm on Mr. Clinton's proposals to slow the growth of Medicare benefits by only $124 billion and Medicaid by $54 billion -- as measured under the economic assumptions of the Office of Management and Budget, the White House budget office. Democrats said it would include a tax cut ranging from $40 billion to $69 billion, compared with the Republicans' latest proposal for a $240 billion tax cut over seven years.
The Democrats also want $80 billion less in other domestic spending cuts than the Republicans and they are seeking $31 billion more in cuts from programs that provide Federal benefits to private corporations. Yet it was far from clear that such a proposal would be acceptable to Republicans or even some conservative Democrats. And White House officials said tonight that they did not plan to present it on Wednesday.
Showing how skeptical some Republicans would be to any plan that stuck to Mr. Clinton's own Medicare and Medicaid numbers, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority whip, said that a seven-year balanced-budget plan containing those figures would be "no deal at all," even if it used Congress's preferred economic assumptions.
In November, to end an impasse that left the Government partly shut for six days, Mr. Clinton agreed to embrace the Republican goal of balancing the budget in seven years, and to use updated assumptions about national economic performance made by the Congressional Budget Office, in consultation with his own budget advisers. The agreement also said the budget must "protect future generations, ensure Medicare solvency, reform welfare and provide adequate funding" for programs ranging from Medicaid to the environment.
Since then the talks have foundered on several points. One has been on what assumptions to make about national economic performance. The Republicans have insisted on using the predictions of the Congressional Budget Office, which are slightly more conservative than the White House budget office. The conservative assumptions mean that millions of dollars more in budget cuts have to be made to reach a balanced budget by 2002.
An even more difficult question for negotiators is the fate of Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, and Medicaid, which provides health benefits for the poor. Democrats have been vowing to protect these programs.
Republicans in their latest budget proposal are seeking $202 billion in savings in Medicare, and $117 billion in savings in Medicaid, over seven years. Mr. Clinton is seeking $124 billion in Medicare savings and $54 billion in Medicaid, over the same period.
In a sign of how difficult it may be to reach a budget agreement despite the best intentions, Mr. Clinton earlier today acknowledged that disputes remained on "80 or 90 issues, policy issues that we have some differences on."
Also earlier today, before the late-afternoon agreement to go into high-gear negotiations, both sides in the dispute sent stinging messages to each other and demonstrations of their power to hold the other side hostage in negotiations.
Shortly before Mr. Clinton huddled with Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich, the President underscored the stalemate by vetoing the third Republican spending bill in two days.
Flanked by Attorney General Janet Reno and uniformed police officers, Mr. Clinton rejected a spending measure for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments and the Federal judiciary because it would convert a police hiring program that was a centerpiece of the 1994 anti-crime legislation into a block grant to states. The grant would allow the money to be used broadly for crime-fighting and not necessarily on new officers.
Mr. Clinton said the bill's failure to pay for more police would "turn back the clock" on efforts to fight crime in America. House Republicans forced a floor vote on Mr. Clinton's most recent budget offer -- sending it to bipartisan defeat by a vote of 412 to 0.
Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a Republican from upstate New York, argued that Mr. Clinton was trying to pawn off an unbalanced budget as a balanced one.
"Just as a rose is a rose is a rose, a balanced budget is a balanced budget is a balanced budget," Mr. Solomon said. "And just as a rose by any other name smells sweet, an unbalanced budget by any other name smells rotten."
In a fiery speech, Representative Harold L. Volkmer, Democrat of Missouri, denounced the Republicans for allowing the partial Government shutdown to continue.
"You're not a patriot when you're willing to shut down Wall Street, when you're willing to shut down the bond market, when you're willing to tell investors that your money isn't worth anything when you get to the bond market," Mr. Volkmer said.
Despite the hard-line poses, both sides have come under increasing public pressure to strike a deal.
The chief executives of some of the nation's largest companies and financial houses today took out a two-page advertisement in leading newspapers, including The New York Times, urging the sides in the budget battle to strike a deal.
The advertisement said: "Without a balanced budget, the party's over. No matter which party you're in."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
Gunman Kills 5 in the Bronx
A would-be robber who relatives said had a history of mental illness walked into a shoe store on a busy commercial strip in the Bronx and opened fire, leaving five people dead, the police said. The dead included a 12-year-old boy and a mother and her two young sons. The shooting also left three people seriously injured. [Page A1.] 
 "She was very decent, very nice," said a neighbor of Maria Carrasquillo, one of five people killed by a man in a shoe store in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx. [B6.]
The man accused of slaying five people in a Bronx store was described by relatives as a paranoid schizophrenic who spent the last two years in and out of mental hospitals. [B6.]
On Pelham Parkway, clusters of neighborhood residents shook their heads and tried to sort out the mayhem. About New York by David Gonzalez. [B6.]
 
Child Welfare Hearing Derailed
A City Council hearing on the child welfare system was derailed when the Giuliani administration refused to let the head of the Child Welfare Administration testify because she would not be speaking first. In response, councilmembers voted to subpoena Kathryn Croft, the agency head, to force her to appear. [B1.]
 
Tracing Santa Back to Chelsea
As a new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society makes clear, Santa Claus as a jolly symbol -- complete with reindeer and sleigh -- was imagined and born in Manhattan. "Santa Claus, as we know him, is a New York creation," said the curator of the exhibition. [B1.]
 
Largess and Computer Literacy
For educators in New York City schools, it takes entrepreneurial drive to get technology into the hands of eager students. The Board of Education has not made a systemwide purchase of educational computers since 1985; forget about the color-and-sound goodies that excite home computer enthusiasts. In these circumstances, educators rely on hustling grants. [B1.]
 
Blood Center Found Liable
A Manhattan jury found the New York Blood Center liable for providing H.I.V.-infected blood to a 4-year-old boy during a transfusion 11 years ago, and awarded him $1.5 million in damages. [B1.]
 
Giuliani Signs Pay Raise
Mayor Giuliani signed legislation that gave him and New York City's 63 other elected officials pay raises of up to 28 percent. As he signed the legislation, the Mayor threw his support behind a proposal by Dr. Rudy Crew, the Schools Chancellor, to raise the salaries of 370 top managers at the city's school system. [B3.]
 
Some Relief for Cabbies
With cabdrivers in mind, the Parks Department has opened the restroom in St. Vartan's Park, near the Queens-Midtown Tunnel's Manhattan entrance, 24 hours a day for a monthlong trial. [B3.]
 
Protester Denies Charges
The protester who has been accused of making anti-Semitic statements and threatening to burn down Freddy's clothing store in Harlem denied that he made any racist or threatening remarks and insisted that the protest was about economic issues. [B4.]
 
Man Sentenced in Bomb Plot
A New Jersey man who pleaded guilty to conspiring with a group of militant Muslims convicted of a terrorist-bombing plot in the New York region was sentenced to the 29 months he had already served in jail and placed on three years' probation. [B5.]
 
3 Charged in Queens Deaths
Three men have been arrested and charged with killing four people in a Queens bodega last month, thanks in part to a survivor who managed to pick out their mug shots from his hospital bed. [B6.]
 
Student Stabbed in Fight
The captain of the John F. Kennedy High School football team was stabbed in a fight that began when he rode the subway to his school, which is in the Marble Hill section of the Bronx. [B7.]
 
REGION
 
A Wintry Finale to Autumn
A pair of snowstorms rolled into the New York region, delivering a one-two punch that closed schools and offices, disrupted airports, complicated holiday shopping and guaranteed what meteorologists said would be the first white Christmas in 12 years. [A1.]
In Kearny, N.J., the snow came with frantic activity: plowing streets, shoveling driveways and sledding on Bunny Hill. [B9.]
Even with such a snowy climax to autumn in New York, meteorologists said they were holding to predictions of normal precipitation and mild temperatures for the winter. [B9.]

HEADLINE: Tory Skepticism on Europe Brings Major Another Defeat

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
A specter is haunting Conservatives the specter of Europe.
Once again the Tory Party is showing its divisions over Britain's ties to the European Union, the issue that has vexed Prime Minister John Major for most of his five years in office. 
 This evening Mr. Major narrowly lost a vote in Parliament on the Government's fishing policy, which adheres to fishing quotas set by the European Union. New quotas, to be adopted in Brussels on Thursday, are likely to reduce Britain's share of the catch by allowing 40 Spanish vessels in rich fishing grounds in the Irish Sea.
The outcome of the vote, 299 to 297, was humiliating for the Government. Enough Tory dissenters on Europe and representatives of coastal fishing areas joined the opposition to hand it a defeat. During the debate critics accused the Government of not defending the rights of Britain's fishermen vigorously enough.
The outcome was largely symbolic since the language of the motion made clear that it was expressing Parliament's opinion and not mandating a change in policy -- roughly the equivalent of an American Congressional resolution. So the Government will not fall or have to submit itself to a vote of confidence.
Nonetheless it showed how tenuous is Mr. Major's hold over his own party, which is trailing the opposition Labor Party by some 30 points in public opinion polls. In Parliament, the Conservative majority has shrunk to five and that could be reduced further by two off-year elections scheduled before the next general election, which must be held by the spring of 1997.
Mr. Major's stature among the party's right-wing "Euro-skeptics," who oppose allowing more power to slip away to Brussels as provided by the Treaty on European Unity, had already been damaged by events on Friday at the European Union summit meeting in Madrid. Leaders of the 15-country group resolved to press ahead with plans for a single currency beginning in January 1999, and to call it the euro.
The Prime Minister sought to apply the brakes to the single currency, arguing in Madrid that such a momentous step should not be taken precipitously and that the economies of many member nations were not yet ready. But his efforts were brushed aside by the other leaders, especially by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. Britain and Denmark have negotiated the right to opt out of the single currency, which Euro-skeptics see as a final capitulation that would lead inevitably to political union.
The Tory right wing wants Mr. Major to promise that he would rule out British membership in the single currency for the life of the current Parliament, meaning through 1996. He has refused, arguing that to do so would relegate Britain to the sidelines and remove any influence he might have during critical talks next year about Europe's future.

HEADLINE: Reserve Board Cuts Key Rate; Markets Climb

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Nudged along by a slowing economy and nervous financial markets, the Federal Reserve lowered a key interest rate today by a quarter of a point.
The cut in short-term rates, which the Federal Reserve said was justified because of the lack of any threat of inflation, allowed the stock and bond markets to regain some of their big losses on Monday. But it left considerable uncertainty about whether Wall Street would be cheered by President Clinton's agreement with Republican Congressional leaders this afternoon to come up with a framework for a budget accord that would be concluded by the end of the year. The announcement at the White House came after the markets closed. 
 The Federal Reserve action, trimming to 5.5 percent the rate at which banks lend each other money overnight, marked the first time in five months that the nation's central bank has yielded to the perception in financial markets that interest rates were too high. [Page D1.]
But in a quirk of the interplay among the Federal Reserve, the markets and the budget negotiators, the small cut in interest rates and the resulting 34.68-point increase in the Dow Jones industrial average may actually ease some of the pressure for a quick compromise on a balanced budget.
The sharp drop in the financial markets on Monday provoked considerable finger-pointing in Washington this morning. Fear spread among politicians in both parties that they might be blamed for reversing the huge run-up in the stock and bond markets over the year. But it was unclear how big a role those fears played in the agreement reached this afternoon among President Clinton, House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, to try once again to settle their differences -- this time by the end of next week.
"A hundred-point drop is not big enough to force anyone to make concessions they view as unwise," one senior Administration official said today. "But it certainly is big enough to get your attention."
Consumers are likely to derive only limited benefits from today's cut. The Federal Reserve left unchanged at 5.25 percent the discount rate, which it charges banks for short-term loans. Only one bank, Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, responded to the Fed's action today by cutting its prime lending rate, which helps determine the rate on a variety of consumer and small business loans. Others may follow soon. Markets also drove down longer-term rates that influence the cost of home mortgages, but they remained above levels prevailing earlier this month and any savings to consumers would be modest.
In Washington, though, symbolism is often more important than substance, and the symbol of a rate cut at a time of a Government shutdown and a possible budget deal is a particularly strong one. The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has waded into the middle of the balanced-budget debate several times, predicting to Congress that a balanced budget accord would prompt the markets to cut long-term rates even further. Several analysts viewed the Fed's rate cut as a carrot dangled in front of White House and Congressional leaders as the nation moved into a critical election year.
To no one's surprise, Mr. Greenspan mentioned none of the political maneuvering on the budget in his terse statement announcing the Fed's cut in rates. "Since the last easing of monetary policy in July," he said, "inflation has been somewhat more favorable than anticipated, and this result along with an associated moderation in inflation expectations warrants a modest easing in monetary conditions."
While the Federal Reserve was concerned about some indicators of a slowing economy -- weaker retail and auto sales, an erratic housing market and some signs that the worldwide demand for semiconductors is winding down after a frenetic year -- it clearly does not view a recession as a real danger. Economic growth, in fact, was not even mentioned in Mr. Greenspan's statement.
What gave the Fed a bit of room to operate was the low inflation rate. Curbing inflation is the Fed's chief mission, and with the Consumer Price Index rising only 2.6 percent so far this year, the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee could initiate a modest reduction without any fear of adding any fuel to the inflationary embers.
No sooner had the Fed acted today than the Secretary of the Treasury, Robert E. Rubin, declared that the economy was in fine shape. "We believe that the current expansion has considerable room to run," Mr. Rubin said in a statement that was released jointly with Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers.
But privately, Mr. Rubin has been warning Administration officials that the markets have built into their current high levels the assumption that a balanced budget deal will be reached. And his warning was borne out on Monday, when the specter of budget impasse was enough to touch off a correction that seemed simply waiting for an excuse to set it off.
The unresolved question is whether the slightly better prospect of a budget deal will be enough to sustain the rebound that began this afternoon. While the Fed's cut buoyed the market, that move is not likely to be repeated soon. As one White House aide put it late today: "Next week Alan Greenspan isn't going to be able to put his finger in the dike."
The Federal Reserve will not meet to consider interest rates again until the end of January, and it is unlikely to act any earlier unless economic conditions change markedly..
So the markets may be riding out the end of the year on the ups and downs of the budget talks, at once reflecting their progress and influencing their outcome. It is a situation that leaves many analysts and fund managers uneasy.
"When you look at the effect the budgets they are talking about have on the economy, it doesn't amount to a hill of beans," said Allen Sinai, the chief global economist at Lehman Brothers. The shrinking of the Federal budget, Mr. Sinai has calculated, could cause a $20 billion to $25 billion "drag" on economic growth next year. In a $7 trillion economy that rolls ahead as relentlessly as the Mississipi River, that is a small drop in the stream.
One crucial piece of information that the Federal Reserve is supposed to rely on -- the latest estimate of growth of the gross domestic product for the third quarter -- may not have been available to its policy makers today. That is because of the continuing shutdown of many corners of the Government, including the Commerce Department, which compiles the statistic. It will not be released publicly until a continuing budget resolution is passed, allowing the department to reopen.
The Federal Reserve's action today concludes a year in which it received an enormous amount of scrutiny for doing relatively little to interest rates. The last change in the Federal funds rate came in July, when the Fed lowered it by a quarter of a percentage point to 5.75 percent. Just as it did today, the Fed left the discount rate unchanged at 5.25 percent.
Seven increases during the 12-month period beginning on Feb. 4, 1994, pushed the Federal funds rate up to 6 percent from 3 percent. The Federal Reserve Board also raised the discount rate in four stages, to 5.25 percent from 3 percent, beginning on May 17, 1994.

HEADLINE: New Group Trying to Nudge Both Parties Toward Center

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 19

 BODY:
A group of centrist politicians met for a second day today to refine its message but acknowledged that it has no Presidential candidate to carry it. And two of its most prominent members, including Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, have distanced themselves from the group.
"We've got the right ideas," former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts said on Monday. "We just don't have a vehicle." 
 Mr. Tsongas, former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado and former Representative Tim Penny of Minnesota presented a paper, "Road to Generational Equity," on Monday that criticized Democrats' and Republicans' handling of the national debt. But Senator Bradley, a Democrat, and Gov. Angus King of Maine, an independent, distanced themselves from the centrist group hours before it released the paper.
"For me, the rising economic security of people who work every day and worry about their future is the most pressing issue our country faces," Mr. Bradley said in a statement from Washington. "The balanced budget is important, but it is only a part of a larger set of challenges."
Mr. King said he was dropping out of the discussions because they were taking too much of his time.
The position paper supported free trade and called for no tax cuts until the budget is balanced, a consumption-based income tax to promote savings and managed care for Medicaid and Medicare recipients.
Mr. Penny said the group's goal was not to field an independent Presidential candidate, but "to challenge one or both of the major parties to move to the center."
Mr. King said he had regarded Senator Bradley and former Gov. Lowell E. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut as the group members most likely to enter the 1996 race, but now perceived both to be "backing away."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, right, and former Gov. Richard D. Lamm listening to former Representative Tim Penny on Monday at a symposium called "Locating the New Political Center inAmerica." (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Clinton Vetoes Bill Restricting Securities Suits

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Ending weeks of suspense for several of the nation's powerful interest groups, President Clinton vetoed a bill late today that would have made it more difficult for shareholders to bring fraud suits against underwriters, corporate officers and accountants.
The legislation would have fundamentally altered the system, in place since 1933, that was designed to discourage fraud in the securities market by relying on a blend of private and government sanctions. While the measure preserved all the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission to pursue fraud claims, it would have placed formidable obstacles before individual investors seeking to have their claims heard in court. 
 Both chambers of Congress had approved a compromise measure early this month. The President's prolonged and very public indecision about whether he would sign the measure produced a flurry of lobbying at the White House from groups lined up on either side of the issue.
Congress is expected to attempt to override the President's veto. Because the House has shown greater enthusiasm for the measure, it is likely a vote would succeed there. A vote to override would be a much closer contest in the Senate.
Mr. Clinton's veto also leaves him in the awkward position of asking some Democratic Senators to publicly reverse their positions. Some had voted in favor of the measure earlier this month in part because Mr. Clinton gave no sign that he disapproved of it.
The legislation was fraught with conflicting political elements for the President, and his closest aides had been engaged in an intense debate about what position Mr. Clinton should take. Mr. Clinton's senior economic advisers -- including Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the National Economic Council, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin -- had argued that the legislation was a measured and appropriate response to complaints about frivolous lawsuits brought against corporate officers and others when a company's stock price dropped suddenly.
The push for the change was initiated by the nation's major accounting firms and by stockbrokers who act as underwriters and could be liable when a company does not perform as well as expected. But that coalition had been greatly strengthened by the support of high-technology companies that say they are especially vulnerable to such costly lawsuits because their stocks are inherently volatile.
But the technology industry, particularly in California, has been an especially vigorous financial supporter of the President and the Democratic Party. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who was a principal sponsor of the bill and is also the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, pressed his arguments in favor of the legislation on the President in a meeting on Monday night.
On the other side, Mr. Clinton was warned by aides to be wary of an anticonsumer message in the bill. "He's unwilling to sign legislation that would have the effect of closing the courthouse door on investors who have legitimate claims," a White House statement said.
Consumer groups, as well as many securities regulators in state governments, warned that the legislation would hurt small investors who had been defrauded.
A major focus of the legislative compromise had been an effort to allow companies to make predictions about their performance without fear that such statements might be used against them.
Because shareholders now may sue by arguing that they were misled by glowing company predictions, corporate officials complain that they are counseled not to offer any meaningful information about future performance. The bill included a provision for a so-called safe harbor that protected a company from liability for forward-looking statements. Under the bill, those statements could not be used in litigation if they included cautionary language identifying all important factors that could change the outcome. In addition, a plaintiff would have to show that someone knowingly made a false statement.
Under the bill, a judge would have been obliged to determine whether a lawsuit was brought frivolously and then fine the plaintiff.
Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican who opposed the bill, had asked Mr. Clinton to veto it on the grounds that it would "choke off many important suits to protect innocent investors."

HEADLINE: Mayor Signs Legislation Raising Pay of Officials

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed legislation yesterday that gave him and New York City's 63 other elected officials pay raises of up to 28 percent, formally ending a political struggle that has already undercut Mr. Giuliani's labor strategy, created new tensions at the Board of Education and subjected the Mayor to a dose of populist outrage.
Brushing aside much of the criticism over the last month as "a shame," Mr. Giuliani said he wanted the raises -- including his own $35,000 increase -- primarily because they cleared the way for increases for scores of deputies, commissioners and other managers who have toiled without raises for at least four years. Salaries for those appointed officials are linked by law to the pay of the Mayor. 
 And even as he put down his signature, the Mayor threw his support behind a proposal by Dr. Rudy Crew, the Schools Chancellor, to raise the salaries of 370 top managers of the city's school system, a proposal modeled on Mr. Giuliani's. The Mayor's support made it more likely that a majority of the board's seven members would approve the raises at a meeting tonight.
The Mayor declared that the raises he was approving would make the city's sprawling government more efficient and improve services by rewarding those who oversee their operations.
The Mayor then rattled off a list of the city's accomplishments -- from the sharp drop in crime to the redevelopment of 42d Street in Manhattan -- that he said already warranted awarding raises.
"I'm happy to do this," he said as he prepared to sign the legislation in City Hall's Blue Room, where he was joined by three members of the City Council, whose salaries would rise by $15,500 a year, to $70,500. "I feel that we're doing the right thing."
And as for any angry citizens out there, he added, "Even if they can't understand this now, as they see improvement in services, then they'll understand this is the right thing to do."
The Mayor signed the legislation, which the City Council approved on Dec. 7 by a vote of 38 to 10, a day after school officials said that Dr. Crew would propose granting raises of roughly 7 percent. Dr. Crew's proposal appeared to raise concerns among at least some members of the board. It also prompted renewed criticism from Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, the teachers' union, whose members two weeks ago rejected a tentative contract negotiated with the Mayor that offered no wage increases for two years.
Ms. Feldman called the Chancellor's recommendation "mind-boggling."
"Isn't it just so common-sensical that you don't do this kind of thing now?" Ms. Feldman said, noting that the teachers' union has been calling on the board and the Mayor to return to the bargaining table, so far unsuccessfully.
The Chancellor's aides, however, said Dr. Crew was obligated to propose the raises because of a 1990 board resolution that links raises for its senior officials to raises for managers at City Hall. In tandem with the legislation giving raises to elected officials, the Mayor issued an executive order giving increases of 7 percent to managers and a 21 percent increase for his deputies and commissioners.
Those officials have already begun receiving their raises -- including lump sums retroactive to July 1 -- in their paychecks, even though the Mayor approved the legislation clearing the way for them only yesterday.
The Mayor's signature ended, at least formally, a process that has generated considerable outrage and a stubborn defense from Mr. Giuliani, who has repeatedly accused his critics of misrepresenting the raises for political gain.
The pay increases grew out of a report issued in October by a mayoral commission that every four years, by law, considers the politically sensitive issue of raises for the Mayor, the Comptroller, the Public Advocate, the 51 members of the City Council, the five borough presidents and five district attorneys.
Once the commission submitted its report, the Mayor had 30 days to accept the recommended raises, modify them or defer them. Mr. Giuliani, however, agreed to submit them to the Council as proposed.
The proposed raises came just as Mr. Giuliani cemented tentative contracts with the teachers' union and the unions representing 140,000 nonuniformed workers that included no raises in the first two years, although they offered 13 percent increases in wages and benefits over the following three years.
Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani once again rejected the notion that the raises should be linked to the union contracts. The city's elected officials, he said, have not had raises in eight years, while unionized employees have received raises in each of those years. The commissioners and most managers, he added, have not received raises in four or five years.
In addition to the raises for the Mayor and Council members, the Comptroller's salary rises by $28,000, to $133,000; the borough presidents' pay grows by $19,000, to $114,000; and the district attorneys' salary increases by $10,000, to $125,000. The Public Advocate's salary increases by $20,000, to $125,000, but Mark J. Green, a potential rival of Mr. Giuliani's in 1997, has said he will not accept it.
Beyond the impact on union negotiations, a recent poll in The Daily News showed voters opposed to the raises. And the Mayor has had to defend them to angry citizens on the radio and at town hall meetings.
Frank Llewellyn of the Same Boat Coalition, which represents more than 100 advocacy groups and social service organizations, said the raises would increase "dangerous cynicism" about politicians.
"Clearly, the economic situtation for most New Yorkers will not improve this coming year," he said. "Why, then, should the salaries for our leaders improve?"
