HEADLINE: Rates Are Rising on Policies That Cover Gaps in Medicare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Adding new fuel to the budget debate, the largest suppliers of private health insurance supplements to Medicare said today that their premiums would rise by an average of about 30 percent next year.
The increase was disclosed by the American Association of Retired Persons and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which provides supplemental coverage to 3.1 million members of the association. Other companies are also raising premiums for these policies, which help fill gaps in Medicare by paying hospital charges, doctors' bills and other expenses not covered by the Government program. 
 The higher charges for these Medigap policies come on top of premium increases that Republicans in Congress and President Clinton have already proposed for Medicare itself. The Republicans want bigger increases than the Administration will accept, and some of the most intense arguments in the budget debate involve this and other Medicare proposals.
More than two-thirds of the 37 million Americans covered by Medicare have Medigap insurance. Average premiums for the Prudential policies range from $51 to $151.75 a month, depending on how much the policies cover.
Much of the rise in premiums is attributed to increased use of outpatient services. Medicare pays the full cost of much in-hospital care, but beneficiaries pay at least 20 percent of the cost of outpatient services.
Jerry Carey, a spokesman for Prudential, said: "Our premiums are dictated by our claims experience. The biggest reason for the higher premiums is that we saw a big increase in claims volume nationwide, especially outpatient claims. We've seen a big increase in utilization of outpatient services."
The increase in claims started in the second half of 1994, when President Clinton's ambitious plan to remake the nation's health care system was dying. The connection between the two events is unclear, but some health care experts suggest that doctors and other health care providers began limiting the number and complexity of services while the debate over the Clinton plan was raging.
There are 10 standard Medigap policies, covering items like prescription drugs, skilled nursing care and the 20 percent of doctors' bills not covered by Medicare.
Discussing Medigap premiums, Wayne F. Haefer, membership director of the association of retired persons, said: "The rates will rise, on average, 30 percent. The size of the increase will vary according to the specific plan and the state where the policyholder lives."
Nationally, premiums for the most basic Medigap coverage sold through the association will average $51 a month next year, and the average monthly premium for the most extensive Medigap policy will be $151.75. In general, Prudential charges the same premiums to residents of a particular state or geographic area, regardless of their age or medical condition. Other companies charge higher premiums to older people, and their rates can exceed $300 a month.
Prudential said its Medigap premiums would rise an average of 40 percent next year in Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Maine, Ohio, Oklahoma, Utah and Wyoming; 37 percent in California, Kansas, Missouri, New Hampshire, Vermont and Wisconsin; 35 percent in Rhode Island, and 34 percent in South Dakota.
The increases will average 17 percent in New York, 29 percent in Connecticut and 30 percent in Pennsylvania. Prudential is waiting for a decision by New Jersey regulators.
Outpatient services, provided at hospitals, clinics and doctors' offices, have been increasing for a variety of reasons. Many patients like to avoid overnight stays in the hospital when possible. Hospitals have financial incentives to discharge patients as quickly as possible. For example, Medicare pays hospitals a set fee for each patient admitted with a given condition, regardless of how long the person is hospitalized. Medicare, health maintenance organizations and private insurers have encouraged the use of outpatient services, hoping to save money.
New technology permits doctors to perform many more services on an outpatient basis. As H.M.O.'s and private insurers limit payments to doctors, some doctors may try to maintain their income by doing more procedures on an outpatient basis.
Susanne C. Bowman, director of insurance services at the A.A.R.P., said that Prudential paid $12 million to $13 million a day in claims for members of the association. Because of higher claims and costs, she said, the company is paying $1 million a day more than it anticipated.
"We had an independent actuary review Prudential's pricing calculations," Ms. Bowman said. "We concluded that the increases were justified. State insurance departments also reviewed the rates and concluded they were justified."
The association said last month that it would end its exclusive arrangement with Prudential when it expires at the end of 1997, but Peter L. Ashkenaz, a spokesman for the association, said this decision was not related to the increase in premiums. Prudential and other companies will be allowed to bid for the right to sell health insurance products to members after 1997.
The association has insisted that Prudential offer the same Medigap rates to all subscribers in a given area, regardless of age, so that older members will have access to affordable coverage. President Clinton recently proposed that all Medigap insurers follow this practice, known as community rating.
Increases in Medigap premiums may encourage more Medicare beneficiaries to enroll in H.M.O.'s, which accept Medicare fees as payment in full for coverage. But, health policy experts say, if H.M.O.'s attract large numbers of young, healthy Medicare beneficiaries, the sicker and older people may be left in the standard Medicare program, and Medigap rates will then rise faster.
"Many elderly people live on fixed incomes," said Gail E. Shearer, a health policy analyst at Consumers Union. "Without community rating, Medigap costs increase much faster than inflation, and people over 75 or 80 can no longer afford the high premiums."

HEADLINE: Harlem Protester Denies Racist Remarks

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
The protester who has been accused of making anti-Semitic statements and threatening to burn down Freddy's clothing store in Harlem denied yesterday that he made any racist or threatening remarks and insisted that the protest was about economic issues.
But even in defending himself, the protester, Tracy Ligon, pointed to the religion of the Jewish clothing store owner, whose plans to expand drew the protests because they would force out a longtime black-owned record store. 
 "I felt that it was wrong that here's a business, Freddy's, which is owned by a Jew, so to speak, who came into the community, had been there no more than three years," said Mr. Ligon, who was a part-time employee of the record store owner, Sikhulu Shange. "Our money, black people's money put Freddy's in business. Freddy built up such an economic stature in the community that he wanted to force Mr. Shange out of business."
Mr. Ligon had been accused in court papers of making several threatening gestures toward the clothing store and its customers and employees during the weeks of protests that preceded the fatal fire at Freddy's, in which eight people, including the arsonist, were killed. At one point, according to the court papers, Mr. Ligon, who goes by the street name Shabazz, was accused of bursting into the clothing store and shouting: "I will be back to burn the Jew store down. Burn, burn, burn."
But yesterday, in an interview at his lawyer's office, Mr. Ligon insisted that there were no racial overtones to his actions. "Let's just dismiss the issue of racism," he said. "We're not talking about racism."
Also yesterday, a senior police official said the Police Department had begun an inquiry into the performance of the Harlem precinct responsible for monitoring the boycott of the store on 125th Street. The inquire comes after Police Commissioner William J. Bratton bluntly said he regretted not having responded more aggressively to the protests taking place daily outside Freddy's.
On Dec. 8, one protester, Roland J. Smith Jr., opened fire inside the store, set the building ablaze and then shot himself, killing seven store employees and himself.
Mr. Ligon, a regular on the picket line, who sometimes protested during his work shift, said yesterday that he had seen Mr. Smith only once, when he showed up on the picket line three or four days before the massacre.
"He seemed to be just like all the rest of the picketers," Mr. Ligon said. "He was just boycotting, saying, 'Boycott, boycott, close Freddy's.' "
Mr. Ligon, a 37-year-old man who has lived off and on in a homeless shelter and spent 12 years in jail for armed robbery and credit-card fraud, was identified and interviewed by the police on Saturday. As one of the three people who made up the core of the demonstrations, Mr. Ligon has been of interest to the police as they try to determine if anyone knew about Mr. Smith's plans to attack Freddy's. The other two protest leaders were Mr. Shange and Morris Powell, the leader of a Harlem vendors' association who made racially charged statements supporting the protests.
Mr. Ligon said yesterday he had known Mr. Powell for years and was one of a group of street vendors who clashed last year with city officials who ultimately succeeded in driving the peddlers off the sidewalks of 125th Street. Mr. Ligon also said he had attended many rallies and meetings led by the Rev. Al Sharpton, who also made racially tinged remarks about the boycott.
Mr. Ligon also acknowledged that he had used the word "bloodsucker" to refer to the clothing store.
Mr. Ligon also said that on the day before the deadly assault, protesters were chanting "Freddy's Dead." But he said that phrase referred to signs that Freddy's had put up saying it was going out of business.
"At no time under any circumstances did I make any threats or gestures, at not time did I go into Freddy's and light a match or pretend to light a match," said Mr. Ligon, who was smoking a cigarette and wearing a Malcolm X sweatshirt during the interview. He said the protesters were also angry at the black Pentecostal church that was the landlord for both Freddy's and the record store.
Yesterday, the senior police department official said investigators from the department's bias unit have spent the last week questioning members of the 28th Precinct in an effort to determine who knew what and when, and if the precinct had failed to adequately deal with the volatile daily scene outside the clothing store.
Also yesterday, Fire Department officials yesterday refuted a claim that 911 operators handling calls from several of the store workers trapped in the basement of Freddy's had not relayed the calls to Fire Department dispatchers.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Clinton and G.O.P. Leaders To Negotiate on Budget
President Clinton and the Republican leaders of Congress agreed to negotiate personally an agreement that would balance the Federal budget in seven years.
It was the first sign of a break in the budget impasse, and the Congressional leaders said they hoped to reach agreement before the new year. "We're serious about this now," Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said. "The President is serious." [Page A1.] 

Fed Cuts Key Interest Rate
The Federal Reserve lowered a short-term interest rate one-quarter of a point, trimming to 5.5 percent the rate at which banks lend each other money overnight. It pointed to the lack of any threat of inflation. [A1.]
 
The price of the 30-year bond rose 110/32 to 11015/32 in reaction to the cut, recovering nearly all its Monday loss. The yield fell to 6.11 percent, from 6.20 percent on Monday. [D15.]
 
Japan to Rescue Mortgage Lenders
The Japanese Government decided to use $6.85 billion in taxpayers' money to rescue the nation's troubled mortgage companies, ending months of bitter wrangling. [D2.]
 
Natural-Gas Futures at Record
Natural-gas futures prices surged to a record as cold-weather forecasts threw traders into a panic over supplies. [D6.]

Warner-Lambert agreed to pay $1.05 billion to buy full rights to six popular over-the-counter drugs from Glaxo Wellcome, ending their joint venture. The two will continue their agreement to market a nonprescription version of Zantac, an anti-ulcer drug. Separately, the F.D.A. approved a version of Zantax as a heartburn rememdy. [D4.]

USA Waste Services said it would buy Western Waste Industries for $510 million, creating the nation's third-largest trash hauler. [D18.]
 
Paper Customers Going Green
Big paper customers said they would consider paper makers' environmental performance in deciding which to patronize. The stand by Duke University, four big corporations and the Environmental Defense Fund is intended to rely on market forces. [D5.]
 
Xerox to Streamline Management
Xerox plans to realign its eight business groups into three to speed decision-making amid increasing competition in the digital copier market. [D7.]
 
I.B.M. and Ameritech in Deal
I.B.M. and Ameritech formed a partnership to service both computers and telephones. In a seven-year, $400 million deal, I.B.M. will service Ameritech's 35,000 desktop computers, while the baby Bell will provide a large part of I.B.M.'s voice and video services. No cash will actually change hands in the deal. [D19.]
 
Costs Jump on Medigap Policies
Suppliers of private health insurance supplements to Medicare plan to raise premiums next year by 30 percent. [A1.]
 
Massachusetts Sues Over Tobacco
Massachusetts became the latest state to sue tobacco companies for the health-care costs of treating smoking-related illnesses. [A16.]
 
The Skies Become
Less Friendly
With airlines reporting profits, the carriers are now cracking down on passengers who try to bend the rules, crowding on at the last minute with too much laggage, for example, or swapping tickets. Edwin McDowell: Travel. [D8.]
 
Fleet's NatWest Deal a Bargain
Fleet Financial agreed to buy NatWest Bank, the New York and New Jersey operation of National Westminster Bank of Britain, for $3.26 billion. At 1.05 times NatWest's book value and 12.3 times its earnings, that is a bargain-basement price. Market Place. [D8.]

Interactive advertising has had an ebullient, even euphoric year, but it faces a shakeout in 1996, attendees at a conference on the subject that drew 500 on a snowy, blustery day were warned. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: A Rate Cut, and a Fistful of Reasons

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
For the second time this year, the Federal Reserve's top policy makers met in the face of substantial market pressure for lower rates and decided to cut -- by the smallest amount possible.
The decision is another example of the way the Fed can use its powers over interest rates not only to change the cost of money, but also to send a reassuring signal to investors and politicians alike. 
 Today's statement by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, announcing the rate cut emphasized the low inflation of recent months while not mentioning any concern about a possible slowdown in economic growth. The result was a clear signal to financial markets that the central bank expects a fairly healthy economy with low inflation -- a good environment for stocks and bonds alike, and a signal that investors responded to today by bidding up share prices and bonds.
"I think they probably made this move more to reassure the markets than to send any signal of concern about the economy," said John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor until his retirement last spring. "I think that they have always been concerned about the effect of a move, or the lack of a move, creating undue alarm in the market."
To be sure, there are as many explanations for today's action by the central bank as there are economists. While the need to reassure markets about the direction of the economy was almost certainly important, other explanations fall into three broad categories.
One explanation is that the Federal Reserve acted on the basis of the economic indicators it generally insists are its only guide to action. Recently, those figures have shown little inflation and some slackening in the pace of economic growth. Retail sales showed some signs of recovery in October but remained lackluster this Christmas season. Factory investment spending is faltering. And consumer prices were unchanged in November, although prices paid to factories and other producers did rise.
"We can well afford to cut interest rates because inflation remains nearly nonexistent and growth has slowed precipitously," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers here.
Another explanation is that after months of pushing for a balanced budget deal, the Federal Reserve took a step back today -- but only a small step.
Mr. Greenspan put the central bank into the budget debate by calling repeatedly for a balanced budget and even suggesting a way to cut spending and reduce taxes. And it was Mr. Greenspan who effectively took the central bank out of the budget debate today, cutting short-term interest rates while issuing a statement that ignored budget issues entirely.
But today's one-quarter of a percentage point reduction in the Federal Funds rate, which banks pay each other for overnight loans, was the smallest step that the central bank could take today. The Federal Reserve also left unchanged the discount rate, which it charges banks for short-term loans.
That leaves the Federal Reserve with room to cut interest rates further if a budget deal is struck. Some economists argue that based on the current levels of short-term market interest rates that investors believe the Federal Reserve could reduce short-term rates by up to a full percentage point in the coming months without rekindling inflation.
A third school of thought says that today's decision was at least partly motivated by the politics of an approaching election year and the approaching expiration of Mr. Greenspan's second term as chairman.
The Federal Reserve tries to keep as low a profile as possible during election years, and today's meeting of the Fed's top officials was the last until Jan. 30 and 31. Given a choice between cutting rates now and reducing them in January, today's move helps the Fed avoid the appearance of playing politics too close to the beginning of the primary season.
Today's rate cut is also likely to please President Clinton, who was already expected to reappoint Mr. Greenspan as chairman and possibly Alan S. Blinder as vice chairman when their terms expire early next year. First appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1987 and reappointed by President George Bush in 1992, Mr. Greenspan is a longtime Republican who has nonetheless managed to woo Mr. Clinton and his top aides with advice and strong support on Administration initiatives like last winter's bailout of Mexico.
Mr. Blinder, a Clinton appointee, was on the verge of leaving the Federal Reserve last summer and returning to his position as a professor at Princeton University when he thought that his influence at the central bank would always be limited because of Mr. Greenspan's many allies on the Federal Reserve's main interest-rate policy committee. But he has now successfully led two efforts, last July and this month, to bring about lower interest rates, and said in an interview earlier this month that he had become undecided on whether to stay.
But the strongest explanation for today's outcome appears to lie in the Fed's reluctance to alarm the stock and bond markets, which had already rallied on the assumption that a cut in short-term interest rates was in the offing.
Mr. LaWare recalled today that when the Fed's top officials met on Feb. 4, 1994, and raised short-term interest rates for the first time in five years, he and some colleagues wanted to start off with a half-point increase in the Federal funds rate. But it was Mr. Greenspan who led the objections to such a move and called instead for only a quarter-point adjustment.
When a decision was needed, Mr. LaWare said, "The phrase the chairman used at the time was 'We don't want to crack the markets.' "

HEADLINE: Japan to Use Tax Revenue To Rescue Housing Lenders

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The Japanese Government ended months of bitter wrangling today by deciding to use $6.85 billion in taxpayers' money to rescue the nation's troubled mortgage companies.
The decision may ease some foreign concerns about the Government's resolve to deal with Japan's banking problems, for in some ways the resolution is reminiscent of the American Government's rescue of savings and loan institutions. 
 But unlike in the United States, where the Government stepped forward to clean up the problems, Japanese taxpayers have been reluctant to pay for the mistakes of bankers who lent recklessly to real estate projects in the boom years of the 1980's. Many Japanese fault the bankers for the nation's current economic troubles.
Consequently, the rescue plan, announced at a televised midnight news conference, is likely to set off fierce public criticism.
"Please understand," Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama said at the dramatic and acrimonious news conference. "It was a decision filled with bitterness."
"It is natural for anger to be voiced," he said, taking questions from selected Japanese reporters. "But this problem is related to the international financial system, and since the financial system is an artery of the economy, it is necessary to establish the credibility of the system. If we postpone a decision any further, there would be chaos."
The mortgage companies, now on the brink of collapse, went on a lending spree in the 1980's. They made loans for giant property deals, some of which went bust when the economy stagnated. Some experts say the Finance Ministry is partly to blame because it exempted these companies from controls imposed on other financial institutions, and Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura apologized to the Japanese people for the Government's decision to use public funds.
Nonetheless, for several years now, the bad loans of the eight mortgage companies have been a nagging headache for the entire banking industry. Liquidating seven of these ailing companies will result in losses from unrecoverable loans estimated at $64 billion. That problem now is being solved with the Government funds, loan forgiveness by the big Japanese money-center banks, new loans by farm cooperatives, and assistance by other financial institutions.
Beyond the $64 billion, there is $12 billion in bad loans that will probably also be unrecoverable.
And these losses are only part of at least $182 billion that is unrecoverable from more than $400 billion in bad debt that plagues the broader Japanese financial system. It is not clear that the Government and financial institutions are ready to deal with this larger problem.
With the mortgage companies, the hope was that the Government would not have to turn to the taxpayers for help, and that instead, the institutions that had stakes in the mortgage companies would divide the losses.
But the Government did finally agree to play a part. It said it would set up a special agency that will use loans and taxpayers' money to help dispose of all the bad loans.
This package is the result of a sharp battle between two main creditors of the mortgage companies: the commercial banks and the agricultural cooperatives, which had the lion's share of bad loans.
The agricultural cooperatives had apparently supported the mortgage companies' lending, but they, too, have been ailing. For awhile, they resisted classifying some of their loans to the mortgage companies as bad debt, maintaining that they would be repaid.
These cooperatives have enormous influence in Japan, and politicians were reluctant to force them to pay. The result is that the co-ops will be asked to give only grants and low-interest loans of about $5.3 billion to the new special agency in exchange for a guarantee that all their claims -- about $5.5 billion -- on the mortgage companies will be repaid.
When asked why the agricultural co-ops were being favored, Prime Minister Murayama replied that it was a political judgment. "Agriculture is a very important industry which produces the people's food," he said, visibly awkward.
The money-center banks, which originally founded the mortgage companies, will provide both capital and low-interest loans to the new agency. They will also be forced to assume the biggest losses, forgiving more than $35 billion in loans now extended to the mortgage companies. Japan's 21 largest banks are expected to record high operating profit this fiscal year, which ends in March 1996. But disposing of these unrecoverable loans is likely to force some of them to report overall losses for the year.
Other financial institutions, which lent funds to the mortgage companies but did not help establish them, will abandon $17 billion currently owed them and provide capital and loans to the new agency.
On average, Japanese citizens will pay about $55 to foot the bill. That amounts to $220 for a family of four. But that amount is likely to be only the starting point.
Costs, or the amount of bad debt, could rise in the process of liquidation. And if the economy worsens and real estate prices fall further, the burden on taxpayers could be several times greater.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Rate Cut Spurs Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rebounded sharply yesterday as the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 1 10/32, to 110 15/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, dropped to 6.11 percent, down from 6.20 percent on Monday. The benchmark issue lost a point and a half on Monday on fears the cut would not occur while Federal budget talks were stalemated. Before rising, bonds faltered in early trading on follow-through selling generated by Monday's steep drop. 
 "Inflation has been somewhat more favorable than anticipated," the Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said in a statement, "and this result along with an associated moderation in inflation expectations warrants a modest easing in monetary conditions."
The Fed move trimmed the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.50 percent. It followed a string of statistics showing the economy softening after a rise in the third quarter.
 Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said, "In addition to the subdued, benign and nonthreatening pace of inflation it is certainly true that some recently released economic statistics indicating a slower pace of business activity entered into the equation as well."
The Federal Open Market Committee's rate cut yesterday, in its last meeting of the year, followed a similar cut five months ago.
Expectations of what the Fed would do yesterday had been divided, with half of the market seeing at least a cut of 25 basis points in short-term rates and the other not expecting any change because of the stalled budget talks. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Nerves, though, remained a bit frayed over what budget compromises will be made to reach an accord. Traders said the early losses were pared after President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed to meet at the White House at 3 P.M. on a seven-year deficit reduction plan. "People are seeing that politicians are actually sitting down to talk," said Gerald A. Guild, head of fixed- income trading at Advest Inc.
After the meeting in Washington, both sides said that there had been progress. Republicans said that if a another high-level budget meeting went well today, they would consider a stopgap spending bill to end the partial shutdown of the Government. They also said they hoped talks would lead to a budget agreement by the end of the year.
 Elsewhere in the market, the Treasury plans to sell $18.25 billion in new two-year notes today and $12 billion in new five-year notes tomorrow. In when-issued trading ahead of the auctions, the twos were being offered at a price to yield 5.27 percent and the fives at 5.50 percent.
In municipal bonds, where New York City's huge $1.3 billion offering weighed on a market already flush with new issues, the bonds offered yields higher than Treasury securities to make them more attractive to investors and easier to compete with existing issues.
Traders said the sale was also helped by the fact that the settlement date -- that date buyers must pay for the bonds -- falls a few days after Jan. 1, when investors normally are receiving cash from interest payments on other investments.
Goldman, Sachs & Company was the senior manager in the sale, which was made up of bonds maturing from 1997 through 2025, with a maximum yield of 6.32 percent for the longest maturity, about 14 basis points more than a comparable Treasury security.
Serial bonds with shorter maturities offered yields from 4.10 percent for an issue due in 1997 to 6.27 percent for bonds due in 2014 and 2015. Other long bonds were priced to yield 6.30 percent for those due in 2019 and 2020.
Though the issue was priced at a precarious time for the markets, as the market awaited the Fed's decision, traders said the deal went well. By borrowing money at lower interest rates the city has reduced its debt service payments.
"The key thing," said Alan L. Anders, director of financing policy for New York City's Office of Budget Management, "is that the city realized a $47 million savings for the current fiscal 1996 budget, only a little less than what we expected."

HEADLINE: Fabian Linden, Creator of Index Of Buyer Confidence, Dies at 79

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Fabian Linden, the economist who developed the widely quoted consumer confidence index of the Conference Board, died at his home in Manhattan on Monday. He was 79.
The cause was cancer of the colon, his wife, Anita, said. 
 Mr. Linden joined the Conference Board, a worldwide business research organization, in 1957 and was active in his post as executive director of its Consumer Research Center until a few weeks ago, his wife said.
He was one of the first American economists to examine consumer behavior as a means of divining shifts in the American economy.
In 1967, he developed the Conference Board's consumer confidence index, which measures consumer attitudes and buying plans. Today, it is one of the two major consumer indicators used by economic forecasters, competing with one developed at the University of Michigan, and it is considered a leading economic indicator by the Federal Government.
The board's index, issued monthly, is also widely watched by business executives and by Wall Street, and is often cited by financial analysts to explain swings in stock and bond prices.
As developer of the index, Mr. Linden became a national authority on consumer behavior patterns. He often told business audiences: "Consumers are better forecasters than economists because they are closer to economic reality. They are the first to feel significant economic change. They are the first to know when they and their neighbors are being hired or fired and first to know whether business activity is expanding or contracting."
Mr. Linden wrote more than 40 books or major studies for the Conference Board, many of which were widely used by business and quoted in the media. His most recent, "How We Spend Our Money," was published this year. Others include "Consumer Affluence: The Next Wave," "Baby Boomers in Mid Passage: A Demographic, Economic and Social Profile," and "Working Women: A Demographic, Economic and Social Profile."
Before joining the Conference Board, Mr. Linden was in the Foreign Service, first in Vienna as an economic attache and later in Paris as a member of the United States delegation to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
He received a bachelor's degree in economics from New York University and a master's degree in economics from Harvard University.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Linden is survived by a daughter, Livia, of Costa Rica; a stepson, Neil, of Manhattan, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Stocks, Bonds Surge After Fed's Action

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
For financial markets, it was almost as if Monday never happened.
Following one of the bigger one-day selloffs in recent years, stock and bond prices both snapped back smartly yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered a key short-term borrowing rate by a quarter of a percentage point. 
 Bond prices had already started to recover before the Fed released its decision in midafternoon. But stocks, which were hammered on Monday, were falling again. Just before the Fed announcement, which came around 2:15 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average, which had plunged 101.52 points on Monday, or 1.96 percent, was down another 20 points.
But the Fed's decision to lower the overnight Federal funds rate to 5.50 percent from 5.75 percent -- the second time it has cut the closely watched rate this year -- prompted a sharp reversal. By the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow was up by 34.68 points, to 5,109.89. Despite a snowstorm in New York that gathered force as the day wore on, trading volume was very heavy, at 479.8 million shares, up from 426.3 million on Monday.
The gains were by no means limited to the 30 blue-chip issues that make up the Dow. The Nasdaq composite index, heavy with high-technology issues, rose 23.85 points, to 1,026.41, nearly reversing its Monday decline of 27.92 points. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 5.12 points, to 611.93, and the Big Board's composite index rose 2.05 points, to 325.71.
On Monday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury, which moves in the opposite direction of the bond's price, had risen by 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. But the yield came down almost that much yesterday. Late in the day, the Treasury's benchmark issue was quoted at a price to yield 6.11 percent, compared with 6.20 percent on Monday. [Page D15.]
Much of Monday's deep price decline in the stock and bond markets had been attributed to worries that the Fed, despite signs of softness in the economy and positive news on inflation, would delay any cut in rates until the impasse over how to balance the Federal budget had been overcome and an agreement had been reached.
Analysts said that if that thought had been on the minds of Fed governors before Monday, the sharp selloff might have shunted it aside.
"The financial markets may have had an influence," on the timing of the rate cut, David Wyss, research director at Data Resources Inc., said. "I think the Fed knew it had to cut rates, and Monday's reaction in the markets was an impetus not to put it off."
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., said that "the Fed should conduct monetary policy on the basis of what the economy is doing. The budget is part of the economy, but it is only part of it, and at some point we will get a budget accord. But it could be an extremely long wait, and in the meantime you cannot expect the Fed to stay frozen."
The cut in the funds rate led one big commercial bank, the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, to lower its prime lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 8.50 percent. Mr. Wyss said other banks would likely follow, but probably not until after the new year.
While the rate cut provided reassurance to stock traders and investors yesterday, some analysts argued that the move carried more symbolic weight than real significance for financial markets.
"The cut is strictly cosmetic, and is designed more to reassure people than to have a real impact on the economy," said E. Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company.
Mr. Metz, who has been bearish on the stock market for some time, said that in his view the cut "does not give us another leg upward. I think it represents a selling opportunity.
"To me, interest rates are not a problem," he added. "There is a financial mania going on, with too much money being thrown at financial assets. I think the Fed is throwing a little gasoline on the flame."
Despite Mr. Metz's concerns, there were no apparent signs yesterday that mutual fund investors, who have been buying stocks on any signs of weakness for the past five years, are beginning to cash out.
"On Monday we had very thin net sales of mutual funds, only $7 million," said Tom Taggart, a spokesman for the Charles Schwab Corporation in San Francisco. "On a normal down day the spread might be $30 million to $40 million. But a lot of people are reshifting their portfolios for tax reasons at this time of year. And I am not hearing anything unusual about today's activity."
Most of the biggest gains recorded in yesterday's stock market advance were by high-technology companies. But interest-sensitive issues, like banks, also gained.
Among computer makers, shares of Dell Computer rose $6.125, to $35.625; those of Compaq Computer gained $3.50 to $49.125, and those of Hewlett-Packard were up $6.625, to $83.875. Intel, the world's leading maker of computer chips, rose $3.125 a share, to $60.375, and Microsoft, the software manufacturer, was up $3.875 a share, to $90.875.
"Technology stocks have been under a lot of pressure for the last month or two, with Monday being one of the biggest selloffs," said Todd D. Bakar, a technology analyst at Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco.
"At some point, people are going to be more selective about this group," he said. "But it seems as if we are still in the mode where people are either buying them all or selling them all."
Among big banks, shares of BankAmerica advanced $1.75, to $64.75. And the Fleet Financial Group, which yesterday announced its second multibillion-dollar buyout in less than a month -- the latest is of the National Westminster Bank's American bank operations -- rose $2.125 a share, to $41.125.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Fleet buys NatWest cheap, in a deal that's widely applauded.

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell 

 BODY:
EVEN bankers sometimes can live well shopping at the bargain basement. Fleet Financial Group confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to buy NatWest Bank, the New York and New Jersey operation of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of Britain, for $3.26 billion.
That price represents 1.05 times the book value of NatWest and 12.3 times its earnings. It is far less than the multiples in other bank deals this year, especially the sky-high premiums paid in New Jersey by First Union, which bought the First Fidelity Bancorporation for $5.6 billion, and the PNC Bank Corporation, which bought the Midlantic Corporation for $3 billion. 
 To be sure, NatWest's franchise is smaller and less well positioned than these other banks and a third of its assets are in low-yielding securities. But many analysts said Fleet's shareholders were coming out ahead. "We think the deal is a winner," said Thomas F. Theurkauf of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. He raised his estimate of 1997 earnings to $5 a share from $4.65, and his rating of the stock to attractive from hold.
Fleet's shares rose $2.125 yesterday, to $41.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, a faster pace than other bank stocks, which were all buoyed by the Federal Reserve's interest-rate reduction.
"Strategically it's a natural for them because it moves them out of New England," Mr. Theurkauf said, noting that Fleet would deepen its penetration of New York City and Long Island, and move into New Jersey. "But often the strategy is easy," he said. "The hard part is making the numbers work."
Many analysts had expected that it would be hard for a buyer to structure a lucrative deal for the NatWest unit, mainly because the British parent company needed to be paid largely in cash.
Fleet, however, has come up with an innovative financial structure that gets around the two pitfalls of cash acquisitions, the need to raise additional equity capital and the charges from accounting good will.
Like any good bargain hunter, Fleet will pay for part of the purchase over time. It will give NatWest $2.7 billion in cash up front, with the remaining $560 million paid over a period of up to eight years.
The delayed payouts will be based on the earnings of NatWest's franchise in downstate New York and New Jersey, which will remain a separate legal entity until the $560 million is paid. Fleet will keep the first $100 million of its earnings; NatWest gets the second $100 million, and the excess, if any, is split. With the operation earning about $200 million a year, and cost savings to come from the consolidation, Fleet estimates it will pay the $560 over four to five years.
The delayed payment has benefits from the time value of money, which makes the deal in effect cost $100 million less than if paid up front.
Moreover, the stretched-out payment delays the pain from the good will costs. Fleet will incur $625 million in good will up front, which will be written off over 20 years. As the delayed payouts are made, more good will charges will be added. But since Fleet already has about $1 billion in good will from previous deals, the additional liability will be offset, keeping the level constant.
Fleet will avoid issuing new stock by selling $13 billion of NatWest's bond and mortgage investment portfolio, and $18 billion of its own investments, freeing $1.7 billion in capital. Its assets will grow only to $90 million from the current $84 billion, but the composition of its portfolio will shift toward higher-yielding loans.
The final part of the purchase price, amounting to $1 billion, will come by selling $400 million in debt and $600 million in perpetual preferred stock, $300 million of which will be bought by NatWest.
Fleet figures it can save $200 million a year on expenses, mainly by eliminating 1,800 jobs and closing 30 branches, most on Long Island.
As for quality, a perpetual concern of those who frequent the remainder bin, Fleet has arranged for return privileges. NatWest's British parent will take back $375 million in problem loans and repossessed real estate before the sale, and has agreed to put $80 million more into the subsidiary's reserves to cover any future problems.

HEADLINE: Largess Vital To Literacy In Computers In New York

BYLINE: By SUSAN BRENNA 

 BODY:
It's not just chip designers, CD-ROM authors and other wizards of the supply side who score entrepreneurial triumphs in the world of technology. For educators in New York City schools, it takes entrepreneurial drive to get technology into the hands of eager students.
The New York City Board of Education has not made a systemwide purchase of educational computers since 1985, when the Municipal Assistance Corporation committed $32.5 million to in-school technology. But that was the electronic equivalent of biblical generations ago. Forget talking encyclopedias and other color-and-sound goodies that excite home computer enthusiasts. Many teachers are still trying to acquire basic hard drives. 
 In these circumstances, educators and their nonprofit partners say, the key to staying, if not current with technology, then at least generationally near, is hustling grants.
"It's a typical New York thing," said Robert McClintock, director of the Institute for Learning Technology at Columbia University Teachers College, which is helping several city schools connect to the Internet. "Who hustles gets it, and who doesn't, doesn't."
Businesses, foundations and all levels of government from President Clinton to borough presidents are financing experiments in educational technology. In the first half of this school year, according to records of the State Department of Education, 22 technology corporations gave city schools $1 million in equipment and training. Tapping corporate largess is Chancellor Rudy Crew's strategy for school upgrades, said his spokesman, David Begel.
But the grants are competitive and spending follows no obvious pattern, with private money bypassing the murky citywide pool to feed single-school tributaries. The result is a scrambling of typical school economies, and a systemwide patchwork of radical contrasts. Mr. McClintock said: "I think it's fairly documentable that the rich-school-poor-school kind of assumption is not really what determines who's got a lot of stuff and who doesn't. It's much more the vision or lack of vision of the key people working on site."
That is how Intermediate School 252, attended by 800 poor and immigrant children in East Flatbush, achieved high quality computer instruction in math and science. Since 1989, the school has competed for and received $1.6 million in Federal demonstration grants, and has more coming for five years.
Overall, New York City, which 10 years ago was considered a leader in computer-assisted teaching, is falling behind national standards, according to statistics collected by Quality Education Data, a Denver educational research firm. Nationally, schools have 1 computer for every 10.5 students. New York has 1 for every 16. Yet that is a better showing than the next two largest school systems, Los Angeles and Chicago, with ratios of 1-to-17 and 1-to-20 respectively.
New York's equipment is also older than the national average. The workhorse of city schools remains the Apple II, designed in 1977 and discontinued in 1990, with newer-generation Macintoshes and I.B.M.'s in about one-third of city classrooms. This year, the board closed computer teacher-training centers in all five boroughs.
Still, to watch the kindergartners at Public School 76 struggling to type C-A-T on their keyboards without removing their thumbs from their mouths is to imagine that city children are chasing the technological edge. The Long Island City computer magnet school, richly endowed with demonstration equipment by I.B.M. and the state, has a linked internal network of one computer for every five children.
Although only 3 percent of schools nationally are linked to the Internet, some students in Harlem, including Angel Ortega, a sixth grader, practically live on line. He attends the Ralph Bunche Elementary School, the recipient of many small grants and outside assistance, including a partnership with the Institute for Learning Technology. At this school, 10-year-olds not only use the Internet, the students themselves installed the Netscape browser that lets them take advantage of the net's hottest feature, the World Wide Web.
Mouse in hand, Angel Ortega haunts the computer labs before and after school, catching up on his electronic mail correspondence with students in Japan. Melinda Robinson, a fifth grader, stays late to send suggested plot lines via E-mail to the producers of "The Simpsons."
At P.S. 20 on the Lower East Side, two fifth graders, Vickiana Rosario and Xavier Jimenez, arrive 45 minutes early most days for lessons in navigating the Internet. Community School District 1 recently received a $555,000 Federal grant to link its elementary schools, including P.S. 20, to the World Wide Web. Part of that paid for a teacher, Adam Baskin, to spend his summer training on school equipment. Now he expects Vickiana and Xavier to help him initiate their classmates.
They are confident.
"If we push a wrong button," Xavier said, "we just find out something interesting."
Scores of other city schools use new technology creatively, but many are simply not equipped, their laboratories virtual personal-computer museums. "Our problem is not that we don't do some of the greatest things in technology in our schools," said Peter Stoll, manager of technology partnerships for the state Department of Education. "Our problem is that it's not universally available."
Only now, by direction of the previous Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, is the central administration beginning to write its first comprehensive plan for integrating technology into classrooms. Joseph Eaione, the director of instructional technology, maintains that it is time to give computer literacy "the imprimatur of the box on the report card." But another significant motivation for the plan is financing. Foundations willing to underwrite systemwide improvements ask, 'Where's your vision?' " Mr. Eaione said, meaning they want to know the educational principles involving the technology.
Amy Poorandatt, a senior who hopes to study pre-med in college, complains that she almost never gets her hands on a keyboard at Richmond Hill High School. A state survey showed that last year, two-thirds of the students at her school received no computer-assisted instruction. "I think a lot of students would like computer skills for jobs and to go to college," she said.
The school is just barely too well off to qualify for Federal Title I antipoverty money, which many eligible schools use for technology. So it has only four computer labs for its 3,100 students, and all have equipment 8 to 10 years old. "We've gotten a few mini-grants, but nothing that would help us with a whole roomful of equipment," said Susan Feldman, the principal. But the school squeezes the most from its hardware, publishing student magazines on the art room Macintoshes.
But Richmond Hill also finds itself forced to buy software of increasingly limited usefulness for its old machines. New York State gives schools $20 million annually for hardware and software purchases, but prohibits schools from combining the funds. Few computers at Richmond Hill are sophisticated enough to run the best of the newer multimedia programs that fill three double cabinets.
Even wealthier schools find it hard to integrate educational applications that seem to improve monthly. "It's like trying to catch water in your fingers," said Rita Sherman, acting principal of P.S. 76.
The barriers to upgrading are numerous. Old buildings lack the wiring to support computer networks and classroom outlets are too few. Schools are still charged commercial rates to have Internet-ready phone lines installed, as much as $600 a line in some buildings.
Some educators say that city children especially benefit from electronic links to a larger scholarly universe. "It's not ideal, but at least it gets them out into the world," said Judy Zornberg, director of District 1's Web project.
Even at schools at which the computer picture is the brightest, the reality of city school life intrudes. The labs at Ralph Bunche had to be closed twice last year and again in September because of leaks from the roof. And in a situation common in schools, there is only one teacher who understands the complicated workings of the internal network, and he is mostly self-trained. That computer teacher, Paul Reese, is known as perhaps the champion computer grant-grubber in the city, collecting equipment and doing the wiring, installation and repair himself.
"One of the things we worry about is, if Paul goes, what happens?" says Mr. Eaione. "None of this is institutionalized."
Such abstractions do not concern Mehmet Cokgoren and Corin Erby, fifth graders and best friends in Long Island City. They just do not want to log off. The two spend their daily half-hour of computer time racing through assignments so they can surf the in-school network.
"We like to experiment," Corin said. "And we're going through the whole CD-ROM encyclopedia of mammals together."
Little do they know how precarious classroom technology can be, though, when it's built on a foundation of grants.
Last year the computer coordinator at P.S. 76 painstakingly assembled donations from three corporations to link up to the Internet. Nynex installed a demonstration-model high-speed phone line, AT&T donated an expensive digital modem and an I.B.M. subsidiary produced the last piece: a central server computer developed for school use. Corin and Mehmet were connected to the net.
Then, just as the school lost $25,000 in Federal magnet funds and its grant hustler, Steve Wills, left on a medical leave, I.B.M. sold its subsidiary to a company that took back the file server. For lack of $6,000 to buy the file server, Mr. Wills said, "The kids lost the Internet."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS
Still Worlds Apart on Air Fares;
eUROPEAN tRAVELERS sEE fEW bENEFITS OF dEREGULATION

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Anyone who flies regularly within Europe knows that air fares are breathtakingly high. Never is that clearer that when some upstart emerges to take on the entrenched carriers.
Consider this: for a midweek economy-class round-trip ticket between Brussels and Rome recently, Sabena and Alitalia both charged $1,600. From Brussels to Vienna and back, Sabena and Austrian Airlines charged around $1,400. On the Brussels-Madrid round trip, Sabena and Iberia charged $1,450. 
 For a striking contrast, consider this: a low-cost, no-frills upstart called EBA Express charged just $195 on all three routes. The only real difference is that EBA offers no meals and requires a day's notice of any change in reservations. And while Europe's high-cost national airlines struggle financially, EBA -- which started flying only last year -- is already profitable and is adding new flights and destinations.
"Intra-European flights are too expensive," said Victor Hasson, managing director of EBA Express, which is owned by City Hotels S.A. of Brussels. "The market demand was there to make a no-frills, low-fare operation successful. We get people to fly where in the past they couldn't afford to fly."
Within Europe, though, innovative carriers like EBA Express remain the exception.
Nearly three years after the European Union lifted most restrictions on the routes airlines could fly within Europe and on what they could charge, many carriers, like Air France, remain state owned and are just starting to cut their operating costs. Few have expanded to new routes, leaving travelers in many cases with a choice between carriers with the same high fares.
A recent study by American Express found that fares within Europe are roughly twice as high as those for comparable distances in the United States. For example, the average one-way fare paid by a business traveler between Boston and La Guardia Airport in New York, a 187-mile journey, was $106, including discounts negotiated by big companies. To fly one-way from London to Paris, a trip of 211 miles, costs $214 using a discount economy fare, the study found.
"I am concerned that consumers have not benefited as much as expected from more choice and lower fares," said Neil Kinnock, the commissioner in charge of transportation policy for the European Union and a former leader of Britain's Labor Party. "Apart from the busiest routes and the simplest of point-to-point journeys, fares are still at levels considerably above what could reasonably be justified by cost levels."
Indeed, the stubbornly high fares are clear evidence that Europeans have so far seen nothing like the upheaval that airline deregulation brought to the United States during the last two decades.
Doug Nordlinger, an American lawyer working in London who travels frequently around Europe, said: "Does the quality of the service merit the higher prices? No. Do I think it's outrageous to pay for a business-class ticket and get what amounts to a coach seat? Yes."
But with the European Union scheduled to remove the remaining barriers to competition on European routes in 1997 and a growing number of small but determined new carriers springing up to grab a piece of the busiest routes, the need to get into fighting trim and bring fares down is finally being taken seriously by Europe's big airlines.
"The European markets were very protected for many, many years and there was no opportunity for the level of competition that has existed in the U.S.," said Bob Harrell, an air fare consultant with American Express in New York. "The system is evolving, but like anything involving government or corporate bureaucracy, it doesn't go as fast as people want it to. It doesn't happen in a year or two, any more than Southwest Airlines in the U.S. magically materialized overnight."
The stakes for European airlines are high. Many analysts say that only four or so of the dozen biggest European carriers will survive in their current form once deregulation is completed, throwing state-owned airlines into the rough-and-tumble of the private sector.
Lufthansa of Germany and British Airways lead the list of those likely to prosper, because both have been privatized and are considered efficient by worldwide standards. Air France is a big question mark, as is Alitalia of Italy, while Iberia of Spain faces a bleak future in the view of many analysts.
For carriers from the United States, the upheaval in Europe is of intense interest. The big American carriers have alliances with European partners that allow them to feed passengers onto each other's flights, giving the American airlines a stake in the industry's health.
And in the long run, a deregulated Europe could allow airlines from the United States to begin carrying passengers between European cities, a practice that is largely banned now. Delta Air Lines, for example, has no plans for a big intra-Europe business, but might be interested in particular routes, especially if they helped to feed its large trans-Atlantic traffic, said Dean Breest, a Delta spokesman.
The list of problems facing European airlines is long.
Many dominant national carriers, especially those like Air France and Iberia that remain state owned, are burdened by high costs and overstaffing. A recent study for Air France, for example, found that compensation costs for the carrier's flight attendants were 1.4 times those of their counterparts at Lufthansa.
The high-cost carriers have survived until now only with government aid. Iberia won approval from the European Union last week for $705 million in new subsidies from the Spanish Government. Air France is in the middle of a $4 billion Government-subsidy program. But the European Union has promised to crack down on further subsidies, and eventually disallow them.
Unions representing airline employees, militantly protecting their pay and working conditions, are quick to strike, hurting service, reputation and profits. The strike-plagued Scandinavian Airline System said work stoppages cost it about $45 million in the first nine months of the year.
Governments, worried about being blamed for further job losses at a time when unemployment across Europe is already high, have proved reluctant to push job cuts among state-owned carriers.
Few carriers have expanded aggressively into new routes. Only 7 percent of European routes that cross borders are served by more than two airlines, according to a recent study by Britain's Civil Aviation Authority.
There are some big exceptions to the trend. Britain, Ireland and Germany have gone much further than other nations in deregulating their domestic airline industries and have pushed their airlines to become more competitive. British Airways, for example, has become Europe's most efficient carrier largely because it must compete at home with a well-established domestic competitor, British Midland, and a growing number of start-ups.
Another British carrier, Virgin Atlantic Airways, which now flies to the United States and Asia from London, is considering offering flights within Europe.
Moreover, even those airlines that have long enjoyed political and regulatory protection from their governments are now being forced to consider serious changes to survive.
Despite a history of vehement opposition from its unions, Air France, for example, has proposed hiring new cabin crew members at lower pay than current employees, and its chairman, Christian Blanc, has sought to stimulate a more entrepreneurial management environment by breaking the company's operations into 11 units, each responsible for its own performance.
The most efficient airlines in Europe are starting to move onto their rivals' home turf, creating further competition. British Airways is already competing in the French and German domestic markets, and a 10-year-old Irish airline, Ryanair, just entered the London-to-Scotland market.
When Ryanair began competing with Aer Lingus of Ireland between London and Dublin a decade ago, annual traffic on the route was about one million passengers. It is now up to three million. On the Scotland-to-London routes, Ryanair has undercut the established airlines, offering round-trip tickets for $100 to $160, compared with about $350 for an unrestricted seat on British Airways or British Midland. And a Greek-owned start-up called Easyjet has come in and undercut Ryanair.
"What we have now is a good old-fashioned price war," said Tim Jeans, a Ryanair director. By making the trip affordable to people who otherwise would not fly, Mr. Jeans said, the annual number of passengers on the London-Scotland route should double to 3.4 million within four years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Intra-European flights are too expensive," said Victor Hasson, managing director of EBA Express, a low-cost, no-frills airline. (Daphne Angles for The New York Times) (pg. D1)

 Deregulation has driven down fares on many air travel routes in the United States. But in Europe, despite goading by the European Union, there are still only the first stirrings of price competition. The result is that fares for trips of similar lengths are typically twice or more as expensive in Europe as in the United States.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Natural Gas Surges on Concern About Cold Weather Forecasts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Natural gas futures prices surged to a record yesterday as cold weather forecasts threw traders into a panic over supplies.
Wholesale natural gas for January delivery soared 36.4 cents, to $2.868 for 1,000 cubic feet, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It traded as high as $2.90, a record for a near-term futures contract, surpassing the high of $2.80 set on April 23, 1993. 
 Natural gas futures prices have been traded only since April 1990. Cash prices for immediate delivery were as high as $9 for 1,000 cubic feet in the early 1980's, when petroleum prices were at their peak.
Analysts said winter storm warnings and cold weekend forecasts for the Northeast prompted heavy buying by companies holding so-called short positions, or futures contracts obligating them to deliver natural gas at a set price.
"There is a large hype element in the market, but any situation like this is going to panic anybody who is short, and you create a kind of stampede effect," said Tom Knight, a trading manager for Fina Inc., a Dallas-based oil and natural gas producer.
Heating oil futures also rose, but crude-oil and gasoline futures ended mixed.
On other commodity markets, soybean and corn futures extended their gains on forecasts for more hot, dry weather in South American growing areas. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 0.40 point, to 245.44.
Gas consumption is up because outside temperatures have been down, said Bruce Henning, chief economist for the American Gas Association, an industry trade group in Arlington, Va. Mr. Henning said average weekly temperatures nationwide from mid-October through Dec. 16 were 4.1 percent below normal and 14.6 percent below last year's readings for the corresponding period.
Natural gas inventories were 10 percent below the level a year earlier as of Dec. 13, the gas association reported last week. The group will release another weekly report today.
Heavy snow was forecast for last night and today in the Northeast, to be followed by cold temperatures.
Mr. Knight said heating oil futures did not respond as dramatically as natural gas to the forecasts because traders were awaiting weekly inventory data from the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's report, which was released after the close, showed American stocks of heating oil and other petroleum distillates down 3.4 million barrels from last week at 131.2 million barrels.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Modest Interest-Rate Cut by Fed Helps to Move the Dollar Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against other leading currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cut was seen as a token measure.
Typically, lower interest rates would hurt the dollar, but the Fed chose to cut a short-term rate by a quarter of a percentage point rather than a half and left alone the more influential discount rate. 
 In light of other rate cuts that began last week in Europe, the American cut had minimal effect.
"They treated it like it was a no-cut scenario," so the dollar rose, with traders selling German marks and Japanese yen, said Dan Ascani, editor and publisher of the Global Market Strategist, an advisory firm in Gainesville, Ga.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.4410 marks, up from 1.4290 late on Monday. The dollar was also changing hands in New York at 101.96 yen, just up from 101.52.
Other late dollar rates in New York were 1.1565 Swiss francs, up from 1.1465; 4.9555 French francs, up from 4.9200, and 1,595 Italian lire, unchanged. The British pound was quoted at $1.5415, up from $1.5403 on Monday.
The dollar was already climbing before the Fed announced the cut, and while the dollar rose on the news, it remained within its recent trading range.
Within recent days, market participants had become less sure that the Fed would ease rates, given contradictions in recent economic data and the discord in Washington over the budget.
But two items made traders more bullish yesterday. The President and Congress said they were ready to negotiate on the budget. And numerous European central banks have been cutting their interest rates since late last week, reducing the risk that an American cut would hurt the dollar.
When a country cuts rates to spur lending and growth, its currency can suffer because the country's assets and investments are less desirable.
The Fed has "given the markets a token cut to let them know they are listening," Mr. Ascani said.

HEADLINE: Who Will Rule Haiti?

 BODY:
Sunday's presidential election in Haiti marked a milestone for democracy there and a success for United States policy. Next February, for the first time in nearly 200 years of Haitian independence, one democratically elected President can yield power to another. That was one of President Clinton's main goals when he dispatched more than 20,000 American troops in September 1994.
The winner, by a large margin, was Rene Preval, who ran with the powerful endorsement of the incumbent, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. While the polling was generally free of the disruptions that marred recent parliamentary elections, voter turnout was low and the campaign was disappointingly short on serious debate. 
 Mr. Preval, who served as Prime Minister during the chaotic first months of Mr. Aristide's presidency before the 1991 military coup, is known as a strong Aristide loyalist. But he has a credible record of his own and need not simply be a conduit for the outgoing President's orders. Mr. Preval's credentials as an opponent of dictatorship go back almost a decade.
But Mr. Preval's own views may be irrelevant. Mr. Aristide gives every indication of intending to rule indirectly through him, perhaps by having himself designated prime minister. That would be unfortunate. The formal achievement of a democratic passage of power would be meaningless if Mr. Aristide continued ruling behind Mr. Preval.
Haiti's transition from decades of abusive government and economic stagnation has a long way to go. Excessive concentrations of political and economic power and a culture of arbitrary policing remain largely in place. The next President will face severe challenges, beginning with the departure of the United Nations forces only weeks after Inauguration Day. To govern effectively, Mr. Preval will have to demonstrate early that he can take hard decisions on his own.

HEADLINE: Welfare in the Real World

BYLINE: By James T. Fleming; James T. Fleming, a Republican, is majority leader of the Connecticut Senate.

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Can states be trusted to administer basic welfare programs fairly and equitably, or will they simply embark on a wholesale "race to the bottom," as President Clinton suggests? Congress might look to Connecticut for an early answer to this important question.
Last spring, the Connecticut Legislature overwhelmingly adopted a welfare reform package that imposes the nation's shortest time limit on benefits -- 21 months -- and reduces payments under the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program by an average of 7 percent. Does this mean Connecticut is shredding the social safety net? Hardly. 
 A typical three-person welfare family in Connecticut can expect to receive benefits totaling $16,832 a year, according to a recent analysis by the General Assembly's Office of Legislative Research. This includes not only direct cash payments ($6,600), food stamps ($2,436) and energy assistance ($212) but also Medicaid ($5,580) and housing subsidies ($2,004). By comparison, a working poor family not receiving welfare would have to earn the equivalent of $9.11 an hour just to keep pace with its neighbors on public assistance.
Welfare recipients are no different from anyone else: they act in their own economic self-interest. In Connecticut they have a fundamental choice to make. Welfare parents can stay home with their children full time knowing that they will be subsidized by the taxpayers to the tune of nearly $17,000 a year. Or they can enter the labor market and risk earning less than the welfare equivalent of $9.11 an hour. No wonder so few welfare parents work.
 Connecticut's contribution to the "race to the bottom" has been to reduce a typical welfare family's benefit from $581 a month to $543, a $38 cut. For some families this may be a burden. But it might also push parents into jobs to make up the loss of income. In fact, this is precisely what has happened. The percentage of A.F.D.C. parents who report earned income has jumped 30 percent since benefits were reduced in July. No small coincidence in my mind.
But President Clinton is adamant about not turning welfare programs over to the states in the belief that the governors will shirk their responsibilities to the poor. He should know. As Governor of Arkansas, Mr. Clinton presided over a welfare system that had one of the nation's lowest monthly benefits. I doubt very much that the governors need a lecture from him about compassion for the poor.
Maybe the President has Connecticut in mind when he suggests that states will slash and burn the social safety net. After all, our cut in the A.F.D.C. benefit and strict time limit are being called the toughest in the nation. Very deliberately, they are.
But this is only part of the story. Our reforms also permit parents to earn income from a job up to the poverty level without losing a penny of their welfare payment. Child-care financing has increased 64 percent, all families are guaranteed medical care and businesses are encouraged to hire welfare parents through a new $1,500 tax credit. All of these changes will work to shift our welfare rolls to payrolls while saving the taxpayers $133 million over the next two years.
But these steps aren't good enough for the Clinton Administration, which has put so many conditions on our 21-month time limit that it may be rendered ineffective and useless. The Administration has also refused to permit our two-tier payment system, which discourages welfare migration to Connecticut by paying newcomers a lower cash benefit.
The Administration desperately clings to the discredited theory that "Washington knows best." But Connecticut's experience under Republican Gov. John G. Rowland suggests that we can count on other states to be fair, reasonable and compassionate in carrying out welfare reform. Even with our benefit reductions factored in, a typical welfare family can expect to receive an array of benefits that place them at 137 percent of the Federal poverty level.
For too long we've had to take a back seat while Federal bureaucrats called the shots in administering basic welfare programs. They've failed. It's time for Washington to step aside and vest this responsibility where it belongs: in Hartford and the 49 other state capitols.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Scheming Italian Entrepreneurs in Troubled Albania

 BODY:
"Lamerica" was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza Cinema, Broadway at 63d Street, and Angelika Film Center, Houston and Mercer Streets, Greenwich Village.
Gianni Amelio's magnificently humane "Lamerica" takes place in 1991 in an Albania visibly coming apart at the seams. After nearly 50 years in isolation under the Communist dictatorship headed by Enver Hoxha and his successor, Ramiz Alia, Europe's poorest country is in turmoil, led by a Socialist Government that will hold power for only one year. Meanwhile, the streets are strewn with rubble and the populace is volatile and anarchic. It is either a scene of devastation or a land of opportunity, depending on one's point of view. 
 "Lamerica" begins with two Italian entrepreneurs who hope to turn Albania's misery into a private windfall. The prosperous Fiore (Michele Placido) and his slick assistant, Gino (Enrico Lo Verso), expect to start a dummy corporation, open a bogus shoe factory and exploit the economic possibilities. Fiore and Gino's idea requires the use of an Albanian figurehead for their company. And it is here that the fiscal plans start collapsing, and this spare, supremely eloquent film takes flight. From a labor camp that once housed political prisoners, they commandeer the most helpless-looking wretch they can find. This old man (Carmelo Di Mazzarelli) is named Spiro and is lost in the past. When asked his age, in one of the film's most profoundly startling moments, he signals with his hands that he is 20. Fifty years in prison have slipped his mind.
What happens next becomes a potent reminder of Mr. Amelio's equally astonishing "Stolen Children," in which Mr. Lo Verso played a carabiniere reluctantly forced to escort two children on a journey across Italy. Directed in the same lucid, simple, beautifully refurbished neo-realist style, "Lamerica"' sends Mr. Lo Verso on another spiritual journey. Separated from Fiore and sent off to watch Spiro, he is gradually stripped of everything that identifies him as a wealthy Italian carpetbagger. Instead, Gino is forced to become part of Albania's upheaval and to discover the world anew.
Albania is an inspired setting for "Lamerica," a film that proceeds matter-of-factly until it raises the stakes to capture a far-reaching poetic vision of immigrant experience. (The title is meant to be an illiterate Italian immigrant's spelling of America, to which Mr. Amelio's grandfather immigrated from Italy after World War II.) The film makes a clear connection between Albania in the 1990's and postwar Italy: both nations were economically devastated and reeling from the effects of dictatorship.
These were the postwar conditions from which Italian neo-realism emerged, exposing the personal hardships wrought by political strife and finding hope and bravery in the daily struggles waged by ordinary people. So this time Mr. Amelio reinvents neo-realism with an especially acute sense of history. A young Italian like Gino, interested only in new-found prosperity and oblivious to the lessons of the past, has a lot to learn from Albania's troubles.
The film's synthesis of fact and fiction is gracefully achieved, as in placing Gino on a jampacked truck transporting would-be immigrants to an Albanian port city. The scene is galvanized by the sad, dramatized fate that befalls one passenger, but its conversation and impossible crowding seem real.
Mr. Lo Verso once again shows himself to be a touchingly naive Everyman, a mournfully handsome actor whose face seems effortlessly revealing. Without a false note anywhere, he also establishes the right prickly intimacy with Mr. Mazzarelli, an 80-year-old retired Sicilian fisherman with no acting experience.
Mr. Amelio's earlier films (including the arid 1990 "Open Doors") have been well received without reaching a large audience. He deserves to become more widely known.
