HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Conferees Reach Accord On Telecommunications Bill
House and Senate negotiators reached agreement on a sweeping bill to rewrite the nation's communications laws, clearing the way for Congress to pass a final bill before the weekend. The new agreement came after Republicans capitulated to Democrats on a wide variety of issues, and it means that the bill is virtually assured of becoming law.
The bill is more moderate than versions passed by the House and Senate and is likely to be less jolting for consumers. Still, the choices may bewilder consumers. [Page A1.]
 
Budget Talks Snag Again
Republicans in the House scuttled an agreement to begin serious budget talks. That agreement was reached by Senator Bob Dole, Speaker Newt Gingrich and President Clinton. The House Republicans balked at approving a spending resolution before a balanced budget was agreed on. [A1.]
 
The shutdown is taking a toll on the Government's statistical reporting on the economy. But this time, most of the monthly numbers have been obtained. [D4.]
 
House Overrides Clinton Veto
The House voted to override President Clinton's veto of legislation to make it more difficult for stockholders to bring fraud suits. The Senate, which is more closely divided, made plans to vote later this week. [A1.]
 
Preparations by Goldman, Sachs
Goldman, Sachs, buoyed by its rebounding profit, is preparing itself for a possible sale next year, top executives acknowledged. [D7.]
 
Hanson to Raise Cash
Hanson P.L.C. put up for sale its Oregon lumber company and offered shares in its New Jersey propane company in an effort to raise $2.3 billion to pay down heavy debt. [D7.]
 
Hoechst to Cut 8,000 Drug Jobs
Hoechst of Germany plans to close more than half its 77 drug-production plants and eliminate 8,000 jobs. The actions followed the company's acquisition in July of Marion Merrell Dow for $7.1 billion. [D8.]
 
Californians May Get to Pick Utility
Californians would be the first consumers in the nation free to choose their supplier of electricity, under a vote by regulators. [D6.]
 
California County Sues Auditor
Orange County, Calif., sued its former auditor, KPMG Peat Marwick, for $3 billion, saying it failed to warn of financial risks. [D6.]
 
Innovative Dividend Offer
Merrill Lynch is raising money for Citicorp by promising a sweeter dividend if Congress cuts the tax deductions for dividends. [D2.]
 
Informix to Buy Software Firm
Informix agreed to buy Illustra Information Technologies for $386 million in stock. Both make database management software. [D7.]
 
Algeria to Develop Oilfields
Algeria is ready to sign several important deals with American, British and French companies to develop its huge oil and gas reserves. British Petroleum is planning a $3.5 billion commitment. [A13.]
 
Ruling Could Cost U.S. $2 Billion
The Justice Department may appeal a ruling that the Federal Government be held financially responsible for canceling contracts with General Dynamics and McDonnell Douglas for the Navy's A-12 Stealth aircraft. The ruling could cost $2 billion or more. [D4.]
 
Historians Want Tax Records
The Government's archivist said the I.R.S. has violated laws requiring that it send historically significant documents to the National Archives. The I.R.S. maintains that legally it must keep most of its records secret to protect confidentiality; the Archives responds that the I.R.S. does not even turn over mundane documents like tax forms. [D4.]
 
Ozone Labeling on Refrigerators
Four refrigerator makers agreed to put labels on the machines saying they cause damage to the ozone layer, even without using a prominent chemical. [A15.]

HEADLINE: OVERHAUL BACKED IN COMMUNICATION

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators agreed tonight on a sweeping bill to rewrite the nation's communications laws from top to bottom, clearing the way for Congress to pass a final bill before the weekend.
The agreement came after Republicans capitulated to Democrats on a wide variety of issues, and it means that the bill is virtually assured of passing Congress and being signed into law by President Clinton. 
 The new measure is likely to reshape the landscape of the entire communications industry, eventually bringing new competition for local telephone and cable-television monopolies and almost certainly provoking a wave of mergers and new alliances in the media and telecommunications industries.
The essential purpose of the measure, and ultimately its most profound effect for both consumers and the communications industry, is to knock down regulatory barriers that currently separate the industry into protected fiefs for local telephone, long-distance and cable-television service.
Advances in technology and rapid change in the marketplace have made those barriers increasingly outdated and, many experts believe, have been harmful to competition and consumers.
The bill would also impose tough new restrictions -- bitterly opposed by civil liberties groups -- against transmitting material considered "filthy, lewd or indecent" over the Internet and commercial on-line services. And the bill would require television manufacturers to install a new chip aimed at letting parents block out violent programming.
The agreement won ringing support tonight from the Administration. President Clinton had been threatening for months to veto the bill if Congress did not retreat on a long list of issues.
"This is a great Christmas present," said Vice President Al Gore in an interview tonight, adding that the agreement satisfied "every single one" of the White House's objections. "This will unleash a new era in the telecommunications revolution, and speed completion of the information highway," he said.
Despite a frenzy of lobbying and political contributions by giant telephone and entertainment companies, the bill that emerged today is substantially more moderate than the one passed by either the House or the Senate and is likely to be less jolting for consumers.
But telephone and cable customers, particularly those in bigger cities, are likely to encounter choices and changes that will be far more bewildering than those that occurred after the Justice Department broke up the old Bell System in 1984. Local and long-distance telephone companies will start attacking each other's markets with new packages of services, and both sides are likely to offer cable television and other video services as well.
If the possibilities are exhilarating, the complexity is likely to be infuriating.
In marathon negotiations behind closed doors, Republicans softened numerous provisions in the bill that would have greatly increased the number of television and radio properties a single company could own.
Under pressure from Democrats, moreover, lawmakers had already backed away from provisions to eliminate most regulation of cable-television prices and agreed to keep most price restraints in place until March 1999.
The most politically significant compromise -- and the most unexpected -- is a deal cut today that appears to resolve the most intractable dispute in the entire measure: provisions to rewrite the antitrust consent decree that broke up the old Bell System and let the regional Baby Bell companies compete in the long-distance market.
The AT&T Corporation and other long-distance carriers had bitterly opposed both the House and Senate bills, arguing that the Bells should not be allowed into the long-distance market until they faced greater competition in the local phone market.
Tonight, executives of both AT&T and some Bell companies said the bill would be acceptable. To placate the long-distance industry, lawmakers agreed today to give the Justice Department at least a partial role in deciding when to let a Bell company enter the long-distance business. Lawmakers also gave long-distance companies a handful of more technical concessions, which could give them a temporary advantage over the Bells in offering a combined package of local and long-distance service.
Local telephone and cable television companies are already upgrading their networks so they can attack each other's markets, although both industries have discovered that what seems simple in theory is turning out to be difficult and expensive in practice. Long-distance carriers like AT&T, MCI Communications and Sprint, meanwhile, are spending billions of dollars to build new capacity for offering both wired and wireless local telephone service.
The political battle has not been over any of the bill's core goals. Indeed, Democrats produced the original bill more than two years ago and almost passed a measure last year.
The main disputes have been over issues about the concentration of media ownership and about the details under which local telephone companies would be forced to open their networks to competitors.
Today's agreement came after weeks of negotiations, mostly between a handful of key lawmakers from both parties. Republicans were led in large measure by Representative Jack Fields of Texas, chairman of the House Commerce Committee's subcommittee on telecommunications, who had been among the most hawkish legislators about abolishing restrictions on media ownership. The Democrats were led by Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina and Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan -- both skilled practitioners of power politics.
Senator Hollings adamantly refused to go along with Republican proposals to relax media ownership rules, and Republicans ultimately had to defer to him in order to avoid a crippling filibuster in the Senate.
The original House and Senate bills would have greatly increased the number of television stations a single company can own nationwide, allowing a company to own any number of stations that reach as much as 35 percent of the audience. At present, the limit is 12 stations that reach no more than 25 percent of the national audience.
The House bill would have gone further, allowing a single company to own two television stations in the same market and many radio stations.
In closed-door negotiations today, Republicans retreated on several key points. They abandoned provisions that would have locked in regulatory loopholes that effectively allow a company to push beyond the remaining ownership limits. They also dropped provisions that would have relaxed local ownership restrictions, agreeing to leave that issue up to the Federal Communications Commission. And they dropped provisions that would have allowed a company to own both a broadcast television station and a cable television system in the same market.
"This bill is both pro-competition and pro-public interest at the same time," said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts. "It's the one gift for consumers in an otherwise dismal Christmas season."
Perhaps the biggest surprise today was the deal struck between local and long-distance telephone companies. It was not immediately clear whether all the Bell companies would support the newest concessions to long-distance carriers, but the deal won the support of the Nynex Corporation and of AT&T.
"Based on what we understand, there have been significant improvements in this legislation," said Herb Linnen, a spokesman for AT&T. "Most importantly, the Congress appears poised to enact landmark legislation that would break down the remaining barriers to full competition in this industry."
Tom Tauke, head of government affairs at Nynex, which owns local telephone companies in New York and New England and faces some of the most intense competition of any local telephone operator in the country, said: "This legislation looks like a major step forward for consumers, the economy of the country and those companies providing telecommunications services. It gives Nynex what it needs to compete."
Even consumer groups, which have been most suspicious of deregulation, were guardedly supportive. "There has been much progress," said Gene Kimmelman, a lobbyist for Consumers Union.
While lawmakers and industry groups have focused on business issues, public attention has been more riveted on concerns about depictions of sex and violence.
Provisions that would impose fines of up to $100,000 and prison terms of up to two years on people who make "indecent" material available to minors over computer networks are now part of the final bill and could pose big problems for companies that provide on-line information services.
The "cyberporn" issue was championed by conservative religious groups, including the Christian Coalition, and senior Republicans viewed the issue with concern. But conservatives largely achieved their agenda, and the issue is certain to provoke a new courtroom battle over Constitutional rights to free speech. Indeed, the measure includes a provision that requires a Federal court in Washington to take up the issue almost as soon as someone challenges its legality.
Liberal Democrats, led by Representative Markey, prevailed on their own social issue: curbing violence on television. Overcoming passionate objections by television broadcasters, Mr. Markey and other Democrats won support for a mandatory V-chip to block TV programming that will now become law as well.


GRAPHIC: Here are details of the securities litigation that President Clinton has vetoed.
 
PREDICTIONS GONE SOUR
Chart: "What a Vetoed Bill Would Do"
Provides a "safe harbor" for predictions companies make about their expected performance. Companies would be safe from legal liability for such statements as long as they were accompanied by "meaningful cautionary statements" identifying all important factors that could affect the prediction.
 
PROTECTING OUTSIDE FIRMS
Protects accountants and securities underwriters from being sued by private investors for "aiding and abetting" fraud, thus denying those deep pockets as a target for plaintiffs.
 
TIME LIMITS
Sets the statute of limitations for filing fraud claims at three years after a violation occurs and one year after it is discovered. The Securities and Exchange Commission had asked for a five-year statute of limitations.
 
FRIVOLOUS SUITS
 Requires judges to make a determination if a suit was brought frivolously or abusively. If such a finding is made, the party bringing the suit would be liable to pay the other side's costs.
 
JUDICIAL DISCRETION
Allows judges to select as the lead plaintiff in a class-action suit, the one with the greatest financial stake, this avoiding the so-called "race to the Courthouse" in which a lawyer may seek a compliant stockholder as a client to control the lawsuit.

HEADLINE: Dow Tumbles After Break in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices of some of America's biggest and best-known companies plunged in the last 15 minutes of trading yesterday, a slide that some analysts attributed to the latest snag in Washington's budget impasse.
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 50.57 points at 5,059.32. Traders and analysts said that a wave of computer-driven sell programs in the final quarter-hour of trading pushed the Dow down by more than 30 points. 
 "The very aggressive sell programs were the ribbon on the package," said Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates Inc., a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Birinyi said one program of close to $300 million involved almost 400 stocks in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues.
The late selloff cast a pall over what had been a fairly good day. The Dow, as well as broader market indexes, spent much of the session on the plus side, as the positive momentum continued from the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to cut a key short-term interest rate.
As a result of the Fed's move, many of the nation's biggest banks, including Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and Chemical, said yesterday that they had lowered their prime lending rates to 8.50 percent from 8.75 percent.
Indeed, despite the sharp decline in the Dow, advancing issues led decliners by a margin of about 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange. At 444.4 million shares, trading volume was heavy.
Among broader market indexes,the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.14 points, to 1,025.27, and the S.& P. 500 declined 5.99 points, to 605.94. The Big Board's composite index fell 2.10 points, to 323.61.
As the day progressed, disquiet grew about the budget talks, which on Tuesday had seemed back on track. By late afternoon, it became increasingly apparent that negotiations had been stalled by differences between the White House and House Republicans about whether Government offices that had been shut since the weekend would reopen before an agreement on a budget was reached.
In a televised appearance in the White House briefing room at 3:30 P.M., President Clinton accused "the most extreme" House Republicans of reneging on a deal that could have ended the partial shutdown.
"Clinton made a hardball statement, and we don't want that," said Albert Goldman, director of market research at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "The market would like to see progress toward a balanced budget made now. We didn't get it today."
The bond market did not care for developments in Washington either, but traders there were more restrained. Bond prices, which had been up early in the day, softened later, and long-term interest rates inched a bit higher.
Analysts said the negative reaction in the fixed-income market probably fed the stock market.
"At current prices, it is almost impossible for stocks to be up when bonds are down," said Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers.
Of the 30 Dow stocks, Philip Morris shares took the biggest tumble, falling $3.50, to $86.375. The company was named in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by the State of Massachusetts, which is seeking as much as $1 billion that the state said it had spent on health care for poor people afflicted with tobacco-related illnesses.
But other blue chips also suffered. Coca-Cola fell by $3 a share, to $74.25. I.B.M. was off $2.50, to $89.375. And General Electric lost $2, to $70 a share.
Transportation stocks bucked the downward trend, led by airline shares. Those stocks rose smartly after a positive reading on earnings from the USAir Group. USAir's stock was up 12.5 cents a share, to $13.25. Much better gains were posted by AMR, the parent of American Airlines, which increased by $2 a share, to $76.125. Shares of Delta Air Lines rose $1.875, to $77.
Based on what he described as a "nasty close," Mr. Goldman said he expected some further weakness when equities begin trading today. Given the downward move in prices since Dec. 14, though, he said any further declines should be viewed as a chance to step in.
"From its intraday high of 5,260 on Dec. 14, the Dow has traded down to a low of 5,025, which we reached on Tuesday," Mr. Goldman said. "That is a fairly big move, and did a lot to correct the 500-point rally we have had in the past seven weeks.
"If the market gets sloppy at the opening, I may advise aggressive accounts to be buyers."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Who counts budget beans best, Congress or the White House?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WHEN the bean counters at the Congressional Budget Office disagree with their counterparts on the President's Council of Economic Advisers, whom do you trust?
The question has emerged as the issue of the hour in the political duel over deficit reduction. 
 On Tuesday, President Clinton agreed that the budget office would manage the accounting for deficit scorekeeping. But the White House insists that the President has not agreed to negotiate a balanced budget on the basis of the relatively pessimistic economic assumptions built into the budget office's projections.
And while those who follow the arcana of budget-making usually side with the Congressional Budget Office because it has a better record at forecasting and a well-founded reputation for nonpartisanship, this time around the White House numbers apparently rest on equally firm technical ground.
"On many points I find myself sympathetic with the Administration," said Laurence H. Meyer, a respected private forecaster in St. Louis.
President Clinton has agreed to wipe out the deficit in seven years. But last week the Congressional Budget Office took a critical look at the President's proposed budget and pronounced it $115 billion in deficit -- not $2 billion in surplus, as the White House projects.
Some $39 billion of the difference reflects budget office skepticism about the likely savings from the Administration's proposed spending cuts and tax changes. But two-thirds of the $117 billion gap mirrors differing economic assumptions.
For one thing, the White House expects technical fixes in inflation accounting to remedy biases that in the past pushed up Government outlays far faster than revenues. The budget office is more conservative -- an assumption that adds billions to its projected deficit. Yet more significant, the White House assumes that the economy will be operating at roughly the current rate of unemployment rather than the more conservative 6 percent assumed by the budget office.
Forced to choose between the forecasts without the luxury of a leisurely examination, most budget watchers would no doubt go with the Congressional Budget Office. Indeed, in newspaper advertisements this week, corporate chief executives proclaimed their collective trust in the "realistic projections" offered by the budget office.
One good reason is that its forecasts have been more accurate in the past. Stephen K. McNees, a vice president and economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston documented this winning record in the July/August 1995 issue of The New England Economic Review.
He found that while the Congressional Budget Office and the White House council had both done respectable jobs in predicting average two-year inflation rates, the budget office was the clear winner at predicting economic growth between 1976 and 1995. The budget office missed on two-year predictions by an average of just eight-tenths of 1 percentage point, while the White House was off by 1.1 percentage points. The difference was even greater on four-year projections: the budget office's average error was nine-tenths of 1 percentage point, compared with 1.3 percentage points for the Council of Economic Advisers.
Why, then, does Mr. McNees lean toward the White House projections? One way of explaining the superior performance of the Congressional Budget Office is that its forecasts have more closely tracked the commercial forecasting services. And this time around, the White House is somewhat closer to the private consensus.
The budget office is projecting the average growth of national output in current dollars at 4.9 percent through 2002, while the White House projects growth of 5.4 percent. Robert J. Eggert, the editor of Blue Chip Economic Indicators in Sedona, Ariz., says that the consensus view of 45 forecasters is 5.2 percent through 2001 and slightly faster thereafter.
Much of the difference lies in the budget office's assumption that unemployment will rise from the current rate of 5.6 percent to 5.9 percent in 1998 and to 6 percent in 1999 and beyond. In essence, Mr. Meyer says, the budget office is guessing that the Federal Reserve will prevent the high employment levels needed to deliver fast-growing tax revenues to fill Government coffers.
If there is a one grand moral to this tale, it's that the budget negotiators' time horizon is too long. The one thing forecasters ought to agree about, says Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the budget office, is that "what you predict won't come to pass."
No one knows whether the economy will grow at 2 percent, 2.5 percent or even 3 percent over the next seven years. That's why no one really knows whether the Republican Congressional package or President Clinton's plan will leave the budget in comfortable surplus or painful deficit in 2002.
There is probably no way for the negotiators to acknowledge this reality and to redefine the terms of the budget battle. But that should not stop the rest of us from focusing on the real economic issue of how well the new budget reflects national priorities.

HEADLINE: Doctors Say H.M.O.'s Limit What They Can Tell Patients

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Doctors across the country say that health maintenance organizations routinely limit their ability to talk freely with patients about treatment options and H.M.O. payment policies, including financial bonuses for doctors who save money by withholding care.
In interviews over the last three weeks, many doctors said such restrictions interfered with their ethical and legal duty to provide patients with information about the benefits, risks and costs of various treatments. 
 Ill feeling over the restrictions is growing as more and more Americans join H.M.O.'s and employers encourage their use to control costs. Typically, H.M.O.'s offer a wide range of services in return for a fixed monthly premium. They recommend a select list of doctors and hospitals, and patients must pay more if they go outside that network.
H.M.O.'s may limit access to certain tests and treatments and require doctors to obtain permission from the H.M.O. to offer them. Doctors may receive bonuses or other financial rewards from the H.M.O. if they control costs and help restrain the use of health care.
But patients are often unaware of these financial arrangements because many contracts between doctors and H.M.O.'s prohibit the doctors from disclosing them. Increasingly, doctors are objecting to these confidentiality clauses, which they call "gag clauses," and they say that patients are entitled to such information.
For their part, health maintenanace organizations say that some of the restrictions are intended to protect trade secrets and proprietary information. Susan M. Pisano, a spokeswoman for the Group Health Association of America, which represents managed care companies, said another purpose was to "discourage doctors from disparaging H.M.O.'s and encourage them to discuss their concerns about payment and treatment policies with doctors and physician managers in the health plan, rather than with patients."
Dr. Christine K. Cassel, president-elect of the American College of Physicians, which represents 85,000 internists, said: "Managed care can be beneficial for patients, but patients need to understand the financial arrangements. To my dismay, gag clauses are becoming more common."
Whitney North Seymour Jr., a lawyer for the League of Physicians and Surgeons in New York, said the confidentiality clauses muzzled doctors who wanted to be advocates for their patients.
A typical clause is found in the contract of Choice Care in Cincinnati, which says, "Physician shall take no action nor make any communication which undermines or could undermine the confidence of enrollees, potential enrollees, their employers, plan sponsors or the public in Choice Care, or in the quality of care which Choice Care enrollees receive."
U.S. Healthcare, which describes itself as the largest operator of H.M.O.'s on the East Coast, has an almost identical clause in its agreement with doctors. David F. Simon, senior vice president of U.S. Healthcare, said the purpose was to protect patients, to make sure they were "not put in the middle" of economic disputes between doctors and the company.
A recent notice to doctors working for the Kaiser Permanente H.M.O. in Ohio says, "Do not discuss proposed treatment with Kaiser Permanente members prior to receiving authorization" from an outside company that sets guidelines for the treatment of patients. In addition, it says that doctors should not discuss the procedure by which they get such authorization.
Asked about this instruction, Jenny M. Hovinen, a spokeswoman for Kaiser Permanente of Ohio, said, "It's a very unfortunate statement, isn't it?" But she said it was part of an elaborate effort to guarantee high-quality care by making sure doctors were aware of the best treatments before discussing them with patients.
Sometimes doctors want to recommend a treatment not covered by the H.M.O. in which a patient is enrolled. Sometimes they want to refer patients to specialists not affiliated with the plan, because they believe that the best care is found elsewhere. Their ability to do so may be severely limited by a confidentiality clause.
"These gag clauses intimidate physicians and discourage them from talking openly to patients about the need for specialty care and the role of managed care companies in limiting tests and treatments," said Neil Weisfeld, deputy executive director of the Medical Society of New Jersey. "It's more like managed silence than managed care."
Doctors who obey such restrictions run legal risks and may be sued for malpractice. Carol L. O'Brien, a lawyer at the American Medical Association, said: "A physician can be held legally accountable for a patient's injury or death if the doctor provides substandard care because of financial constraints imposed by an H.M.O. Juries have awarded hundreds of thousands of dollars in damages in cases where doctors failed to put the patients' interests first."
The association's ethics authority, the Council on Ethical and Judicial Affairs, declared recently that doctors should inform patients of "all relevant financial inducements," including incentives to limit care.
Doctors in New York have filed a lawsuit challenging a confidentiality clause, on the ground that it "destroys the physician's liberty to convey needed information to patients concerning H.M.O. operations." The lawsuit, by the League of Physicians and Surgeons, says the restriction "stifles discussion of quality of care issues and H.M.O. practices that are harmful to patients." The case was argued last week before a state judge, who has yet to issue a decision.
Other contracts say that doctors may not make "disparaging remarks" or "derogatory remarks" about H.M.O.'s. Some contracts say that if doctors are dropped from a particular health plan for any reason, they may not contact their patients to inform them of that fact. The H.M.O.'s apparently fear that such doctors will encourage patients to leave one health plan and follow the doctors to another.
The doctors' complaints illustrate the tension between them and H.M.O.'s as health plans try to monitor and regulate the doctors' behavior.
Dr. Daniel A. Gregorie, president of Choice Care in Cincinnati, defended the confidentiality clause as a way to prevent doctors from sharing their frustrations with patients.
"Physicians are angry, frustrated and, to some extent, depressed because the world as they've known it is changing rapidly and radically," Dr. Gregorie said. "But physicians should not take out that frustration in a nonconstructive way by sharing it with patients. That does not help the patients. It just makes them more anxious about the care they are receiving."
An editorial being published on Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine says that some H.M.O.'s use financial rewards and penalties to force doctors to skimp on care and then try to prevent them from speaking out. A co-author of the editorial, Dr. David U. Himmelstein, had a contract to treat patients of U.S. Healthcare in the Boston area, but the company terminated the agreement "without cause" last month. The doctor had criticized the H.M.O. at an industry conference a few weeks earlier.
Dr. Himmelstein, an associate professor of medicine at Harvard, is a founder of Physicians for a National Health Program, which advocates a Government-financed system of national health insurance like the one in Canada.
Mr. Simon, who works at the headquarters of U.S. Healthcare in Blue Bell, Pa., said: "This is a tempest in a teapot. Dr. Himmelstein was not dismissed because of his political views, which have been known for many years. His services were no longer necessary to serve our members in New England, given the expansion of our network of doctors in the last year."

HEADLINE: Orange County Sues Marwick For $3 Billion

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 20

 BODY:
Orange County sued its former outside auditor today for $3 billion, accusing KPMG Peat Marwick of failing to detect and warn of the risks to investments that resulted in the nation's biggest municipal bankruptcy.
Peat Marwick, the nation's second-largest accounting firm, denied wrongdoing and said the county was blaming others for its own mistakes. 
 The suit opens a second front in the county's battle to blame brokers and other professionals for a $1.64 billion investment loss. It has a $2 billion lawsuit pending against Merrill Lynch & Company, the main investment house used by the former county treasurer, Robert L. Citron. Merrill Lynch also denies wrongdoing.
Today's lawsuit said Peat Marwick, which billed itself as pre-eminent in municipal audits, had been specifically asked to evaluate Mr. Citron's investments because internal county auditors lacked the expertise.
Peat Marwick completed audits for 1992 and 1993 and had nearly completed its 1994 review of county books when the county disclosed its huge investment losses and filed for bankruptcy-law protection on Dec. 6, 1994.
Despite many "red flags," nowhere did the firm warn that Mr. Citron had violated the state's Constitution and laws and his own investment guidelines by transforming a portfolio of taxpayer funds into "a massive wager on interest rates remaining low or falling further," the lawsuit says.
John R. Miller, director of Peat Marwick's government assurance practice, said the county's problem was its own failed investment strategy, not an accounting lapse.
"This is a continuation of the county's pattern to blame others for its investment decisions," Mr. Miller said.
He said investigations by a State Senate committee, the State Auditor and the county grand jury had yielded no accusations of wrongdoing against his firm, and he expects none.
"We're not financial advisers," Mr. Miller said. "Our role was to attest to the financial statements of the county and insure that they comply with generally accepted accounting practices. I'm very comfortable with those disclosures."
In its suit against Merrill Lynch, the county contends that the company devised and encouraged the huge borrowings and reinvestments in interest rate-sensitive securities.

HEADLINE: Federal Shutdown Begins to Affect Economic Forecasts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The partial Government shutdown has begun to take a toll on the Government's statistical system, delaying publication of various reports that affect securities markets and denying Federal Reserve policy makers full economic information in setting the nation's monetary course for the next six weeks.
But officials at the Labor and Commerce Departments, which produce the bulk of nonagricultural data, say they see no immediate threat to the integrity of the figures themselves once the Government fully reopens and can process and publish what they have collected. 
 "I don't think we yet face the prospect of gaps in the system," Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, said. For such irreparable damage, he added, "we'd have to go into January" without gathering data.
About 260,000 Federal workers, including most in the Labor and Commerce Departments, have been furloughed this week as a result of the budget stalemate in Washington.
But unlike the situation in the Government's partial mid-November shutdown, which occurred during data collection for the employment and other reports, the current furloughs come after most of the monthly numbers have been obtained.
"We got lucky this time," said William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics. "These data have all been captured."
Still, officials expressed concern about what would happen if the legions of Federal statistical workers, virtually all of them deemed to be nonemergency workers and thus subject to furlough, do not soon return.
The most "vulnerable" set of statistics, according to Mr. Ehrlich, is the Current Population survey, a monthly tally conducted by the Census Bureau and used by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to compute the nation's unemployment rate. If furloughed employees are not back by Tuesday, the first broad reading of economic performance for December could not be published as scheduled on Jan. 5.
And according to a Labor Statistics memo, a two-week interruption that ended Jan. 2 would bring "severe delays" in publishing figures on consumer prices for December and in collecting prices for January. The December Consumer Price Index report is scheduled for release on Jan. 12.
Already, this round of furloughs prevented the Commerce Department on Tuesday from issuing its revised estimate of gross domestic product for the third quarter along with a mass of updated historic G.D.P. data and its compilation of housing starts data for November.
These normally would have been factored into deliberations of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's policy-making panel, which met later that day and decided to cut short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point.
The figures were not supplied to the Fed in any form, though economists said they doubted the missing data would have been decisive.
Bob Moore, a Fed spokesman, commented, "I think we have everything we need."
Today, the Commerce Department did not publish as scheduled its compilation of exports and imports for October, a report that often has political as well as economic repercussions. On Thursday, the Labor Department will not issue its weekly tabulation of first-time claims for unemployment insurance, an erratic indicator but also one of the most current.
Department officials said they have fielded scores of inquiries from Wall Street analysts and corporate executives about the delayed figures, which in most cases can be issued within a day or two of a return of furloughed workers.
But beginning next week, the situation becomes more serious, with the labor statistics bureau due, among other things, to start mailing surveys to companies for January's Producer Price Index.
Mr. Ehrlich said that while larger businesses were likely to be able to respond accurately to late inquiries, smaller companies might find this difficult, thereby impairing the integrity of the data.

HEADLINE: Man Gets 10-to-20-Year Term for Raping Wife

 BODY:
Declaring that "there are too many places on this earth where wives are considered chattel," a judge sentenced a Washington Heights man to 10 to 20 years in prison yesterday for beating and raping his estranged wife.
Marital rape convictions are rare, often because women are too afraid to pursue charges or because of societal ambivalence toward their plight -- factors that Justice Franklin R. Weissberg of State Supreme Court in Manhattan alluded to before sentencing 37-year old Jose Santos. 
 "There are far too many places on this earth where the rape, assault and battering of a wife by her husband is considered acceptable, or at worst, a trivial offense," he said. "Unfortunately for this defendant, this state and this courtroom are not such places."
The victim, a 35-year old home-care attendant whose ankle was broken in the May 9 attack in her apartment, was not in court. In statements included in the probation report, she said she had suffered not only physical injuries but also mental trauma because Mr. Santos had invaded the "sanctity" of their marriage.
The woman had testified that Mr. Santos burst into her apartment, threatened her with a knife, choked her and knocked her down. As she fell, her ankle broke.
"Despite her terror and pain, he cold-bloodedly raped her," Justice Weissberg said. "He then kept her prisoner for almost three hours while she begged him to take her to the hospital for treatment."
A jury of seven men and five women deliberated only three and a half hours Dec. 4 before convicting Mr. Santos, an unemployed guitar teacher, who testified that his wife had attacked him with the knife and delayed going for treatment while she dressed and put on makeup.

HEADLINE: Israel and Syria Agree to Renew Peace Talks, Secluded in Maryland Under U.S. Auspices

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Meeting under United States auspices, Israel and Syria will renew their efforts to negotiate a peace agreement in the seclusion of a rural resort in eastern Maryland next week, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today.
The intensive new phase of negotiations, which the two countries agreed to undertake when Mr. Christopher visited the Middle East last weekend, will start next Wednesday at the Wye Plantation on Maryland's Eastern shore, a conference center an hour's drive from Washington. 
 After three days, the negotiators will adjourn over the New Year's holiday and resume again in early January for three more days, allowing the Israeli and Syrian delegations a week's time to return to their respective capitals for consultations. Secretary Christopher will later go back to the Middle East on Jan. 10 for further talks.
"I believe that the environment, the location will make it possible to intensify the talks and create an opportunity for more progress than we've made up to this point," Mr. Christopher told reporters.
The Maryland negotiations invite comparison with the format that the Administration used last month in Dayton, Ohio, in talks that led to the peace agreement on Bosnia. But in Dayton, the heads of state of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia came to work out a peace agreement, but left it to American negotiators to shuttle among them thrashing out the details. At the Wye Plantation, lower-level Syrian and Israeli negotiators will meet face-to-face, but are not expected to achieve an immediate breakthrough.
The talks will be closed to the press, as they were at Dayton.
Mr. Christopher provided details of the talks during a year-end news conference at which he enumerated the Clinton Administration's foreign policy successes this year and spoke of its goals for 1996.
These included persuading the Syrians and Israelis to sit down once more to revive a mutually suspicious dialogue that was suspended six months ago because of continuing disagreement about Israel's withdrawal from the Golan Heights, which Israel wrested from Syria during the 1967 war and has since annexed.
Israel, which made peace with Egypt in 1979, has reached more recent peace accords with Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization. But Syria, the most intransigent neighbor, has long made any peace conditional on Israel's withdrawal from the Golan Heights, a windswept, barren mountain plateau that dominates both northern Israel and southern Syria and provides an important source of water. Syria also exerts hegemony over Lebanon, where Islamic militiamen are left to pursue a mostly ineffectual guerrilla struggle against Israel.
"The circle of peace will not be complete until Israel has peace with Syria and Lebanon," Mr. Christopher said.
In announcing the talks in Jerusalem last Saturday, the Secretary of State said President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel both wanted to make rapid progress toward a peace treaty. But then, as today, Mr. Christopher would not predict when such a treaty might be concluded.
The first formal peace negotiations between Syria and Israel opened in Madrid in 1991, and promptly foundered. Two subsequent attempts over the last year to reopen the talks also failed. But Mr. Assad has shown greater seriousness about reaching an agreement with Mr. Peres, who came to power last month after the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.
But the issue of the Golan Heights continues to appear intractable. Israel has said the "depth" of its withdrawal is contingent on the depth of peace agreed to by Syria, including trade and tourism ties. As a condition of normal relations, Syria insists on the return of the entire heights, including strategic terrain occupied by Israeli surveillance stations.
Mr. Christopher counted among the Clinton Administration's other foreign policy successes the brokering of the peace agreement on Bosnia, the restoration of democracy in Haiti, the unconditional extension of an international treaty preventing the spread of nuclear weapons and the stabilization of the Mexican economy after the peso's collapse a year ago.
He said the Administration could continue pursuing its policy of engagement with China, even though its record on human rights, which included a recent prison sentence for that country's most prominent dissident, Wei Jingsheng, was "not satisfactory to us."
Mr. Christopher played down the resurgence of the Communist Party in Russia's parliamentary elections, saying the results proved that "democracy has taken strong root in Russia." But he expressed the hope that the parties favoring economic reform would unite behind a common candidate for the Russian presidential elections next June.
He also said the Administration that took "a very important step" in freezing North Korea's nuclear program, and that it was "constantly vigilant" about the latest reports of North Korean troop activity.
At a separate news conference, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said that the North Korean military has increased the pace of its regular winter training exercises this year, but that reinforcement of American troops in South Korea was not necessary at this time.
"It's always been on our watch list," Mr. Perry said of North Korea, which has two-thirds of its million-member army within 60 miles of Seoul. "Perhaps it's a little higher now than six months ago. But not high enough to call for extra military deployments."

HEADLINE: New Mexico's Indian Tribes Vow to Defy Move to Close Casinos

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., Dec. 15

 BODY:
Since July, when the New Mexico Supreme Court ruled that the state's Indian-run casinos were operating in defiance of the law, United States Attorney John J. Kelly has been under pressure from legislators and gambling opponents to close the lucrative operations. The Indian tribes, insisting that they have the power of sovereign nations, have refused to stop voluntarily, since gambling has become their economic lifeblood.
So on Thursday, Mr. Kelly announced an ultimatum: By Jan. 15, the 10 tribes operating casinos must shut down or face legal action. 
 Tribal leaders said they were shocked by the edict and would do everything they could to oppose it. They say pacts that they signed with Gov. Gary E. Johnson, and that were approved by the Federal Department of the Interior, give them the right to run the casinos.
The issue, as they see it, is just whose law they are beholden to. The dispute is over how much leverage tribal sovereignty gives the Indian leaders when they come into confrontation with the Federal Government and state governments.
"We're not going to let anyone come onto our reservation and shut us down," said Randy L. Jiron, First Lieutenant Governor of Isleta Pueblo, south of Albuquerque. "If it comes to going to jail or prison or dying on the line, we have to make a stand. Otherwise, we might as well kiss sovereignty goodbye."
Mr. Jiron said gambling revenue was crucial to pay for projects like a proposed $4.8 million building for the pueblo's young people. The casino employs about 600 people, he said, most of them non-Indians.
Mr. Kelly is allowing the casinos to stay open through the holidays, and has said he will not bring law-enforcement officers onto the reservations to enforce the edict. Instead, he said, the Government will begin legal proceedings to force disobedient tribes to forfeit their gambling equipment. He has not said what he will do if they refuse to comply.
In a letter to the tribes on Wednesday, Mr. Kelly raised the possibility that the Legislature would amend the gambling laws soon after its 1996 session opens on Jan. 16, so the shutdown might last only a few days.
In the 10 months since Governor Johnson, a Republican, signed gambling pacts with the tribes, keeping a promise he made in his 1994 campaign, the corridor along the Rio Grande has shown signs of becoming an elongated Las Vegas strip, with pueblos competing to see which one can build the glitziest casino.
The building boom has continued even though the New Mexico Supreme Court ruled in July that the pacts were illegal because the Governor did not consult with the Legislature. Last month the court went further, ruling that state law did not allow casino gambling.
Under the Federal Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988, tribes can negotiate agreements allowing them to offer any form of gambling permitted elsewhere in the state. Since New Mexico has historically allowed charity casino nights along with raffles and bingo games, Mr. Johnson and the tribes used this as justification to allow full-blown, Las Vegas-style casinos on the reservations.
Mr. Kelly has given the tribes until next Friday to respond to his letter. Meanwhile, the tribes and their lawyers are wondering why they were allowed to go for so long, investing millions of dollars in new casinos, and why the United States Attorney could not have waited another month, when the Legislature would again be in session.
"It's senseless," said Mr. Jiron of Isleta Pueblo. "They let us go all this time and gave us all this rein, and all of a sudden they're trying to stop us."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Risks of Cutting Too Far;
Toyota Learns Customers' Limits With the Corolla

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The Toyota Corolla has been Japan's best-selling car for 26 years. So when Toyota introduced a fully remodeled and lower-priced version of the car in May, it expected a big lift in sales.
But sales have been disappointing and Tsutomu Kusaka, a Toyota dealer in Yokohama, thinks he knows why. The new Corolla not only is cheaper than the old one, it also "looks cheaper," he said. Instead of painting the bumpers, Toyota left them black. And "the interior has become much poorer," he said. Toyota heard the complaints and five months after introducing the car, the Corolla was reborn with power windows and locks and nicer seats. 
 The tale of the new Corolla has raised a warning flag for Japan's automobile industry. Faced with a prolonged economic slump at home and a strong yen making it more expensive to export, Japan's car manufacturers are racing to cut costs and lower prices to make their products more competitive.
But as the fate of the Corolla shows, cutting costs too much -- or too obviously -- can backfire, turning consumers off. Indeed, there is a danger that if Japanese companies handle cost-cutting poorly, they could jeopardize their hard-won reputation for superior quality and customer satisfaction.
"That is like walking on the tightrope," Louis R. Hughes, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, said during the Tokyo Motor Show in October. "It's a very fine balance."
The Nissan Motor Company had the same problem as Toyota when it introduced its remodeled subcompact, the Sunny, in 1994 minus some features that had been available in the previous model.
(The equivalent American models have not been greatly affected by the scaling back in Japan. The American Corolla, manufactured in the United States and Canada, is somewhat different from its Japanese counterpart and is not due for a remodeling until 1997. And Nissan's American division left the equipment on the cars it sells as Sentras virtually intact.)
So far, experts agree that cost-cutting by Japanese companies has not led to any visible deterioration in the fundamental quality of the cars, as measured by the number of defects or the frequency of breakdowns.
"The Japanese won't take the risk of hurting their quality image," said Chris W. Cedergren, senior vice president of Autopacific Inc., a consulting company in Santa Ana, Calif. "That's going to have a much more debilitating effect on their business than higher prices."
Rather, the problems of the Corolla and the Nissan Sunny came from the removal of standard features and luxury appointments, including power windows, vanity mirrors, elegant upholstery and the like. In industry jargon, this is called de-contenting, or taking the content out of the car.
Removing standard features is the simplest way to cut costs and prices but is not very effective in the long run. More savings can be gained by designing the car to be less expensive to manufacture, by speeding up development time or by improving assembly line efficiency.
"What we're trying to do is take cost out where the customer doesn't see it," Henry D. G. Wallace, executive vice president of the Mazda Motor Company, said of the cost-cutting efforts his company is making on all of its cars.
Analysts say the new Honda Civic, introduced in September, shows how costs can be cut without hurting customer perceptions of quality or luxury. In Japan, the new Civic is about 5 percent less expensive than the old one. In the United States, because of the effects of the strong yen, the price of the new Civic is about 1.5 percent higher than the old one.
Honda did eliminate some frills. It replaced the rear disk brakes with cheaper and less technically advanced drum brakes. And, it used fewer threads in the fabric on the back seat.
But Honda got much of its savings by lowering development costs and using more American materials. It also designed the new Civic with an improved, quieter engine and more interior space, so critics said that over all the new model was better than the old one.
Toyota is normally a master of this kind of hidden cost-cutting. In its 1994 annual report, it boasted how it had trimmed overall costs by $1.5 billion in a single year. It used more common parts and fewer model variations, and reduced excessively complicated automation in its factories.
Both Japanese and American executives agree that Japanese cars have been built with excessive quality and luxury. Places would be painted that no one could see. Some of the fabrics used even on economy cars "were so high cost we would shake our heads," said one American auto executive who asked not to be identified.
But the changes on the Corolla were apparently too visible. Since the model change, sales of the Corolla sedan and coupe together have been averaging about 15,000 a month, below Toyota's target of 17,500. The shortfall has contributed to a decline in Toyota's market share in Japan this year to below 40 percent, from about 42 percent in the past couple of years.
This is the second slip-up for Toyota with what is supposed to be its "people's car." The previous Corolla, introduced in 1991, turned out to be too luxurious and expensive for people's tastes.
That Corolla had been designed during the "bubble economy" of the late 1980's when soaring land and stock prices made people feel extravagant. But the bubble burst just as the new Corolla reached the market.
So in designing the new Corolla, Toyota hoped to adapt to a new consumer frugality. The base price was reduced to under 1 million yen, or $10,000, a decline of about $1,000 from the older model.
Still, it appears that once consumers get used to things, even excessive quality or features, they notice when they are taken away.
"The interior design ranked down a bit," said Norio Shibata, a 58-year-old engineer who bought a Corolla in 1992 but decided on a Nissan Sunny this August. "The material they used for the inside of the door looked obviously plastic." However, Mr. Shibata said it was mainly a matter of engine horsepower that made him switch to a Nissan.
Bob Sliwa, a Japan-based automobile writer, said the doors of the new Corolla rattle when they are shut. And while Toyota put in a simplified engine that gets better mileage, "simplifying the engine makes it less smooth," he said.
Other features of the older Corolla are also missing. In one model, the AM-FM stereo radio was replaced by an AM monoaural radio. In another model, the self-adjusting air-conditioner was replaced by a manually controlled model. Instead of full fabric seats, some versions of the new Corolla had seats made partly of vinyl.
Akihiro Wada, executive vice president of Toyota, said the sales problem of the Corolla was not from cost-cutting per se. "It was a mis-design, to tell you the truth," he said, indicating the new design was simply not pleasing to customers. He added that other Toyota models, the luxury Crown for example, were selling well despite similar cost cuts.
He and other Toyota executives said the new Corolla offered better mileage and a roomier interior than the old one. Much of the cost reduction in the Corolla, they argue, came from reducing the number of parts by about 25 percent, not from removing content.
Another factor in the disappointing sales, company executives said, is that Japanese consumers are turning away from sedans like the Corolla toward mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles.
Still, in October, only five months after introducing the new Corolla, Toyota added some standard features. These included a driver-side air bag, full-fabric seats, power windows and automatic door locks. The base price of the car was raised 49,000 yen, or about $490, to 1.04 million yen, or $10,400. It is still too early to tell whether the changes will make a difference.
Nissan had a similar problem with its Sunny. "We made a mistake in the Sunny," said Tadao Takei, executive vice president of Nissan.
The new Sunny was introduced in Japan in January 1994. It, too, had a manual air-conditioner instead of a self-adjusting one and manual windows. The rear of the car had a rounded look that, it turned out, did not appeal to consumers.
Sales quickly fell more than 20 percent below the levels of a year earlier. By May 1994, Nissan restored the power windows and self-adjusting air-conditioner as standard features, without raising the price.
This September, somewhat early for a midterm face lift, Nissan rushed out a new Sunny with a square rear for a "grander, more orthodox look," according to Nissan's news release.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Fall on Snag Over Budget

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury prices gave up their early gains yesterday, as the bond market was weakened by a poorly received Treasury auction and yet another setback in Washington budget talks.
By the end of the day, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped 9/32 of a percentage point; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, edged up to 6.12 percent, from 6.11 percent on Tuesday. 
 The 30-year bond initially posted moderate gains as investor enthusiasm lingered from Tuesday's market rally that was set off by the surprise interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve.
But prices retreated in the afternoon. Adding pressure to prices was a drive by brokers to sell securities and thus push down their prices ahead of the Government's afternoon auction of two-year notes. The hope was to draw more investors to the auction by wooing them with cheaper prices.
But even at the lower prices, the auction failed to attract a big turnout. The Government sold $18.25 billion in two-year notes at a yield of 5.29 percent. That was more than market expectations of about 5.26 percent, suggesting that weak demand gave investors leeway to demand higher rates.
Demonstrating the poor turnout, the bid-to-cover ratio, which compares the number of bids submitted with those accepted, was 2.18 to 1, weaker than the average of recent two-year note sales.
The soft auction results helped drive down prices in the broader secondary market, where newly auctioned securities are traded.
Elsewhere in the market, prices of short-term Treasury securities fell 4/32 of a point, and intermediate maturities ranged from 3/32 to 5/32 of a point lower.
Analysts said market prices also were hurt by news of a collapse in Washington budget talks as a meeting between President Clinton and top Republican leaders was scuttled.
Republicans and White House officials had Mr. Clinton would meet again with the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, and and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, to discuss terms for ending the partial Government shutdown.
But the President strongly rejected a Republican demand to keep the Government partly closed until a balanced-budget agreement is reached.
"The headlines coming out of Washington that budget talks are not going anywhere gave a good excuse to sell prior to the auction," said Kathleen Stephansen, senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "But it turns out the auction didn't go well."
Investors and traders in fixed-income securities fear that the breakdown in negotiations endangers chances for a balanced-budget agreement. Prospects for such a deal have helped fuel a powerful market rally in recent months.
"People are getting jittery about that," Ms. Stephansen said.
The Lehman Brothers daily Treasury bond index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.79 points, to 1,284.62.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 119 15/16 , up 1 1/8 points from late Tuesday. The average yield to maturity was 5.68 percent, down from 6.75 percent.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Homesick for Communisim

BYLINE: By PHILIP TAUBMAN 

 BODY:
Many Russians, to rephrase Winston Churchill, apparently believe that Communism is the worst form of government except for all the other forms.
That seems astonishing, especially to an American who lived in Moscow in the last years of the Soviet Union. After enduring all those endless lines in the Arctic winter to buy a stunted head of cabbage, after quietly suffering all the grandiloquent nonsense about Lenin's ideals and studying Marxism-Leninism until the mind went numb, after watching your country sink into an economic and political stupor, how could someone vote for the Communist Party? 
 Millions of Russians did in Sunday's parliamentary election, raising the Communist Party from the dead and making it the most powerful political organization in Russia. The resurrection is disturbing, yet at the same time intriguing.
In one sense, the vote seems to be the political version of the Stockholm syndrome, the phenomenon common in hostage cases when terrorized victims begin to identify with their captors. Russia is still recovering from more than seven decades of Soviet tyranny, and many Russians apparently still identify more closely with the dictators who controlled their lives than with the democrats who freed them.
But something else seems to be at work. Many Russians, particularly the elderly and those still living in rural areas, appear genuinely nostalgic for the security blanket that came with Communism. For all the terrible pain it inflicted, and the millions of lives it destroyed, Soviet Communism provided a crude safety net that gave citizens the illusion that the Communist Party was looking after their interests. The development of a free market has ripped away the net.
The Communist system was suffocating, patronizing and calculated to keep the country obedient. Some Russians recognized it as a narcotic, and fought to overcome it. The internal security forces were always there to silence them. Most Russians chose not to take that risk, or ceased to care what the purpose of the system was as long as bread was cheap, jobs were plentiful, education was universal, health care was free and vacations were subsidized. The bread was excellent, but many people now seem to have forgotten that lots of the jobs were pointless, education was politically contaminated, health care was atrocious and Soviet vacations were Spartan.
The whole enterprise was ideologically dressed up as a workers' paradise. Though some Russians were true believers, most were smart enough to see through the pseudo-science. But the system still enveloped them.
Now that people have had a taste of unemployment, inflation, crime and other problems that have come with democracy, it is shrewd politics for the new Communists to suggest that the old days were actually pretty good. The party, at least for now, has distanced itself from the most brazen practices of the past, including one-party politics, censorship and repression of dissent.
The reporting and the polling data from Russia show the Communists gained from discontent about an uneven economy and upheaval in Russian life. Voters in Moscow, St. Petersburg and some other urban centers -- where the benefits of reform have materialized most quickly -- voted for reform candidates. Nearly everywhere else, Communists and nationalists did well, singing from essentially the same page of promises about restoring order and economic stability, shorthand for the Communist safety net.
Reform in Russia is far from dead, but it has run into a formidable obstacle -- the past. To prevail in the months and years ahead, the reformers will have to convince millions of their countrymen that the uncertainty of freedom is preferable to the security of Communism, as deadening as it was. PHILIP TAUBMAN

HEADLINE: Make a Budget Deal Now

 BODY:
As budget talks floundered in Washington yesterday, President Clinton angrily blamed the band of fire-breathing conservative Republican freshmen in the House for preventing Speaker Newt Gingrich from negotiating seriously. The President was not wrong in his assessment, but he was not wholly right either. The negotiations are at an impasse at least as much because Mr. Clinton has not shown his own hand on where he wants the budget to go. With a substantial part of the Government still shut down in the week before Christmas, both sides need to take the process more seriously and make concessions to get things going.
The budget talks come at an extremely fluid time on both sides of the aisle. On the Republican side, the first signs of disagreement are emerging between Speaker Gingrich and Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader. After the first budget shutdown of a few weeks ago, Mr. Dole was not the only one to recognize that it was the Republicans, not Mr. Clinton, who got the public's blame for intransigence. He has made it clear that he did not agree with keeping the Government shuttered in this second round. The President slyly went out of his way yesterday to drive a wedge into the G.O.P. camp by praising Mr. Dole for making a good-faith effort to negotiate, as opposed to Mr. Gingrich. 
 But on the Democratic side, the divisions are even deeper. Many liberal Democrats were dismayed when Mr. Clinton boxed himself in last month by promising to balance the budget according to Congressional scorekeeping. They feared that in order to get a deal, he would scrap key parts of his agenda, including programs that protect poor children. But if Mr. Clinton refuses to move toward the Republicans, he risks losing the support of dozens of moderate and conservative Democrats. Among these is a group of lawmakers calling themselves the Blue Dogs, a parody of the old term "yellow dog Democrats," whose party loyalty was so great that they would vote for a yellow dog over a Republican. Right now it is the conservative and moderate Democrats and some moderate Republicans in the House and Senate who are waiting for Mr. Clinton to sit at the table and deal.
In face-to-face negotiations with Republican leaders, Mr. Clinton has been stalling. He effectively reneged on his promise to show how he would balance a budget in seven years, using the more conservative economic assumptions of the Congressional Budget Office. In fact, his plan fell at least $300 billion short. Tactically, it may have been shrewd of him to hold back. The public opinion polls show that the White House has captured the high ground politically, with growing numbers of Americans viewing the President as resolute in protecting programs that help children, the poor and the elderly. But now Mr. Clinton should move. He should seize on some of the ideas of the centrists and try to forge a unified Democratic position that modifies the White House's original proposals.
Specifically, Mr. Clinton should continue to demand that the Republicans modify their cuts, preserving federally guaranteed Medicaid, food stamps and nutrition programs. In exchange he should radically scale back, if not drop, his proposed middle-class tax cut. The blue dogs favor no tax cut at all until the budget is balanced, a position that might give the President some cover if he moves toward it. Mr. Clinton would also move the talks along by signaling a willingness to raise the heavily subsidized premiums that the elderly pay for Medicare. Republican leaders have gone first on this proposal, and it has won some support among the moderate Democrats.
The deal that could emerge from this process is probably not one that liberals would swallow. Nor is it one that the cadre of true believers breathing down Mr. Gingrich's neck would accept. But with the right mix of concessions and demands, Mr. Clinton might be able to break the current impasse, get a better deal than he could get from endless delays and preserve a broad set of principles on which he can run for re-election.

HEADLINE: Take This Job. Please.

BYLINE: By Warren B. Rudman; Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican, is the author of the forthcoming "Combat: 12 Years in the United States Senate."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The voluntary retirement of 12 senators at the end of this term, including the exceptionally able Sam Nunn of Georgia, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, Alan Simpson of Wyoming and David Pryor of Arkansas, has caused speculation and distress.
These are people at the top of their game -- people who were likely to be re-elected. How could they walk away from the power and prestige of a Senate seat? Consider a typical day for a typical senator, based on my experience and that of colleagues. 
 6 A.M. You head to Capitol Hill for breakfast with constituents. You find they have been shocked by an editorial that morning in the largest paper in your state. It accuses you of driving the children of America into the arms of atheism. Why? Because your view of the Constitution obliged you to vote against a bill to require prayer in the public schools.
8 A.M. You discuss the day's agenda with the staff. An aide brings in hundreds of letters that arrived yesterday. You read as many as time permits, then dictate the message you want conveyed to constituents' various concerns.
9 A.M. You have three committee hearings going on simultaneously, and you attend parts of all three, knowing you are spread too thin. Your press secretary slips you a note: 20 reporters have called about your criticism of the President last night. You return some of the calls between hearings.
12 P.M. Your state party chairman calls to say that a handsome golf pro who recently married a very rich woman has decided he wants to be a senator. You think you can defeat him, but will have to raise $10 million in the next two years, instead of $5 million for a normal race.
12:15 P.M. You take prominent businessmen from your state to lunch in the Senate dining room. They agree on the urgency of a balanced budget -- of course, only if it does not mean higher taxes or reduced benefits for them. You pick up the tab.
1 P.M. to 6 P.M. Bells start calling you to votes on the Senate floor. They ring all afternoon. Many are on amendments relating to abortion, flag-burning, pornography and school prayer. None will pass, but their sponsors are eager to make statements for the papers back home. New senators, the ones obsessed with protecting the flag, don't seem equally concerned about protecting the economy. The number of votes, in committee and on the floor, has nearly doubled since 1980, when I entered the Senate.
You go to your party's campaign office (on the Hill) and get a list of people to ask for money. You have to call from there: it's illegal to call from your office. You hate asking strangers for money, but you have the golf pro to worry about.
6 P.M. You attend fund-raisers for two colleagues. Several people call you Gramm because you co-sponsored the Gramm-Rudman Balanced Budget Act. One fellow says, "Gramm, are you really in favor of atheism?" You choke down peanuts and two small sausages for dinner.
8 P.M. You are back on the Senate floor for debate on major budget amendments. The mood is angry, people are bitter, ideologues on both sides reject compromise. Some people won't speak to each other.
1 A.M. The majority leader gives up and adjourns. Late nights have become the rule. You wonder if you'll be able to leave the next afternoon to spend the weekend in your home state. It will be filled with meetings with constituents, fund-raising, town meetings and press conferences.
1:30 A.M. You're home. The family is sleeping. You ask yourself, "Who needs this?"
I have long opposed term limits. For one thing, life in the Senate will increasingly result in self-imposed term limits. When you look at life there, the rush for the exits isn't surprising. I left in 1992. I am 65 years old. I felt 75 in the Senate. I feel 35 now.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens After Clinton Cancels Meeting on the Budget

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against most leading currencies yesterday after budget negotiations between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans crumbled late in the day.
Efforts to rejuvenate the budget talks fell through when the White House dropped plans for the second meeting in two days of President Clinton and top House and Senate G.O.P. leaders. Optimism had risen following Tuesday's meeting that the two sides would resolve the impasse. 
 Stock and bond prices, which had been higher earlier yesterday, turned tail and sank after the talks collapsed. The dollar followed as investors looked to other currencies for more lucrative investments.
"That tipped the dollar down a little bit toward the end of the day, but it wasn't a massive selloff, just a little bit of a drift-off," said David Glowacki, senior trader at the NBD Bank in Detroit.
Trading was light, exaggerating moves in the dollar. "We're really in the holiday trading mode," Mr. Glowacki said.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.4400 German marks, down from 1.4410 marks late Tuesday. The dollar also slipped to 101.90 yen, down from 101.96. The British pound was quoted at $1.5360, down from $1.5415 on Tuesday.
The Mexican peso gained sharply against the dollar as traders continued to react to the Federal Reserve Board's decision on Tuesday to cut a key interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point.
The cut improved the peso as an investment vehicle vs. the dollar, pushing the dollar to 7.52 pesos vs. 7.63 on Tuesday. The interest rate decline did not affect the dollar significantly against European currencies because central banks there have also cut interest rates recently.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.1545 Swiss francs, down from 1.1565; 4.9415 French francs, down from 4.9555; 1,594 Italian lire, down from 1,595, and 1.3669 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3754.
