HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE;
Michael Jackson's Sound of Silence

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
The latest chapter in the Michael Jackson tale ended last week when doctors advised him to take the rest of the year off after his collapse during a rehearsal at the Beacon Theater on Dec. 6 for an HBO concert special. (Mr. Jackson, 37, was taken to Beth Israel Medical Center North and found to have a gastrointestinal ailment; he is recuperating at EuroDisney.) This is a medical-related withdrawal reminiscent of the one that caused him to cut short his last tour, in 1993, to seek treatment for an addiction to prescription painkillers. Both times there was widespread speculation on the truth about Mr. Jackson's medical problems. Their seriousness aside, these ailments have resulted in Mr. Jackson's retreat from singing into silence.
On Dec. 4, two days before he collapsed, Mr. Jackson tried to promote the HBO special with a news conference at the Beacon. The many members of the news media in attendance begged him for a comment. Their attempts ranged from the cold-hearted ("Are you still married?" one person yelled out) to the harmless ("Say hello!" shouted another). All questions received the same response: silence. 
 Instead of speaking, Mr. Jackson brought out the special guest who was to join him during the concert. His guest was not a musician but a mime, Marcel Marceau. The two clowned around together onstage, with Mr. Jackson imitating the old mime routine of being trapped in an invisible box, an apt metaphor for his life off the stage.
This pairing was a perfect one, because Mr. Jackson seems to be transforming himself into a mime. He likes to whiten his face, as mimes do. (After Mr. Jackson's collapse, a medical technician said there was so much makeup on his face that medics had to lift his shirt to check his complexion.) But more significant, the axis of Mr. Jackson's career has been turning away from his singing and toward his body.
As the lead singer of the Jackson 5 in the 1960's and 70's, it was his astonishing young voice that commanded attention; in the 80's, he shifted the spotlight to his feet and his style with the moonwalk, the choreography of "Thriller" and other video spectacles. In the 1990's, the focus has been on other anatomical parts as talk of plastic surgery and allegations of child molestation have hounded him.
Mr. Jackson's reaction to the news media circus around him has been one of silence, of retreating deeper into Neverland, as he calls his California ranch. Two summers ago, he answered those who doubted his heterosexuality by marrying Lisa Marie Presley. Last year, he responded to those who still doubted his heterosexuality by kissing his wife on the MTV Music Awards. These are the noiseless moves of a mime.
On the few occasions when Mr. Jackson did break his silence, it was to ask for quiet. The two interviews he granted in the last year were to extinguish scandal, not to talk about his music. And most of the new songs on "HIStory" are pleas for silence, directed at the news media ("Scream" and "Tabloid Junkie") and at those who would destroy the world ("Earth Song" and "Money"). The album closes with a tribute to a fellow mime, "Smile," with music composed by Charlie Chaplin for his film "Modern Times."
Unlike Mr. Chaplin and Mr. Marceau, Mr. Jackson's pantomime never ends; he can no longer remove his painted face. If it is a mime's silence that Mr. Jackson seeks, it is so he can experience the childhood freedom and irresponsibility that a lifetime in the public eye has never allowed. "Michael has the soul of a mime," Mr. Marceau said in an interview after their news conference.
The soul of a mime is a complex one, part child and part artist, part clown and part tragic figure. "I've seen Michael on TV for years, and I think that he is a poet," Mr. Marceau said. "But now he is in the tradition of French poets like Verlaine and Rimbaud because his subject is the lost childhood."

 
 
A Romantic, Darkly
 When asked whether he thinks any of his European solo albums will be released on an American label, Scott Walker just laughs and says "no chance." He's being a little pessimistic, and that is in line with his reputation as a dark and morbid romantic.
Mr. Walker, 51, was born in Ohio, and moved to England in the mid-1960's to seek glory with his beautiful baritone in the Walker Brothers, a band that achieved superstar status there with hits like "The Sun Ain't Gonna Shine (Anymore)." But the pop machine soon wore Mr. Walker down. A singing idol on the surface, he longed for privacy and to be taken seriously as a songwriter. In the solo albums he has released since the group broke up in 1968, he has slowly turned from crooning pop to brooding French chansons to minimal art songs, growing more morbid, cerebral and intense with each new record and influencing such musicians as David Bowie, Elvis Costello and Julian Cope.
"You use whatever comes up," Mr. Walker said of his dark side, speaking by telephone from London. "And that side flows for me more than another side does. Unlike other artists, I don't have a constant dark side, and I don't think I had it when I lived in America. You don't have time to develop it much in America, unless you experience something really extreme, because the speed of life there is just too fast."
In England, life moves a little slower for Mr. Walker. This year, he released his first album in 11 years, "Tilt" (Fontana/Mercury U.K.), with sparse, orchestrated pieces sung in the upper register of Mr. Walker's voice. Its lyrics are slippery and complex, ranging from quotes from the trial of Adolf Eichmann to a soliloquy to the corpse of Che Guevara. Mr. Walker demands a lot of his listeners. "I had to work at the lyrics, so they should too," he said.
"In the studio I was trying to find things that weren't related to anything anyone had heard before," he said of the music. "I picked a group of musicians very carefully so that we could make a song that related to the lyrics. We worked as economically as possible, using no frilly or superfluous sounds. I let the words create each track for me."
Mr. Walker let a decade elapse before recording "Tilt" because he could not find a record company that would agree to release his music without making him submit a demo tape. Mr. Walker says he believes that the first time he sings a song is the truest and most representative version.
"I have a terror of singing," he said. "That's one of the reasons I don't perform. I want to do my vocals as quickly as possible, because that's going to be the one that's closest to the vocals in my dreams. If I get it wrong when I try it, it drives me insane. I even had an arrangement with the studio so that I could call up on the day I felt like singing it and go in."
"I don't even own any of my own records, and I would never listen to them," he continued. "They would drive me crazy. They drive other people crazy, but not for the same reason."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
The Joys of the Flat Tax, Excluding the Equations

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
About halfway through tomorrow night's "Firing Line" debate on a flat tax, Jerry Brown says, "What we have here is a real muddy discussion."
That's not exactly the problem, since the two-hour give-and-get does clarify the motives of both proponents and opponents, but the encounter is disjointed and at times perplexing. 
 "It is absolutely true," says a proponent. "It is factually untrue," counters an opponent. "I think that's factually wrong," says an opponent. "It's factually correct," responds a proponent. "I did my math right," says a proponent. "You didn't do your math right," says an opponent. At one point in a discussion of interest income, one of the experts says, "Oh, excuse me, I think I got it backward." Viewers may find themselves calling their accountants.
The presence of Mr. Brown among those who favor the evening's proposition, "Resolved: The flat tax is better than the income tax," complicates matters. His three presumed allies -- William F. Buckley Jr., our host; Pete Du Pont, a former Governor of Delaware, and Dr. John Goodman, president of the National Center for Policy Analysis, a conservative think tank -- extol a bill being offered by Richard K. Armey, the House majority leader.
Mr. Goodman displays a blown-up postcard to show how simple the tax return would be without the mountain of I.R.S. provisions that only lawyers and accountants can climb. Even more appealing to the yeasayers is the prospect that by charging the same rate on all levels of income and easing the bite on the well-to-do, a flatter tax would encourage individual enterprise and national growth.
For his part, Mr. Brown is not wild about the Armey bill, which would spare recipients the reporting of income from dividends, interest and capital gains on the ground that corporations have already paid taxes on them. Showing less hair than when he was Governor of California and having exchanged tie and coat for a populist denim shirt over a black T-shirt, Mr. Brown favors the idea of a flat tax because, he maintains, it would do away with the fat-cat lobbying of a contribution-hungry Congress. For him, anything would be better than the present "banquet feast of corruption."
Opposing Mr. Brown but joining him in the principle that the well-to-do ought to pay a bigger percentage of their income than the less fortunate or enterprising are Lester Thurow, a professor of economics at M.I.T.; George McGovern, who ran for President when the country was still young; Dr. Steven C. Mann, a professor at Texas Christian University, where the debate is held, and Robert Kuttner, a prolific writer on economic matters. "The more you get out, the more you ought to pay," says Professor Thurow. The antis predict that if dividends and interest are exempted, corporation biggies will promptly begin taking their salaries in stocks and bonds.
However, their defense of progressivity has its limits; with varying degrees of enthusiasm, they would retain deductions for health, mortgage payments and charitable contributions, which also favor the well-to-do and which friends of the flat tax would abolish. But the progressives would put a cap on the deductions so that the very, very rich wouldn't get away with too much.
Mr. Buckley scorns such hedging and celebrates the joys of unprogressive taxation, which would treat all Americans, rich and poor, equally. In a giddy flight, he acclaims Picasso, that un-American Communist, as an exemplar of talent that should be unconstrained.
I cannot promise that these two hours will enable you to decide whether a flat tax would be boon or boondoggle or just not worth worrying about, but credit "Firing Line" for even taking on so unsexy a subject. And keep in mind, for the moment you are still entitled to a tax deduction for contributions to public broadcasting.

FIRING LINE
Flat Tax

(Channel 13 in New York)

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Dr. Ruth Westheimer;
The Bible as Sex Manual?

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
MENORAHS always make Ruth Westheimer a little sad.
Hanukkah of 1938 was the last Jewish holiday she spent with her Orthodox family in Frankfurt before she was sent off at age 10 to the safety of a Swiss orphanage. Her parents and all her relatives died in concentration camps. 
 Last Sunday, Dr. Westheimer, known, of course, as Dr. Ruth, the outspoken sexologist, was sitting in the cluttered three-bedroom apartment in Washington Heights where she raised her two children and became famous, in that order. The sky was going pink over the Hudson River. A Steuben glass menorah was on the table. Hanukkah would be starting in an hour.
"Yes, for me Hanukkah is very sad," she said. "But the life force that's in me makes it a wonderful holiday, too."
Along with the clutter in her very lived-in living room, menorahs and other Jewish objects were everywhere.
"I believe my soul isn't entirely German," she said, serving some brownies she didn't make (she doesn't cook -- later she would order in Chinese food for dinner), "because my home is so disorderly. All my German friends here keep very neat homes." Fortunately, her husband, Fred (Freddy to her), is also disorganized. "If one of us would be very neat, that would be very bad," she said. "And I like all this stuff. I like the doll houses friends give me. I like all my little tchotchkies and fancy stuff from Switzerland and China. It's nice to be Dr. Ruth and have nice things, even if my Chagall is just a $150 reproduction."
She poured coffee. Her shoes (size 4) clicked across the kitchenette. "Dr. Ruth could live on Park Avenue," she said, finally sitting down with a copy of "Heavenly Sex: Sexuality in the Jewish Tradition," her latest book.
"I come from Nazi Germany," she said. "And the one thing I've learned is that you must stand up for what you believe. That's why I wrote this book.
"I hope that Jews and non-Jews alike, anybody interested in family life and the idea of 'shalom bayit,' or 'peace in the home,' will want to read it."
"For years," she continued, "I wondered why I could talk about the things I talk about so openly. Now I know. For us Jews, sex was never a sin."
Dr. Westheimer, who commands hefty lecture fees, teaches at New York University, has 13 books in print (here and abroad), is the host of a series of Playboy instructional videos called "Making Love" and writes a column distributed by the King Features Syndicate.
She has not moved to Park Avenue, she explained, because her synagogues (she belongs to two) and Y.M.H.A. (she's been president for three years) are in the neighborhood, a still sizable community of German Jewish World War II refugees.
"Because of my experience with the Holocaust," she said, "I don't like to lose friends. And I think I have a pretty good life here. Look at the size of this!" She stopped at a big box containing a castle for her grandson.
"Yesterday, I ordered it from a small store on Madison Avenue and had it delivered," she said. "It's nice to call, and on the same day -- boom -- it comes! When my own kids were growing up, I couldn't afford this." Her son and daughter, both with doctorates in education like their mother, live in New York.
"I'm a very lucky mother," she said. "And it's not that I didn't shout enough either."
P EACE in the home, according to the tradition-oriented "Heavenly Sex" (written with Jonathan Mark and published by New York University Press), comes in large part from good sexual relations. "The great rabbi Simeon ben-Halafta called the penis the great peacemaker of the home," she writes in the book.
Not the sort of thing that sits well with everybody.
For instance, Rabbi Robert Hirt, the vice president of Yeshiva University's affiliated Orthodox theological seminary, who has not read the book, said: "The flaunting of intimate things in a public way takes away from their intimacy. Judaism has a tradition of tzniut, meaning modesty or appropriateness."
Dr. Westheimer (whose Upper East Side practice attracts some Orthodox and Hasidic clients) doesn't want the book to offend. "The very Orthodox won't read it," she said. "They don't read secular books. And there will be people who will tell their students not to touch this book because it's so explicit. It touches on issues of homosexuality, abortion and the Song of Songs as sexually arousing. But there are also many issues we did not touch."
Still, in less than 200 pages "Heavenly Sex" manages to find in the Torah, Talmud and other religious sources some very explicit passages to support the book's thesis that "God is the ultimate sex therapist" and that the Bible is the "wisest guide to sex ever written." Among other things, it cites the Book of Ruth as an encouragement for single women to initiate sex, providing the relationship leads to marriage.
And that's not all. She includes a Talmudic specification that an unemployed man must make love to his wife every day and the writings of a 12th-century rabbi who suggests couples use different positions while having sex.
"Judaism," the book contends, as it covers everything from Adam and Eve to Onan and a husband's responsibility for his wife's sexual pleasure, "is a tradition that appreciates the weakness of the heart."
Recently, Dr. Westheimer (who speaks every year to the graduating class at the Jewish Theological Seminary) was a guest on CNN, where she said that Prince Charles should have kept his mouth shut about his unhappiness with the Princess of Wales. "If they were Orthodox Jews, he could not have said publicly that he never cared for her," she said as she cleared the table. "And you know what else? He could have given her a divorce decree."
Dr. Westheimer does not shy away from divorce. After all, it took two before she hit gold with her present marriage, which has lasted 34 years. "He's an engineer and very quiet," she said. She and the German-born Mr. Westheimer met on a ski tow in the Catskills -- he was short enough to share it without knocking her off. "This household could not have two people in it like me," she added.
Suddenly, things got very noisy and nonsexual. "Ari!" she yelled to her 5-year-old grandson, who came in with her husband. In a flurry, the two of them lighted one menorah and packed another to take to her Reform synagogue for a community lighting ceremony.
"They're all German Jews there," Dr. Westheimer said. "They always start right on the dot." She and her husband, their grandson and Mr. Mark, her co-author of "Heavenly Sex" and an editor at Jewish Week magazine, made a commotion in the lobby as they greeted the doorman and an old friend in a housecoat who wanted to know which bulb to light on the lobby's menorah.
"Is it left or right?" she asked.
"Yes!" Dr. Westheimer said, bolting out into the cold night.
"Do you have the menorah?" Mr. Westheimer yelled.
"Yes, I've got it, Freddy," yelled his wife, who was already ahead of him on the sidewalk, clutching her grandson in one hand and a little Bloomingdale's bag in the other.
"It's a good thing we're both fast walkers," Mr. Westheimer muttered cheerfully as Dr. Westheimer, who wasn't even wearing an overcoat, raced some of the five blocks to the the Hebrew Tabernacle of Washington Heights, where she waved hello to some dignified elderly friends and marched straight to the front of the synagogue.
"There are so many kids here," Dr. Westheimer said, adding: "It's like a miracle to see all these grandchildren of Holocaust survivors! Hitler didn't intend for us to have any grandchildren."
When it came time for her to help her grandson light their menorah, her face glowed almost as brightly as the candle flames.
Later, she pointed to a stained-glass window she gave in memory of her family, and read aloud the Hebrew on it. "It means 'I don't want to die,' " she said. " 'I want to live.' "
After a riot of kisses, she was out the door, tearing up the street with her rambunctious grandson and pointing out menorahs in windows.
"Hold this," she said to her husband, pushing her shopping bag at him. "I have to run with him."
She did.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Authority Bond Rating Drops

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
The day after the New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced a three-year cost-cutting plan to avert a toll increase through 1998, Moody's Investors Service yesterday downgraded the authority's bond rating a notch from A -- the third best -- to Baa1. 
 Moody's said the authority's plan lacked "immediate measures" to insure a balanced budget in the absence of a toll increase. It also chastised the authority for using nonrecurring revenue sources like surplus construction funds to pay operating costs. The downgrade could mean higher interest rates for the authority. Edward Gross, acting executive director of the authority, called the move "unjustified."

HEADLINE: Racism That Led to Harlem Tragedy Must Not Be Ignored;
Economics Isn't Excuse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Attempts to downplay the evils of racism by citing economic factors and motives can be heard regarding the tragedy on 125th Street in Harlem, but also about every other horrific and genocidal course of racist conduct from the institution of slavery to the Holocaust. 
 "Economics" is still used as a justification for excluding blacks from white neighborhoods ("they'll bring our property values down"), and for anti-Asian bigotry ("they're taking all our jobs away").
Many people seem relieved when they hear that a particularly repulsive racist act can be explained away by pointing to economic factors. Why?
Racism is a moral evil, not a rational economic reaction. Racists are not "persons disabled by economic pressures" (to coin a politically correct term); they are evil people who do incredible harm to others.
At a time of economic stress and increasing racial tensions, we should not permit economic factors to mute our outrage at racist activity.
 
MICHAEL J. GORMAN
Whitestone, Queens, Dec. 13, 1995

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Still Drained By Snapple, Quaker Sees A Big Charge

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Still bleeding from its acquisition last year of Snapple, the Quaker Oats Company warned Wall Street today that earnings in the quarter ending Dec. 31 would fall short of expectations. Quaker also announced plans for a $40 million pretax charge against earnings in the quarter, mostly to cover the cost of getting rid of overcapacity in Snapple's bottling operations.
Shareholders were apparently more disappointed than shocked. Quaker's shares slumped 75 cents, to $34.875, in trading on the Big Board. Analysts said a steeper decline had been prevented as the result of buying by investors who saw Quaker as a takeover candidate. 
 "For takeover players, bad news is good news," said John McMillin, who follows Quaker for Prudential Bache Securities.
Snapple, the tea and fruit-beverage company Quaker bought last December for $1.7 billion, is operating at a pace that suggests it will pile up losses of about $55 million in the quarter, the result of weak sales and the cost of junking inventories that do not have the new labels and packaging Snapple will introduce next year. The loss marks the end of a disastrous year in which Snapple lost $75 million as revenue fell more than 10 percent.
"The bottom line is that Snapple has not sold well in Peoria," Mr. McMillin said. "Although Quaker's strategy was to make it a national and then a global product, it remains an East Coast-West Coast yuppie brand."
Analysts said the problem with the takeover talk was that it was hard to see who would be interested in buying a food company as big as Quaker Oats. The most frequently mentioned possibilities have been Cadbury Schweppes and Nestle, but there have been no indications that either of those European-based companies is eager to make such a deal. At its current stock price, Quaker is valued at almost $4.7 billion.
Because of Snapple's rocky start, it will take Quaker years to recoup its investment, even if in the future Snapple grows as robustly as Quaker projected when it made the deal. After buying Snapple, Quaker spoke of the company's achieving "annual earnings growth of at least 10 percent after inflation."
Most of the $40 million restructuring charge will go toward freeing Quaker from production agreements that Snapple signed with bottlers before Quaker acquired it. Those contracts were signed in anticipation that Snapple would continue to grow rapidly.
About $10 million of the charge will go toward two problem regions for Quaker: Europe and the Pacific Rim. The company has invested heavily in Europe over the last decade with limited results, as it tried to make its Gatorade sports beverages a global brand. And in the Pacific region, Quaker is trying to build up its food businesses.
Quaker, which is based in Chicago, said that the restructuring would save $15 million annually in future years. It will lead to a reported loss for the current quarter as high as $60 million, rather than a profit just under $7 million, or 5 cents a share, as Wall Street had expected in earnings to be released in February.
Some analysts doubted that the restructuring and inventory charges represented a clearing of the decks that marked Snapple's low point. The moves were the first announced since William D. Smithburg, Quaker's chairman and chief executive, became more closely involved, after the departure in October of Philip Marineau, formerly the president and chief operating officer.
"I think it's just another piece of bad news coming on the installment plan," said David Rabinowitz, who follows the company for Smith Barney.
The changes announced will not overcome the distribution and marketing disadvantages Quaker faces in competing with Coca-Cola and Pepsico, Mr. Rabinowitz said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ebbs vs. Mark and Yen; Traders Await Budget Progress

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
As Washington continued to dither over the Federal budget yesterday, the dollar continued to waver in foreign-exchange markets before finishing lower against other leading currencies.
The dollar started the day stronger as hopes rose for a resumption of stalled negotiations between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans over a plan to balance the budget in seven years. 
 As the day wore on, and no firm strategy emerged to revive the talks, the currency weakened, finishing slightly lower against the German mark and the Japanese yen.
"People still expect a deal," said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics in New York. "I think there's no two ways around that, but the question is: When exactly is it going to get done? As time drags on and they continue to have difficulty even setting up meetings, some people get discouraged."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.4377 marks, down from 1.4400 late Wednesday, and at 101.79 Japanese yen, down from 101.90.
Traders say the dollar would be likely to strengthen on news of a balanced-budget deal, because that would decrease the possibility of higher inflation. Indeed, even though the deal might lead to lower American interest rates -- something that tends to make dollar-denominated investments less attractive -- that would be more than offset by the prospect of scant inflation.
With governments in Europe lowering rates to stimulate their own sluggish economies, a further rate cut in the United States would be less likely to hurt the dollar's value.
Some other late dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.1576 Swiss francs, up from 1.1545; 4.9320 French francs, down from 4.9415; 1,587 Italian lire, down from 1,594, and 1.3620 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3669. The British pound was quoted at $1.5417, up from $1.5360 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Hartford Remembers Better Days;
G. Fox Display Recalls a Once-Proud Store and City

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 21

 BODY:
On a recent afternoon, Jerry Orfitelli introduced his two granddaughters to an old friend he thought they would never get to meet: the G. Fox & Company department store, a Hartford institution that closed three years ago.
Together they walked into "Winter Wonderland" -- a six-floor smorgasbord of Christmas displays, children's attractions and December kitsch set up in the otherwise vacant building to benefit charities -- and the memories rushed over him. 
 There were Mr. Orfitelli's annual visits to buy his Easter suit; the day he and his schoolmates had cookies and milk in the penthouse office of the store's president, and his stint as an employee in "Toy Land," leading nervous children to Santa Claus.
"To go through those revolving doors again and see that big grand escalator that I must have raced up at least a thousand times, it's a joy," said Mr. Orfitelli, 55, a retired insurance consultant. "This place, the magic, it's still here."
The 11-story building has been largely empty since its final business day, Jan. 22, 1993. But thanks to Winter Wonderland's creator, the son of a Holocaust survivor, it has been transformed into a combination exhibition hall and fantasy land that has attracted more than 70,000 people since Thanksgiving.
The event has provided a brief reprieve for a city that was devastated by the store's closing and that has suffered one economic blow after another as its main industry, the insurance business, has scaled back. What makes Winter Wonderland's success even sweeter is that it comes as some have declared the 78-year-old Art Deco building a white elephant and a symbol of a downtown that has seen better days.
Nostalgia is the lure for many vistors, But others are drawn by the lavish displays: a forest of shimmering Christmas trees that use enough power to light a typical Hartford block; a floor filled with mechanical figurines like bubble-blowing bears and Martians landing on the North Pole; an indoor race track where toddlers can putter about on battery-powered jeeps; the displays of electric trains and ornate Victorian doll houses, and 16 Santa Clauses for children to visit.
It is a wild homespun mix of private toy collections (several hundred Barbies), finely made miniatures and Christmas glitz. Tour buses have come from as far as New Hampshire and New York City.
Still, it is clear that G. Fox has become a place with little for sale besides dreams and memories.
"Imagine New York City without Macy's," remarked Mickey Hernandez, a native of Hartford who was taking her 2-year-old niece to see Santa Claus. But in Hartford, the store meant even more.
"G. Fox was the only game in town," she said. 'Going to the mall isn't the same thing."
The mastermind behind Winter Wonderland, now in its second year, is Arnold L. Chase, 44, executive vice president of Chase Enterprises, a family-owned real estate and communications company. He was tired of looking out his office window at the building's boarded-up windows and frustrated that downtown Hartford was so often deserted at night and on weekends.
For years, Mr. Chase had been staging an elaborate haunted house at his home. He is an electronics wizard who grew up taking apart and putting together radios and other mechanical gadgets.
To Mr. Chase, the G. Fox Building was a giant toy that would allow him to play on a grand scale, with the proceeds going to charity.
At first, the city, the building's owner, resisted, but two years ago it offered free use of the building for Halloween and winter events.
The Halloween venture is clearly Mr. Chase's first love.
This year, it featured a subway car that rumbled out of control, giant tarantulas that dropped from the ceiling, an hors d'oeuvres plate of finger stumps, and bodies and skulls that gushed fake blood. The ticket lines stretched several blocks, and Mr. Chase had an ambulance regularly rushing up to the curb, to receive a decapitated body that would be carried out on a stretcher with its arms flailing. He would then follow with the head.
"It contributed to the mood," he said.
Winter Wonderland has a different effect on visitors. At first glance, Mr. Chase, an observant Jew, would appear to be an unlikely architect for the project. "I personally can't relate to the holiday," he admitted sheepishly.
Still, it is Mr. Chase's distinctive imagination that infuses the project, and before embarking on it last year, he researched what sort of feelings he wanted to evoke, even videotaping customers at F.A.O. Schwarz in Manhattan. "I asked everyone, 'What does Christmas mean to you?' " he said.
He is clearly delighted with the results.
"Look at that," he said, pointing out a family that had just got off the escalator. "Three generations -- grandparents, parents and kids. Where else could they all go out and have fun together?"
Mr. Chase estimates that the events at G. Fox have raised about $80,000 over two years for the American Diabetes Association and other charities and brought a quarter million people into the city. He said that at least $1 million had been invested, though he declined to identify his personal stake. This year's event is also sponsored by McDonald's.
Tickets cost $8 for adults and $5 for children, with the event running through Dec. 31.
But the future of the building is uncertain. Mr. Chase has asked the city to let him transform it into a year-round entertainment center, with the profits going to charity. But city officials have held onto hopes that the building can be sold. A few weeks ago, Mayor Mike Peters said two developers were interested, and the building has been shown recently to potential buyers.
Mr. Chase said he would try to move his events to another city, perhaps New York, if G. Fox were no longer available.
Since the city bought the building for $1 in 1993, it has deteriorated. An escalator hand rail is so severely cracked that visitors are told not to rest their hands on it. The walls are smudged, the floors scuffed, the bathrooms not sparkling.
Still, those who visit Winter Wonderland do not notice the flaws. "It is beautiful," Ms. Hernandez exclaimed.
Mr. Orfitelli sat his granddaughters, Rachel, 2, and Jordan, 5, at the winding 1950's lunch counter that was reopened on the third floor and told them, "You don't see anything like this anymore."
A little later he added, "I just wish someone would buy it and keep it this way. Everyone wants to go back to department stores at Christmas, and there are none left."
"This lets a grandfather show his grandkids, 'This is what it was like when I grew up,' " he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Day Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the long bond modestly higher in lackluster trading.
With the future release of many economic reports on hold because of the partial Government shutdown, many dealers and investors remain focused on the budget talks, with few venturing to take strong positions before the outcome is known. 
 The benchmark 30-year bond rose 9/32, to a price of 110 24/32 to yield 6.09 percent, down from 6.12 percent on Wednesday.
Meanwhile, the short end of the market did reasonably well because of seasonal factors, with the rate for the three-month issue down ten-hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.89 percent.
Strong buying was also helped by the expectations of some that there will be more rate cuts by the central bank, and a flight to safety of investors moving away from longer maturities to the short end of the market because of the uncertainty surrounding the budget talks.
Traders say the market views the week's lack of progress on the budget deficit as reducing the chances of a quick settlement. There were no top-level meetings scheduled in Washington yesterday.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said trading was thin yesterday, with most participants choosing to watch news wires for headlines about the negotiations. He said that for the most part, long bonds were confined to a less than a half-point move, before ending slightly higher on the day.
He also said that the day's five-year note auction went pretty much as expected, following a less than stellar two-year note auction on Wednesday. The $12 billion sale of the new five-year issue is done in a so-called Dutch auction format, meaning that all the notes are sold at one yield, which is the highest needed to sell all the debt. At yesterday's auction that yield was 5.550 percent -- the lowest in almost two years.
In the day's only big report, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its general business conditions index rose sharply for December even though price pressures moderated.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that "over all the report was higher because shipments and orders were up," but looking behind those figures, she added, there was some underlying weakness. "
She said most of components were down, including number of employees, the average workweek and prices paid and prices received. "The declines are extremely noteworthy," she said, "as they suggest that the employment report for December will continue to indicate a weak labor market, and that inflationary tendencies remain very favorable."
These data, she added, will set the tone for Government reports for January and February and perhaps play a role in the next Fed decision on interest rates.
The Public Securities Association has recommended a 2 P.M. close today, instead of the normal 5 P.M., for the holiday weekend.

HEADLINE: For Big Broadcasters, Communications Bill's Big Issues Are Settled

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
For the big national broadcasters, the unsettled status of the telecommunications bill was not totally unsettling because none of the issues they care about remain in dispute.
The bill, whenever it is passed by Congress, will give the largest station owners, such as the broadcast networks, the right to increase their television station ownership up to a level equal to 35 percent of the television homes in the country. 
 The provisions for radio are scheduled to be loosened even more, with no limits set on the number of stations any one broadcaster can own nationally, and a sliding scale on the number they can own in one city.
The prospect of such a change in radio drove up the stock prices yesterday for big radio station owners such as Infinity Broadcasting, which saw its shares rise $3.75, to $36.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The only reason television station owners did not experience the same bounce, said Derek Blaine, an analyst for Paul Kagan Associates, a firm that specializes in media companies, was "broadcast valuations are already sky high in anticipation of this bill being passed."
One senior network executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that renewed haggling over the bill between Democrats and Republicans yesterday was not likely to affect anything in the bill important to broadcasters, other than timing. "An awful lot has been resolved," the executive said. "I suspect even if this were to carry over until next year, it would still come out pretty much this way on the major issues."
The major issues for the broadcast networks have been the lifting of the current cap on ownership -- from stations that reach up to 25 percent of the national television homes to stations that reach up to 35 percent -- and how much of a station a company must own to have that station count against its 35 percent total.
The latter issue, called attribution, would have the most impact on Rupert Murdoch's Fox Broadcasting Company, because Fox has taken a minority percentage in a number of recent station deals. Fox had wanted the new telecommunications bill to include a provision that would keep intact the current complicated attribution formula. Current rules have allowed Fox to buy a 20 percent stake in stations owned by New World Communications without having that investment count in the total number of stations attributed to Fox.
The Federal Communications Commission has already given notice that it will conduct a rule-making procedure on the attribution rules, and the commission is widely expected to toughen those rules. If the New World stations are forced to be counted as part of the total attributed to Fox, that network would jump immediately to the 35 percent national limit. That development would endanger other deals Fox has made for minority interests in companies such as Savoy Broadcasting and Black Star Broadcasting.
The question of the timing of the passage of the bill is most important to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which gained a waiver from the F.C.C. when it completed its deal to acquire CBS last month. The combination of stations owned by Westinghouse and stations added in the CBS deal means the CBS/Westinghouse stations now reach 33 percent of the country.
That deal was concluded in anticipation that the station limit would grow to 35 percent. If the telecommunications bill is delayed, CBS will be forced to ask for an extension to its waiver. "We expect to get it," a senior CBS executive said. "But it could get ugly. We'd much rather have the bill passed."
If the bill passes in the next week or even sometime next year, the immediate result is likely to be a renewed buying frenzy in television stations. Broadcasters will seek to expand their station base, "knowing that economies of scale are especially good in the broadcast business," said Sharon Armbrust, a senior analyst with Kagan Associates.
David Westin, president of ABC, said if the bill passed, "We'll be looking for television stations, though prices are certainly going to be a challenge." He noted that station prices have soared since the television marketplace was roiled by Fox's investment of $500 million for its 20 percent stake in New World two years ago. That set off a long roundelay of affiliation switches, which led to a further round of defensive moves by broadcasters.
The most significant of those moves was the signing of long-term affiliation contracts between networks and affiliates.
Mr. Westin said those contracts would affect whatever station purchases were made by networks in the wake of the bill. "Because of things like 10-year affiliation deals, networks will necessarily look first to buys stations already affiliated with them," Mr. Westin said. "You can look for some deals that result in affiliation swaps. But as a practical matter we'll be looking first to ABC affiliates."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Rains in Brazil and Argentina Send Soybean Prices Plunging

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Soybean futures prices plunged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as rains aided parched crops in Brazil and Argentina, relieving drought conditions that threatened to severely hamper world supply.
Analysts cautioned, however, that predicted rainfall of up to 1.5 inches would provide only temporary relief to the region, which has seen virtually no rain in two months and stifling hot temperatures. 
 "There's really only one story in the soybeans market, and that's the South American weather," said Dale Gustafson at Smith Barney in Chicago. "But forecasters continue to suggest the temperatures are going to stay quite hot, and these rains, while useful, will be soaked up very quickly."
On other commodity markets, grain futures also retreated, while natural gas futures again surged to record highs. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 0.59 point, to 246.02.
Soybeans for January delivery retreated 14 cents, to $7.18 1/4 a bushel, falling for the second straight day from two-and-a-half-year highs.
Unexpectedly strong rains fell overnight in dry soybean and corn-producing regions of Argentina, and the weather system was headed for the Rio Grande do Sul region in southern Brazil. That area produces about 30 percent of Brazil's soybean crop, the world's second largest behind the United States'.
Wheat and corn futures retreated in sympathy with soybeans, but losses were limited by continued strong export prospects. Wheat for March delivery fell 2 1/2 cents, to $4.99 a bushel. March corn fell 2 cents, to $3.52 1/2 a bushel.
Natural gas futures soared to record highs for the fourth straight day on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid continued cold temperatures in the Northeast at a time when supplies are tight. United States inventories of natural gas are 12 percent below levels a year ago, the American Gas Association, an industry trade group, said.
January natural gas rose 27.9 cents, to $3.350 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Natural gas futures prices climbed 70.7 cents in the first three days of trading this week, and yesterday rose 64.9 cents, to $3.720 for 1,000 cubic feet, before falling back on profittaking of the expiring January contract.
Tim Evans, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group in New York, said the rally was likely to continue because cash market prices also continued to climb. "The only question for this rocket ship now," Mr. Evans said, "is how far out of the solar system is it going to go?"

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Lower interest rates are causing another surge in refinancings of home mortgages.

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
THE wave of home-mortgage refinancing of three years ago is back, though not quite as strong.
"There's a real surge," said Ellen Bitton, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company. "Normally the week before Christmas is dead, but it hasn't abated at all. We're crazed." 
 Mark Schwabber, president of Skyscraper Mortgage, mortgage brokers with offices in Connecticut and New York, said 28 percent of his business was now refinancing, compared with 5 percent a year ago. Toward the end of 1993 -- considered the height of the refinancing market -- he said refinancings made up 35 percent of his business.
Within the last few weeks, bond yields, to which many mortgages are keyed, hit the lowest they have been in 24 months. And a drop in short-term interest rates this week by the Federal Reserve, followed by lower market rates, contributed to the public's perception that the timing might be right to take another look at the terms of home mortgages.
These rate drops are "setting the stage for a New Year's gift" for consumers and mortgage lenders alike, according to Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates, an organization that tracks the mortgage industry.
Currently, Mr. Havemann said, refinancing makes up about 25 percent of all mortgage loans. Last year, he said, refinanced mortgages were "negligible, trivial, hardly anything" statistically.
And more refinancing business is expected, he said, echoing the voices of others in the mortgage business. "It's a real possibility that rates could come down more," Mr. Havemann said.
He pointed out that the average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in January 1995 stood at 9.33 percent -- while this week the national average was 7.23 percent.
Today's upswing in refinancing is coming not only from people who missed the last wave of refinancing. Some other homeowners refinanced last time with 30-year mortgages carrying rates that are adjusted ever three years -- and the three years are up. Another group of customers refinanced only a year or two ago, but are trying to get an even better deal.
"The conventional wisdom," Mr. Schwabber said, "was that it pays to refinance only if your new rate will be at least two percentage points less than your current rate. That thinking is now out the window. There are people refinancing with only one point lower -- and saving money."
As an example, Mr. Schwabber said a homeowner might have received a mortgage for $100,000 at 8 percent interest earlier this year. The mortgage rate for the same loan is now at 7 percent, he said, and if the person refinanced now, he could borrow $110,000 -- for $2 less a month.
Increasingly, buyers are taking advantage of a procedure called Consolidation Extension and Modification, he said. Under this procedure refinancers can switch to a lower rate mortgage and pay only $300 in lawyer's fees and $500 for a title update. For a $200,000 mortgage taken out a year ago for a percentage point higher, the homeowner now could save $1,656 a year. Even with the refinancing costs figured in, the homeowner could break even in less than a year and start saving money, the mortgage broker said.
"Customers with mortgages over $500,000 are refinancing with one- half percent difference," Mr. Schwabber said.
Nevertheless, mortgage brokers and lenders point out that rates are still higher than they were for houses or apartments bought or refinanced at the end of 1993. While a home buyer who closed on a house at the beginning of January 1994 might have gotten a 30-year fixed-interest loan at 6.75 percent, in today's market, that same loan would be almost a full percentage point higher. And while one-year adjustable loans were written back then as low as 4 percent, the same loan now averages 5.64 percent interest.
Yet Abe Eisner, executive vicepresident of GFC Mortgage Bankers Inc., a company lending in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Florida, still sees a definite boom right now and predicts "it will continue into 1996 as rates are projected to come down even more."
While there appears to be a boomlet in refinancing, mortgage brokers also report more new purchases, which they say reflects an upturn in the residential real estate market.
But whether they are buying or refinancing, mortgage brokers say customers seem to be more creative than ever in shopping for deals. And they suggest that banks are becoming more flexible in accommodating consumers' needs.

HEADLINE: Ghosts of Christmas Past At the City's Historic Houses

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
IF you want to get away from the glitter, the pressure and the noise of Christmas, you might visit New York City's historic mansions during the holidays. They are seldom crowded; the Van Cortlandt House, set in the romantic, wintry landscape of Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, has only about half a dozen visitors a weekend. The Merchant's House Museum, a beautifully restored late Federal house, is tucked away nearly out of sight, next to a vacant lot on East Fourth Street in Greenwich Village. These and several other great houses are oases of calm in a city frenzied with Christmas revels. Indeed, they are among the secret treasures of New York. But they are simply decorated, and there will be no lavish parties inside. For -- not to be a Scrooge -- in old New York, there were few Christmas Day celebrations as we now know them.
The story of how Christmas came to New York is part of the social history of the city itself, one that is reflected in a chronological tour of its historic houses. From the Morris-Jumel Mansion in Washington Heights to the Abigail Adams Smith House on the Upper East Side to Historic Richmond Town on Staten Island, these houses represent the city's various eras, including Colonial New York and the Victorian Age. 
 To understand the evolution of Christmas in New York, you must look to Europe in pre-Christian times. There have always been celebrations in northern countries during the period now called Christmas week. The harvest was over; it was the winter solstice. The typical pre-Christian was on layoff. He would kick off his proverbial wooden shoes, have a drink, kiss his mate and engage in general licentiousness. In the fourth century, church fathers wisely chose Dec. 25, near the time of the solstice, as the birth date of Jesus. That made pagans more likely to incorporate the Christian liturgy into their ceremonies.
Still, Christmas Day as we know it was not widely observed. There were no decorated trees. There might be parties on St. Nicholas Eve, Dec. 5. But the tradition of St. Nicholas arriving on a white horse with candy and gifts was a later invention. Until the 1800's, Christmas and New Year's were interchangeable terms. And the month of December, generally, was a time of revelry, not necessarily connected to Jesus' birth.
During the Reformation, the Puritans banned Christmas celebrations as pagan and Pope-ish. The Puritans brought their traditions to the New World, and Christmas festivities were banned in Massachusetts. In Dutch Calvinist New York, holiday parties would have been frowned upon, though this didn't stop the lower classes from getting drunk and shooting guns and behaving noisily in general.
But at the start of the 19th century, New York began to change. There were new immigrants, new industries and unemployment. Christmas week revels became rowdier, with parades of callithumpians, as they were called, or drunken vagabonds, begging for money.
 
Merry Modern Christmas
In a way, the story of modern Christmas begins in 1810, with John Pintard, a member of the gentry and founder of the New-York Historical Society. Pintard hated the rowdiness of Christmas-New Year's parties. He was woken up at night by bands of callithumpians. The season, he thought, had become divorced from its spiritual origins.
In his forthcoming book, "The Battle for Christmas" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1996), Stephen Nissenbaum, a professor of history at the University of Massachussetts at Amherst, writes that Pintard and his patrician friends invented Christmas to control the noisy immigrants who disturbed the peace during the Christmas week. Pintard first campaigned to make New Year's Day a holiday of family visits, an alternative to nighttime revelry. Upper-class men visited, and women stayed home and provided food. But the disturbances continued. Pintard turned to St. Nicholas Day, then to Christmas Day itself, trying to create formal celebrations.
In 1810, Pintard paid for a broadside published by the New-York Historical Society with a picture of St. Nicholas and a poem. In 1819, a fellow member of the historical society, Washington Irving, published "The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon, Gent.," promoting Christmas as a family occasion. Two years later, another friend of Pintard, Clement Clarke Moore, wrote "A Visit From St. Nicholas."
Mr. Nissenbaum has a social historian's explanation for Moore's poem. Moore was a Hebrew scholar and slaveholder who owned much of Chelsea. He watched in horror as the city filled with foreigners and the pastoral world he had known as a child was transformed. In 1818, Ninth Avenue bifurcated his entire estate; Ninth Avenue became a metaphor in Moore's mind for the hordes of immigrants who threatened the established order, Mr. Nissenbaum writes.
Moore's poem "A Visit From St. Nicholas" sought to create an ideal Christmas of domestic family festivities. It represented a nostalgia for a Christmas, notes Mr. Nissenbaum, that never existed. "The household visitor Moore portrays," writes Mr. Nissenbaum, "has come neither to threaten his genteel host, nor to make any demands on his generosity." Charles Dickens's "Christmas Carol" was a further embellishment of the Christmas legend.
 
Such Tranquilizing Trees
The Christmas tree didn't arrive in New York until probably the mid-1800's, introduced perhaps by German immigrants. Mr. Nissenbaum says he believes that the Christmas tree tradition was spread through popular literature, a further effort to shift festivities from drunken street scenes to domestic observances.
Christmas celebrations came to a peak in New York in the 1890's with the building of big department stores. The invention of plate-glass windows and electric lights made lavish displays possible. In "Land of Desire" (Pantheon, 1993), a history of department stores by William Leach, the merchant princes of the city laid claim to Santa Claus "and the imagery of Christmas holidays" to lure shoppers and clamoring children into their grand emporiums.
To experience the holiday in old New York, you can visit the city's historic mansions, some of which are open during Christmas week. But take note of a new emphasis among curators for accurate historical interpretation: some houses held Christmas activities earlier this month, in keeping with St. Nicholas Eve. And for historical truth, houses that reflect New York before the Victorian era are not elaborately decorated at all.
 
Perhaps the Oldest
The Morris-Jumel Mansion, at 65 Jumel Terrace, is probably the oldest house in Manhattan, a grand Palladian structure atop Harlem Heights. It was built in 1765 for a British colonel, Roger Morris, and eventually owned by Stephen Jumel and his wife, Eliza, who married Aaron Burr after Jumel died. The house is decorated minimally, appropriate for old New York. On Dec. 29, there will be a wreath-making workshop "as a traditional symbol of community and connection," says a brochure.
Another way to experience Christmas in early New York is to take the subway for an easy ride to the Van Cortlandt House. The house, built in 1748, is decorated for the year 1820. The house is hung with garlands of beauty berries and boxwood. On the main stairway is a wreath with a pineapple, pineapples being a traditional symbol of hospitality, often brought from far away by merchant seamen. The four apples on the wreath represent the four points of the compass.
Hanging in the hallway is a kissing ball, a tradition from late-18th-century England made with boxwood from the Van Cortlandt grounds. There are two spheres, with a Nativity figure and mistletoe inside, an interesting blend of the sacred and profane in Christmas decorations.
The West Parlor is set up for holiday punch, with a huge china bowl. Typically, the punch would have the juice and rind of lemons, limes or oranges, and sugar, rum and brandy. The concoction was allowed to blend for several days.
The dining room is decorated for the "second dessert" course; people of the time loved sweets. Food is the principal decoration in this room, with delicacies stacked and pyramided in the center of the table. There is a tower of cream puffs encased in spun caramel like a golden web, and a tower of cherries and strawberries, out of season; in the old days, they were grown in hothouses for wealthy families. There are glittery candy mints, sugar-coated Jordan almonds and pfeffernuesse stacked in a tower. On the sideboard are brightly colored jellies surrounding a shimmering blancmange decorated with sugared fruits. (None may eaten by visitors.) Be sure to visit the upstairs nursery with the oldest doll house in the country, from 1744, with two sides separated by slats, so little girls playing together could see each other.
In the Dutch chamber upstairs, straw and carrots are stuffed into a wooden shoe for St. Nick to give to his horse.
Upstairs, the East chamber has been decorated as if for a visiting family, as the season was a time for holiday guests. Note the lead pewter baby bottle that has been set out.
 
An Unlikely Setting
The Abigail Adams Smith Museum, at 421 East 61st Street, is a jewel of Manhattan, a house constructed of Manhattan schist, surrounded by parking lots, warehouses and practically underneath the Queensboro Bridge. It has been restored to the way it was in the 1820's and 30's when it was the Mount Vernon Hotel, a resort on the East River. Even in its modern setting, this house has a peaceful feeling. There are greens and candles but no Christmas tree. In the entryway, a table is set with nuts and marzipan sweets. There are kissing balls, and a towered arrangement of apples, a pineapple and greens on the dining table. The fireplaces are decorated with fresh fruits and greenery. There are garlands of pine and cones on the stairway. In the tavern room and kitchen, gourds are piled in wooden bowls.
For a more urban experience, visit the Merchant's House Museum, once the home of the Tredwell family. The house has been "frozen in time," to 1870, when the Tredwells did their last major redecoration. With its red damask furnishings, the house is festive.
In the parlor is a tabletop tree reproduced from an 1850 Godey's Lady's Book. There will be a traditional New Year's visiting day, with hot cider, dips and cookies served in the kitchen downstairs.
To remind yourself of the historical development of Christmas, you might visit the New-York Historical Society's exhibition on Clement Clarke Moore, and the Pierpont Morgan Library at 29 East 36th Street, Murray Hill, which owns the original manuscript of Dickens's "Christmas Carol," on display during the holidays with rare Dickens memorabilia.
 
A Victorian Celebration
But to experience Christmas in its full, Victorian flowering, you should journey to Historic Richmond Town on Staten Island, where there will be traditional Victorian holiday celebrations. In the courthouse, built in 1837, is a big Christmas tree with candles and documented reproductions of late 19th-century Victorian decorations made from tinsel, paper and bits of scrap. On Dec. 29 there will be a doll and teddy bear party, to which children can bring their own toys to meet other dolls and stuffed animals. There will be games, contests, prizes and refreshments.
Some houses on the grounds will have docents in period costume. The Stephens House is hung with holly and boxwood and has a tabletop tree. There is a reproduction of a pine cone Santa from 1860.
The Bennett House also has a tree with replicated and authentic Victorian decorations, including glass beads, and tin brilliants made from the original Staten Island molds. There is to be a magic lantern show with glass slides from the 19th century.
The tavern, built in 1820, is decorated with evergreen, and the cast-iron wood stove will be lighted for Christmas. Cider and homemade pound and gingerbread cake will be for sale.
The climax of the celebrations will be the Christmas Cotillion in the courtroom on New Year's Eve. There will be 19th-century dances, and a midnight "collation" in the boardroom with 19th-century recipes from "Mrs. Beeton's Cookbook," including lobster salad, sausage-and-beef pies, tipsy cake and Christmas pudding. Visitors are encouraged to wear Victorian ball gowns. This is a popular event, and prepaid reservations are required.
When you leave Richmond Town, take the Staten Island Ferry back to Manhattan if you can. Chances are, the light will be darkening and the mist rising on the waters. Standing on the deck, bundled up against the cold, you will have the sense, as the foghorn sounds, of returning from a journey back in time.
 
These Old Houses

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Partners Half a World Apart
The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Foundation for the Arts in Nagoya, Japan, have finally consummated their relationship. It took a lot longer than anyone anticipated. Four years after signing a letter of intent, the two signed a 20-year agreement last week establishing a museum in Nagoya that is to be called the Nagoya/Boston Museum of Fine Arts. 
 For a while it seemed that it would never happen: the deal was complicated by the shaky economy in Japan and by political battles within the foundation. Originally the museum was to have opened next year; now it is scheduled to be completed by fall 1998.
If it all works as planned, the new museum will give the Museum of Fine Arts another venue in which to exhibit works from its collection. But that's only part of the story.
There are also considerable financial benefits for the cash-strapped Boston institution. Money for the new museum will come from the foundation, the city of Nagoya and from the Aichi Prefecture, in which Nagoya is situated. The foundation will provide $1 million a year for the Boston museum's operating budget, as well as three $5 million grants.
Brent R. Benjamin, deputy director of curatorial affairs at the Museum of Fine Arts, said the first $5 million was delivered when the letter of intent was signed in 1991, and was used to pay off bonds. "We haven't formally decided what the rest will be used for," he added. "It will probably go toward building our endowment." The foundation is also to reimburse the museum for expenses it incurs in mounting shows in Nagoya.
It is not the first time the Museum of Fine Arts has derived a financial benefit from working with a Japanese institution. "Over the last 15 years we have been sending shows to many different parts of Japan, which have generated funds for our annual operating expenses," Mr. Benjamin said. "One of the ideas behind the Nagoya project was to institutionalize this practice so that we wouldn't be dealing with lots of different places. We wanted to find one place where we would have an ongoing relationship."
Under the agreement, the new museum will present two shows a year from Boston as well as one five-year loan exhibition. The first six-month show will be "Monet, Renoir and the Impressionist Landscape" and the first of the long-term exhibitions will be "Art of the Ancient Mediterranean World," with works from the Museum of Fine Art's Egyptian, Greek and Roman collections. The new museum is to occupy three floors of a new building that will also include a hotel and city offices.
 
 
 
Less (Hoopla) Is More (Substance)
 All the recent fuss about celebrity auctions has left some art connoisseurs feeling a bit queasy. It sometimes seems that the more famous a seller's name, the more lavish the publicity and the poorer the taste and quality of the goods being sold.
The arrival of Christie's catalogue of art and objects belonging to Sir John Pope-Hennessy comes as a relief after the glitz surrounding the auction of works collected by Frank Sinatra and the announcement of the forthcoming spring sale of property belonging to Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.
Sir John, a major art-world figure who died a little more than a year ago, was the former director of two London institutions: the Victoria and Albert Museum and the British Museum. He was a leading authority on the Italian Renaissance, and headed the department of European painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan from 1977 to 1986.
Known in the art world as "the Pope," Sir John once wrote that "object-based relationships are more constant than human ones (they never change their nature and do not pall)."
This passion makes his collection of Old Master paintings and drawings, prints, sculpture, illuminations, furniture and decorative objects particularly interesting. Most of the works offered in the Jan. 10 auction in New York are to come from Sir John's home in Florence, where he retired in 1986.
Christie's expects the auction to bring $1.3 million to $2 million.
"The whole sale gives you an idea of how fascinating his eye was," said Anthony Crichton-Stuart, head of Christie's department of Old Master paintings in New York. "He was quite a discerning collector, but since he didn't have unlimited resources, he bought carefully and the collection grew over time."
Among the highlights are Franceschini's "Last Communion of St. Mary of Egypt From the Hermit Zosimus" (circa 1680), which the artist painted on copper. Christie's estimates that it will sell for $100,000 to $150,000.
Another painting, "Lake Geneva From the Slopes of Cologny Looking Toward Eaux-Vives, With an Artist Sketching Seated on a Bench With His Companions" (1778), by Simon Malgo, is intriguing because it is not typical of Sir John's taste. He inherited it from his mother, Dame Una Pope-Hennessy. Christie's estimates it will bring $70,000 to $100,000.
Another work he inherited from his mother, Piaggio's "Marriage of the Virgin" (1520), estimated to fetch $60,000 to $80,000, was only recently attributed to the artist. "If it belonged to someone else I would have found long ago who painted it, but since it is my own I feel no interest in the problem," wrote Sir John in his 1991 autobiography. "It is nonetheless a satisfying picture."
 
 
 
. . . It Was a Very Good Year
 Sotheby's and Christie's are ending the year on a positive note. Both companies announced their year-end figures this week, and both had good news to report.
Sotheby's 1995 auction sales totaled $1.7 billion, a 25 percent increase from the $1.3 billion it reported in 1994. "We've had the strongest year since 1990," said Diana D. Brooks, the auction house's chief executive officer. "The reasons were the strong sales in Impressionist and modern art and jewelry and the strong single-owner sales."
Christie's rise in sales stemmed from exactly the same areas. Its sales totaled $1.5 billion, a 17 percent increase from the $1.3 billion it reported a year ago. While neither auction house came close to posting the high figures they did at the height of the market (in 1989, Sotheby's sales were $2.9 billion, and Christie's were $2.1 billion), both houses sold goods at higher prices than they had in six years.
"We sold 108 lots for $1 million or more this year" said David Tyler, Christie's commercial and finance director. "That's the most since 1990."

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise, Broad Indexes Eclipsing Dow

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks closed sharply higher yesterday on hopes that new talks planned between the White House and Congressional leaders that are scheduled for today will end the dispute about balancing the Federal budget in seven years.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 37.21 points to close at 5,096.53, nearly recovering a 50-point loss in the previous session. In the broader market, advancing issues led decliners, 1,417 to 951, on Big Board volume of 419.9 million shares. 
 The Nasdaq composite index did better yet, jumping 15.37 points, to 1,040.64, propelled by strength in technology stocks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.55 points, to 610.49, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.00 points, to 325.61.
The American Stock Exchange index rose 2.99 points, to 537.49. And the Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 5,988.45, up 45.39 points, or 0.76 percent.
"We had a nice snap-back from yesterday's late selloff and managed to hold gains," said Ron Hill, research director at Brown Brothers Harriman. "The fact we'll see continued budget talks is a positive here after they broke off acrimoniously yesterday."
The Senate's Republican majority leader, Bob Dole, said he thought there had been some progress, but he called it "process progress."
On Wednesday, President Clinton detailed the latest budget impasse at an afternoon news conference, which led to a computer program-assisted selloff in stocks.
Wall Street also seemed to bet that the Federal Reserve would again lower interest rates early next year, given continued signs of a slowing economy. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said that manufacturing activity increased in parts of the Northeast in December, but that the outlook for the next six months was not as bright as it was a month ago. The Philadelphia Fed, one of 12 regional banks of the Federal Reserve, said its index of current manufacturing activity rose to 21.5 in December from 7.9 in November.
On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve lowered the Federal funds rate, the rate at which banks lend one another money, by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent, in an effort to bolster the economy.
Yesterday, shares of biotechnology companies, and to some extent, drug makers, soared on news of positive results in a clinical trial for Centocor's drug Reopro, which breaks up blood clots. Centocor surged 7 1/16, to 32 1/8. Eli Lilly Centocor's marketing partner for Reopro, rose 4, to 55 1/4.
"The hot group was biotechs," said Frank Gretz, a technical analyst at Shields & Company, "and when you get a new leadership group that's positive."
Other biotechnology stocks gaining included Biogen, which rose 4 3/4, to 63; Chiron, up 7 1/4, to 109 1/2; Amgen, up 3 5/8, to 55 1/2, and Cephalon, up 3 7/16, to 37.
"There was good news for Centocor seeping through to the rest of the group, reminding when new drugs have success in trials it can do wonders for the valuations of these companies," Mr. Hill said.
Kmart was the most active stock, rising 1 5/8, to 7 5/8, on volume of nearly 15.5 million shares. The struggling retailer eliminated its dividend on Wednesday, and said it had reached an agreement with creditors that would prevent mortgage debt holders from seeking early repayment.
Coca-Cola lost 1 1/2, closing at 72 3/4, after issuing a fourth-quarter forecast on international sales that fell short of analyst expectations.
UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, tumbled 17 7/8, to 180 1/8, after forecasting disappointing fourth-quarter earnings. American Airlines' parent, the AMR Corporation, lost 2 3/8, to 73 3/4, and Boeing fell 1 1/4, to 76 3/4. An American Airlines flight crashed in Colombia late Wednesday night, killing most of the 164 people aboard. The accident involved a Boeing 757 jet.
In Nasdaq trading, Avid Technology tumbled 10 5/8, to 19, after the company warned about its fourth-quarter performance. Unitech Industries fell nearly 80 percent, or 8 1/2, to 2 1/4, after it forecast a significant loss for the year. The company, which also trades on Nasdaq, said it believed its financial results for previous quarters had been misstated, and several top executives resigned.

HEADLINE: Police Investigate Threats Against White and Korean Store Owners

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
At least 10 white or Korean store owners in Harlem have received racially charged threats since the arson attack on Freddy's clothing store that left eight people dead, police officials said yesterday.
Though officials say they do not know whether the threats are dangerous or merely harassing, police officers have been posted outside several stores on West 125th Street, the police said. 
 In one incident, a caller telephoned the Sneaker City shoe store on Wednesday and asked if the store was Korean-owned, said Christopher Walker, a store clerk. When Mr. Walker replied that the shoe store was indeed owned by a Korean, the caller said: " 'You see what happened at Freddy's -- your store is next,' " said Mr. Walker, who began working at the store more than a month ago.
In another case, said a law enforcement official who spoke on the condition of anonymity, a black man walked into the Electronic Outlet at 200 West 125th Street and said, "This store sells used merchandise and we're watching you." The man also complained that the business, owned by David Betesh, who is white, was not hiring black employees.
Mr. Betesh's brother, Stephen, who owns another electronics store called Kiss, at 230 West 125th Street, received an anonymous letter making ethnic slurs and threats to physically harm the owner and the store, said Tom Kelly, deputy police commissioner for public information.
The postmark shows that the anonymous letter was mailed on Dec. 9, a day after Roland J. Smith opened fire inside the nearby Freddy's clothing store, set the building ablaze and then shot himself in the chest; killing seven store employees and himself. Mr. Kelly would not detail the slurs enclosed in the letter.
A third case involved Bargain Land, a discount store on West 145th Street, which the law enforcement official said had also received anonymous telephone threats.
Mr. Kelly said that detectives were investigating whether the various incidents were related, and whether they were serious threats or pranks. But given the charged atmosphere, he said, the police were not taking any chances.
"This thing kind of feeds on itself," Mr. Kelly said. "We're investigating them all. You take them all seriously."
Mr. Smith had been among a group of protesters who had picketed Freddy's, complaining that the Jewish-owned clothing store was trying to evict a black-owned record store from the building. While protest leaders have contended that the dispute was economic, not racial, workers at Freddy's said the protesters frequently used racial slurs and threats.
Law enforcement officials are still investigating whether anyone else knew of Mr. Smith's attack or helped him plan it. A high-ranking official in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said investigators were also aware of the subsequent threats to other stores, but said there was no evidence at this point that they were linked to the earlier deadly blaze.
Michael A. Hardy, a lawyer representing Morris Powell, one of the leaders of the protests at Freddy's, said that he knew nothing of the reported threats and that the police had not questioned his client about them.
In investigating the arson and deaths at Freddy's, the police have reviewed videotapes of the protests, identifying demonstrators. Officials have even begun an inquiry into the performance of the 28th Precinct to determine whether the precinct responded aggressively enough.
One of the regular protesters, Tracy Ligon, known by the street name of Shabazz, had been accused in court papers of making several threatening gestures toward the clothing store and its customers and employees during the weeks preceding the fatal fire.
In the court papers, Mr. Ligon was accused of bursting into the clothing store and shouting: "I will be back to burn the Jew store down. Burn, burn, burn." In an interview earlier this week, however, Mr. Ligon said the protest was economic, not anti-Semitic, and he denied making threatening gestures or remarks at the protests.

HEADLINE: Let C.E.O.'s Heal Budget and Themselves

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Aesop could never have written this fable: A hundred chairmen of the board, virtuosos of a bottom line that threw millions of the middle class on the trash pile, ran a two-page advertisement (Dec. 19) warning us the party's over if we don't balance the budget. These guys would be amazed to learn that an equated budget is not a magic elixir, or finding the Holy Grail. It doesn't fix crime or increase family values.
Let the C.E.O.'s heal themselves and offer a plan with the Government to retrain workers. Better still would be fair-share income tax. For a $270 billion shortfall in a $7 trillion economy isn't as obscure as locating a needle in a haystack. 
 What happened in America is that wealth is stacked in the hands of 20 percent of the people. Republicans stand guard over this abundance. They want the "have-nots" to pull themselves up by their bootstraps. The Democrats concur but want to supply the boots. Hence the baloney of balancing the budget.
The G.O.P. wants the disenfranchised to pay for the Great Society. There are no funds that can be squeezed from the middle class and the poor. To think otherwise is nonsense.
 
EDWARD L. RESNICK
Boynton Beach, Fla., Dec. 20, 1995
