HEADLINE: No Break in Impasse Over Balanced Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Unable to reach agreement on reopening the Government or virtually anything else, the White House and Congressional Republicans nevertheless pushed on today and started examining a sheaf of proposals to balance the Federal budget by 2002.
After 32 days in which the bargainers had traded more accusations than offers, that in itself was progress. Republican leaders and President Clinton are to meet at the White House on Friday to see whether today's review uncovered any common ground. 
 Mr. Clinton's lead negotiator, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said with apparent hesitance today that he was feeling better about the talks than on Wednesday, the day of their most recent collapse. The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, said he hoped to strike a deal with Mr. Clinton on Friday that would both balance the budget and reopen closed Government agencies.
But he added, "I'm not sure I'll succeed."
Nor was anyone else. By most indications, a thunderhead has settled over the balanced-budget discussions and shows few signs of quickly passing over. Republicans in the House said they were told in a closed meeting this evening that the talks were at a standstill and that one of their chief bargainers, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, was both pessimistic and deeply frustrated.
In a reflection of that, the House voted to take a Christmas break of at least five days starting on Friday. Although the members will be on call for summoning back to Washington if there is a budget agreement, the vote was a clear sign that many of them believe no accord is in sight.
The six Cabinet agencies that except for essential services have now been idled for six days -- tying a record for a Government shutdown set only last month -- have almost no prospect of resuming operations until after Christmas at the earliest. That means 260,000 Federal workers will continue to be furloughed.
Both sides said this was a revolting state of affairs, and each said the other was to blame.
"We believe they really don't want to balance the budget," Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the head of the House Republican Conference, said of the White House. "Frankly, we're not used to people who don't deal in good faith."
The Democrats laid responsibility on Speaker Newt Gingrich and his charges in the House, who are taking by far the hardest line in the budget talks. "I don't know what, if anything, could move the House Republicans," said Pat Griffin, the chief lobbyist at the White House.
In fact, there is adequate responsibility to go around. Republicans could easily vote to give closed Federal offices a temporary stipend, thus ending the shutdown. But they believe that the shutdown is a lever that will pry Mr. Clinton into serious budget negotiations, and so they have refused to reopen the Government until a balanced-budget accord is in hand.
For its part, the White House is the only player in the talks -- and the number of those players has grown to at least five with the addition of various Congressional factions -- that has refused to present a balanced-budget plan that uses the Congressional Budget Office's economic forecasts as a base line. As a result, the Administration's seven-year proposal differs from the others by hundreds of billions of dollars. Republicans cite this as evidence that Mr. Clinton prefers to prolong a standoff that so far has been politically damaging to the Republicans.
Republicans in the House today presented a study that rebutted one of their opponents' central contentions: that although the Republican budget plan would achieve fiscal balance in 2002, it would bring huge deficits thereafter. The new study, by the Congressional Budget Office, predicts that the Government would actually run a $10 billion surplus in 2003 and that the annual surplus would grow, reaching $50 billion by 2005.
Mr. Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said in a statement that it was the Democrats who had asked the budget office to conduct the analysis.
In today's negotiating session, Mr. Kasich and the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, met with a Democratic team that included Mr. Panetta; the White House budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. The bargainers pored over three plans, one offered by a group of conservative House Democrats who call themselves the Blue Dogs, another by a group of Senate Democrats, and the third by a group of Senate moderates of both parties.
The three plans differ chiefly in how much of the $240 billion tax cut in the Republican plan they would preserve, and in how the reduction in that cut would be divided among various Federal programs that the Republicans' budget would pare back. One proposal, from the Blue Dogs, would forgo the tax cut entirely and funnel much of the savings to Medicare and Medicaid. So would another, offered by Senate Democrats. The third proposal, offered by the bipartisan group of Senate centrists, contemplates a $130 billion tax cut.
The White House and the Republicans issued a three-sentence statement tonight calling the day's work "constructive." They pledged to meet again on Friday.
But the talk outside the meeting room was positively fetid.
Vice President Al Gore, honing the White House's message of recent days, summoned reporters to say that the White House could deal with Mr. Gingrich but that the more conservative Republicans in the House were "an extremist wing" with an "extremist ideology."
Republicans took offense. Thirty-two self-proclaimed moderate Republicans in the House sent Mr. Clinton a letter professing solidarity with their colleagues. "It serves no one to resort to the rhetoric of extremism," the letter stated.
And the main targets of Mr. Gore's wrath, the House's large class of freshman Republicans, held a news conference to defend themselves. One of them, Representative William M. (Mac) Thornberry of Texas, said, "For some people, it may be extreme to truly believe in something, then speak openly and then keep your promises."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 23, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Federal budget negotiations misstated the number of Cabinet agencies closed in the current Government shutdown. Nine agencies, not six, are shut for all but essential services: the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Commerce, Justice, State, Interior, Veterans Affairs, and Housing and Urban Development.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Budget Stalemate Goes On, But With Quieter Tone
There was one bit of progress in the talks on ending the stalemate over the Federal budget: The negotiations between the President and the Republican Congressional leaders ended without the usual rancor.
But little else appeared to change, as the principals said afterward that they would not meet again until next Friday, making it almost certain that many Federal offices will remain closed at least until the New Year. People on both sides said the talks had touched on the barriers to an agreement, including spending for Medicare and Medicaid. [Page 1.]

The Senate gave final approval to a Republican plan to overhaul the nation's welfare system, ending a guarantee of cash assistance for poor children. The vote cleared the bill for President Clinton, who has said he will veto it. [1.]

CBI Gives In to Praxair
Ending a two-month battle, CBI Industries accepted a $2.2 billion bid from Praxair after it was unable to find a rival bidder. The companies are two of the world's leading producers of industrial gases. [41.]
 
Stake in Hospital Chain Sold
Richard Rainwater, the Fort Worth-based financier who made a fortune in hospital investments, has agreed to buy a stake in Charter Medical, a troubled chain of psychiatric hospitals that is moving into managed care. The company said that Mr. Rainwater and his wife, Darla Moore, would pay $69.7 million in cash. The shares of Charter Medical, which changed its name to Magellan Health Services Inc., jumped 16 percent. [41.]
 
Rate Vote Was Near-Unanimous
Federal Reserve policy-makers decided in November not to wait for resolution of the Federal budget stalemate to cut interest rates, if economic conditions warranted such a move. The Fed's Open Market Committee voted 10-1 to cut a key rate by one-quarter percentage point, minutes show. [43.]

Taking Citicorp Threat Seriously
John Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, has often talked of moving the company's headquarters from New York. But it appears that the Giuliani administration is listening more closely now, and officials said it had begun talks to try to insure that Citicorp stays. [32.]

Anheuser to Sell Cardinals
Anheuser-Busch has reached an agreement to sell the St. Louis Cardinals baseball team for $150 million to a group of investors who say they will keep the team in the city. [38.]

Dow Nearly Flat After Early Surge
After rising more than 30 points early in the session, the Dow Jones industrial average finished up only 1.44 points in light trading before the Christmas holiday. Biotechnology shares continued to soak up money pulled out of information technologies earlier in the week. [43.]

The yield fell on the 30-year Treasury bond to 6.06 percent, the lowest in nearly two weeks, from 6.09 percent. Trading was thin, exaggerating the price movement. [40.]

The dollar rose against leading currencies as the market's shifting sentiment on the Federal budget negotiations turned positive. [42.]

Corn Futures at 11-Year High
Corn futures prices climbed to an 11-year high as South American crops faced a return of hot, dry temperatures after a scant rainfall. Soybean futures also rose. [42.]

Receivers to Monitor Waste Haulers
Justice Walter M. Schackman of New York State Supreme Court named nine receivers to monitor the finances and assets of 18 waste-hauling companies that are charged with being part of a Mafia-dominated cartel that used arson and threats to control New York City's commerical garbage business for more than half a century. [31.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Trader Sentiment On a Budget Deal Turns Positive

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against leading currencies in New York yesterday as the market's shifting sentiment on Federal budget negotiations turned positive.
President Clinton and his Republican opponents in Congress negotiated to balance the budget in seven years at the White House yesterday, prompting hope that the stalemate would soon end. 
 The dollar also drew strength from rising stocks and bonds early in the day. Foreign investors interested in buying American securities need dollars to pay for them.
The dollar finished with a strong gain against the Japanese yen and closed slightly higher against the German mark.
In New York trading was abbreviated ahead of the Christmas holiday on Monday, the dollar was quoted at 102.70 Japanese yen, up from 101.79 late Thursday. The dollar was worth 1.4380 German marks, up from 1.4377 on Thursday.
The mark was supported by a comment from a Bundesbank official who indicated another interest rate cut in Germany might not be forthcoming soon.
The German central bank cut two interest rates by half a percentage point a week ago. Lower interest rates generally weaken a currency as traders look for countries where currencies pay higher yields.
After the comments, the German Government said preliminary western German inflation numbers showed prices 1.4 percent higher than a year earlier in the 30 days ended in mid-December. The inflation numbers were in line with economists' expectations; with inflation rising, central banks are generally reluctant to cut rates.
The dollar wavered against major currencies during the day in New York where volume was thin, allowing individual trades to have an exaggerated effect on the price.
It was higher in the morning, helped by strength in overseas trading, then turned lower after noon before turning up again.
"It was thought some major players who were long on dollars were taking profits before the Christmas holiday," said David de Rosa at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
While Friday's budget talks prompted no breakthroughs, both Mr. Clinton and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, sounded upbeat about the prospect of reaching an agreement.
The British pound was quoted at $1.5400, down from $1.5417 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Tackling a Crucial Highway to Keep Skiers Happy

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SILVER PLUME, Colo., Dec. 21

 BODY:
 On a mountain slope, 23 feet of snow is a skier's blessing. On a mountain highway, it is a skier's curse.
Interstate 70, which climbs through here and is the nation's highest stretch of Interstate, winds past sheer cliffs and deep gorges. 
 But it is not merely a scenic tourist road. In the two decades since this stretch in the Rockies opened, the highway has become the main street for the busiest ski areas in Colorado, the busiest skiing state.
In the 100 miles between Denver and Vail, the Sunday-afternoon traffic crush at the Eisenhower Tunnel, just west of this tiny old mining settlement, can look like a commuter's rush hour -- above the tree line. The annual traffic at the tunnel has tripled in 20 years, hitting 8.5 million vehicles this year.
Last winter, when 281 inches of snow fell on the road, the results were predictable. Trucks jackknifed, skiers' four-wheel-drive vehicles slithered, and the state police closed the highway a record 35 times. The closings cost "tens of million of dollars to Colorado's ski industry, the backbone of the tourism economy," said John Frew, president of Colorado Ski Country USA, a resort association.
This year, with planeloads of skiers' disembarking hourly at Denver's new airport, the authorities are marshaling high and low technology to keep traffic flowing over the Interstate, which peaks at 11,165 feet.
The techniques include computer-controlled message signs, strict enforcement of tire-chain laws for trucks and raising the wages of snowplow drivers to entice more people into the job. Widening the four-lane highway would help, of course, but experts say it would be prohibitively expensive.
With the impetus from the state's $2.5 billion ski industry, Colorado's assault on snow and ice may point the way for other snowbound sections of the nation.
"Colorado is one of the leading states in appropriately applying technology to problems, as opposed to the brute force of widening highways," said Christine Johnson, director for Intelligent Transportation Systems at the Federal Transportation Department.
Trying to make Interstate 70 here a "smart highway," Colorado authorities last month enlisted cellular-telephone technology to help install 9 message signs and 12 emergency roadside telephones. By next month three low-powered highway radio stations are scheduled to broadcast traffic conditions at 530 kilocycles.
Last month, highway officials started a statewide telephone information network. Running through a menu, callers can hear up to 25 messages. After 10,000 people called the number -- (303) 639-1111 -- in one 24-hour period, the state Transportation Department moved to increase the number of phone lines to 50 from 38.
To keep skiers off the Interstate when traffic slows to a long snake of red tail lights, the department has started using a fax system to warn ski areas along the highway. Ski areas now have chalkboards at the tops of lifts to post road conditions.
"Yesterday was first time the fax worked to our satisfaction," a spokesman for the Breckenridge Ski Resort, Jim Felton, said, referring to a snow-and-ice storm that closed the Interstate for the fifth time this season. "Only 45 minutes after a report of an accident, we got faxes that I-70 was closed in both directions."
Few resort operators want customers to remember three-hour waits in cold cars at 11,000 feet as the unpleasant finale to their last ski vacations. "We want to give people the option to do a little shopping, to get a bite to eat, whatever it takes to keep them off the road," said Joe May, manager of government affairs for Vail, the largest ski resort in Colorado.
Rough driving conditions have led some skiers to abandon the sport.
"I don't want to play bumper cars on I-70," said Daniel Pincher, a political economist in Denver. "Or you ski all day and then get in horrendous traffic jams on the way home. Just stop and go."
Last season a shortage of snowplow drivers prolonged many delays, as the ski season stretched into June. Reflecting the labor shortages and high rents at resorts, half of the snowplow drivers assigned to Interstate 70 had left by March.
"Last year in Vail, McDonald's was paying $10 an hour, and that's a lot less stressful than plowing highways," said Dan Hopkins, a spokesman for the Transportation Department. "We found it impossible to hire drivers."
To make the job more attractive this year, the state has raised drivers' salaries 15 percent, extended health benefits and offered low-rent apartments.
"We are into the beginning of winter with a full staff," Mr. Hopkins said. "This should help us maintain a constant, consistent response to the storms."
Adding horsepower, highway workers will start using next month two trucks that are new to the Rockies. A de-icer truck will spread a solvent to prevent ice on the asphalt, and a "pusher" will push stalled cars and tractor-trailers onto shoulders to open traffic lanes for the plows.
Last year truck accidents helped to raise closings of Interstate 70 to double the level of past winters. Viewing the problem as a threat to the state's financial security, the Legislature is expected to approve next month a bill to increase sixfold, to $252, the penalty for truckers who try to cross the Continental Divide on snowy days without tire chains. Points would also be assessed against violators' licenses.
To enforce the existing law on chain use, the state started roadside inspections last month. and budgeted extra money to insure that the highway patrol checked for violators on weekends and holidays.
"I think the word will spread pretty quickly about Colorado," Mr. Frew of the resort group said. "Our biggest problem has been truckers who don't live here, who don't know the mountain, who don't respect the weather."
Last season a third of the one million out-of-state skiers arrived with limited snow-driving skills, because they were from warmer areas.
Although highway technicians are drawing up plans to post weather advisories on the World Wide Web, there is little that computers can do in face of an ill-timed blizzard. On Nov. 26, the Sunday after Thanksgiving Day, a major storm hit Vail Pass, and the police closed the pass for nine hours just as tens of thousands of drivers were returning to Denver from the holiday weekend.
"People just abandoned their cars," recalled Laura Bishop, a freelance writer from Denver who was on a family visit and who took refuge in a hotel in Breckenridge. "It was wall-to-wall traffic. The snowplows couldn't get through."
As motels filled up, the overflow of snow refugees went to shelters that the Red Cross improvised.
"That day it was 70 degrees in Denver," Ms. Bishop said. "But up in the mountains it was totally different."

HEADLINE: Judge Says Budget Impasse Could Shut Nation's Courts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
A senior judge who represents the policy-making board of the Federal judiciary today warned that the budget stalemate might force the nation's courts to shut down shortly after New Year's Day.
Gilbert S. Merritt, the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, said in an interview that "a breakdown in constitutional order" could occur if money was not authorized soon. 
 His warning came as an additional 20,000 workers were ordered off the job today, bringing the total number of furloughed Federal workers to 280,000, about one in seven people on the Government's nonmilitary payroll. The partial shutdown reached its seventh day today, surpassing the six-day shutdown that involved 800,000 workers in mid-November and making it the longest on record.
The White House and Congress are trading accusations over who is more to blame for the deadlock. The shutdown results from their inability to agree on several spending bills needed to finance Government operations in the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. Meanwhile, they are also arguing about legislation to balance the Federal budget by the year 2002.
The White House has issued a six-page list of Government functions suspended by the budget deadlock, ranging from granting farmers special permission to use restricted pesticides on crops to the reimbursement of banks for Government-guaranteed loans that have defaulted.
Judge Merritt's warning came in a separate statement. The 840 Federal judges would remain available for work, he said, but it is unlikely that the courts would continue to be staffed by clerical, probation and security personnel.
"The judges cannot run the court system alone," said Judge Merritt, who sits in Nashville. "And if the judiciary shuts down, you can't arrest people for Federal crimes because you can't bring them to court."
Republicans said the White House was to blame for the problems. "President Clinton shut down the Government," said Michele Davis, spokeswoman for Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. "He vetoed three bills last week that would have reopened" national parks, museums and monuments and restored the missing services, she added.
The shutdown of the national parks forced the cancellation today of the first of the annual Bracebridge dinners at Yosemite National Park in California. Bracebridge, an Ahwahnee Hotel tradition since 1927, recreates a Renaissance feast and includes an eight-course meal.
About 1,650 guests, picked by lottery from among 60,000 requests, were turned away after park rangers closed the gates to Yosemite on Wednesday.
Although the Clinton Administration cited various aspects of law enforcement among its examples of lapsed activity, it did not mention the threat Judge Merritt found to the judiciary.
"If this goes into the first week in January, we are going to have a serious problem," the judge said in the interview. He spoke as the chairman of the steering committee of the Judicial Conference, the policy-making body for Federal judges.
William H. Rehnquist, the Chief Justice of the United States, has long urged Congress to consider a separate financing bill for the judiciary, but there has been no response so far, the judge said. The judiciary is now running on funds it gets from fees, which are not allocated to any specific year's budget. But this money will soon run out, Judge Merritt said.
The White House list included such highly visible examples of service loss as 23,000 passport applications not being accepted on the average day, 383,000 daily visitors affected by the closing of the national parks and 92,400 people in Washington denied admittance to the Smithsonian museums, the National Zoo and the National Gallery of Art.
Among other effects of the shutdown listed were these:
*Suspension of activity involving sales of timber from national forests.
*No processing by the Federal Housing Administration of 2,500 home purchase loans and refinancings.
*Suspension of civil enforcement actions by the Environmental Protection Agency, except for Superfund cases, that yield an average of $3 million a day in fines or injunctive relief against polluters.
*No processing of 20,000 applications a day for student loans or Pell grants.
*Blockage of more than $92 million a day in foreign sales because of the closure of the center that licenses exports of military items and sensitive technology.
In a related development, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said that publication of the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index, scheduled for Jan. 11 and Jan. 12, respectively, would be delayed about a week even if furloughed employees returned to work by Tuesday. And employment figures for December, scheduled to be made public on Jan. 5, will be delayed if workers do not return by Tuesday.
"The absence of this information potentially could create a degree of short-term paralysis in decision making with resulting long-term adverse effects on the nation's economic well-being," said Commissioner Katharine G. Abraham. "For example, companies could delay investment or hiring decisions, causing a decline in output and national income."

HEADLINE: Peres Says Israel, With Regional Pact, Would End Atom Effort

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel would be prepared to close its nuclear program if there was a regional peace in the Middle East, though he stopped short of confirming that Israel possesses nuclear weapons.
Mr. Peres made his comments at a lunch with Israeli journalists in Tel Aviv, after one of them asked whether his new priorities include a change in nuclear policy. 
 "Yes," he said. "Give me peace and we'll give up the nuclear program. That's the whole story."
Mr. Peres used a word in Hebrew, "garin," that means "nucleus," and in the context was a reference to Israel's nuclear program at the Dimona station in the Negev, where Israel has long been suspected of developing nuclear weapons.
"If there will be a regional peace, I think we can make the Middle East free of the nuclear threat," Mr. Peres continued.
But when a reporter tried to pin him down on whether he meant that he would dismantle the Dimona station, Mr. Peres became evasive. "We've never said Dimona deals with what you attribute to it," he said. "What I'm saying is that after peace arrives, we'll be in a Middle East free of nuclear weapons."
The subject of nuclear weapons was broached by the reporters, not by Mr. Peres, and it remained unclear whether he was presenting a new policy or talking generally of future options.
He also left unclear how broad a regional peace he had in mind before abandoning the nuclear option. Israel has negotiated peace treaties with Egypt and Jordan, and will begin new talks next week with Syria, but none of these countries is known to have any nuclear capacity.
The only countries in the Middle East that have demonstrated an interest in developing nuclear weapons are Iraq and Iran. In 1981 Israel bombed a reactor under construction in Iraq, evidently to deny President Saddam Hussein any possibility of producing weapons.
At the lunch, Mr. Peres reiterated Israel's deep distrust of Iran, noting that it was developing a nuclear capacity despite large reserves of oil and natural gas as power sources. He had reportedly raised the issue with President Clinton at their meeting in Washington last week.
"It is not a rich country, and it goes and invests hundreds of million of dollars in nuclear power," he said of Iraq. "For what, if not for grave, horrible intentions?"
Although Israel has never confirmed possession of a nuclear weapon, the United States and other governments have long suspected that this was the purpose of the Dimona nuclear reactor that Israel built with French help in the 1960's. Mr. Peres was instrumental in building the plant. This week, the Israeli daily Haaretz reported that a study by the Rand Corporation, commissioned by the Pentagon, concluded that Israel had enough plutonium to make 70 nuclear weapons.
Israel has never agreed to sign the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
Mr. Peres noted that as long as its neighbors suspected that Israel had a nuclear weapon, "that in itself can act as a deterrent." He added: "Let them suspect. I don't see any reason to allay their suspicions."

HEADLINE: Talk of Move By Citicorp Alerts Mayor

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Citicorp has long been one of the anchors of New York City's economy, but in recent years, the company's chairman has often spoken of leaving, wondering whether a mammoth financial institution with such global reach would perhaps be better off if it were not so rooted to one place.
Lately, these musings of the chairman, John S. Reed, have begun to attract the attention of the Giuliani administration, which has started talks with Citicorp to insure that it stays put, officials said yesterday. If Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, were to move, it would be a blow to the city's reputation and its ability to retain other large corporations. 
 Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, has more than 20,000 workers in New York City, but Mr. Reed has never spoken about pulling all of them out. What he has said is that the company might move its top officials -- from 50 to 400 senior managers who are its brain trust -- to a place like Boston or Palo Alto, Calif.
John M. Morris, a spokesman for Citicorp, which was founded in New York in 1812, emphasized yesterday that no decisions had been made on relocating any workers.
Mr. Morris said Mr. Reed believed that New York has become too insular for its top managers. The city is known for securities exchanges and capital markets, which may have been Citicorp's focus in the past but are not necessarily what it wants to concentrate on in the future, company officials have said. In recent years, Citicorp has begun shifting toward consumer products and business in other countries.
Mr. Reed has said that if the top people in the company were based in a city with a technological orientation, like Palo Alto, they might be better prepared to compete in the financial services industry in the next century. And Palo Alto also has lower costs than New York.
"John thinks that you have to look out for what business is going to be like in the future," Mr. Morris said. "He is saying that if we were in a different milieu, there would be more thinking about the future, instead of being caught up in the day-to-day operations."
Mr. Morris said that Mr. Reed's thoughts on moving are nothing more than that. But the Giuliani administration is taking no chances.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson had met with Citicorp officials in recent weeks, though he declined to describe the talks.
"We've had discussions with him and with Citibank," the Mayor said, referring to Mr. Reed. "And it's probably better if we do those confidentially rather than negotiate them in the newspapers."

HEADLINE: ...but G.O.P. Falters on Pro-Business Laws

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Republicans took control of Congress last January armed with a sweeping agenda to undo decades of regulation and in many cases tilt the laws toward industry and away from consumers, workers and even investors.
Why, then, has it been so hard to enact pro-business laws? To the dismay of many giant media and telephone companies this week, quarreling among House Republicans has jeopardized a bill that would overhaul decades of outdated regulations. 
 And that is hardly the only ambitious Republican initiative that has hit a roadblock. Bills that would slash environmental regulations, reduce the bargaining power of labor unions and make it harder to sue companies over defective products have all run into obstacles -- both expected and unexpected:
*The House passed a measure in the spring that would block Federal agencies from issuing new regulations on environmental, health or safety issues without first documenting that the costs to business would be exceeded by the benefits, but Senate Republicans have been unable to bring the measure up for a vote.
*Tort legislation that would make it far more difficult for people to sue companies accused of making defective or dangerous products or to file malpractice suits against doctors has been stopped for now. The House and Senate both passed separate bills months ago, but the measures differ so much that the chambers have not even tried to reconcile them yet.
*The House has passed a bill that would require the Federal Government to compensate landowners if the value of their property declines as a result of new environmental rulings, but the Senate Judiciary Committee is still working on its version.
Some conservatives are plainly vexed. "To recall Shakespeare, there has been a lot of sound and fury, signifying nothing," said Edward Hudgins, director of regulatory policy at the Cato Institute, a conservative research group in Washington.
So far this year, Congress has sent only one major business bill to President Clinton -- a securities measure that would make it more difficult for investors to sue companies on charges of fraud and misrepresentation. President Clinton vetoed the measure on Tuesday, but the House overrode the veto on Wednesday, and the Senate followed suit today.
Despite unusual intramural bickering among Republicans, many lawmakers still predict that Congress will pass a telecommunications bill early next year.
If enacted, the huge bill would knock down regulatory barriers that prevent local telephone, long-distance carriers and cable television companies from invading each other's markets. It would also relax many ownership restrictions on television and radio stations and is almost certain to touch off a new wave of giant media mergers and alliances.
But that measure is unusual, in that Republicans inherited the bill from Democrats and both political parties agree on many principles. And even there, Republicans seemed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory this week by attacking a House-Senate conference agreement their own leaders had negotiated.
Why so much struggle?
Some of the gridlock was inevitable. Senate rules make it hard to pass bills without at least 60 of 100 votes, and the Republicans have a majority of only 53 to 46.
That, in turn, has created a fissure between Senate Republicans, who often have little choice but to compromise with Democrats, and the more fiery House Republicans who often need only a simple majority.
But Republicans have also run into unexpected problems. One of them is business itself. The most powerful opponents of the telecommunications bill this year were long-distance telephone companies, which opposed provisions that would give the regional Bell telephone companies fairly easy access into the long-distance market.
Likewise, it was Wall Street securities firms and insurance companies that helped kill a bill to repeal the Glass Steagall Act and allow banks to enter their markets.
On top of all that, many Republicans were startled at the criticism over environmental deregulation. It turned out that affluent suburban Republican voters -- an important constituency -- were as protective of nature as many liberals.
And some business lobbyists admit they were not quite prepared for the new era of Republican dominance in Congress. "For 40 years, we have basically been a reactionary force trying to stop the liberal majority," said Bruce Josten, senior vice president at the Chamber of Commerce. "Now we have to learn how to shape and frame the debate, how to move the ball down the football field."
And as the team learns, the list of big bills that have stalled is growing longer. Lobbyists for industry contend they have made progress this year, and they never expected many of their favorite bills to pass immediately.
"We're only at halftime," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
"If you look at the range of legislative items, you realize it's very broad," Mr. Jasinowski continued. "It's a lot of stuff, with a great deal of complexity and a lot of substantive issues. I never had expectations that these things would pass quickly."
The ideological zeal of freshmen Republicans may have contributed to the logjam. This fall, the House passed a sweeping bill to make it far more difficult to sue companies over defective products and services and to limit punitive damages that a court can award. It would also make it harder to recover money from companies that are tangentially related to the suit and would cover litigation over services as well as products.
The Senate, unable to win support for so broad a measure, passed a bill that would limit only lawsuits over actual products. The two bills were so different that a House-Senate conference committee did not even hold its first meeting until last week. No progress is expected anytime soon, and few people believe that a final bill will go beyond the Senate measure.
The feuding over telecommunications law stemmed from fissures both within industry and within Republican ranks.
By essentially knocking down regulations that currently separate local telephone, long-distance and cable television into separate and protected fiefs, the communications bill has always involved bitter fights among rival segments.
That fighting had ebbed in the last two years as almost every group became more interested in raiding new markets than in protecting its own. But the fighting did not end between local and long-distance telephone companies, and companies like AT&T have waged a bitter and thus far unsuccessful battle for significant change.
Just as it seemed that House Republican negotiators had worked out a compromise, however, they found themselves under fire from their own right wing.
Conservatives outside the conference committee were furious on Thursday that Republican negotiators had agreed to Democratic demands to keep many current ownership restrictions on television and radio broadcasters.
Many Republicans were also angry that Vice President Al Gore had been boasting that Democrats had gotten their way on "every single one" of their demands.
"What you've got is a lot of guys with buyers' remorse," said one Republican operative who is trying to soothe ruffled egos.
Another G.O.P. lawmaker said, "There's a masculinity issue here."
But the upshot was a strange scramble by many of the biggest communication and media companies to build up Republican support. Industry executives say Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner Inc., called Speaker Newt Gingrich to plead for the bill even though the final agreement would extend regulation of cable television prices until 1999. The Bell companies and many individual television broadcasters mobilized as well.
In the end, many experts predict, Congress will pass this bill and perhaps others. But nobody has any illusions that it will be easy.

HEADLINE: Fed Panel Voted in November By 10 to 1 to Hold Rates Level

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided in November that they would not wait for resolution of the Federal budget stalemate if economic conditions warranted to lower interest rates.
A summary released today from the Nov. 15 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee showed the panel voted 10 to 1 to keep rates unchanged but set the stage for a future reduction. 
 On Tuesday, the central bank lowered a key short-term rate to 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent.
In a brief statement after this week's private meeting, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said he and his colleagues had determined that inflationary pressures were even milder than expected and that lower rates were appropriate.
The minutes of the Nov. 15 meeting said, "The members agreed that the committee could not freeze its policy options while it awaited the outcome of a prolonged Federal budget debate nor could it commit itself to a specific response to a particular fiscal policy agreement."
The outcome of the budget fight between President Clinton and Congress -- still unresolved and the cause of a partial Government shutdown this week -- was only one of many considerations in determining the course of interest rates, the summary said.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, was the lone dissenter at the Nov. 15 meeting.
Members of the open market committee agreed that most signs suggested the economy was growing at a slower pace, but they said the surprisingly strong expansion during the summer pointed to a cautious approach toward lowering rates.
But Mr. Lindsey said he favored lowering interest rates because the economy was becoming too sluggish.
Before Tuesday's reduction, the Fed cut rates by a quarter percentage point, to 5.75 percent, on July 6. From February 1994 to February 1995, it had increased rates seven times to stifle inflation.
The panel is composed of 7 Fed governors in Washington and 5 of the Fed's 12 regional bank presidents. One of the governor positions is vacant.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Turn Higher In Slow Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities turned higher yesterday in thin trading during an abbreviated pre-Christmas session that exaggerated movements of prices.
In the shortened session, which ended at 2 P.M., the price of the 30-year bond rose 14/32 , to 1116/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.06 percent from 6.09 percent on Thursday. That was the lowest yield in nearly two weeks. 
 Traders said the market was buoyed by optimism that an agreement to balance the budget could be achieved before the new year.
The market rose despite a stronger-than-expected final reading of 91 points on the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for December, up from 88.2 in November.
The consumer sentiment index, which had been predicted to come in at 90.3, was higher than the preliminary reading of 90.5, traders said. Increases in consumer confidence are generally considered inflationary by the bond market because they signal higher spending.
"The market is anticipating that short-term rates are going lower, to which I fully agree," said Charles Roden, the managing director at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
But Mr. Roden added that increased business acitivity would put pressure on securities with longer maturities.
"The increase in business activity," he said, "will also raise inflation fears and stimulate the demand for money, with rates increasing as demand begins to exceed supply, both negatives for the market. And it is for that reason that I do not believe long-term rates will go much lower. That is why I'm keeping my inventories of debt securities, especially in the long end, very thin."
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said it would be interesting to watch the market's response next week to the budget negotiations between the White House and Congress, particularly if Congress approved a measure financing Government operations temporarily.
"This would allow both the Commerce and Labor Deparmments to start producing their economic statistics as early as next week," Mr. Fine said.
The markets will be closed Monday for the Christmas holiday.
In the futures market, the March bond contract ended firmer in dwindling volume.
Robin Mesch, fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston, said she expected the market to rise next year.
"A modest target price on the bond contract future is 123," Ms. Mesch said, "but we really think 127 is achievable. That may seem grandiose, but that's what the technical charts are saying.
"The question in our minds is, What will tell us we are wrong? One might be if the futures contract breaks below 117. Then we'd have to re-evaluate, but our strategy would be to continue to buy into dips in market prices."

HEADLINE: Black Faith Healer Helped the Oppressed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Harlem Church Is Outpost of Empire" (news article, Dec. 17), on the United House of Prayer for All People, which became a crucial player in a racially charged dispute involving its tenant, Freddy's clothing store in Harlem, the site of the recent tragedy: 
 It is not enough to say that in the 1920's and 30's the church's founder, the preacher Sweet Daddy Grace, won supporters because of his "charismatic preaching and claims of miraculous healing powers."
In the North, Mr. Grace appealed to many black people who migrated from the South and who experienced not only white racism in the "promised land," but also discrimination by black denominations because of their "country ways."
In the South, Sweet Daddy Grace similarly found supporters among those who arrived from the countryside.
Sweet Daddy Grace gave hope to hundreds of thousands whose living conditions were especially perilous: when urban areas, already overcrowded, were becoming even more so; when unemployment figures were staggering; where white-led violence was part of everyday life in many rural counties; where poor sanitation in black neighborhoods caused public health problems, and where segregation policies and economic barriers often obstructed black people from getting medical care.
Faced with a choice between the promises of a faith healer and no medical attention at all, many chose the faith healer.
Finding salvation in a heartless world was one of the ways that many African-Americans found sustenance to continue to struggle against so many odds.
 
ADELE OLTMAN
New York, Dec. 20, 1995

HEADLINE: The Capitalist;
Consultacrats

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis 

 BODY:
A FEW MONTHS AGO THE Economist carried an impressive full-page advertisement for a New York management consulting firm called Towers Perrin and, specifically, its "People Strategy." The ad made no real attempt to explain what that strategy was. Instead, the Towers Perrin ad offered an intriguing little graph. Five words -- "surplus," "alignment," "gaps," "performance" and "importance" -- appeared within the graph, and a single line of text beneath it described it as "a new way to look at organization capabilities." That was it. There was no further explanation. The reader was left tointerpret the little graph on his own. Here it is, at left:
A handful of words and a couple of straight lines, you may say. Not worth troubling over. But then you do not fully understand the strange world of management consulting. Consultants earn their living by dreaming up concepts that people who actually do business feel that they cannot live without. Often these concepts are deceptively simple. In the60's a Boston consulting firm stood corporate America on its ear with a square divided into quadrants containing tiny pictures of a dog, a cow, a star and a question mark. Otherwise intelligent people spent a lot of valuable time classifying their businesses as animal, mineral or punctuation. 
 Not since then, I think, has a diagram held as much mystery and allure as the Towers Perrin graph. Towers Perrin employs 5,600 people and currently advises 700 of America's 1,000 largest companies. Its ability to sow its concepts into the collective corporate mind should not be doubted.
AT THIS POINT YOU MAY WISH TO STUDY THE graph more closely. I did. Given that it is associated with something called People Strategy, it seems most likely that it has to do with people. If so, the graph would appear to divide people into three basic states of human existence. People with a great deal of performance but no importance (for instance, the man who excelled in rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic) enjoy a "surplus." People with a great deal of importance but scant performance (Sylvester Stallone? King Hussein of Jordan?) suffer "gaps." People whose importance is perfectly consistent with their performance are aligned. Alignment would seem to represent people's ideal state, a sort of Aristotelian mean. But maybe you see it differently.
Sadly, my own naive reading of the graph raises as many questions as it answers. Which is worse, gaps or surpluses? How do you know when you are aligned? Is there any justice in the world when someone who holds his performance steady falls out of alignment simply because he rises in importance? Certain I had failed to get to the bottom of the matter, I decided to call Towers Perrin.
The man who answered the phone was helpful and efficient -- fully aligned, I would say. He told me that what I was failing to understand was known around Towers Perrin as "gap analysis." He sent me a package of information about gap analysis. It contained many larger but equally indecipherable graphs. In the midst of these loomed a colossal version of our little graph, with the following explanation:
 
In the "real world," a team of managers knowledgeable about different aspects of the organization gather and evaluate an array of data. This iterative process involves identifying and analyzing essential capabilities, which the team then evaluates and "scores" in terms of importance and performance. The results are captured in a graphic, like the one that follows, that highlights strengths and weaknesses. The goal is to align importance with performance -- the red "alignment" band running through the center. Anything out of sync falls into the "gap" band or "surplus" band.
Leave aside for the moment the carpet-bombing approach to the English language. The careful reader will now see the point of the little graph. It can be summarized in plain English: if a job is important, a company should do it well. If a company does important jobs badly, or wastes a lot of time on unimportant ones, it will not make as much money as it could.
This is an important truism, no doubt often ignored by corporate executives. But does the graph truly help them to grasp it? Apparently so. According to Pat Milligan, the Towers Perrin expert on gap analysis, "If you interviewed a C.E.O., he could tell you whether or not he was aligned, but he can't communicate it to the people below him in the organization. This is the one tool the clients have really glommed on to. They love to be able to use a graphic representation to do the analysis and to measure on an ongoing basis how well they are closing the gap." Hence its prominence in the Towers Perrin ad campaign.
NOW, THE POINT OF MOST GRAPHS IS TO simplify complicated information. The supply and demand curves in economics, for example, are elegant summaries of entire markets. The Towers Perrin graph is just the reverse: it takes a simple idea and makes it very, very complicated. The graph itself is an example of "surplus." Had it been created not by a management consulting firm but by, say, the Labor Department, Newt Gingrich would have held it up to ridicule as an example of government waste. And rightly so.
Then again, I may be missing the point all over again. Businesspeople have special needs. Anyone who has ever sat beside a corporate executive on a transatlantic flight knows that businesspeople often cannot explain clearly what they do for a living. Usually this is not because what they do is complicated. It is because they want to believe that what they do is complicated, and they want you to believe it, too.
Perhaps the little Towers Perrin graph satisfies this desire, and that is why it has been so warmly received in corporate America. That is, it was never really meant to be understood. It was always meant not to be understood. It succeeds on its own terms. It is, you might say, fully aligned.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By TERENCE NEILAN

 BODY:

European Soccer
Q. My husband and I would like to attend the 1996 European soccer championships in England. How can we buy tickets? -- Claudia Genna relli, Brooklyn

A. It's a complicated business.
The first of the 1.3 million tickets for the event initially went on sale by mail in England last year to season-ticket holders at English clubs. This year they were made available to the general public in England, with application forms distributed through the Midland Bank. 
 Tickets on sale this way are intended for the English market. But if you have friends in England you could try asking them to pick up a form and mail it to Euro 96, Post Box 1996, Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffs. ST5 1LE. The telephone line for ticket information in England is (0178) 274-1996. Tickets cost from $24 to $208 each, calculated at $1.60 to the pound. Credit cards are accepted.
The championships will be held from June 8 to 30 in eight English cities. Each of the 15 other countries that qualifies for the competition will be allocated 7,000 tickets, plus 11,000 for each of the two teams in the final.
Once Europe's demands are satisfied, governing bodies in countries that are not taking part in the championships and have expressed an interest in getting tickets can apply. Among them is the United States Soccer Federation, which is referring all inquiries to the official inbound tour operator for Euro 96, Gullivers Sports Travel, which is based in England but has offices in Vista, Calif.
Gullivers is offering two packages, although it will not know for certain how many tickets it will have available until Feb. 28. The company says refunds will be made if enough tickets are not available.
Its top package, called the Grand Finale, for which the company says tickets are assured, includes round-trip economy air fare from New York, six nights' accommodations in luxury hotels, seats at a semifinal game at Wembley, London, and the final game, also at Wembley. The price is $5,995 a person for two people sharing a room.
The Affordable Euro 96 Package includes six nights' accommodation in either rooms with private bath at the Kingswood Halls of Residence, part of London's Royal Holloway College, or in three-star or four-star London hotels. Accommodation prices at Kingswood start at $699 a person. Three-star accommodation costs $895 a person for a double; the four-star option is $995 a person.
Air fare is extra, and tickets are made available through a $395 add-on package, which includes round-trip transportation to Wembley Stadium for the semifinal on June 26 and the final on June 30.
More information: Gullivers Sports Travel, 973 Vale Terrace, Suite 202, Vista, Calif. 92084; (800) 235-3158, fax (619) 941-2997.

Traveling to Vietnam
Q. I plan to visit Vietnam in January. Is it true credit cards are not accepted there? And that payment for hotels and travel by an independent traveler there cannot be made in advance? What is the status of traveler's checks? -- J. S. French, Franklin, Mich.

A. The age of plastic has reached Vietnam.
American Express, Mastercard and Visa credit cards are accepted in some of the leading hotels in Hanoi and Ho Ci Minh City, according to the Vietnamese Embassy in Washington. And traveler's checks are beginning to make inroads.
However, if you are an independent traveler who is not part of a package tour, or traveling with a group, hotel bills and travel costs within Vietnam must be paid in Vietnamese dong or dollars.

Ramadan in Egypt
Q. Please tell me how Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting, will affect my independent visit to Cairo and Luxor next February. Are there days on which major sites, including bazaars, are closed? -- Barbara Pierson, Bellport, N.Y.

A. Museums and other tourist sites might close an hour early during Ramadan, from Jan. 21 to Feb. 21 next year, but according to the Egyptian Tourist Authority, travelers are encouraged to visit during that time. The streets tend to be less crowded during the day, and at night a festive mood takes over.
The first meal of the day for Muslims is served at sunset, so from 5 to 7 P.M. people tend to be at home. At 7, however, they take to the streets until about 2 A.M., after consuming the second meal of the day, the tourist office said.
Because Ramadan is a period of charity as well as fasting, many of the rich in big cities provide banquets in the streets for the poor, with some families trying to outdo their neighbors in generosity.
Ramadan is followed by a three-day period of feasting and entertainment called Eid. TERENCE NEILAN

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
Yugoslavia's Disintegration, From All Angles

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen; Roger Cohen, a correspondent for The New York Times in Paris, covered the Balkan wars and is writing a book about them.

 BODY:
THE BODIES LIE SCATTERED. A woman's leather purse is discarded on the road. The corpses and the bag have equal value in this small town in eastern Bosnia because these Muslim bodies are now no more than objects. Serb men pass by, loading them onto trucks, one body after another, like sacks of produce. It is arduous, unappealing work. They puff; they grimace; they seem just a little uneasy. But the job must be done. This is Zvornik in April 1992, at the start of the war in Bosnia. There were 49,000 Muslims in the town. Now there are none.
The camera cuts to Vojislav Seselj, an extreme nationalist Serbian politician who led paramilitary forces in Bosnia at the beginning of the war. Yes, he concedes, the "ethnic cleansing" of Zvornik and other Bosnian towns by Serbian "special commando units" happened. He talks in a matter-of-fact way, recalling the details. "Milosevic was in control," he continues, referring to the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, "and the operation was planned in Belgrade." 
 Again the camera cuts, now to Mr. Milosevic. His jaw juts. His skin is so closely shaven as to appear raw. His eyes have an impenetrable gleam. "There is no one who can believe what is mentioned as organized genocide, even organized from Belgrade, even organized by me!" he says, his voice rising as he dismisses accounts of the eviction and killing of Muslims on the 70 percent of Bosnian territory seized by the Serbs at the start of the war. "It is really out of all consideration."
This remarkable sequence illustrates the unusual power of "Yugoslavia: Death of a Nation," a series of five one-hour documentaries made by Brian Lapping Associates in London for BBC Television. The series, already shown to acclaim in Britain and several other Western European countries, is to be broadcast in the United States by the Discovery Channel this week, Tuesday through Saturday, at 10 each night. So vivid are the images, so extraordinary the access granted by all the chief protagonists of Yugoslavia's destruction, that the impression is often one of watching a state unravel, stage by gruesome stage, through the very eyes of those whose decisions precipitated the Balkans into more than four years of bloodshed.
The achievement, by a team that in 1994 made an Emmy-winning documentary series on the Watergate scandal, is an important one. The wars of Yugoslavia's destruction have already been much obscured. Serbs, Croats and Muslims all have their own versions of the truth. Western governments, concerned to justify their hesitations, have often portrayed the conflict in whatever way suited their policies. When, for a long period, the war was intractable to the Clinton Administration, "genocide" became a "problem from hell" with its origins in the 11th century.
But here, through videotape never previously seen in the West, and through the words of those who took more than 200,000 people to their deaths, the facts are allowed to speak for themselves, and responsibilities are made clear. For the future of the Balkans, an area where violence feeds on a much-obfuscated past marked by savage conflict, the documentary may conceivably provide a solid basis for reasoned debate in the place of renewed killing. "Death of a Nation" has already been shown in Serbia, where it was widely vilified by the authorities, and it is about to be broadcast in Croatia and Bosnia.
"I'm interested above all in how big decisions are made," says Norma Percy, the producer of the series for Lapping Associates, "because I believe things are generally dictated by a few people or one man. So we try to speak to everyone involved, which is a very good research technique, in that you check statements against each other. Social sweep and history are not really our focus." A diminutive woman, she speaks in a mild, almost distracted way, but there is also a sudden intensity about her at times that suggests she is not easily shaken from an idea or the scent of a story.
When she made "The Second Russian Revolution," an acclaimed series on Soviet perestroika, she asked Politburo members to tell her what happened inside the Kremlin in the same way they told their wives when they arrived home in the evening. The bosses of the Soviet empire were initially aghast. "I guess they never told their wives," Ms. Percy says. But as glasnost grabbed them, they talked. In the same way, the leaders of the former Yugoslavia open up, often with a shocking frankness, almost as if their consciences have been racked by the wars they unleashed and a catharsis on camera is welcome.
THEIR EVIDENT FASCINATION with Western television is intriguing. Throughout the wars, all sides have tried to use television, particularly CNN, to get their points across. Most members of the Bosnian Government became sound-bite masters; the Croats were also proficient; the Serbs, generally inept. No doubt each of the parties saw an opportunity in a long documentary to establish its case. But in these five programs, researched and made over a two-year period, different views are juxtaposed with such immediacy that the viewer has the sense of being a witness with constant access to all sides of a case.
It is terrible to watch the tragedy unfold. In one split second in 1987, it is possible to see what might have been the first germ of the horror. Mr. Milosevic is in Kosovo, the then-autonomous southern area of Serbia whose population is 90 percent ethnic Albanian. He is addressing a crowd of Serbs, who say that the mainly Albanian Communist Party authorities and police have beaten them. Mr. Milosevic hesitates. For a moment he seems to be at a loss. As a Communist apparatchik, he must side with the party. But as a Serb, his instinct is to side with his people. At last, he opts for the call of his blood and takes the plunge. "Nobody has the right to beat you," he says, rebuking his own party and thus the one authority that has held Yugoslavia together since World War II. "It will not happen again."
This fascinating piece of videotape was found in Belgrade by Michael Simkin, a researcher for the series, although the authorities in the Serbian capital had said that no shots of the 1987 visit to Kosova existed. Similarly, the videotape of the ethnic cleansing of Zvornik was found lying around in Reuters' Belgrade office by Paul Mitchell, a director of the series. A Serb cameraman from Reuters Television had been invited to watch the killing by the paramilitary leader known as Arkan, who led the rampage. Other remarkable shots of secret meetings of the highest Yugoslav authorities were also unearthed.
"The amazing thing about the Yugoslavs is they film everything," Mr. Mitchell says. "They filmed it because they believed they would thus be able to show who had allowed Yugoslavia to be destroyed." The advent of the hand-held video camera, widely used by all sides during the wars, clearly helped produce this stunningly complete archive.
After Kosovo, Mr. Milosevic is transformed into the hero and chief vehicle of a resurgent Serbian nationalism. Yugoslavia, always a delicate mosaic of nations and religions, cracks under this pressure. First Slovenia, then Croatia, begin to go their own way. The Serbian President explains his actions in an interview. Kosovo, he says, is not just another Serbian region, it is "all our history." Moreover, the Albanians were practicing a "Nazi policy" of persecution of the Serbs.
These phrases are very telling. They point to the way history, even of the medieval period, will be used by all sides, but particularly the Serbs, to justify often barbaric acts, and how language will be debased during the wars in the interests of propaganda. There are indeed many beautiful Serbian monasteries in Kosovo, and it was an important center of the medieval empire. But that does not change the fact that 90 percent of the population is now ethnic Albanian, just as Hebron, in the West Bank, once a Jewish city, now has a population that is overwhelmingly Palestinian. To call these Albanians Nazis is simply to stir hatred with blind invective.
The documentary also illustrates vividly how the Croats fanned the sparks of war. Croatia's extensive arms-smuggling program before its secession from Yugoslavia in mid-1991 and the outbreak of war is explained with great frankness by the people who organized the traffic. Again, remarkable videotape made at the Hungarian border confirms the smuggling. The role of Gojko Susak, the Croatian defense minister, in starting the fighting in Eastern Slavonia by attacking a mainly Serb village with a grenade is revealed. Over all, Croatia's insensitivity to the fears of its Serb minority becomes clear.
What is less clear is the roots of these Serbian fears. There is scant allusion in the documentary to the impact on the Serbian psyche of the genocidal attack on Serbs by Croatian Fascist Ustashe forces during World War II. This was certainly a factor in the outbreak of the war in Croatia.
But Ms. Percy prefers to focus intensely on the personalities and the decisive meetings behind Yugoslavia's implosion. The agonized history of the area, the backdrop of economic depression that allowed nationalist leaders like Mr. Milosevic and Croatian President Franjo Tudjman to exploit resentments, the ideological vacuum that went with the fall of Communism in Europe -- all these broad issues in Yugoslav society are treated only glancingly. The result is a documentary of sometimes claustrophobic intensity but also one that might have benefited from a few more voices of ordinary people.
Still, the voices of the protagonists are amazingly revealing. Thus Radovan Karadzic, the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, says quite simply that 10,000 NATO troops, deployed at the start of the war, would have stopped the conflict at once. "Five thousand troops in Zvornik, five thousand in the Posavina corridor, and we Serbs were finished," he says.
But this was not about to happen. Arriving in a besieged Sarajevo in December 1992, Lord Owen, the European mediator, tells the exhausted population: "Don't, don't, don't live under this dream that the West is going to come and sort this problem out. Don't dream dreams." The disarray of the European Union and the United States before a resurgence of war in Europe is captured in these words. It was a disarray that would lead to tragedy after tragedy, culminating with the massacre of Muslims from Srebrenica last summer. In fact, the West did not get decisively involved until August 1995, when NATO embarked on a concerted bombing campaign against the Serbs: then the war was quickly ended, albeit on terms that appear tenuous.
Alija Izetbegovic, the President of Bosnia, emerges as a mild-mannered man, given to an indecisiveness that led his people into a war for which they were not prepared. One rather labored section on his capture early in the war by Serbian forces suggests how close the ragtag, Muslim-led Bosnian forces came at that moment to outright defeat.
The makers of "Death of a Nation" worked with an unusual technique. They began with a series of "research interviews" in which major themes were thrashed out and a certain familiarity established. Only some time later did they move on to filmed interviews. Often, they would ask all the people who had been present at a meeting the same question. Thus when Mr. Milosevic denied that a crucial meeting with Mr. Tudjman had taken place in 1991, a meeting in which they discussed how Bosnia would be carved up between them, the interviewers could simply tell him that Mr. Tudjman had revealed details of the meeting. Mr. Milosevic then conceded that the encounter had indeed happened.
The programs -- accompanied by a good book, "Yugoslavia: Death of a Nation," by Laura Silber and Allan Little, two of the wars' veteran journalists -- contain several scoops. Borislav Jovic, the senior aide to Mr. Milosevic, reveals how the two men decided to "pull a fast one" and arm the Serbs of Bosnia and Croatia in preparation for war. That way, Serbia's role was less clear, Mr. Jovic points out with disarming openness.
Another almost unbelievable piece of film shows the Yugoslav State Council debating in March 1991 whether to stage a military coup to stop the disintegration of the country. Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, the federal defense minister and a Serb, argues passionately for the military action, saying Croatia is leading the state to disintegration. But the cumbersome collective body, in a labored voting procedure, finally opts by a single vote to reject the coup. Seldom, if ever, has such a moment, replete with all its curious banality and intense poignancy, been revealed on camera in such a way.
Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Jovic then expected, and encouraged, General Kadijevic to act alone and stage a coup. But the general, bound by the addiction to procedure of many lifelong Communists, hesitates to override the constitution. The rest, so to speak, is history.

HEADLINE: THE RADICAL CENTER OR THE MODERATE MIDDLE?

 BODY:
A major premise of Michael Lind's article "The Radical Center or the Moderate Middle?" (Dec. 3) is that a political party can't appeal to both. I disagree. I say the party that commits to solving our No. 1 economic problem, falling real wages, will win over both groups. People vote their pocketbooks, and falling wages are hurting most Americans.

LOUIS COHEN
New York

HEADLINE: In the Region;
In Westchester, Office Space Is Less Wide Open

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
REPORTS on the 1995 office market in Westchester County have just been issued, and brokers are sounding celebratory about an overall strengthening of the market and a greater interest in Westchester buildings from outside developers.
Three of the four reporting companies show a decrease in the county's office vacancy rate and all point to improvements, especially in downtown White Plains, which is considered a linchpin of the county's economic health. 
 In one report by Rostenberg-Doern of Purchase, the county's overall vacancy rate this year is 18.7 percent, down from 22.3 percent at the end of 1994.
"I think this year represents that our time has finally come," said John Rostenberg, principal with the firm. "For so long we've lagged behind everyone in the tri-state area. We're finally catching up."
He pointed out that Fairfield County, Conn., which has had a much faster recovery than Westchester, absorbed less space this year than Westchester. "Total absorbtion in Westchester this year was 720,000 square feet," Mr. Rostenberg said. "In Fairfield, it was 445,000."
Mr. Rostenberg attributes much of Westchester's improvement this year to Oxford Health Plans, a major managed-care company that signed a lease in the third quarter for 267,000 square feet of space in downtown White Plains.
"That deal alone represented a pickup of 14 percent of the vacancy in the entire county," Mr. Rostenberg said. "In one fell swoop, one deal can make an enormous difference." Of course, that difference was felt most keenly in the White Plains market, where the vacancy rate dropped to 26 percent this year, from 30.6 percent last year.
This is the third year in a row in which vacancy rates have dropped, according to Rostenberg-Doern. After spiking to 26.9 percent in 1993, largely because of I.B.M. consolidations, Mr. Rostenberg said, rates have declined by 8 percentage points since then. "I think people are starting to realize that Westchester has more Class A space available and better values than neighboring counties," he added.
Other reporting companies release varying figures, based on the use of different criteria. For instance, some companies include owner-occupied buildings, while others do not.
According to the Edward S. Gordon Company's White Plains office, the overall vacancy rate this year is 16.6 percent, compared with 16.8 percent last year, while Cushman & Wakefield reports a rate of 17.6 percent, down from 18.6 percent last year.
Only CB Commercial, in White Plains, reported an increase, of 23.2 percent from 22.6 percent, last year. "Due to our use of different criteria our statistics are different," said Frank Tomassulo, first vice president of CB Commercial. "But our report shows an overall strengthening of the market. For instance, there was 9 percent more leasing activity in White Plains this year than in 1994, and that's one of the most significant markets in the county."
Michael H. Siegel, executive director of Edward S. Gordon's Westchester/Fairfield office, said: "Oxford impacted the numbers as much as 3 percentage points. It's going to take another big transaction for the market to really see a rebound back to its previous levels before the downturn in the real estate market in the late 1980's and early 1990's."
EVEN though big deals are still needed for the market to fully recover, Mr. Siegel said that would not be the trend. "Westchester's market is fundamentally changed from what it had been in the boom years of the 1980's," he said. "Now it's a market made up primarily of small transactions."
Of the 431 transactions recorded by the Gordon company this year, 337 were for less than 5,000 square feet of space. And the leasing amounted to almost two million square feet without Oxford, Mr. Seigel said.
According to brokers, another sign of Westchester's recovery was the announcement this quarter of the purchase of six office buildings and a majority stake in two others by the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Melville, L.I. There was also the purchase of a vacant building by another Long Island concern and a decision by an Italian developer, SCI S.p.A., to complete construction of an office building that was stalled in 1990.
Halpern Enterprises, one of the last family-owned developers in Westchester, agreed to sell most of its office portfolio, representing 940,000 square feet, to Reckson for $83 million. The Long Island company, which was once a family-owned business, reorganized as a publicly held trust in May. Jon L. Halpern, president of Halpern Enterprises, will head up Reckson's new Westchester division.
"This is a recognition of the changing face of real estate," said Carl Austin, president of Austin Corporate Properties of White Plains, which brokered the deal. "It brings to the table an institutional presence with a pro-active entrepreneurial approach to real estate."
Mr. Austin predicts more such mergers and consolidations. "Real estate companies will continue to evolve to meet the market," he said. He also predicted the conversion of some office buildings, which have been languishing on the market. "Some could become residential condominiums," he said.
Another major deal in the fourth quarter was the purchase of 2900 Westchester Avenue, in Harrison, a 97,000-square-foot building, which had been vacant for several years. It was bought for a reported $3.6 million by the 2900 Westchester Company, of Hicksville, L.I.
The new owner plans to refurbish the building, including redesigning the lobby, building a cafeteria and doing significant rewiring, according to Jim Baranello, the company's director of operations.
He said he was hoping to attract the "high-end client," like law firms and investment companies. "We think the time is right," Mr. Baranello said. "Westchester has done a slow improvement. And we feel that many of the people who live in Westchester now and commute to Manhattan are getting sick of it. If they had the option of moving into a refurbished building that met their needs, they would."
