HEADLINE: At a Riverdale Co-op, Resident Owners Take Hold

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
AS a builder, the late Alfred Kaskel never promoted his name, so it never became as familiar to the public as Levitt, Lefrak or Trump. Instead, he named his company after his daughter, Carol, and Carol Management came to be one of New York City's largest residential builders during the booming 50's and 60's. It built about 18,000 apartments in the city, in all boroughs except Staten Island, and a few thousand more in the wider metropolitan area.
But after his death in 1968 the company gradually sold these buildings, either by converting them to co-ops or by selling them to companies planning conversions. Among these was the ambitious Skyview development in northern Riverdale, built in the early 60's. Skyview consists of three 20-story buildings with 1,300 apartments and indoor parking for 1,050 cars, plus tennis courts and a freestanding health club with an outdoor pool. It stands on 32 acres of high ground along Arlington Avenue, and offers residents views up and down the Hudson River. 
 Coronet Properties bought Skyview in 1984 to convert it to a co-op, but like many others who bought at 80's prices for conversion, Coronet was forced eventually to turn back its unsold apartments to its lenders, having sold about 40 percent of them before the market collapse of the late 80's.
Last year Skyview began yet another phase in its history. The sponsor's unsold apartments went into the hands of a new investor, the debt burden on all shareholders was lightened by a restructuring of the underlying mortgage on the property, and control of the board of directors passed to the resident shareholders themselves.
Accordingly, Skyview stands now as a leading example of a major ex-rental property in the city that was a "late converter" in the 80's: it has an occupancy of 36 percent longterm rent-stabilized tenants who never bought, mixed with newcomers or former renters who did buy, plus a smattering of sublessees from the sponsor or former owner-occupants. Its major holder of unsold shares has begun to benefit from the stronger rental market. And the board is embarked on a 10-year improvement plan that it hopes will strengthen its position in the so-far dreary sales market as well.
"There is a lot of potential here if you renovate," said one recent buyer, Scott Hoenig, 38, who bought a studio apartment two years ago with his wife, Karen, for $58,000. They proceeded to spend over $6,000 in a do-it-yourself upgrade job, and now use the apartment during the week to be close to their jobs in the city. They also own a house in Pennsylvania.
Another recent buyer is Ramona Perez, who works in the credit department of a paper company in Purchase, N.Y., and bought a 19th-floor one-bedroom from the sponsor for $74,000 in May after living in the building as a renter for two years. "Since I'm paying about the same as I was when I was renting, I thought I might as well buy," she said.
It is that philosophy, common enough among apartment seekers though notably absent among people who have already lived for years in a building as regulated renters, that Benjamin Orbach is convinced will in due time build the level of resident ownership at Skyview.
Mr. Orbach is a former Bank Leumi lending officer who joined The El-Ad Group, based in Fort Lee, N.J., and backed by Israeli investors, after it acquired the unsold sponsor-held shares at Skyview. El-Ad also owns unsold apartments in other properties for a total of 2,000 throughout the metropolitan area, Mr. Orbach said.
At present, he usually rents out rather than sells his vacancies, he said, typically getting rents of $725 to $750 for studios; $950 to $1,100 for one-bedrooms; $1,250 to $1,400 for two-bedrooms; $1,450 to $1,600 for three-bedrooms, and $1,900 to $1,950 for the occasional four-bedroom.
But as rents strengthen and interest rates hold steady or decline, he says, the economic case for purchasing grows stronger. A vacant two-bedroom apartment that would rent for $1,300 a month, for example, would have a monthly maintenance charge of about $800 as a co-op.
If the $500 difference were applied to debt service rather than rent, it would "buy" a $71,000 fixed-rate co-op loan (30 years at 7 1/2 percent), or even more with an adjustable-rate loan. Every additional $100 that the buyer has available for debt service would purchase an additional $14,200 in loan.
Such an apartment might be sold by El-Ad for $90,000 to $110,000 in the current market, Mr. Orbach said. With about $20,000 to use as a down payment, the apartment seeker could own rather than rent. The buyer will lose the taxable interest that might have been earned on a bank deposit of the cash needed for the down payment, but will have gained the opportunity to recover the investment when the unit is sold. If prices rise, the buyer may find that the original investment has appreciated significantly once the loan balance is repaid.
Meanwhile, during the period of ownership, interest on the loan and on about half the monthly maintenance cost is tax-deductible, saving about $3,600 a year for the buyer of the two-bedroom apartment who is in a 30 percent bracket.
Current prices are about 20 percent lower than they were seven years ago, said Jean Morrison of Morrison Associates, who was the sales broker in most of Coronet's conversions and is still the on-site sales manager at Skyview. However, the board of directors has taken a more relaxed view about subleasing during a weak sales market than some co-op boards, so that about 8 percent of the apartments have been subleased out by people who have moved.
OF the total 1,300 apartments, 49.8 percent have been sold to individual shareholders. It is close enough to the 50 percent figure that usually opens bank doors for co-op financing to have made it easier for sellers to sell and buyers to buy, the management says. Loan availability is also important to buyers who took 10-year sponsor financing in the mid-80's and now need to refinance.
Buyers who came into the building expecting to stay for the long term naturally have the greatest stake in its future. Brian J. McCarthy, 32, who became president of the board a year ago, and his wife, Peggy, bought a one-bedroom apartment in 1989 and combined it with another one-bedroom two years ago, so they and their young daughter and son now have a three-bedroom, two-bath apartment. Mr. McCarthy estimated his total purchase and reconstruction cost at $150,000.
A burst of about 25 sales to longterm renters occurred a few years ago when banks holding unsold shares were offering bargain prices to lift the ratio of owner-occupancy and thereby make the remaining unsold shares more valuable to an investor. One of the renter buyers was Ellen Wholey, assistant principal at P.S. 8 off Mosholu Parkway, a 21-year renter who was able to buy her own two-bedroom, one-bath apartment for $49,500. The sponsor's initial prices were too high for many renters, she said. "I have no intention of moving," she said, so ownership seemed more desirable than renting.
The building has to overcome a stigma left by the unpopularity of Coronet Properties, the original sponsor, with many nonpurchasing renters before its default. It invested a reported $12 million to improve its public spaces, but it also sought to deprive renters of the use of a clubhouse on the property, the Sky Club, to which renters had long grown accustomed. A tenants committee filed a successful diminution-of-services claim with the state rent office, and a rent reduction was ordered for 400 tenants.
Eventually the case was settled, and the atmosphere has improved. "At this point we have reached a good rapport with the management and things are working pretty well," said Jeanne Seelav, president of the Skyview Tenants Association.
The principal in Coronet Properties, Norman Dansker, also was the target of a 42-count criminal indictment brought by the New York State Attorney General, alleging fraud through the concealment of essential financial information from buyers. Most of the charges were dismissed before the trial in State Supreme Court. Last March a jury acquitted him on the remaining charges.
On the management side, the Skyview board has brought in Blue Woods Management Group, headed by Donald E. Wilson, who formerly managed the property for John J. Grogan & Associates of Manhattan, and now is stationed at Skyview. "Skyview has gone through many lives, many phases," he said. "It's got financial controls now, it's making physical improvements, and it's got a strong board. I think it's on the right track."

HEADLINE: Support for Reich

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Instead of reviewing Charles A. Reich's "Opposing the System" (Nov. 26), Francis Fukuyama presented an ideological essay attacking what he views as the counterculture of the 60's and its corrosive remnants. Mr. Reich's forward-looking book argues that corporate control of our political economy is worsening and has subordinated human values to shortsighted commercialism, which has largely corporatized government in the same devolutionary direction. 
 Since Mr. Fukuyama refuses to recognize the effect of large corporations in eroding our democracy by their power of money over politics, their flight abroad over domestic labor, their maintenance of a large corporate welfare state while the social safety net for children is being torn apart and their weakening of legal systems governing the protection of workers, consumers, environment and competition in an era of giant mergers, his essay became an op-ed piece, bypassing Mr. Reich like a ship passing another in the night.
There are serious economic deprivations and abuses for which welfare mothers and other people fallen on hard times cannot be blamed. Given the gross inequalities of wealth (the top 1 percent have wealth equal to the bottom 95 percent in the United States), an unabated corporate crime wave dutifully documented in the business press and a thriving corporate welfare system, Mr. Reich sees more declining living standards for most Americans. Unless Mr. Fukuyama sees that a society rots from the head down and that corporate power needs analysis, he will never understand Mr. Reich's thesis in order to review it.
 
RALPH NADER
Washington

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Wall St. Shedding Its Budget Blinders

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
All year, the markets blithely ignored Washington's budget histrionics.
No matter how strident the warnings -- Newt Gingrich's prediction a few weeks ago of a "market crash" if the White House failed to give way to the Republican agenda, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's admonition about the danger of playing political games with the debt limit and the prospect of national default -- investors just kept buying. Wall Street was convinced it understood the odd theatrics of Pennsylvania Avenue, and had seen it all before. When the table-pounding ended, investors were certain, a plan would emerge to balance the budget by early in the next millennium. 
 But somehow the market's immunity to political impasse wore off last week. When hopes of a budget deal suddenly faded on Monday, the Dow plunged 101 points. When the Federal Reserve trimmed interest rates by the slightest possible margin on Tuesday, and President Clinton and the Republicans seemed serious about talking to each other, the news touched off a 34-point rally. And when, predictably, the deal started falling apart again the next day, a selloff swept the market, followed by hourly gyrations as one side or the other snarled, feinted toward negotiating or went home for Christmas.
So what changed? Why was the market suddenly spooked? And after reacting too late, is it now overreacting?
The first change, of course, is in the market itself. Ever since the Dow broke the 5,000-point level, brokers and analysts have been poised for an excuse to sell. Now the bad-news rule is fully in effect: Bad news that everyone ignores when optimism reigns and the markets are on an upswing seems world-shattering when everyone is on edge.
The second change came in the gradual dawning on Wall Street that political negotiations in Washington for the last year have been driven by dynamics different from those at any other time in recent memory. Anybody looking merely at the figures -- a few hundred billion dollars here, a few hundred billion there -- might be tempted to think that the obvious solution is to split the difference and move on.
But this is a fight about ideology, not numbers. And in such battles, adversaries may well calculate that no deal is better than compromise. Some of Mr. Clinton's political advisers are counseling exactly that strategy.
"In my old life, I probably would not have understood what is driving this process," Mr. Rubin, a former investment banker, said the other day. "On the Street, we would have closed this deal a few weeks ago." So one way to explain the market's sudden volatility is that it has finally realized that it may have misread the political cues about the likelihood of an accord.
In strictly economic terms, investors have little to fear. Clearly, the deficit is on the way down -- it has been heading south for three years, and the Republicans are only accelerating the process. Right now, everyone is just arguing about the details.
But perceptions often trump reality in this town, so the real lesson of the week is that Republicans and Democrats can no longer squabble endlessly, confident that Wall Street will impose no external discipline on the process. Though most politicians here are loath to admit it, nothing would bring about the semblance of an agreement faster than a few hundred points of "market correction," especially in a new year in which a Congress with a shaky mandate and a President with shaky polls all face the voters.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Borrowing Time to Pay Back Student Loans

BYLINE: By ANNA D. WILDE 

 BODY:
JEANNETTE GALANIS was not worried freshman year when she started the process of borrowing $21,000 to attend the University of Colorado.
Nine months after her 1994 graduation, she changed her mind. She had just received her first bill, for $70, from one lender. Then she got another bill, for $50, on a different loan. Within days, two more bills from two more lenders arrived. 
 From her $17,500 annual salary, or $1,050 a month after payroll taxes, she owed a total of $325 monthly to four lenders. That was 31 percent of her take-home pay.
"I was completely panicking," said Ms. Galanis, who is 25. "I thought, 'What can I get rid of in my life that I don't need to be paying?' "
The first things to go were the vegetables. Ms. Galanis, president of the United States Student Association, a student lobbying group based in Washington, cut her grocery bill to $40 a month, eating mostly pasta and crackers. She turned down the heat in her apartment, took in extra roommates and cut out long-distance telephone calls. But she missed two payments, despite emergency loans from friends.
Desperate to avoid default, she sought to reduce her monthly payments and settled on a form of refinancing that is becoming increasingly popular with former students. Ms. Galanis consolidated her loans through the United States Department of Education, refinancing them with one large loan at a lower interest rate, but with a longer repayment schedule.
Although the consolidation will end up costing her more over the 25-year life of the loan, it allowed Ms. Galanis to send all her money to one lender and slashed her monthly payment. She now pays just $100 a month. "My parents are happy I'm now eating vegetables," she said.
As student debt loads have risen, more and more recent graduates are struggling to make heavy monthly payments, often to a confusing variety of lenders. The average amount of the most common Federal student loan grew by 41 percent, to $3,313, from 1985 to 1995, according to a report from the College Board. Education experts say the amounts have risen because of increasing college costs, a general shift from education grants to loans, and a higher ceiling on the amount of money each student can borrow.
Consolidation can ease the monthly payment burden and give students more flexibility to pay high-interest debts like those from credit cards, advisers say. It also gives breathing room to graduates who are just starting their careers.
Another benefit is less paperwork. Students can take out a different loan for each year of school, and lenders often sell those loans on the secondary market. By the time students graduate, they could owe money to several lenders. The Education Department estimates that 98,000 students consolidated Federal loans in the 1994 fiscal year, up more than fourfold from 1987.
Most lenders will consolidate Federal student loans. The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae (800 524-9100), the largest servicer of those loans, is a major consolidator. The Education Department also offers a consolidation program (800 848-0982), and its interest rates are likely to be lower than at private lenders.
While consolidation can help, it can be costly. Rates may be higher for the consolidated loan because private lenders determine the new interest rate by figuring the weighted average of the smaller loans, rounded up to the next whole percentage point.
And because the term of the new loan is often longer than those of the individual loans, graduates ultimately can pay thousands of dollars more.
"The advantage is better cash flow," said Raymond D. Loewe, president of Educational Planning Systems in Marlton, N.J. "The disadvantage is that you're going to pay more over the life of the loan."
Financial aid advisers at the Stanford Law School use a computer to show students how much they will pay if they consolidate or if they keep their original loans.
"When they see the actual figures, they're like, 'There's no way I'd be willing to consolidate,' " said Ruth Burciaga, assistant director of financial aid at the law school.
Mary Erikson, a 1989 Stanford Law graduate, said she regretted not checking before she consolidated her loans.
"As soon as I did it, I wanted to slit my wrists," said Ms. Erikson, who is now 47 and a defense lawyer in Atlanta, but "I was caught between the devil and the deep blue sea."
She had borrowed about $49,000 to get her law degree, but as a low-paid public defender, she could not make the $750 monthly payments. She also had to pay off about $7,000 in high-interest credit card bills she accumulated "just to stay alive and dress" in law school. So she consolidated her loans in 1990.
Now Ms. Erikson, who went to law school after years as a newspaper reporter, is paying $620 a month on her student loan. But the lower payment has not made her finances any easier. She still cannot afford to buy a house and has fallen behind on scheduled contributions to her individual retirement account.
"I panicked," she says of her original monthly payments. With the consolidation, she will pay about $186,000 over the 25 years of the new loan. Her original loan, which would have been paid off after only 10 years, would have cost her about $90,000.
"Once I realized what I had done," she said, "I was just horrified."
MS. ERIKSON could have tried several other options besides consolidation. Financial aid advisers say debts can be restructured without the higher interest rates or the longer repayment periods that consolidations often entail. Sometimes lenders will allow students to delay payment until they are financially stable.
Borrowers who want to avoid the headache of complex repayment schedules can give lenders permission to withdraw monthly installments directly from a checking account. For a simpler overall loan structure, graduates can ask one lender to buy all their loans, merging the payments without changing the terms of any of them. In most cases, borrowers would not pay a fee for this service.
Dr. Nancy Gnizak-Wiley, an orthodontist in Coral Springs, Fla., graduated from Columbia University's dental school with about 15 different loans totaling $180,000 and two five-inch-thick folders of loan materials. "It was a whole mumbo jumbo," she said.
To simplify the payments, she brought nearly all the loans together with one lender, but did not consolidate them. Now, she makes a payment of $1,200 a month.
Whatever option borrowers choose, financial aid advisers say, they must above all avoid default, which can stain their credit ratings. The Education Department estimates that the default rate on student loans was 15 percent in 1993.
Consolidation can cost more over all, but that "is better than ruining their credit rating if they don't make the payment," said Julie L. Disa, director of financial aid services at Johns Hopkins Medical School.
Michael A. Roy, a manager at Automatic Data Processing in Boston, defaulted on some of his undergraduate loans in 1993. His interest rate went up drastically after the lender turned over the loans to a collection agency. And even while working for a New England bank, making about $30,000 a year and authorizing loans for customers, he couldn't get a credit card. Concerned, he ordered a copy of his credit report.
"The only bad thing on it," he said, "was my student loans."

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
These Figures Spell Good Times, Not Bad

BYLINE: By ROBERT EISNER; Robert Eisner, professor emeritus at Northwestern University and a former president of the American Economic Association, is the author of "The Misunderstood Economy: What Counts and How to Count It."

 BODY:
SOCIAL SECURITY will go bankrupt in 2030! Health care must be cut to save it! Our older citizens must sacrifice to save our children! These dire warnings are the sound bites of the day.
How much politicians and pundits offering the warnings of crisis -- and policies to meet them -- are really motivated by deficit paranoia is not all that clear. Many seem bound and blinded by an ideology that dictates that government do less and stop giving (the undeserving) the proverbial free lunch. That free lunches are not necessarily all that bad, and certainly better than no lunch at all, seems to escape them. 
 In fact, there is no need to pit young against old, or poor against rich. There can be and will be plenty for all if we just permit the economy to continue to grow at even the modest rates of the past. And if it grows more rapidly, the next generation will enjoy unparalleled prosperity while their parents and grandparents look on in the comfort they have earned.
We are frequently told that our elders must sacrifice -- by delaying retirement or accepting lower Social Security benefits -- because they will become too numerous for a relatively declining working population to meet its current commitments. A clear look at the numbers should bring all of us to reject that assertion.
It is true that the ratio of people who are 65 and older to those aged 20 to 64 is estimated to rise from 21.4 percent in 1995 to 35.5 percent in 2030, according to the middle projections of the Social Security trust fund. In other words, instead of almost five people working to support every potential retiree, there will be fewer than three.
But the more relevant figure is the ratio of the total population in the ages of dependency, including those under 20 as well as those 65 or older, to the working-age population. That ratio is also projected to rise, but only to 78.6 percent from 70.8 percent.
If the percentages of those working remain the same, that would mean that working adults would have to give up, on average, 11 percent more of their earnings to continue current support of parents or grandparents and children. Will not someone have to sacrifice? Should it be the working population, their children or their elders? Or do we have to demand sacrifice from some of the relatively better off to protect, as well as we can, those nearer the bottom?
The correct answer is none of the above. What has been ignored so far -- and in almost all public discussion -- is a simple fact of growth. Those in the working population will, indeed, have to give up a larger percentage of their incomes to support those not working. But their incomes will be so much higher that they will still have far more left than they have now.
The Clinton Administration and the Congressional Budget Office have differed in projections of the rate of growth over the next seven years, but let us take for starters the more pessimistic budget office assumption that gross domestic product, after adjustment for inflation, will increase at only 2.3 percent a year. If that rate were to continue to 2030, the total product would be more than twice what it is now, precisely 121.6 percent higher.
In that time, the population will grow from 273.08 million in 1995 to 343.13 million, an increase of 25.7 percent, again using the middle estimate of the Social Security trust fund. So the increase of total product would be almost 100 percentage points more than the increase in population. Output per person would therefore be 76.4 percent higher in that "crisis" year of 2030 than now. Every child, working person and retiree could have 76.4 percent more.
We get qualitatively similar results even with more pessimistic figures on growth. I have assumed implicitly that product per capita would grow at 1.63 percent a year. That is hardly unreasonable in light of history -- it has averaged 1.84 percent over the last 35 years.
But suppose that growth were only a feeble 1 percent a year. By 2030, output per person would then be 41.7 percent higher than now -- enough for young and old, rich and poor, to have 41.7 percent more.
Or we can make the even more pessimistic assumption that output for every working person grows 1 percent a year. That 41.7 percent increase from those working would then have to accommodate the larger proportion of nonworkers. This would reduce the available output per person in the entire population to 35.5 percent more than now.
WHY then change Social Security to force future retirees to work longer? Why reduce Social Security benefits when output is growing and there can be more for everybody? And why risk reducing the quantity or quality of health care in order to cut costs? As we grow richer, we can indeed afford more of everything.
And we can grow much richer still. More and more businessmen and economists are recognizing that our potential for growth is significantly more than 2.3 percent or 2.5 percent a year, if we do not have government policies -- budgetary or monetary -- to hold down that growth. Rather than insisting willy-nilly on budget balancing, we should invest more in the education and health of our people and have a Federal Reserve committed to full employment and maximum growth. A better future can then be better still.
Of course, John F. Kennedy's argument that "a rising tide raises all boats" is not entirely applicable. A continuing increase in the disparity of incomes, with real wages declining and the rich getting richer than ever, can dissipate the potential gains for many.
But that rising tide gives us the opportunity, and an easy opportunity, to make everyone better off. There is no good reason for anyone to be worse off as we proceed deeply into the next century. And there is no reason for people to start making themselves worse off now by sacrificing to reduce the supposed misery of their future.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROOSEVELT ISLAND;
Workers Detail Claims Against Suspended Officials

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
As state investigators probe the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, several present and former employees have detailed their charges accusing two administrators of waste, theft and the use of employees for personal business.
The administrators, Barry Chafetz, the agency's vice president of operations, and Tom Sloan, director of facilities and grounds, denied the accusations. The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal has suspended them with pay, pending an inspector general's inquiry, 
 Six former and present workers gave interviews, including Mildred Rivera, who was fired recently after a year as the warehouse manager, and Kevin O'Connor, whose maintenance job was eliminated this year. The others spoke on the condition they not be identified. Among their claims:
* The officials bought hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of unneeded equipment, including a steamroller, a tractor, a ditch digger and a log splitter. In an interview, Mr. Sloan said he was saving money by getting equipment that enabled the staff to do special tasks instead of hiring costly contractors.
* Mr. Sloan, according to the employees, insisted that many of the packages delivered to the warehouse be held for him to open, and he often put them in his personal car and drove away. "They were never seen again," said Mr. O'Connor. But Mr. Sloan responded that he often delivered packages around the island and denied keeping any for himself.
* Employees renovated Mr. Chafetz's home in Queens, installing a counter top, sink, closets, wiring and a washer-dryer, and building bunk beds and an altarlike object to be taken to his synagogue. Mr. Chafetz said the work was done on weekends, and he paid for it. But one worker said nearly 20 days of the work were paid by the agency. Mr. Chafetz's associates deny that.
Ms. Rivera said that she was fired "because I knew too much, about things coming into the warehouse and how many things were going out." Mr. Sloan said she was fired for incompetence and lying about a parking violation.
Mr. Sloan attributed the charges to employees disgruntled about how he and Mr. Chafetz cracked down on the agency's unions, including the business service employees and Teamsters. "This is just malarkey to get Barry and myself out of the way," said Mr. Sloan, who has been at the agency a year and a half.
"I was hired to get the job done," Mr. Sloan said. "I found employees basically working only two or three hours a day, hiding on the island. I caught people sleeping in cars. These people literally didn't know how to do anything."
 BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: Help for the Self-Employed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Workers Out on Your Own, Unite!" (From the Desk Of, Nov. 26), Edith Rotkopf calls for the formation of a union to represent the interests of the self-employed. What she needs is a trade association. 
 Since colonial times, associations in the United States have promoted the interests of businessmen and businesswomen in every industry and profession imaginable.
Ms. Rotkopf cites specific obstacles facing the self-employed and suggests that a union could assist in overcoming those obstacles. With respect to each one, however, hundreds of associations are already providing help to their members.
For example, Ms. Rotkopf refers to the high cost of health and other insurance for the self-employed. Group health insurance programs have been a standard membership benefit offered by associations for decades. Unemployment and business interruption insurance, also advocated by Ms. Rotkopf, can likewise be obtained through an industry association. If there are enough interested members of an industry or profession, an association will provide the service.
Most important, Ms. Rotkopf wants an organization that will champion and help market the valuable services of the self-employed. Such industry promotion is the primary reason for the existence of many associations. By pooling resources, members of an industry can achieve vastly superior results, acting through an association as opposed to acting individually.
But these are just a few functions of trade associations. Other important tasks include lobbying, establishing codes of ethics, setting professional standards, collecting and disseminating data on industry practices and market trends, and educating customers and suppliers about important competitive issues.
 
HUGH K. WEBSTER
Washington, Nov. 29
 
The writer is a partner at Webster, Chamberlain & Bean, a Washington law firm that represents trade associations.

HEADLINE: Retraining America Isn't Impossible Job

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "American Inequality: Its History and Scary Future" (Op-Ed, Dec. 19), Benjamin Schwarz estimates the cost of reversing the slide toward inequality by upgrading people's skills at $170 billion a year, a "politically impossible" price. 
 The estimate derives from a calculation by Prof. James Heckman of the University of Chicago, who sought to determine, based on data about income gains from additional education and job training, the cost of reducing inequality back to its 1979 level.
Because Professor Heckman's estimate included the cost to individuals of forgone income while gaining new skills, the direct cost to Government would be much smaller -- in the range of $60 billion a year. Still huge, but politically impossible?
The sum is less than a third of what families and companies spend annually on the postsecondary education and training of our economic elite.
It is less than the Federal Government's annual burden of "corporate welfare" -- tax breaks and unwarranted subsidies for particular companies and industries -- as estimated by think tanks across the political spectrum.
Political possibilities may seem limited these days, but dedicating $60 billion a year to restoring America's culture of opportunity is hardly out of reach.
 
ROBERT B. REICH
Secretary of Labor
Washington, Dec. 20, 1995

HEADLINE: Mexico Still Lags on Democratic Reforms

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Thomas L. Friedman's Dec. 17 column on Mexico: 
 While commendable that Raul Salinas de Gortari, the former President's brother, is in prison for allegedly masterminding an assassination and now for inexplicable enrichment, he is still the only one being prosecuted for such crimes by President Ernesto Zedillo.
Each recent Mexican administration has had one scapegoat at the beginning to "prove" that the new president was breaking with the dishonesty of the past. But after high-profile convictions, operating above the law continued to be a way of life.
Neither the Mexican judicial system, social security, the congress nor the electoral process has experienced the reform needed to meet First World democratic standards. Economic policy hasn't changed a bit -- President Zedillo was an architect of President Salinas's discredited "economic miracle."
It is questionable whether Mr. Zedillo himself is committed to reform. He has been part of the system and has benefited from it for a long time.
Dimetrio Sodi de la Tijera, formerly of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and now an independent, revealed this year that the president has discretion to disburse one-third of all funds the government takes in -- without accountability. This "presidentialism" has yet to be addressed by Mr. Zedillo.
Mr. Friedman is right: Americans must care. Their future is tied to Mexico's progress or the lack of it.
 
RICHARD ALBERT SEID
Mexico City, Dec. 19, 1995
 
The writer was opinion-page editor of The News, an English-language newspaper in Mexico.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
How Movies Fade Out on Politics

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
"WHITE MAN'S BURDEN" is a muddled movie that thinks it's about race though it's really about class. Set in an America in which the black majority lords it over the white minority, this role-reversal story has a vision of race relations so schematic and outdated it barely connects to reality. Harry Belafonte plays the representative black man, wealthy and elegant. John Travolta is the typical, unemployed, uneducated white man who kidnaps him. If black means white, then this film suggests a world in every Caucasian lives in a mansion and there are no Colin Powells or Johnnie Cochrans.
 
Lines Between the Lines
 Yet buried deep in the film is a single scene with a chilling ring of truth. "So you lost your job, tough luck!" the Belafonte character yells at the white man. "Get another one! You blame everybody in the whole world but yourself!" In life only the politically suicidal would express it so bluntly, yet that explosion reflects the hidden anger politicians appeal to when they suggest that social services should be cut. With its class conflict seeping in almost accidentally, "White Man's Burden" is a prime example of the timid way that politics is revealed in current movies: through subplots, chance remarks and the potent issues the films choose to avoid. 
 There are obvious reasons for this pussyfooting around. A typical two-year gestation period from script to screen makes true topicality impossible, and the fear of offending a mainstream audience is strong.
But there is something less practical going on. Even the most overt political films, like "The American President" and "Nixon," avoid strong statements because they have been shaped in a climate of confusion and pessimism. The political atmosphere they inadvertently reflect is one in which there is little consensus about foreign policy, little hope of reducing crime, few heroes or villains for a movie to cling to. It turns out that movies, today more than ever, are most realistic about politics in the backhanded way they echo Americans' bewilderment.
In reality the average person can't tell the difference between the Bosnians and the Serbs, and Congress half-heartedly approves sending American troops to Bosnia. This perplexity emerges on screen as nostalgia for the clear-cut days of the cold war, when the Soviets were the bad guys. "Crimson Tide," one of last summer's hits, is set in the present yet offers a tortured plot that pits American nuclear weapons against Russian ones. The new James Bond film, "Goldeneye," so desperately needs the cold war that it actually has a prologue set in the bad old U.S.S.R., introducing the Soviet villains who even now haunt Bond as Russian villains. Conservative law-and-order attitudes and rampant hero-worship invade all films based on Tom Clancy novels.
Liberal political films are just as wary as conservative ones. In Rob Reiner's "The American President," the widowed President (Michael Douglas) is a Clinton-like Democrat who romances an environmental lobbyist (Annette Bening). When he is forced to choose between an environmental protection bill and a vague "crime bill" (he can't win both), the movie makes it clear that the honorable choice is to keep his promise to the lobbyist with whom he's sleeping.
 
Age of Diminished Heroes
 In this fiction, signing the environmental bill will reduce pollution drastically, though it will cost the President support from Congress and big business. The film hands its President a problem with a definite solution, and a political price that makes him seem heroic. It depicts an easy movie choice as a tough realistic one.
But it's impossible to imagine any easy, clear-cut solution to crime, even in fiction, so "The American President" frames this crucial issue as a dispensable one, first giving it equal weight with the environment and then pushing it off to the margins. The film's strongest fairy-tale element isn't its romance but the unbelievable proposition that the President will clean up the environment today and come back with an even better crime bill tomorrow. (Like the new improved health care bill promised when the last one failed?)
Crime, however, seems such an inherent part of American life that a film like "Heat" casually suggests there is no moral difference between a cop (Al Pacino) and the master thief he's pursuing (Robert De Niro). In terms of audience sympathy, the movie presents a level playing field, and Mr. De Niro's more controlled, subtle performance makes it easier to root for the robber than the cop. Movie audiences have always responded to sympathetic crooks, of course, but rarely has a good cop carried so little moral authority.
Films that address political issues head-on usually go against the grain; that's their reason for being. Tim Robbins's "Dead Man Walking" (opening Dec. 29), with Sean Penn as a murderer on death row, takes a strong stand against the death penalty at a time when more states are reinstating it and carrying out executions. But such a pointed political film is an oddity these days.
Even the most conspicuous political film of the year is most convincing in the messages it sends inadvertently. In many interviews, Oliver Stone has compared his Nixon character to a Shakespearean tragic figure. Yet the film's simplistic psychology -- Nixon was unloved and went to the wrong college -- reduces politics to the machinations of a pathetic, puny personality. That's an acceptable message for an age of diminished heroes.
Another reason for the film's hollowness becomes apparent only at the end, when the movie cuts to news tape of Richard Nixon's funeral, with all the living Presidents attending. That one glimpse is more revealing than the previous 3 1/4 hours. It suggests that Oliver Stone doesn't need to humanize Nixon. History has already started.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PREDICTS A PACT ON BUDGET WILL BE REACHED

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton predicted today that an agreement would be reached on a seven-year plan to balance the budget, saying, "I am confident we can end this impasse."
But a 67-page working document used in the negotiations and made available today reflected hundreds of disagreements that participants acknowledged could not be resolved in a matter of days. 
 In his weekly radio speech today, Mr. Clinton said, "Our talks are making progress," and he maintained that both sides shared the goal of "reaching an agreement as soon as possible." The Government has now been partly shut down for eight days, with 280,000 Federal workers furloughed, but there was no work on the budget talks in the Capital today.
Without any of the harsh words the two sides have exchanged for most of last week, Mr. Clinton did urge Congress to reopen agencies to end the financial and emotional turmoil not only for the furloughed employees, but for 460,000 more employees with emergency status who are working but not getting paid.
Lower level staff talks are to resume on Wednesday, and Mr. Clinton will meet Republican leaders on Friday. But most members of Congress have left town with no expectation of being needed here before Jan. 3.
The cold reality of what lies before negotiators was shown in the document made public today, which showed side-by-side comparisons of their plan with an alternative offered by conservative House Democrats and another reflecting Administration views, all assembled by the Republican staff of the House Budget Committee.
The paper reflected both grand and picayune differences. There is the choice between a Republican Medicare plan, with "savings" of $132.7 billion over seven years and an Administration plan, with "savings" of $37.5 billion. But there are more lines of print devoted to different plans for selling off the nation's helium reserve that would save either $47 million (Republican) or $23 million (Administration) over seven years, sums that have almost no impact on whether the budget is balanced but considerable impact on a small, profitable industry.
The document describes some proposals, like an earlier date the Administration urged for cost of living adjustments on military pensions, as costs because they would increase the deficit. But the 20 pages devoted to comparing tax cut proposals speak only in terms of "tax relief," not "costs."
The Administration has not presented its own side-by-side set of comparisons, but may do so next week. For the moment, negotiators have only one slightly tilted set of comparisons to work from, not two.
The official Republican answer to the President's radio address was meant to be low-key, since it was delivered by a second-term House member, Representative Ron Lewis of Kentucky, who has no role in the budget discussions.
Mr. Lewis complained that the President has yet to propose a plan that would balance the budget in seven years. He said Republicans asked the President to negotiate in good faith, and he called the effort to balance the budget "a historic struggle, perhaps our last great chance to stop robbing our children."
And though he accused Mr. Clinton of saying one thing two years ago, when he urged restraints on Medicare spending, and another today when he called the Republicans extremists for doing the same thing, his tone was generally mild.
Similarly, Mr. Clinton's description of his priorities today was low key. He said, "We have to balance the budget in a way that reflects our most fundamental values: increasing opportunity, asking everyone to assume responsibility, strengthening our families and the economy, and recognizing the duty we owe to each other, to our parents, our children and those who need and deserve our help."
But the seasonal amelioration of rhetoric does not remove the main obstacles to an agreement. The first is distrust. Many Republicans do not believe the President really wants a seven-year agreement on a balanced budget, and cite as evidence his failure to offer such a proposal as calculated by the Congressional Budget Office.
On the other hand, the Administration, many House Democrats, and Senators of both parties doubt the commitment of House Republicans to the sort of give and take any compromise will require. They cite the House's refusal to pass temporary spending bills that would reopen closed Government offices as evidence of a fatal rigidity.
As recently as Tuesday, both Senator Bob Dole and Speaker Newt Gingrich spoke of finishing a budget by Dec. 31. "We'd like to get it done with a budget by the end of this year," Mr. Dole said. Going further, Mr. Gingrich said, "There is an agreement that we will get this done by the end of the year." And at a Republican caucus, after being asked whether members should plan to stay, even if they had bought nonrefundable airplane tickets for a family vacation, Mr. Gingrich dismissed the faint-hearted, saying "Anyone not willing to tear up a ticket to balance the budget doesn't belong here."
By Friday, a different note was being sounded. Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, chairman of the Appropriations Committee paraphrased Winston Churchill and proclaimed to the House: "We will never, never, never give in. We will stay here till Doomsday."
Of course, Congress left town within a few hours, in recognition that the end was not in reach. For, as the side-by-side comparison makes clear, the differences are not just in the numbers.
For example, when the Republican staff put the comparison together, they used quotation marks just once in 67 pages -- in a sarcastic reference to the President's proposal for more volunteers for Americorps, his prized national service program.

HEADLINE: Road Near Rain Forest Of Panama Creates Rift

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Over the objections of several senior Administration officials, the United States Army is embarking on a training exercise that will build a gravel road into the buffer zone protecting one of the most spectacular rain forests in Latin America, raising concerns among environmentalists about potential damage.
The Army's Southern Command has scheduled the exercise in the lush Valle del Risco in Panama to teach several thousand National Guardsmen and Army reservists how to construct roads during their annual duty training next year. The Army has already spent $3 million preparing for the exercise. It will cost another $2.2 million to ship National Guard engineers and heavy construction equipment to Panama. 
 The Panamanian project, part of a United States Army civic assistance operation for 1996 called New Horizons, has prompted protests by Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs, and Brian Atwood, the administrator of the Agency for International Development. This week they sent a joint memorandum to Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, asking that the project be blocked until a comprehensive assessment could be made of its environmental impact.
Unless a decision is made to cancel the project, the road will be built.
"It's probably received more reviews than any project in the history of the State Department," said William J. Hughes, the United States Ambassador to Panama, who supports the project. He said the road would alleviate the poverty and mortality rate of the valley's native inhabitants, who are Guaymi Indians.
The Panamanian Government first approached the United States Agency for International Development for assistance, but was twice rejected because it fell short of American-recognized environmental standards. Panama's President, Ernesto Perez Balladares, then turned to the Southern Command with a personal appeal, an American official said, to fulfill a campaign promise to build the road, which lies in his home district.
The current dirt track ends at Risco, a rural village two miles inside the Palo Seco Forest Reserve, which forms a natural buffer zone for La Amistad International Park, a pristine wilderness of mist-shrouded peaks and lush jungle straddling the frontier between Panama and Costa Rica. The park encompasses what is described as the largest undisturbed cloud forest in Latin America, with as many as 40 percent of its plants and animals not found elsewhere.
The new road would not encroach on La Amistad wilderness itself. But environmental experts for Conservation International and the National Resources Defense Council fear it would increase the risk of environmental degradation. Moreover, squatters could move in more easily, and clear the forest.
The Panamanian Government would like to incorporate part of the 7 1/2-mile road into a longer 46-mile highway it has been trying to build since 1983 from Almirante, a town on the Caribbean coast, to the oil-producing area of Chiriqui Grande.
Ambassador Hughes said the new road would alleviate Risco's inadequate health care, which is reflected in an infant mortality rate exceeding 40 percent, and open access to better schools and markets. He said the local governor promised to keep out squatters. The valley's indigenous population is estimated at 2,000 to 5,000 people.
In their internal memorandum, a copy of which was made available by other officials, Mr. Wirth and Mr. Atwood said the road did not qualify for funds from the Agency for International Development for lack of an internationally recognized environmental assessment.
Congressional legislation covering civilian agencies like A.I.D. makes the protection of tropical forests and biodiversity a priority in dispensing foreign aid. The Defense Department is covered by a different executive order that permits the application of local environmental laws if the host country is actively involved.
Capt. Chris Yates, of the Army's Southern Command, said the Panama Government did its own environmental assessment and concluded that the new road would have "minimal to no impact." The representatives of the Agency for International Development remained opposed.
Mr. Wirth, the State Department's ranking official on environmental issues, and Mr. Atwood, who supervises American civilian assistance to foreign countries, requested on Nov. 13 that the project be delayed.
"This remains our recommendation," the latest memo said. "In fact, our misgivings about this project have grown in the past month."
Their memo to Mr. Talbott said that "the environmental implications for the Valle del Risco and the region are even greater than previously envisioned."
Captain Yates described the road-building project as an "engineer and medical readiness field-training exercise" scheduled from January through June 1996, bringing in up to 6,000 National Guardsmen and reservists from 17 states.
Captain Yates said the Panamanian Government did its own environmental assessment and concluded that the new road would have "minimal to no impact."
But Mr. Wirth and Mr. Atwood said that any assessment must be comprehensive and internationally recognized.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 19; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

LENGTH: 1557 words

HEADLINE: With Harlem at a Crossroad, Visions for Economic Future Diverge

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY and JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The Rev. Lawrence E. Lucas, a priest at Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Harlem, harbors an ideal vision for his neighborhood's economic lifeline, 125th Street. Salsa and rhythm-and-blues would sound from busy storefronts, the aromas of curried goat and shrimp-and-rice stew would spice the air -- and the merchants would be almost exclusively black and Hispanic.
C. Virginia Fields, the City Councilwoman for most of Harlem, imagines a more homogeneous environment. People would come from all over, not just Harlem, to enjoy a lunch of smothered chicken at Sylvia's Restaurant, browse at a Barnes & Noble outlet, buy a Senegalese carving and stop at the Gap before heading home. 
 The Harlem community has been in the throes of self-examination since a black gunman burned down a white-owned clothing store on 125th Street two weeks ago, killing himself and seven others in what the police said was a racially motivated attack. What many residents said they are finding, beneath the surface, are questions that center less on race than on the differing expectations for Harlem's commercial future.
In the weeks before the fire, a black merchant being pressured to move by a white, Jewish store owner helped stage protests that witnesses said turned anti-Semitic at times. But the protests outside Freddy's clothing store also seemed to tap into a more prevalent sentiment: If black merchants cannot earn a living in predominantly black Harlem, where can they look to get ahead?
Derek Q. Johnson, the acting president of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corporation, said that Harlem's economic condition -- reflected best by 125th Street -- was at the root of other heated episodes in the neighborhood's history, including the city's confrontations with illegal street vendors in 1992 and 1994.
"It is a community from which lots of the economic foundation has left and where jobs, particularly at the local level, are at a dearth," Mr. Johnson said. "The combination of those factors makes for a very tense environment around questions of economic development and economic growth."
Indeed, the community's economic structure is on the verge of even more debate, now that the Federal Government has designated greater Harlem, along with the South Bronx, as an Empowerment Zone. Touted as the largest renewal project in upper Manhattan's history, the zone will receive $300 million in public money over the next decade to bolster social services, finance education programs and spur economic development through job training, loans and business partnerships.
Although the program will not begin until early next year, its directors said they are questioned daily by fledgling and would-be entrepreneurs eager to submit applications. How that money is spent -- and whose businesses will benefit -- will be closely watched in Harlem, officials said, for it will determine the neighborhood's future.
There is strong support in some quarters for a Harlem commerce dominated by black and Hispanic merchants. Some residents and business owners, saying Harlem should be as true to its ethnicity as other communities controlled by particular ethnic groups, cited two Brooklyn neighborhoods as examples: Bensonhurst, predominantly Italian, and Williamsburg, predominantly Jewish.
"In terms of commercial enterprise," said Father Lucas, a former vice chairman of Community Board 10, which covers central Harlem, the area "should be 90 percent owned, operated and controlled by people of color."
But others, particularly the community's business and political leaders, said such visions are both unrealistic and counterproductive to any revitalization effort. Barbara Askins, executive director for the 125th Street Business Improvement District, said that without "anchor stores" like the Gap and Home Depot, Harlem residents would "go downtown or to New Jersey."
"We have to look at the overall participation of minorities and stop focusing on the one issue of store ownership," she said. "We don't want it so that African Americans are locked out. We want local minority entrepreneurship as well as the large anchors to pull in the traffic. One cannot be without the other."
Finding the proper balance in Harlem is a complicated task, as the city's 1994 application for Empowerment Zone designation acknowledged: "Harlem is viewed as the cultural capital of African Americans, internationally renowned for its people and their contributions to politics, literature, music, dance, sports and art."
The application continued: "It is also viewed as a dangerous place, the 'inner city,' the metaphor for urban America, the place where social pathology abounds. This duality gives Harlem its special character of opportunity and problems. Residents know both."
According to the 1990 census, 87 percent of the nearly 100,000 residents in central Harlem are black, and 10 percent are Hispanic. The annual median household income is $13,252, less than half the citywide figure of $29,283. The city's unemployment rate at the time was 9.3 percent for men, 8.7 percent for women; in central Harlem, it was 22.3 percent for men, 13.7 for women.
Although there are encouraging signs of vitality along 125th Street -- from established black businesses to Body Shop, Foot Locker and Strawberry outlets -- the neighborhood's commercial picture remains distressed. According to the Empowerment Zone application, most of the neighborhood's stores offer "a limited range of goods," prompting as many as 70 percent of its residents to shop elsewhere for clothes, gifts, electrical appliances and furniture. And as of 1994 central and east Harlem had more than 1 million square feet of vacant commercial space.
An element not referred to in the Empowerment Zone application was that of race. For decades most buildings on 125th Street were white-owned, and the stores white-operated. Today, there are more black merchants -- the 125th Street BID estimates that 158 of 322 businesses between Fifth Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard are black-owned -- but resentment lingers over the sense of a business culture in the grasp of a white, absentee group.
This year, a dispute arose over a plan to build a Pathmark supermarket on a vacant, city-owned lot on 125th Street in east Harlem. The plan was bitterly opposed, principally by Hispanic merchants who argued that the giant store would endanger the more than 200 bodega owners in the area. In the end, the city approved the supermarket plan.
And last year, the Giuliani administration forcibly removed illegal street vendors from the thoroughfare, to the delight of many merchants and to the dismay of some who thought the peddlers turned the street into a bustling bazaar. To this day, the remnants of those vendors continue to stage sporadic demonstrations, often against white-owned businesses; they participated in the angry protests in front of Freddy's in the weeks before the clothing store was destroyed by fire. Their rallying cry is "Buy black."
"There is a legitimate feeling in the community that the opportunities for many residents here is blocked," said Joseph Haslip, a Democratic Party district leader in Harlem. "And many people feel that their access -- and the access of black people in general -- is blocked by certain forces in the community who represent the interests of big money. And that continues to create tension and resentment."
A manifestation of that tension could be found last week. Beneath the Christmas garland strung over 125th Street, several police cars idled in front of a few white- and Korean-owned stores that have received racially charged threats. The police said they did not know whether the threats were anything more than harassing.
Many Harlem leaders and residents said they were outraged by such incidents, describing them as isolated. But they said such episodes demonstrate the need for more communication between those with disparate views on how their community should be developed.
"What's needed now is a bridging of the gap between the two extremes," said Mr. Johnson of the Empowerment Zone.
Lloyd A. Williams, president and chief executive of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, agreed. "We need the people who are going to be impacted by the development plans to have input," he said. "The community board plays a critical role. But the community board, as well as the elected officials and the BID, need to become more inclusive and start talking to each other."
The goal of inclusion is more than politically correct chatter, residents said. Shortly after the deadly fire at Freddy's, Harlem's political leaders held a news conference to denounce the violence and to encourage shoppers to support 125th Street merchants. Two hours later, many of Harlem's church leaders held their own news event in which they defended the right to peaceful protests against injustice -- and expressed support for the Rev. Al Sharpton, who had figured in at least one of the protests.
"Some of us are more interested in an agenda of social change," Mr. Sharpton said. "Some, at the other press conference, are more concerned about business development."
"Many of us come from different traditions," he continued. "And until we can reconcile the two, these tensions are likely to continue."

HEADLINE: At Two Harlem Stores, Same Battle to Survive

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
John Baynes looked out on the snow falling hard on Harlem. It has been a tough year for business on 125th Street, he said, the toughest in a string of many tough years.
Down the street, Arthur Rosen also studied the snow. No question, he said, his thick forearms resting on a microwave stand for sale, this has been the toughest year of all. 
 Mr. Baynes, who is black, and Mr. Rosen, who is white, share more than a ZIP code. Both men are in their early 50's. Both inherited businesses from hard-working fathers. And both have spent more than three decades trying to make a living on 125th Street, the Harlem thoroughfare that sometimes seems richer in history than in reality.
But it is the differences separating the merchants of 125th Street, not their similarities, that have been the focus of attention since Dec. 8. On that day, in what police say was a racially motivated attack, a black gunman stormed a store owned by a white man on 125th Street, killing himself and seven others in a rain of bullets and fire.
Last week, Mr. Baynes and Mr. Rosen shared reflections on what business life is like on 125th Street, reflections shaded in part by race. But Mr. Baynes spoke for both when he said: "It's a constant fight. A constant battle."
The Rosen family has been selling in Harlem since 1938. The last 35 years have been at Bargain World, at 8 West 125th Street. In the mid-1960's, Arthur Rosen joined the business founded by his father, Abe. He stocked shelves, made deliveries, installed linoleum over the tired floors of Harlem tenements. The store did well enough to endure economic vagaries and neighborhood unrest.
But in November 1980, the business came close to collapse when an electrical fire gutted the underinsured store. Weeks later, the two Rosens were mugged in front of Bargain World; Arthur Rosen was shot and his elderly father was pistol-whipped.
"It was my decision to stay," said Arthur Rosen, who is 51. "I had a burned-out building that the family owned in the middle of Harlem and a business that had supported us all these years. So we put it all back together again."
Now the store has 25,000 square feet of retail space, almost 50 black and Hispanic employees and a reputation for largess to civic groups and churches. Its owner is ubiquitous, guiding his broad frame through narrow aisles packed with televisions and ceramic elephants, kitchen sets and portraits of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
But the bustle belies what Mr. Rosen calls "the toughest Christmas and the toughest year since I've been in business." He pointed to the day after the deadly fire at the white-owned clothing store, when protesters stood in front of Bargain World and promised to drive the store out of the neighborhood.
A week later, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani led a gaggle of aides and reporters on a shopping trip to 125th Street. He stopped at several stores, including Bargain World, where he spent $32.40 on Christmas lights and two Santa Claus dolls. "It was another show of faith by the city," Mr. Rosen said. "It was a positive approach to a negative time in 125th Street's life."
The day of the Mayor's visit, John Baynes watched as the entourage, awash in camera lights, passed by his store window.
"By virtue of him being in a black community, I could see him telling the white stores that 'you belong here and we want you to stay here,' " Mr. Baynes recalled. "But on the other hand, he didn't stop here and say, 'Mr. Baynes, you've been here 30 years and I want to thank you.' "
For three decades, the Baynes family has run Theresa Fashions, a clothing store for "mature women" at 252 West 125th Street. The shop embodies a family work ethic established 50 years ago by Milton Baynes, an emigre from the West Indies who worked long days and nights as a presser.
By the early 1950's, he had saved enough money to open two women's apparel stores in Brooklyn. In the mid-1960's, disturbances on the streets of Harlem prompted a white store owner on 125th Street to put his business up for sale. Milton Baynes bought the business, which he passed on to his son, John.
John Baynes, 53, is proud of working in Harlem. Years ago he encouraged a local artist to see the forbidding steel of the store's riot gates as a canvas; soon the likeness of a magnolia was blossoming there. Now the gate bears a mural of famous world monuments.
But Mr. Baynes said that festive paintings belie the struggles inside, particularly for black-owned businesses that do not get enough support from black consumers. "I have customers who will come in saying they need a special dress that they can't find anywhere else," he said. "They'll use me as a last resort to find it, and I'll spend a lot of time in the market, shopping, until I find it.
"What I feel is that if the community wants to keep black businesses healthy and active, go to them first! Give your black proprietors a first crack at it."
On this snowy morning, few customers came to the 1,500-square-foot store, which Mr. Baynes rents from a white landlord with a midtown business address. The unwelcome quiet allowed him time to share sometimes conflicting emotions.
He said he did not support boycotts, including those that were sought by protesters against Freddy's and Bargain World. But he admitted to yearning for a stronger black presence on 125th Street.
Mr. Baynes said he tried not to see business on 125th Street in terms of color, but he could not shake a sense of opportunities lost. "The strip went from being Jewish to Korean, without the blacks getting a handful of it," he said.
He holds the community's black leaders partly responsible for the plight of the street's black merchants. "Not one of my politicians has been inside my store in the 27 years I've been here," he said. "Not one."
A few days after the fire at Freddy's, Mr. Rosen and Mr. Baynes engaged in a mild debate on a local radio show. Several days later, they met for the first time and talked, as Mr. Rosen put it, about "how terrible it was what happened on the street."
Then the two merchants returned to their stores, where business is off like no other Christmas. Outside their windows, the snow continued to fall. And the people on 125th Street struggled to keep their balance.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Arthur Rosen, left, owner of Bargain World, called a recent visit to the 125th Street by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani a positive approach. John Baynes, right, who owns Theresa Fashions, said: "I could see him telling the white stores that 'you belong here.' But he didn't stop here." (Photographs by Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Overture to Damascus

 BODY:
First came a striking public overture to Damascus by Israel's new Prime Minister, Shimon Peres. That was followed up by some helpful high-level American message carrying. On the Syrian side, President Hafez el-Assad recognized the risks of waiting too long to help shape the pattern of regional peace.
So now, the long-stalled talks between Israel and Syria are set to resume this week in Maryland with a more ambitious agenda, higher-level participation and new hope for progress. Expectations of an Israeli-Syrian breakthrough have been raised before only to be disappointed. This time real progress may be possible. 
 Mr. Peres signaled a significant change in Israeli negotiating strategy when he appealed to President Assad to help bring about a comprehensive regional settlement. It is the right moment for a new initiative.
Mr. Peres's slain predecessor, Yitzhak Rabin, was inclined to let the Israeli public digest the new accords with the Palestine Liberation Organization and Jordan while he proceeded with unhurried negotiations with Syria, narrowly focused on details of territory and security. President Assad, for his part, had seemed determined to burnish his credentials as an Arab leader by resisting the kind of step-by-step bargaining with Israel that has been successively embraced by Anwar el-Sadat, Yasir Arafat and King Hussein.
Mr. Peres now invites Mr. Assad to assert his leadership in the cause of peace. Details to insure Israeli security while the Golan Heights are returned to Syria remain as indispensable as ever. But Damascus may find these easier to accept if negotiations are expanded to include issues of development, trade and regional cooperation. This would cast Syria in the flattering role of a bargainer for the broader Arab community rather than that of a humiliated petitioner for the return of lost territory.
Mr. Peres's idea of peace has long been premised on giving all countries a positive stake in reaping the potentially great rewards of economic cooperation instead of merely erecting new trip wires to provide adequate warning time in the event of renewed military conflict.
Mr. Peres's approach makes sense, building as it does on the already rapidly expanding web of agreements between Israel and other Arab states. But it can only succeed if Syria responds with imagination and good faith. The first signs are encouraging. Mr. Peres's appeal drew a quick and positive Syrian reply.
The deepening of peace on Israel's other frontiers, demonstrated by the presence of Arab leaders at Mr. Rabin's funeral, may have prodded Mr. Assad to re-examine his strategy. Israel's new peace treaty with Jordan and the negotiated transfer of West Bank cities to Palestinian self-rule put pressure on Damascus to reach a favorable agreement before its leverage evaporates.
Agreement with Syria, which also controls Lebanon's foreign policy, would at last give Israel peace on every border and open up exciting possibilities of regional cooperation in economic development, medical care and use of scarce water resources that would benefit tens of millions of people.
Syria can serve its own interests and ambitions by bringing an equally positive vision to the negotiating table when this week's talks get under way.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Buchanan For President

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, IOWA

 BODY:
So I've made up my mind for 1996. I'm voting for Pat Buchanan. Really.
Well, not really. But of all the Presidential candidates, Mr. Buchanan is clearly the most interesting. It is he who has diagnosed what's troubling Americans these days -- the impact of the global economy and rapid technological change on their lives and communities, and the failure of traditional Republicans or Democrats to deal with it. 
 It is summed up in a question that you can hear all over America: If the economy is doing so well, why have I just been downsized out of a job and why do I feel like my community is eroding? AT&T's stock soars and it announces plans to buy out 77,800 middle managers. The Cleveland Browns move to Baltimore, despite selling out every home game for decades to a loyal Cleveland community, because the team needs a stadium that produces more revenue. Average U.S. wages grew last year by the smallest amount on record -- 2.7 percent. All this produces what Labor Secretary Robert Reich calls "a profound sense that economic forces are out of control -- that neither hard work nor general economic improvement will lead to higher incomes."
It does lead, though, to Buchananism. Give ole Pat credit. While other candidates are talking in abstractions about "balanced budgets," Mr. Buchanan is painting a vivid picture for people, explaining why they feel insecure: It is because Mexicans working for 50 cents an hour have taken their jobs, "faceless bureaucrats in Geneva" at the World Trade Organization are telling them how to run their communities and the combination of the two is eroding their workplace, American values, families and neighborhoods. While recently touring Iowa, Mr. Buchanan told The New York Times that he would much rather preserve family farms than see them give way to more efficient conglomerates, even though this might mean higher food prices. "I don't worship the market system," he said. "I don't worship at the altar of efficiency."
But while Mr. Buchanan has properly diagnosed our anxiety, his prescription -- raising walls of protectionism and anti-immigration -- will lead only to economic ruin and a politics of resentment.
So who has the answer? It certainly isn't the Dole-Gingrich Republicans, argued the Harvard University political theorist Michael J. Sandel, whose forthcoming book, "Democracy's Discontent," deals with this issue. "The traditional Republicans are uncritical advocates of the free market, free trade and the global economy and at the same time they pose as advocates of community and family values," says Mr. Sandel. "But it is precisely unfettered markets which are now most responsible for the breakdown of community and traditional values. Walmart, not big government, is responsible for the demise of Main Street across America. But most Republicans won't face up to that contradiction."
Mr. Clinton has one right prescription, which is investing more in job training and education, as we opt for more free trade agreements, to enable Americans to better compete in the global market. But that's not enough to blunt Buchananism, because Mr. Buchanan is not just giving voice to people's economic fears, argues Mr. Sandel. He is also giving voice to their fear that they are losing the moral anchors in their lives. When Mr. Buchanan says our schools no longer teach right from wrong, that our nation can't control its borders and that patriotism is giving way to multiculturalism, he strikes a popular chord.
"What makes this moment so volatile is the fact that the global economy and technology have not just disrupted the economic foundation of people's lives and left them feeling powerless," says Mr. Sandel. "These same changes have also created an environment in which people feel that from family to neighborhood to nation, the moral fabric of their lives, and our sense of belonging to a particular place with a shared civic life, is unraveling around us. These two fears -- the loss of economic security and the erosion of a sense of community -- together define the anxiety of our time."
Because he has tapped into that anxiety Mr. Buchanan is winning voters' trust, but for policies that promote hate and division. President Clinton's challenge is to tap into those same feelings in order to win voters' trust for policies that not only make good economic sense, but can also bind us together.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
