HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
A Special Christmas Feast, Without the Shopping

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant 

DATELINE: WEST TISBURY, Mass.

 BODY:
There are still touches of green in our snow-draped vegetable garden here on Martha's Vineyard -- leeks, kale, carrots, turnips, parsnips and next fall's garlic -- reminding me that savoring what we have grown or gathered is one of our happiest Christmastime rituals.
Christmas Eve dinner for the two of us will include a black duck I shot in Town Cove a few days ago, a turnip bigger than a softball prized from its bed of straw in the frozen earth, a parsnip as thick as a man's wrist from the same place, wild rice -- a gift from a Minnesota friend -- and a buttercup squash that was stashed with others of its kind in the coldest room in the house in late fall. 
 In other years, the turnip would have been boiled and mashed, but we recently discovered that thin strips of raw turnip, particularly one that has been left in the ground through a few frosts, are crisp and sweet in a salad. The parsnip will be cut in quarter-inch cross sections and baked for a half-hour or so after being coated with orange juice, brown sugar and butter; its nut-like flavor goes well with wild game, especially waterfowl.
This privileged intimacy with what we eat is cause for rejoicing, whether it is vegetables from the garden, the black duck taken as it made its vertical leap from the pool where 60 years ago my boyhood chum Beany Alley hooked and lost the largest sea-run brook trout I have ever seen, or the nine-point Adirondack buck that on a morning of new-fallen snow this past November stared at me from between two trees 135 yards away in the forest. I wouldn't have seen the animal were it not for the marvelous eyes of my friend and guide, Basil Cheney, and when we dine on the buck I give thanks to the animal, to Basil, to my Adirondack host, Joseph Cullman 3d, and to the gods of the hunt. I have no such rapport with a roast from the A & P.
Our holiday meal will be preceded by 20 oysters grilled on the half shell after being sprinkled with seasoned bread crumbs and dotted with butter. Ruth and I harvested a bushel of them from Tisbury Great Pond earlier this month, taking advantage of a calm, sunny day to go in our canoe to the pond's barrier beach where the bivalves would be at their saltiest.
Wearing chest waders and with a wire basket floated by an inner tube tethered to me, I raked the oysters from the bottom with a potato fork. Bright sun and no wind made it easier to spot the quarry. I have raked oysters on dark, rough days, but under those conditions most of what I get is clumps of them mixed with empty shells and other debris.
 When you can see what you are doing, you can get many more large single oysters.
Clumped oysters are just as succulent as the singles, but you have to break them apart. Separating the clumps is a job for Ruth, who chooses to remain on shore. Armed with a little billy club, she judiciously taps them asunder and when one is accidentally broken she eats it on the spot. The unbroken oysters are carefully placed, deep side down, in a basket. So stored, with a damp burlap bag or blanket over them, they will last for a couple of months if kept in a cool place.
Putting stores by is an honorable pursuit, although admittedly there are times when it would be more economical -- if the hours spent nurturing the crop had been devoted to earning a living -- to purchase what we ate.
 Our '95 potato crop was an example of this. Ravaged by drought and insects, it amounted to little more than three bushels instead of the usual eight, and most of those potatoes are so small that peeling them gives you writer's cramp. On the other hand, reaching into the warm earth under the pre-drought plants in mid-July for a batch of new potatoes, boiled with their skins on, made it worth the gambit.
Sometimes the a crop's value is essentially symbolic, like the lettuce in the Christmas Eve salad. Several years ago, I built a cold frame out of some discarded plywood and an old storm window and put it against the south side of the house. We start plants in it in the spring, and in the fall we keep a dozen or so lettuce plants in it, banking it with straw and covering it with blankets on cold nights, so that on Christmas Eve we can enjoy a home-grown salad, which will include leeks, turnip, grated carrot, slices of tomatoes that we dried last fall -- boiled for one minute to reconstitute them -- and our own white wine vinegar-raspberry dressing.
The pumpkin for this year's Christmas Eve pie was grown by someone else. While visiting her parents in Wanaque, N.J., Ruth, during a hike with her 94-year-old father, found a brace of large pumpkins left in the woods by Halloween pranksters, and being an inveterate scavenger, brought them back to Martha's Vineyard.
The cast iron stove that heats the room in which we will eat will be fed with wood from trees that were blown down or shattered in storms, mostly white and red oak and locust. Some of it was from our own trees, but most came from the woods of
others, ours for cleaning up the worst of the storm-caused shambles.
There will be a few presents to unwrap on Christmas eve, but the most important gifts will have no ribbons around them.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

THE BUDGET
 
Talking the Talk
After weeks of name-calling, percolating their budget data and trying in vain to reconcile their priorities without betraying their ideologies, Democratic and Republican leaders thought they could make a deal to produce a balanced Federal budget within seven years -- and, more immediately, pass a spending measure that would end the shutdown of the Federal Government. Not so fast, said 73 House Republicans, the shock troops of Newt Gingrich's army.
 But after face-to-face talks at the White House on Friday, President Clinton and some Republicans expressed optimism, then adjourned until next Friday.
 
TELECOMMUNICATIONS
 
Off the Table and Into the Bog
It's the greatest bill in the history of telecommunications, its backers say, bringing unimaginable benefits to the telephone, broadcasting and cable television industries by allowing them to traffic in one another's markets. Maybe even consumers will benefit, if increased competition and deregulation work the way the theories say they should. The bill would, for instance, lift all limits on how many radio stations a single owner could have nationwide, which means fewer owners over all. The sponsors say that would provide more competition and program diversity. Yet just as the conferees seemed to be wrapping up their work, a group of House Republicans rebelled (sound familiar?), protesting that the bill contained too much regulation and made too many concessions to the Democrats.
 
INVESTING
 
Congress Limits Lawsuits
Overiding a Presidential veto for the first time in the Clinton Administration, the Senate and House limited the ability of shareholders to file fraud suits against corporate officers, underwriters and accountants. The law allows the Securities and Exchange Commission to continue pursuing fraud claims but places formidable obstacles before individuals who want to do the same. In his veto message, President Clinton said he was concerned that the bill would hurt small investors. The veto enraged some Democrats, including Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee and a sponsor of the legislation.
 
INTEREST RATES
 
A Nudge From the Fed
Saying it saw little danger of inflation anywhere in the economy, the Federal Reserve lowered its Federal funds rate by one-quarter of a point, to 5.5 percent -- its first rate cut in five months. Few banks followed suit by cutting their prime rates, and the markets seemed preoccupied with the budget stalemate and bad news on earnings in the technology sector.
 
TOBACCO
 
A Fifth State Seeks Damages
In a complaint in state court, Massachusetts sued the nation's largest tobacco companies, trying to recoup Medicaid and other health care costs for treating smoking-related illnesses. The state estimated the costs at $200 million a year. Florida, Minnesota, Mississippi and West Virginia have similar suits pending.
 
BANKING
 
The Consolidation Continues
Fleet Financial agreed to pay $3.26 billion, most of it in cash, for NatWest Bank, the New York and New Jersey banking subsidiary of the National Westminster Bank of Britain. Fleet said it expected to trim 1,800 jobs and close 30 branches, most of them on Long Island.
 
GOLF
 
Bigger Is Richer
Cobra Golf, which flourished with its lines of oversized clubs, accepted a $700 million takeover offer from American Brands, which makes Titleist clubs and balls and Foot Joy golf shoes.
 
WILDCATS
 
Offensive Platoon Takes Field
As Northwestern University prepares for a rare trip to a bowl game -- it will play the University of Southern California in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1 -- the school is besieged with requests from companies hoping to license its insignia and its mascot, Willie the Wildcat. In addition to the usual caps, shirts and towels, Northwestern has licensed pasta shaped like the initials N.U. and caps and sweaters for dogs and cats. The school rejected requests to market Northwestern toilet seats and toilet paper.

TIMING
 
Soros Bets on Russia
After pulling most of his investments out of Russia, George Soros has decided it's time to go back in. Not that he likes what he sees; he describes his assessment as "cautiously pessimistic." Despite the breakdown of many governmental and financial controls, Mr. Soros said: "It is all a question of timing. Right now you have a situation where you can buy assets undervalued."
 
BEVERAGES
 
Gagging on Snapple
Acknowledging that its $1.7 billion purchase of Snapple had been disappointing, Quaker Oats warned that earnings in the current quarter would take a hit and said it would take a $40 million pretax charge to cover the cost of getting rid of overcapacity in Snapple's bottling operations. During 1995, Snapple revenue fell more than 10 percent. "The bottom line is that Snapple has not sold well in Peoria," said John McMillan, a Prudential Securities analyst. "Although Quaker's strategy was to make it a national and then a global product, it remains an East Coast-West Coast Yuppie brand."
 
TAXIS
 
Higher Fares in New York?
The cost of short trips would rise sharply, longer trips less so, under a plan proposed by the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission. The idea is to encourage drivers rainforest "to go on out and pick up fares, not sit in front of hotels waiting for airport rides," said Christoper R. Lynn, the commission chairman.

HEADLINE: DECEMBER 17-23;
Wall Street to Washington: May Be a Bumpy Ride Ahead

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
The financial markets finally woke up to the fact that the budget negotiations in Washington could easily go nowhere -- exactly what Wall Street, which has counted on big deficit-cutting, has long insisted is unthinkable. So on Monday, in a warning shot to Washington, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped an attention-getting 101 points. It recovered some when the Federal Reserve, nervous about conflicting evidence of a weakening economy, eased its short-term rate by a slim quarter of a percentage point. But for the rest of the week the Dow rose and fell with the level of oratory in Washington, suggesting that the last week of an otherwise banner year could be a bit rough. DAVID E. SANGER

HEADLINE: Economic Development Cannot Replace Public Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, one of Harlem's more influential religious leaders, seems to accept at face value Republican politicians' talk of "economic development" as a way to create jobs and solve the problems of Harlem, breaking the "dependency cycle" of social welfare programs ("The Political Dance of Calvin Butts," Dec. 3). 
 Over half the people who live in Harlem make less than $10,000 yearly. Almost as many receive public assistance. Can Mr. Butts actually believe that this magic wand of economic development will significantly change this? Can he actually believe that Governor Pataki and the State Legislature or Mayor Giuliani -- the same people who have increased City College tuition, raised subway fares 20 percent and cut funding at Harlem Hospital -- are going to produce jobs to replace the programs that keep people from becoming homeless and going hungry?
The possibility Mr. Butts might become a mayoral candidate is frightening. Having influenced blacks to support Ross Perot and vote against Governor Cuomo, he might be a spoiler again, attracting just enough votes from the Democratic candidate to doom us to four more years of Rudolph Giuliani.
 
MICHAEL HENRY ADAMS
Harlem

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For Labor, a Nation to Envy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
JOHN SWEENEY, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president, was called a militant and a radical when he supported janitors from his service workers union who blocked bridges into Washington last summer to demand higher wages. So it is no surprise that Mr. Sweeney should speak with awe and envy, as he did recently, about what France's workers have accomplished.
No one is predicting an American replay of the events in France, where workers shut down the railroads, subways, buses and mails to protest planned cuts in pensions and health insurance, and hundreds of thousands of workers took to the streets in a dozen cities. But the betting among many labor experts is that American unions will begin using aggressive tactics not seen since the 1930's. 
 "There are so many potential hot spots in the American economy that when you strike the match, which Sweeney and some other people are about to do, there are going to be some explosions," said Steven Fraser, a writer and labor historian.
For many reasons, any such explosions are likely to be smaller than France's. For one thing, while public-sector employees spearheaded France's strikes, most American government workers are barred from striking and face severe penalities if they do -- something air-traffic controllers learned the hard way from Ronald Reagan.
Also, American workers do not share France's tradition of general strikes and mass unrest, a legacy that runs from the storming of the Bastille in 1789 to the worker-run Paris Commune in 1870 to the worker-student general strike of 1968 that helped push Charles de Gaulle from power.
 
Revolutionaries All
 American workers cannot count on much public support, either. The French, thinking of themselves as to-the-ramparts descendants of the Revolution, tend to sympathize with workers acting like sans-culottes, overturning buses and blocking highways; American drivers spewed unprintable epithets at the janitors on Washington's bridges. In France, the working class is taught to resent the rich, while American workers are told that, with a little luck, they too can be rich.
American labor's less-than-lustrous record on strikes is also discouraging militancy. The mighty United Auto Workers won nothing in its 18-month walkout against Caterpillar, while workers at the Detroit Free Press and Detroit News are out on the wintry streets after five months on strike. If there is any encouragement, it was the strike against Boeing, which ended this month after the union fought off concessions on health insurance and won a better pay package and protections against Boeing's sending work overseas.
Still, some labor leaders see one overarching reason why American workers may be ripe for mass protest: their wages have not kept up with inflation.
"If you take the phenomenon where the average worker's wages are standing still or regressing while the stock market is past 5000 and corporations are healthy and wealthy and C.E.O.'s are making more money than ever, if you put all this stuff together, it has the seeds for general unrest in this country," said Gerald McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
If Washington ignores labor's concerns about stagnant wages while Congressional Republicans cut new holes in the safety net, some union leaders say, labor's minions might be spurred to action. In that way, the Republicans could provoke labor militancy as the French Government unwittingly did when it moved to cut labor's privileges.
So Mr. Sweeney is straining to mobilize workers. "A lot of people might say, 'Let's have a one-day strike around the country,' " said Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council. "But if not many people join the strike and if most Americans feel inconvenienced by it, that's certainly not going to do the labor movement any good."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1514 words

HEADLINE: Back When We Liked Ike

BYLINE: By Eugene Kennedy; Eugene Kennedy's "Recovering Authority," written with Sara Charles, will be published next year.

 BODY:

THE LOST CITY
Discovering the Forgotten Virtues of Community in the Chicago of the 1950s.
By Alan Ehrenhalt.
Illustrated. 310 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $24.
THE author's dedication, crisp and epigraphic as a headstone, both honors his father's memory and manifests the thesis of this provocative book. If William Ehrenhalt was born in Chicago in 1898 and died there in 1986, the dedication tells us, he "flourished 1950-1960." So, too, contends his son, Alan, did America in that decade termed "apathetic" by many of those who now long for its homely strengths of community and good order. 
 "The Lost City" is Chicago during the Eisenhower era. Mr. Ehrenhalt presents the metropolis as a polyptych, allowing our glance to rove across it or to focus on one of four major panels. At dead center is the Loop and the fabled Cook County Democratic political culture. Just south of that is the community of Bronzeville, where segregated wards restricted black ambition and achievement. Beyond that stretches the self-contained and self-nurturing enclave of a Roman Catholic parish, St. Nicholas of Tolentine. Farther west, a classic postwar suburb, Elmhurst, sprouts out of the prairie as swiftly as corn once did. Through these Mr. Ehrenhalt, the executive editor of Governing magazine and the author of "The United States of Ambition," illustrates his vision of America before the fall, an Eden against whose tranquillity we rebelled in the 60's, demanding unlimited choice and freedom and thereby exiling ourselves on the cold and morally trackless plains of modern life.
Earthly Edens are always remembered the way aging actresses were filmed in the 1930's -- through filtering gauze from a flattering angle, with a deft use of shadow. The author is well aware of the mitigating effects of retrospect, however, and factors them into his exploration of the parallel worlds of mid-century and millennium. A shrewd understanding of the chronic fault lines in the human condition informs his analysis. He has a good eye for the sins and shortfalls of the admired past as well as for the virtues that can be identified in the much bewailed present.
In the 1950's, Mr. Ehrenhalt suggests, Americans inhabited neighborhoods whose very crowdedness and circumscribed privacy contributed to an environment of easy intimacy, unlocked doors and low crime rates. Residents, raised in the Great Depression and World War II, were accustomed to deprivation and delay of gratification. Their dreams were of making something of themselves, not of "having it all," and they were realistic about the boundaries within which they had to pursue their lives, marriages and careers.
Mr. Ehrenhalt argues that "stable relationships, civil classrooms, safe streets -- the ingredients of what we call community -- all come at a price. The price is limits on the choices we can make as individuals, rules and authorities who can enforce them, and a willingness to accept the fact that there are bad people in the world and that sin exists in even the best of us."
The 60's, in the writer's opinion, addressed many of the previous decade's problems, like the moral hypocrisy and racial segregation that burned like abandoned mines beneath the surface of his Arcadian America. Yet the social uprisings of the 60's not only exposed the weaknesses of the 50's but also compromised the era's strengths, without providing alternatives to them.
The ideas of the 1960's constitute, in Mr. Ehrenhalt's words, "the manifesto of an entire generation . . . now in its 30's and 40's," and those ideas include an uncritical acceptance of choice as a self-justifying virtue, authority as a vice and sin as a function of social forces rather than personal behavior. Such notions, the negative image of the values that anchored the 1950's, have "brought us a world of restless dissatisfaction, in which nothing we choose seems good enough to be permanent . . . in work, in marriage, in front of the television set." So, too, the "suspicion of authority has meant the erosion of standards of conduct and civility," while the transformation of sinners into passive victims who have been dealt "bad cards in life" places us "a step away from deciding that there is no such thing as right and wrong."
Mr. Ehrenhalt is not just another sociological scold, however, but rather a critic who invites readers to sift through the relics of the 1950's to discover how another age can shed light on our own. Indeed, the author is countercultural himself, as when, for example, he explores what he terms "the uses of sin." The culturally correct perception of the late Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago has long been that of an unforgiving and unforgiven political boss. In making the 1950's more three-dimensional, Mr. Ehrenhalt presents Daley in a subtler fashion, documenting his reforms and accomplishments, and observing that his tolerance of human failure in those around him is a strength, not a weakness, for anyone who wants to govern successfully in a sinful world.
The Democratic machine in Chicago operates differently today under the old mayor's son, Richard M. Daley. Reformers have, among other things, almost completely destroyed the capacity to exercise patronage. "But," Mr. Ehrenhalt asks, in the face of this and other supposed advances, "are the schools better, the streets safer, the local government more responsive to the day-to-day concerns of the residents? Virtually everybody realizes that the answer to these questions is no. Is there a feeling of community that fosters attachment and commands the loyalty of 40 years ago? The answer to that question is equally clear."
In similar fashion, he examines the city's "bungalow people," the thousands of forgotten Chicagoans who lived in brick-faced one-story houses with finished cellars and tended lawns that advertised generally lower-middle-class Roman Catholic decency and customs. The church's parishes so dominated the city's cohesive neighborhoods that it was natural to feature them in real estate advertisements, such as "St. Nick's parish, 6 rm brick -- beautiful." Those neighborhoods, each with bankers and storekeepers who knew everybody on a first-name basis, provided strong familial and group identity as well as the pre-air-conditioning street life that promoted constantly overlapping patterns of socialization. That kind of community has disappeared, along with individuals in "the lost city" like the benign old pastor, Monsignor Fennessy, and the ex-Marine first curate, Father Lynch, who interposed himself into people's lives with a sense of mission and moral purpose.
Also gone are the cramped, Levittown-like houses that were built near the farm town of Elmhurst and finally engulfed it. They represented an Ozzie and Harriet culture, one that was cursed with a false innocence that has become a staple of ridicule for late-century sophisticates. But a closer look, Mr. Ehrenhalt suggests, reveals contentment born of striving to achieve postwar dreams of family and success that is humanly admirable and that has seldom been seen since.
Understanding the enormous risks he is taking, Mr. Ehrenhalt enters Bronzeville, the large segregated area within whose political, social and economic limitations African-Americans were contained. Yet in that universe a vibrant culture embracing and expressing family, religion, politics, music, theater and even the numbers racket flourished -- as did extraordinary political leaders like William Dawson and spellbinding preachers like Clarence Cobb of the First Church of Deliverance. The author is not blind to the evils of segregation but neither is he ignorant of the arid and dangerous housing projects that now stand, all but ruins, where Bronzeville once bloomed in the shadows cast by the skyscrapers of a white city. The substitute housing -- called "vertical ghettos" -- has failed to improve the lives or opportunities of those who must live in it.
"BRONZEVILLE'S leaders," Mr. Ehrenhalt writes, "were doing what leaders in any community are supposed to do: maintain a set of institutions that can give a semblance of order and stability to life. . . . Nor is it too much to say that the absence of functioning institutions and leaders has been a calamity for those left behind on the streets of what used to be Bronzeville in the years since then."
"The Lost City" is not an exercise in nostalgia for lost worlds. Mr. Ehrenhalt's concern is to rehabilitate the positive values of community and authority that gleam like seams of gold in the fallen structures of the 1950's. It is a goal that he sees as no less important for future generations than, say, reducing the crushing deficit. True, Mr. Ehrenhalt fails to distinguish between authoritarianism and authority, and, true, he overromanticizes both brightly lighted Bronzeville and pre-Vatican II Catholicism. Nonetheless, he cannot fail, because of his fair and engaging manner, to draw the reader into hard thinking about the social conditions and institutions necessary for truly human lives.

GRAPHIC: Photo. (Ray Bartkus)

LENGTH: 4088 words

HEADLINE: WHO NEEDS AMERICA ONLINE?

BYLINE: By Jesse Kornbluth; Jesse Kornbluth won the 1994 award from the Computer Press Association for investigative reporting.

 BODY:
Ah, doughnuts, breakfast of champions!" Ted Leonsis exclaimed as he entered a conference room one morning in March and spotted a tray of standard-issue pastries. Leonsis is not a small man, so his quip drew a laugh. It also reassured his associates, who remembered how little pleasure Leonsis had found in his last meeting in this room.
A month earlier, two Californians traveled to America Online headquarters in Vienna, Va., to present a proposal for an on-line site dedicated to surfing, the real kind, done in water. Assuming that the members of America Online's staff would be corporate types, the two Californians, Mark
Bertignoli and Bob Wolfe, wore newly purchased suits and ties. Their presentation was equally buttoned up. Ten minutes in, Leonsis had heard enough. He turned to a colleague and fumed, "These are the [expletive] surfers?" and started reading his mail. 
 Bertignoli and Wolfe took the hint. Now, for their second-chance presentation, they strolled in wearing caps, sunglasses, Hawaiian shirts, shorts and sandals. Bertignoli's first words were, "We're back, bitchin' and bad." Before he outlined his plans for Surf Net, he gave Leonsis a T-shirt from a cult film called "Surf Nazis Must Die." Only when he had done everything but ride a wave did he segue into cyber-speak: "Check this -- we can literally beam out from the beach. We can have live chat with near-video on demand, using a 540c laptop, a PC/MIA pocket insert and a 14.4 modem connected to a cell phone. And we can upload pictures in two minutes to a folder on a Web site."
"What ABC did at the Super Bowl," said Randy Dean, head of America Online's sports department.
"And then there's the interactive stuff," Bertignoli said. "We'll have trivia contests, a fantasy league, pictures of the surf injury of the month."
The Californians showed off their graphics, then were ushered outside to await the verdict.
"A fairly small market," a skeptic noted.
"No," Leonsis said. "This isn't about surfers. It's about surf, sharks and sex -- and by sex I mean healthy bodies, pretty people, California. You saw that 30-foot wave, you took a deep breath. But you didn't really want to be there. That's the beauty of this: it's not just surfing for surfers, it's also for wannabes."
The debate was brief. Bertignoli and Wolfe returned. But before Dan Krifcher, manager of an America Online division called Greenhouse, welcomed them to the service, Leonsis had two more questions.
"You full time?"
"You bet."
"Profit or not?"
"Megaprofit."
Leonsis nodded. "Profit is cool."
COOL" IS THE HIGHEST ACCOLADE IN the Leonsis lexicon, and he has conferred it on more than two dozen presentations this year. As a result, the Greenhouse -- a unit of America Online that the 38-year-old Leonsis formed in summer 1994 to attract fresh ideas from nontraditional sources -- has introduced an array of disparate talents. There's a writer who bills himself as a 60-second novelist, a site for people of color, a Health Zone, an astrology service, a cyber free-for-all called Hecklers Online and, with midsummer fanfare, Surf Net. Leonsis, who is president of America Online Services Corporation and its chief programmer, promises much more. "Between January and June of 1996, we'll launch 70 Greenhouse sites, which is equal to all the deals we signed last year," he says. "I can't think of a movie studio that productive."
America Online can afford it. The company has grown from 300,000 subscribers in 1993 to more than 4 million today, with 250,000 members joining each month, making it the most popular on-line service in the country. As a result, the company has been a favorite of investors, who have driven up the stock price more than 2,800 percent since 1992. The Greenhouse signings are, nevertheless, necessary -- even crucial -- to America Online's future. Despite its current dominance, the company is vulnerable, and not just to its direct competitors, an increasingly aggressive Compuserve, a revived Prodigy, the yet-to-be-announced News Corporation-MCI Online Ventures service and the enormously endowed Microsoft Network.
According to conventional wisdom, the only significant destination in cyber-space is the World Wide Web; by this argument, all commercial services are doomed to be nothing more than Internet-access providers. "We see a lot of talent entering the field on the Web without the blessing of the branded services," says Edward Bennett, president of Prodigy. "And where human attention goes, advertisers will follow."
Some commercial services have already positioned themselves as Internet navigators. Leonsis calls them "Johnny-come-lattes" and scoffs at the conventional wisdom. "They all say, 'Content is king,' " he says. "But how can you argue that when there are 200,000 Web sites? The more that's out there, the better it will be for a service with strong programming." In other words, with such a huge and bewildering proliferation of sites, users will want a central starting place.
So the challenge for Leonsis is to develop compelling content that is available only on America Online. Here he has a competitive advantage: he is the first on-line executive who can make a sizable investment in talent. On most networks -- including America Online in pre-Greenhouse days -- the economics of cyber-space are attractive to only the on-line service. Typically, these services charge customers a monthly fee that covers the first 10 hours of use. Their profit lies in signing up a great many customers, and then enticing them to stay on line for more than the basic 10 hours. For the independent creators of programming, however, the reward is minuscule: 20 percent of the revenue they generate. In the first wave of on-line growth, services tended to form alliances with established media companies (@times, the on-line version of The New York Times, for instance, has been on America Online since June 1994) and to encourage user-generated content -- "chat rooms" and bulletin boards. As services began to look alike, however, it seemed that the key to growth was original programming.
The Greenhouse is the first to recognize that quality programming costs money. And so, in exchange for 20 percent of the equity, America Online invests between $100,000 and $500,000 in its partners' sites. It's no wonder, then, that two months after America Online announced the Greenhouse, it had 2,000 applications.
Suddenly, every service created its own version of the Greenhouse or found a reason not to need one (see box) or attacked America Online. Leonsis, who was mostly unknown outside the new media universe just a year ago, loves the attention and the competition. Now he is in a position roughly equivalent to head of programming at a television network or production chief at a movie studio; he finds it an apt comparison when it's suggested that he might become the Brandon Tartikoff of cyber-space.
TED LEONSIS HAS NEVER HAD A PROBLEM with high visibility. On the rare occasion in his bachelor days when he was dateless, he tended to join paired-off friends at restaurants carrying a bust of Elvis Presley and announcing to the hostess, "Table for eight -- and the King doesn't like to be kept waiting." But his taste for the dramatic obscures the fact that Leonsis is a passionate student of "new media."
An only child, Leonsis grew up in Brooklyn and Boston; he went to Georgetown University planning to become a teacher. He worked as a writer at Wang, where he learned to love computers. At 25, he started his first company by turning a data base about software products into a publishing enterprise. It's not surprising, therefore, that when Leonsis became a co-founder of Redgate Communications in 1985, at 28, he positioned it as "a new life form," not as an advertising agency. "At Wang, the basic premise was that you could take a keystroke and digitize it," he explains. "Bill Gates went a step further. He understood that once you digitize information, you change its DNA. Gates saw that anything could be software. So in '84 and '85, no matter what meeting I was in, I felt something cataclysmic was happening, that dogs would sleep with cats and the sun would set in the East."
Which led Leonsis to experiment. At Redgate, he produced the first multimedia CD-ROM. He started six personal computer magazines and was the co-author of three books. He created an all-digital multimedia service and a CD-ROM shopping program. "Every other word out of Ted's mouth was 'digital,' " recalls Bob Nicholson, a former Air Force public-affairs officer (and a 20-year veteran of the Internet and its progenitor, Darpanet) who has worked with Leonsis since 1986.
By 1994, the little agency in Vero Beach, Fla., that specialized in digitizing and redirecting information had seven offices, a staff of 120 and billings of $70 million a year. Leonsis didn't see that his future was on line. But Steve Case, chairman of America Online, had noticed that Leonsis' ability to bring buyers and sellers together through personalized digital technology was on a parallel track with his company's efforts to create an electronic marketplace. He arranged a breakfast with Leonsis; after a 90-minute conversation, he proposed that America Online buy Redgate. "Ted was coy," Case says, "but I knew he was mesmerized by the opportunity to play on a bigger stage."
Leonsis quickly developed a strategy for the next stage of America Online's growth. "People work and come home, but they also need a third place -- the gym, a bar, whatever," he says. "When they push away from the dinner table, that third place is reading or talking or TV. Right now, online is in about 10 percent of American homes. If it's going to grow, it's got to attract the big audience, which, as a reflex, settles in front of the television set at 9 P.M. every Thursday. In that sense, my real competition isn't Bill Gates, it's 'Seinfeld.' "
But in August 1994, when Leonsis joined America Online and logged onto the network in search of talent he could throw against "Seinfeld," he had trouble finding any great sites. On other networks he found the same numbing sameness. He thought he knew why: on-line services built their business on the wrong model. "Instead of developing original programming, we forged alliances with big media companies," he says. "But many of our partners look at online as an ancillary delivery system, a place to slap electronic versions of newspapers and magazines and press releases onto a medium that seems small and not terribly important to them. There's too much: online, not cable TV, is the medium with 500 channels, and it's ugly. We're all pretty pathetic."
But amid the dross, Leonsis found the Motley Fool, a stock advisory site on America Online developed by Tom and David Gardner, two brothers in their 20's. The Gardners had the finest education offered by New England prep schools and elite colleges and then found they were allergic to conventional employment. They were equally dismayed by professional stock pickers, who as a group underperform against the Dow Jones average. If Wall Street was populated by "the wise," they reasoned, they would do better to embrace Fooldom. Using $50,000 of their own money, they bought stock, went on line and began comparing notes with their fellow amateurs. They were an immediate hit, both in the market, where they were outperforming the Dow by 22 percent, and on line, where they were on their way to converting 5,000 initial customer entries a month into 300,000 a month.
"Two kids became our No. 1 personal-finance providers -- two kids!" Leonsis says. "Why? Because they tapped into the DNA of our community." Surely there must be others who could dispense knowledge and create a comfortable environment that allowed subscribers to become collaborators. A few weeks later, Leonsis and his colleagues brainstormed their way to a possible solution: a division that would transform the ultimate cyber-experts, the users, into content providers.
Some Greenhouse content is quite high-minded. When its Afrocentric site, Net Noir, made its debut in July, its first guest was President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti. The Health Zone's fitness programming includes an interactive food diary that describes the caloric, fat and nutrient content of users' diets with just a few keystrokes. And on the Better Health and Medicine Forum -- founded by Elin Silveous and her husband, Dr. Allen Douma, soon after her multiple sclerosis was diagnosed -- there are 240 support groups and bulletin boards with 1,500 topics.
Most initial Greenhouse investments, however, go to those who see themselves primarily as entertainers. Dan Hurley is a journalist who started writing "novels while you wait" on a Chicago street corner more than a decade ago and has since produced 17,254 "one minute" novels. He now conducts an on-line forum in which he interviews a member and then produces an instant story. Eugenie Diserio introduced herself to Leonsis by sending him some hostile E-mail ("I'm having trouble logging on. Did everyone in the world buy modems last Christmas? Is America Online going to be like Power Rangers?") and soon found herself starting Astronet, an interactive astrology service.
It is Hecklers Online, though, that best expresses Leonsis' view that the ideal content provider is a party host, not a monologuist. Hecklers is a site where guests are regularly roasted and audience members are invited to ask impertinent questions. "Sean Michael and Scott Davis and I are old friends from high school who spent a lot of detention time together," says Mike Ragsdale, one of the site's three founders. "One night we were sitting around drinking beer and we decided to have some fun on line, so we went into a chat room and asked, 'What is a jihad?' Someone answered, 'A holy war.' We typed back, 'Isn't that an oxymoron?' Then a bunch of us would jump into a chat room and harass the people there until we'd be the only ones in 'Gay Cops in Houston.' "
Surfers, the terminally ill, diet specialists, hecklers -- this is a ragtag band of talent. Isn't online supposed to be cutting edge, geared to the young and hip? "When I first got here, I thought we should be the MTV of the 90's," Leonsis says. "But it wasn't an accurate analogy. As I double-clicked into our community, I saw it was the American Association of Retired People, Christianity Today, military people, pet lovers -- a real Norman Rockwell picture of America. Face it, when you go to a cocktail party and America Online diskettes are being used as coasters, you know you've become mainstream."
AS IF PROGRAMMING America Online, continuing as president of Redgate, running America Online's new Internet connection and being a husband and a father of two weren't enough, Leonsis has taken on another role: point man in the propaganda war against the Microsoft Network.
Leonsis understood from the beginning that the on-line world has the potential to become significant to more than Wall Street and the current 11 million American users. And so, shortly after he arrived at America Online, he gave a five-minute talk on the subject. "This is the most important battle in the fight to stop Gates," he said. "Operating systems are episodic -- you buy them once every few years. But online is ongoing. It's bigger than computers -- it's about operating your life." The bottom line: beat Gates before Gates beats America Online. So he set the Greenhouse in motion.
That zeal was not enough to keep NBC from moving its on-line site to the Microsoft Network. This defection from America Online was widely noticed, not least because it caused America Online stock to lose 6 points in two days. Leonsis, predictably, played this as a signal that the Microsoft Network would feature banal programming from brand names. "We told NBC: 'We need to do original programming with you, not just run promotional material as news. We paid you $1 million a year. We'll give you $1.5 million if you deliver original material.' The word is that Microsoft offered NBC $4 million. If so, it says they'll have every brand in there. It will be hard for a network that broad to have a point of view."
Martin Yudkovitz, president of NBC Interactive Media, laughed at that analysis. "If Ted wasn't interested in NBC, he did a magnificent job at hiding it," he says. The Microsoft retort is even stronger. "We didn't pay tons of money to recycle NBC's old content," says Bill Miller, director of marketing for the Microsoft Network. "Microsoft as a shark buying everything -- that's wrong. If we wanted to do that, we would have announced 15 deals with names you've heard of."
Miller contends that it's Microsoft, not America Online, that's friendlier to the unknown content provider. "Greenhouse is a great program, and I wish I'd thought of it -- though I'm not sure I couldn't have," he says. "But if you're not a winner in the Greenhouse competition, it's hard, if not impossible, to get onto America Online."
More recently, Time magazine moved from America Online to Compuserve. Once again, Leonsis put great spin on what looked like a defection. "We have five Greenhouse areas that have been performing as well as Time," he explains. "If we didn't spend that money on Time, we realized we could spawn a dozen Greenhouse deals that might also perform at that level -- and we'd have equity in them. That was very compelling to us."
As with NBC, memories differ. "What Compuserve is offering isn't just money," says Barrett Seaman, special-projects editor for Time. "You hit 'News' on Compuserve, and you'll get Time -- we'll be their gateway to the news. If we had gotten that kind of exposure on America Online, we might still be there." (As America Online users well know, The New York Times icon is almost always on the service's welcome screen, giving it a visibility that makes it unequaled as a news site on that network.)
At this point, even an observer who enjoys cyber-tennis might have trouble deciding whom to believe. But that's an old-media preoccupation. This is nothing less than media war, conducted by media via media, in which all victories are measured by points of market share. All that seems clear -- for the moment, anyway -- is that the service that wins the first scrimmages will be the one that creates the first generation of on-line celebrities.
Here, at least, America Online has the advantage. As Leonsis likes to point out, the leaders in radio didn't flourish in the early days of television, and the leaders in the television business did not spawn the lucrative cable business. Rather, the pathfinders tend to come from young, small, aggressive companies with no legacy of success -- and that, Leonsis says with satisfaction, means America Online, not Microsoft.
So he takes pleasure in telling the story of Brian Henley, the creator of a golf site called I Golf: when Henley was named a Greenhouse partner, he not only quit his regular job, he also convinced the Callaway Corporation, a maker of golf clubs with no history of interest in online, to pay $250,000 to sponsor his site for one year. Leonsis is delighted that the Motley Fools have, with Greenhouse financing, moved out of their one-room office, hired a staff and opened three new sites, including an entertainment review that they've called, inevitably, Follywood. And he cackles when he considers that customers spent 80,000 hours at Hecklers Online in its first month.
But these, Leonsis knows, are the good times. "The Microsoft launch was true to form," he says. "The expectation their public relations machine creates is very hard to meet -- this was a software upgrade, after all, not an AIDS vaccine. But it's an awesome company, and they will figure it out. The challenge for America Online is to get as big as we can as fast as we can. That means more families, more minorities, more women coming to America Online. And it means getting ready for the backlash against the Internet, when the venture capitalists get burned and customers get lost and the magazines start running articles titled 'Whither the Web?' "
All that pressure drives Leonsis in one direction: to sign more talent. "But I know if we open 40 new areas, 10 will be home runs, 10 will be good, 10 will be like everyone else's -- and we'll be embarrassed by the last 10." Leonsis leans back in his swivel chair. "And when that happens," he says, sounding very much like a network programming czar, "I'm going to have to start canceling shows."
 
THE COMPETITION
 
AMERICA ONLINE'S Greenhouse has not gone unnoticed by the competition. The other commercial services have cultivated new talent or, more commonly, asserted that talent development is nothing new.
 
Compuserve
With 3.9 million subscribers, Compuserve is the second-largest on-line service, but it has been marketed so casually that it sometimes seems invisible. This year it woke up, announcing that next spring it will unveil a streamlined network -- Project Wow! -- for newcomers to on-line services and invest in Entertainment Drive (E Drive), which has been drawing an estimated 600,000 Compuserve users. But Compuserve doesn't usually invest in unknowns. "We get 150 inquiries a week from people who want to go on line," says Kevin Knott, vice president of product marketing. "Only a few can make it. We'll help anyone get up on the Internet, but we're very particular what we put on our service. It's very difficult and expensive to establish a new brand."
 
Prodigy
Prodigy, with two million members, was the first service to reach out to a family audience. Since Edward Bennett took over as president in May, Prodigy has made it a priority to broaden its audience by developing talent, producing a remarkable number of new Internet sites that can be accessed only through Prodigy: 150 in the past 60 days. "Our aim is to give people information they can use," Bennett says. "We have sites about AIDS, computer-generated music, even one run by adopted children for adopted children."
The secret of Prodigy's speed and scope is that it hires people to develop its sites in-house. "This way, we own 100 percent of our new areas," Bennett notes. "We found that classic information providers wanted too big a cut. They think their content is their brand. They don't understand the medium."
 
Microsoft
The Microsoft Network, with 600,000 subscribers, made its debut in August with enormous fanfare and modest content. "We cast a broad net and made deals with more than 200 independent contract providers from companies valued at less than $10 million," reports Bill Miller, MSN's director of marketing. "These are people who, almost completely, found us."
MSN is primarily an Internet-access link, not a commercial on-line service. "On-line services have said, 'We'll create the world and give you everything you could want,' " Miller explains. "We believe the Internet is too vibrant and strong to limit our customers to Microsoft, so we see our role as helping our users make sense of the Internet. We will invest in good ideas and good people, but the majority of people who look to us for funding will wind up on the Internet, where the barrier to entry is fairly small. We tell them, 'Do a great job on the Net and we'll promote you to MSN.' " Microsoft does occasionally skip this intermediate stage, however -- most recently when it hired Michael Kinsley, of "Crossfire," to start an on-line magazine.
 
News Corporation-MCI On-Line Ventures
In the summer, Rupert Murdoch's Delphi service (100,000 subscribers) was on the verge of a major face lift. Delphi built a 200-desk, state-of-the-art newsroom, held endless meetings with print journalists and announced a contest to name the service. Then News Corporation and MCI announced a joint on-line venture, and two staffs and many ideas had to be integrated. Five months later, the electronic newsroom already seems like an artifact; according to the latest strategy, journalists will be hired, but more to provide content for traditional on-line categories than to create original content for an on-line newspaper.
This approach, sources at News Corporation-MCI suggest, will be matched by a unique on-line environment. Despite the delay, Anthea Disney, former editor of TV Guide and now editor in chief of this new venture, sounds confident of eventual success. "I had no interest in trading 30 million readers a week for a rate base of 100,000," she says.

HEADLINE: Democracy's Trap

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan, a contributing editor of The Atlantic Monthly, is the author of the forthcoming "The Ends of the Earth: A Journey at the Dawn of the 21st Century."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
America needs to curb its missionary zeal to establish multiparty systems in every third world country as fast as it can. Our rote prescription for undeveloped and newly "liberated" nations -- elections within one year, followed by stability -- is more likely to lead to chaos than democracy.
This is not to deny democracy's successes, especially in some Eastern European states. But we must acknowledge its limitations, at least as a quick fix, in a world torn by exploding populations, diminishing natural resources, struggling governments and ethnic rivalries. We should shift our foreign development strategy from one of instant gratification to one of mature patience, encouraging a slower, but more realistic, route to democracy. 
 We seem to assume that our victory in the cold war has paved the way for worldwide democracy. But the demise of the Soviet Union does not necessarily justify creating political parties in, say, Rwanda, where the establishment of a multiparty system and a coalition Government in 1992 hardened ethnic divisions that erupted into civil war and genocide in 1994.
Or in Cambodia, where the United Nations spent several billion dollars on a high-profile election in 1993 that has given us an increasingly dictatorial, corrupt and brutal Government that cannot even control its army.
Or in Haiti, where we can only hope that Jean-Bertrand Aristide, whom we did not allow to run for a second presidential term, can keep the country together from behind the scenes.
States are not formed by elections. They are formed by geography, war, settlement patterns and the rise of literate bourgeoisies. Nor are countries necessarily strengthened by elections. Indeed, democracy initially weakens many states because it demands ineffectual compromises. Totalitarianism is anathema to us, but remember that Bosnian Muslims, Croats and Serbs lived together peacefully and intermarried under Tito's jackboot.
Yet even the Balkan countries -- with their high literacy rates, low birthrates and some tradition of a middle class -- are better candidates for democracy than much of the third world. When elections are introduced suddenly into societies where the poor predominate, random crime and gangsterism often fill the void vacated by tyranny.
Witness South Africa, where in the past year violent crime has increased by as much as 75 percent in some areas. Of course, this is preferable to apartheid, and political violence there has greatly subsided. But if the Government cannot eventually stabilize crime rates, a new form of tyranny, or chaos, could evolve.
Democratic elections often intensify ethnic and regional divisions rather than heal them. In the Caucasus, the collapse of the Soviet Union brought nationalist-democrats to power in Armenia and Azerbaijan. Each leader furthered his country's slide into a brutal war against the other. Only after the freely elected President of Azerbaijan, Abulfez Elcibey, had been toppled in a coup that brought a former Communist leader to power did a modicum of stability return. Some months later, the two countries agreed to a cease-fire.
Because democracy neither forms states nor strengthens them initially, a multiparty system is best suited to nations that already have an established bureaucracy and a middle class which pays income tax and where the main issues of property and power-sharing have been resolved, leaving politicians to argue about budgets. Two perfect examples are Taiwan and Greece, both middle-class, ethnically homogeneous societies that have moved fitfully but successfully toward democracy for decades. Likewise, Chile's impressive economic growth and the withering away of its military dictatorship have made it a suitable candidate for real democracy.
Sometimes an authoritarian regime becomes so odious that out of concern for its citizens (or out of worry that it will destabilize its region) we feel compelled to get involved. Thus Nigeria may be the next battleground of democracy -- and we need to be cautious there.
Nigeria has a volatile mixture of ethnic and regional divisions, and it has a long history of money laundering, drug smuggling and forgery scams. Its increasingly urbanized population is doubling every 22 years and its natural resources are rapidly being depleted. If the West were to force the reintroduction of democracy before attending to other changes, like a reorganization of the military, and leave the day after a "successful" election, Nigeria could slowly unravel.
The example of Nigeria also illustrates how hypocritical Americans can be about exporting democracy. Nigeria is far less developed than, say, Egypt, according to the U.N. Yet, with an eye on geopolitical priorities, the United States doesn't even dare to consider where a real democracy might lead Egypt.
What can we do? We should shift our emphasis in the third world from holding elections to promoting family planning, environmental renewal, road building and other stabilizing projects. We need to sponsor more bread-and-butter literacy and agricultural programs (especially those that focus on women, who in many societies are the keys to cultural transformation). Yes, some dictators may take advantage of such programs, but this approach is better than throwing up our hands and more practical than elections.
History and cultures can rarely be forced by expensive stunts like the United Nations elections in Cambodia. And each failure only provides more ammunition for American isolationists.
This is why even in the Balkans, where there has been a level of social development not enjoyed in Haiti or Cambodia, arming the Bosnian Muslims to create a regional balance of terror is a safer bet than risking NATO's reputation on elections within a year, followed by peace.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Weak Retail Season, And Dubious Prospects
Hardened shoppers, early discounting and a snowstorm that blanketed the Northeast in the crucial final week of Christmas shopping combined to give retailers their worst holiday seasons in years, analysts, economists and other retail experts said. And things won't get better for retailers, many experts said, until more go out of business, reducing the competition.
"We will have continued store closings, continued bankruptcies and an ongoing shake-out in the industry," an investment banker said. Figures on sales will not be available until later this week, but the estimates offered were gloomy. [Page 1.]
 
Israel Overhauls Banking System
The Israeli Government approved sweeping changes in the financial industry, requiring the country's powerful banks to sell substantial parts of their assets. The overhaul has far-reaching implications for the concentration of economic power, as well as for the planned privatization of state-owned banks. [54.]
 
A Railroad Across the Seas
Carl Malamud, whose nonprofit research group, Internet Multicasting, persuaded the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Patent Office to set up public-records distribution sites on the Internet, has set out on a much more ambitious effort to extend a high-speed, multimedia version of the Internet into more than 100 countries. [56.]
 
'We Got Grottoes, We Got Angels'
A nationwide boom in religious statuary is under way. At the Coreglia Studios in North Bergen, N.J., "We got grottoes, we got angels, we've got just about every saint there is," said Walter Baldaccini, whose family company makes plaster and concrete statues of saints, religious figures and Nativity scenes. [1.]
 
An Expensive Day in Tokyo
The spread of Christmas throughout Asia is a tribute to the power of retail stores in shaping social customs. Shops pushed the concept of Christmas to peddle gifts, and now Christmas is becoming an Asia-wide festival. In Japan, it is not a national holiday or even a family occasion, but rather the most romantic day of the year for young lovers, who exchange expensive gifts. [4.]
 
Holding Hands in Cyberspace
Christmas cards, letters and phone calls, the traditional ways that families stay in touch, have been joined by voice messaging and electronic mail. Now the Trueman family, which stretches from the California coast to the Brooklyn Bridge, may be a model of what's next: They stay in touch through a family site on the Internet's World Wide Web. [55.]
 
Spiked Heels and All
Mattel is planning to develop and sell multimedia products and software based on its toy brands, which include Barbie, Hot Wheels, Cabbage Patch Dolls and Polly Pocket. [56.]
 
A Paper's Coverage
Angers Politicians
The Star-Ledger, the 16th-largest daily in the country and the largest in New Jersey, has begun to change under a new editor, Jim Willse, the former editor of The New York Daily News. His effort to inject some edge into the paper's coverage of government is a part of what may be the most ambitious effort to revitalize a large newspaper anywhere in the country. [57.]
 
santa@santaclaus.com
More children are turning to E-mail to make their needs known to Santa Claus, routing it through a site on the World Wide Web run by lawyers in Miami. And that is just one of many holiday-oriented sites on the Internet. Another is Rockefeller Center, with a real-time view of the skating rink and Christmas tree. A camera at France Telecom North America takes a new picture every time the page is viewed. Taking In the Sites. [55.]

HEADLINE: Stadiums' Last Contests Involve Their Fates

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 24

 BODY:
There is a building boom of sorts in professional sports, as peripatetic owners move their teams to new stadiums or new cities.
But lost in the usual debate over the emotional and financial costs of the moves is the question of what to do with the old stadiums. 
 That question is increasingly being asked in cities around the country where sentimentality, a sense of history and some hard economic realities are forcing the issue.
Here, the focus is Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium, the home of the Atlanta Braves baseball team. Until recently, few people had disagreed with the plan to tear it down after the 1996 Summer Olympics finished using it. The land was to be turned into parking lots for the Braves after they were ensconced two blocks away in a new stadium built for the Olympics.
But a group of small-business owners and city officials are asking whether there might be a better use for the 29-year-old stadium, where Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth's career home-run record.
In Detroit, the nation's oldest ball park, Tiger Stadium, would be demolished under a proposal approved by the City Council earlier this month and replaced by a new stadium a couple of miles closer to downtown. While diehard members of the Tiger Stadium Fan Club are fighting to keep the team in place, others, mainly residents of the surrounding community of Corktown, seem to have accepted the move and are about to embark on a six-month study of ways to reuse the stadium. Their suggestions include a super Little League park, a velodrome or a "total athletic-entertainment center."
Similar discussions may soon take place in Pittsburgh, Denver, Houston, Cleveland and Foxboro, Mass., where stadiums have closed, may close or are about to close.
Rick Nafe, president of the Stadium Managers Association and executive director of the Tampa Sports Authority in Florida, said a community had few uses for a building as specialized as a stadium. But his organization is studying the question.
Andrew Zimbalist, an economist who wrote the book "Baseball and Billions," about the finances of the sport, said demolishing stadiums was a waste of important economic resources that are often magically fused with great moments.
For the late A. Bartlett Giamatti, the former commissioner of baseball, the serene, almost rural setting of a ball park surrounded by urban chaos brought to mind the root of the word "paradise," which in Persian meant "enclosed green space."
But now, Mr. Zimbalist noted, "it is getting more like the Joni Mitchell song, and they are paving over paradise to put up a parking lot."
Stadiums have rarely remained standing after their teams have left. As soon as the Chicago White Sox moved across the street to the new Comiskey Park in 1991, the old park was torn down.
A similar fate was generally accepted here as city officials and organizers of the Olympics cobbled together agreements more than 18 months ago for a new stadium that would help insure that the Braves remained in the city. At that time, City Councilman Robb Pitts said, everybody was interested in "keeping peace and not picking a fight."
But two weeks ago, Mr. Pitts offered a council resolution to study how to reuse the stadium.
Alice Bussey, the owner of a florist shop here, is among a group of small-business owners who would like to see the stadium stay open for track-and-field meets, soccer games and as an incubator for small businesses. With its food preparation facilities, the stadium could house training and space for small catering businesses, she said, and its storage areas could serve as warehouse or manufacturing space for start-up businesses.
Ms. Bussey concedes that there are those in the nearby Summerhill and Mechanicsville communities who would like to see the demolition of the stadium, which, when it was built in the mid-1960's, displaced many of their neighbors and brought the regular disruptions of game-day traffic. But she insisted that the old stadium offered an opportunity that could not be passed up.
Reginald Williams, the executive director of the Atlanta-Fulton County Recreation Authority, which manages the stadium and would cease to exist if the park were demolished, agreed and said that alternative areas nearby could provide the estimated 2,500 parking spaces that were to be put on the site of the old stadium.
"It's not a life-or-death situation and the world won't come to an end if the stadium is torn down," Mr. Williams said. "But this facility has tremendous potential for the city and the whole region. There are limitations to what can be done in the new stadium, with the Braves playing 81 home games a year there. But there would be few limitations on us, whether you are talking about track and field, international soccer matches, college football or concerts and a corps of small businesses to serve all of that."
Few in Atlanta talk sentimentally about the need to preserve the place and the left field stands where Hank Aaron hit his record-breaking 715th home run. Not so in Detroit, where Bill Dow, a board member of the Tiger Stadium Fan Club, fairly aches at the thought of a Tiger Stadium without the Tigers, or no Tiger Stadium at all.
Earlier this month, a little over a year after Detroit voters passed a referendum prohibiting the city from helping to finance a new stadium for the Tigers, the City Council, with the help of state government, overturned that measure and voted to build a new stadium with amenities that would provide the team's owners with more revenue. Mr. Dow and others among the 11,000-member stadium fan club went to court and are trying to block the move.
Residents and owners of businesses in the shadow of the 83-year-old ball park have a keen interest in the stadium's future use.
For years, the community has seen the stadium as its focal point but has also seen itself as a pawn of its needs, said Steve Palmer, head of the city-financed Corktown Citizens District Council. The area's businesses and quaint Queen Anne and Victorian houses were replaced with dusty parking lots, and the neighborhood was crisscrossed with highways to bring suburbanites to the games. More than 2,000 homes have been torn down, Mr. Palmer said, and a community that numbered about 3,000 households a couple of decades ago is now down to 722 households.
So the community hopes that the team's departure will not further destabilize the neighborhood, said Mr. Palmer. "While we might be reconciled to the team moving across town," he said, "we don't make the assumption that the old stadium has to be torn down."
With the help of planners, architects and residents, the district council will begin next month to devise new uses for the old stadium. The ideas floating around range from the tame to the "pretty wild," he said. Some people have suggested that the stadium could be adapted to accommodate the growing interest in rock climbing or to have kayak runs through a series of terraced pools.
Those who hope to save the stadiums may find hope in Washington's R.F.K. Stadium, which the Washington Redskins football team is scheduled to leave in 1997 for a new stadium in Prince Georges County, Md.
"There is life after the Redskins," said James A. Dalrymple, the stadium's general manager, noting that they had begun planning for a Redskin-less future more than nine years ago. "It may not be as plush and you may have to work harder to keep the stadium booked up, but it was never a thought to demolish the stadium."
In the past few years, R.F.K. has attracted a number of world-class soccer matches and a slew of college football games and is being considered as the temporary home of a new professional baseball franchise proposed for Virginia.
"We didn't wake up two weeks ago and realize that the Redskins were leaving," Mr. Dalrymple said. "We realized that we had to be prepared, and we have worked our way through the angst."

HEADLINE: RETAILERS REPORT A SHOPPING SEASON WORTH FORGETTING

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Hardened shoppers, perpetual sales and a snowstorm that blanketed the Northeast during the crucial final week of Christmas shopping combined to give retailers their worst holiday season in years, analysts, economists and other retailing experts said yesterday.
"This is the worst Christmas since we have been keeping track of the month of December," said Richard N. Baum of Goldman, Sachs & Company, which has monitored specialty retail sales monthly since 1988. 
 Most experts say they believe that stores will be able to return to the traditional and profitable formula of retailing -- buy things cheaply and sell them for a lot of money -- only when there are fewer of them. Already, there has been evidence of consolidations and the sheer fading away of some stores: at least eight retailers filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1995.
"Clearly, 1995 is one of the worst years in recent memory," said Henry D. Jackson, the principal of Peter J. Solomon, an investment-banking firm in New York. "And the outlook for 1996 is similar. We will have continued store closings, continued bankruptcies and an ongoing shake-out in the industry."
For consumers, of course, all the sales promotions meant that they could do their holiday shopping without paying full price. But good news for them was bad news for the stores, and while hard figures on revenue will not be available until later this week, the estimates offered were roundly gloomy.
"I cannot recall a Christmas that was as lackluster as this in the 37 years I have been monitoring retailing," said Kurt Barnard of Barnard's Retail and Marketing Report in New York. "And this is the only one like it not caused by a recession. The nation is clearly overstored."
Many merchants blamed consumer debt and joblessness for empty stores and clamped pocketbooks.
But other experts say that the dismal season more likely reflects larger trends in American retailing: too many stores carrying too many of the same chenille sweaters, too few shoppers who want to buy a dozen full-priced gifts for every member of their family.
"People should not be blaming the economy in an up-and-down way," said Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "Right now, we are at a growth rate of about 2 percent, which is soft, but not all that bad. There are structural changes, as opposed to cyclical ones," affecting retailing now.
The images of department-store coat racks with 40 percent-off signs, and women's clothing stores where not a creature was stirring early in December, may well serve as the ghost of Christmas future.
Across the country, retailers tried to take advantage of the last week before Christmas, which this year coincided with Hanukkah and contained an extra weekend of shopping days as Christmas fell on a Monday.
But the customer seduction took the form of heavy promotion, which, even when it brought masses of shoppers, cut into profit margins.
"I'm looking around and everything is on sale," said John Konarski, vice president of the International Council of Shopping Centers, calling from a strip mall in West Springfield, Mass., yesterday. "I mean, even the candy place has a sale."
A Bed Bath & Beyond store in Los Angeles hung a sign in the front of the shop that read, "We will match any price from anyone." In Bradlees on Union Square in Manhattan on Saturday morning, a few shoppers fingered reduced-price sweatshirts. Racks of panties and bras seemed untouched. Sale signs were so prominent as to inhibit movement.
Even in popular categories like computers and their accessories, margins took a hard hit.
"We talked to a manager in a Best Buy store in Los Angeles who told us, 'Yes, they are buying, but at prices that make you wonder what will happen to the bottom line,' " said Mr. Barnard, the retailing consultant, who spent the last two weeks in California cruising malls.
As predicted all season, specialty retailers like women's clothing stores did particularly badly. While analysts were estimating sales increases starting in the mid-teen percents for chains like Staples, which sells office equipment, women's clothiers were expected to realize flat-to-3-percent growth.
Regional department stores, with a few exceptions, were expected to post similarly low increases. "Most stores are going to be flat to 2 percent ahead for December," predicted Peter N. Schaeffer, a retail analyst at Dillon, Read & Company. "And some stores will have some negative numbers."
Once the season is over, retailers will have to face hard facts about the future of the industry and the marketplace in which it operates, experts said. That includes consumer debt and the cost-cutting and layoffs at American corporations.
More fundamentally, perhaps, demographic and psychological shifts in the population have hurt retailers, as has the fact too many stores are selling the same products at a constant discount.
"People are simply not accumulating," Mr. Straszheim of Merrill Lynch said. "As the population ages, they care more about their financial futures, like Social Security and health costs. And the experience of the last decade is the later you shop, the cheaper stuff is."
A lack of fashion inspiration hurts the clothing chains, too, Mr. Barnard said, adding, "If you go to malls, you see so many stores that carry the same thing, so much so that sometimes the only way you can tell the difference between one store and another is the name on the door."
Of course, as with so many sad tales, there are winners. Luxury merchants, who sell special things for those who can afford them, like lime-green leather suits, are expected to make out smartly.
"As far as we're concerned, this was a very, very strong Christmas," said Brian Blake, president of the Gucci Group N.V., a unit of Investcorp. "We have not had to take any price reductions to any significant degree." While Mr. Blake was coy with figures, the company posted an 85 percent increase in net sales for the third quarter.
Among large chains, Sears, Roebuck was remarkable for its comeback. "The past week was the best sales week in Sears history," said John Costello, the company's senior executive vice president. He said sales for December were expected to exceed $3.5 billion.
"One of the reasons that department stores were able to come back is that they have a wide base of merchandise," Mr. Konarski of the shopping-center council said. "Shoppers want choice."
Bloomingdale's, owned by Federated Department Stores, expected to squeak in with single-digit same-store sales -- branches operating for a year or more. "Our business in Florida, where we had no bad weather, was 10 percent ahead," said Michael Gould, the chief executive. "You look at that and say, 'Jeepers, creepers, what the Northeast could have been without the snow.' "
Indeed, the heavy snowfall "took about $3 million out of our business," said Philip Miller, chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue.
A spokeswoman from Macy's East, another Federated store, refused to comment, although Michael Steinberg, the chairman of Macy's West said, "The last three days were very strong."
Some categories of merchandise -- what Mr. Baum of Goldman, Sachs called "feel-good" items -- moved well. Those include tasty, naughty snacks, fruit-scented candles and bath oils, and cashmere. Fragrances and cosmetics were snapped up at all prices throughout the season, which might indicate that women shunned apparel for perfume and makeup. "Our cosmetics business is sensational," Mr. Miller of Saks said. "It was up 22 percent."
But for small specialty stores and discounters, bad news is around the corner. "This season is going to be very hard on retailers' fourth-quarter margins," Mr. Schaeffer at Dillon Read said. "We're going to see another large group of bankruptcies in first quarter."
In future years, the result may be that those who survive will be able to sell their wares without giving away the store, as consumers learn what it is to pay full price again.
