HEADLINE: Doctors Try to Master Their Fate Through M.B.A.'s

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif., Dec. 24

 BODY:
Doctors who hope to heal their profession, or at least their portfolios, are thronging graduate business schools, a few of which have begun pampering doctors and catering to their chaotic schedules.
The most elaborate of the programs begins Jan. 7 at the University of California at Irvine, where the charter class of 60 has an average annual income of $230,000. One student made $1.5 million last year. The class, which will meet for one long weekend a month at a palm-lined hotel on the coast of Orange County, costs $48,000 for two years (laptop computer included). 
 Admissions officials at several top business schools said that while their master's of business administration programs had always drawn a few doctors who wanted to run hospitals, the students in the new crop are worried about preserving their authority and income at a time when medicine is being driven increasingly by insurers and cost concerns.
"They realize that if they don't do this, they're on the defensive," said William K. Laidlaw Jr., the executive vice president of the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business, an accrediting group.
Dennis J. Aigner, the dean of Irvine's Graduate School of Management, said the doctors were quite different from the aspiring tycoons who usually fill his seats. "People ask these docs, 'You make $230,000 a year. Why would you go to business school?' " Dr. Aigner said. "This isn't about making more money. This is about survival. They're faced with a significant decline in income."
Dr. Norman F. Sokoloff, 49, an orthopedic surgeon in Sunnyvale, Calif., plans to fly down to Irvine for each four-day session in his twin-engine Cessna. He said his profit had stagnated and then fallen as managed care had increased. "Physicians can become like an ant colony -- flushed away by the rain, because they don't have the tools to deal with it," Dr. Sokoloff said. "We have to learn how to ride this tide."
Dr. Sokoloff has plenty of company. Edmund J. Wilson, an associate dean at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University, in Evanston, Ill., said: "We're getting them for part-time, full-time and non-degree programs. They've gone from essentially zero to a very noticeable presence."
Columbia Business School in Manhattan has five doctors in its full-time M.B.A. program and 11 in its program for executives. The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia has had at least five doctors in each weekend M.B.A. class for the past five years.
The University of South Florida in Tampa has graduated 100 doctors in three years from a doctors-only M.B.A. program where the students are called "execudocs." Classes begin with continental breakfast, and a brochure says the course is "designed to accommodate the most demanding schedules."
A few young doctors are getting a head start by finishing medical and M.B.A. degrees at the same time. David Axelrod, 26, who raced sailboats as an undergraduate at Harvard, is scheduled to get both degrees in May from Duke University in Durham, N.C.
Mr. Axelrod said the biggest conflict between the fields was that doctors focus on individuals, while business people think in aggregates. "Providing a heart transplant to a 65-year-old man is perfectly clinically logical," he said. "But denying it is economically logical. I want to help physicians to feel comfortable making some of these tough choices."
The charter class for Irvine's "health-care executive M.B.A." is 90 percent doctors, including commuters from Arizona, Nevada and Taiwan. The city of Irvine, named for a family that bought three vast Spanish ranches, is filled with Jaguars, bluff-top mansions and other totems of the upper crust.
Classes will meet at The Hyatt Newporter, a retreat overlooking Newport Beach's Back Bay. The classroom has a ceramic-tiled fireplace, and the students' rooms, each with a wrought-iron balcony, overlook a pool and golf course. "They'll have lunch out here in the garden each day. Sometimes out by the pool, depending on how our weather is," the catering director, Monica Mueller Cheeks, said during a tour.
The course has a waiting list of 20.
Ann C. Jennings, the program's director, said many applicants she met were discouraged and disillusioned by changes in their profession. Indeed, some admissions interviews seem to have taken the tone of crisis counseling.
"The doctors said they are being treated as contractors by some of the health care organizations," Ms. Jennings said. "They said they're told, 'If you can't deliver X patients in a day for X amount of dollars, then we'll go down the street and get someone who can.' "
One Irvine student, Dr. Arnold W. Malcolm, 51, a radiation oncologist in Burbank, said he wanted to be able to take on bureaucratic rules -- like having to send patients across town for tests simply because a health maintenance organization has a contract with a laboratory.
"Whether they're in a wheelchair or on a stretcher doesn't make any difference," Dr. Malcolm said. "The patient is coming second."
Another student, Dr. Paul A. De Ridder, a 49-year-old urologist in Santa Ana, Calif., said doctors who cannot talk the language of spreadsheets and efficiency could become "skilled laborers" for insurers.
"Medicine was always mom 'n' pop, where every doctor had his own office, and a nurse who had been there forever," Dr. DeRidder said. "Now, we're part of an integrated delivery system."

HEADLINE: Public Housing Project in North Dallas Spurs Lawsuit and Charges of Racism

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 24

 BODY:
A plan to build a low-income housing project in a predominantly white neighborhood, part of a seven-year effort to rid public housing here of what a court called "vestiges of racism," has led to a lawsuit by neighbors and countercharges that more than a vestige of racism remains.
The 75-apartment project is the first step by the Dallas Housing Authority to put into effect a Federal court directive calling for 474 units in predominantly white areas to reduce the concentration of poor people in the inner city. 
 Last May the housing authority acquired property in North Dallas, a mostly white area of horse pastures interspersed with 200-unit apartment complexes and $150,000-home developments.
After the project was announced, 14 homeowners' groups claiming to represent 2,600 local residents formed a consortium and sued to stop the project. They maintain that their legitimate concerns about property values and overloading of schools and police and fire services have been brushed off.
"This is not a bunch of people who are against people in public housing," says Cliff Whittle, a homeowner who lives about a quarter of a mile from the site of the proposed housing project. "It's an economic and fairness issue."
Mark Wilkinson, president of the consortium, said: "They wanted real bad for us to have a problem with the people. But we don't like the process. And I do know that unless this becomes something the community can embrace, it will fail."
But Alphonso Jackson, a black man who heads the housing authority, said the neighbors had other fears as well. "First, they have a legitimate concern about the loss of property value," he said. "I think they have a legitimate concern about crime. I think the third concern is basically race."
Mr. Jackson said the housing authority had taken steps to alleviate the first two concerns. "And the third, I can't do anything about," he said.
The controversy here is being played out in courts and neighborhoods all over the country, though not always with this degree of local resistance. Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has vowed to reverse three decades of public housing policy that has concentrated minorities and poor people in inner-city areas.
Mr. Cisneros has promoted a policy that seeks to disperse the poor through a combination of voucher programs, block grants and discrimination suits against those who oppose particular programs. He has also scrapped several plans to upgrade large public housing projects of an earlier era. But in Dallas, the impetus came through a lawsuit against city officials.
Eight years ago, Judge Jerry Buchmeyer of Federal District Court found that Federal, state and local officials had conspired to keep black residents in the huge and poorly maintained West Dallas Housing Project. Local public housing officials were ordered to tear down most of the project, a 3,493-unit complex built in the 1950's next to a lead smelter. The replacement units, Judge Buchmeyer ordered, were to be built in the white, middle-class areas of North Dallas.
Elected officials spent the next seven years trying to reverse Judge Buchmeyer's decision. By the time city officials conceded that they would have to comply with Judge Buchmeyer's order, there was not enough land available in North Dallas to build the 3,200 replacement units that the judge ordered.
In the end, it was agreed that the housing authority would build 474 permanent units, and about 2,700 families would be moved into existing housing through vouchers and certificates. The 75-apartment project is the first to be scheduled for construction.
The North Dallas homeowners' suit listed a number of alleged wrongs: violations of the Open Records Act and of the principle of states rights; misuse of taxpayer funds by paying too much for the property; inadequate public transportation for the low-income residents, and the strain the project would put on local schools and fire and police departments.
But the biggest problem, Mr. Wilkinson says, was being told that "we've already addressed your logical concerns."
"And the emotional concerns, we can't do anything about that," he added. "Something like this is a very emotional experience. So when they said they didn't need to hear from us, that led to the lawsuit."
The homeowners do not deny that racism exists. But they say they are not racists, and neither are their concerns based on racism. Instead, radio call-in shows and letters to the editor complain of "Big Brother," "social engineering" and "socialist judges."
At one point Representative Dick Armey, a Republican whose district includes North Dallas and who is the House majority leader, threatened to hold Congressional hearings on the housing authority's site-selection process.
But a spokeswoman for Mr. Armey said she did not know where the matter stood. "He was supposed to mention it to the Banking Committee chairman," she said on Friday. "I don't know whether he did."
Indeed, Mr. Jackson appears to have won the first round. In October, Judge Buchmeyer overruled the homeowners' objections and approved the housing authority purchase, clearing the way for groundbreaking to begin next May.
Mr. Jackson contended that the time to appeal Judge Buchmeyer's order had run out, but a lawyer for Mr. Wilkinson and the homeowners, Larry Friedman, said his clients had authorized an appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit "just earlier this week."
Mr. Wilkerson says he knows he "has no hope of defeating the first site," but wants to appeal anyway to "set a precedent" for future battles. Indeed, the next fight could come in two or three weeks; Mr. Jackson hopes to have a second site under contract by then.
"Henry Cisneros made a big statement by tearing down that complex in Chicago," said Mr. Wilkinson, referring to Cabrini Green, a huge inner-city project. "This is going to be a wave across the nation. But they need to get the process right, because we don't need another series of failures."

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Woman Works Toward a Career and Reunites With Daughter

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY 

 BODY:
Christmas will be sweet this year for Faith Bowman and her 8-year-old daughter, Catey. They may be poor, but they are living together, and that is more than they can say about last year.
Since they couldn't afford a Christmas tree, they have painted one on the kitchen wall, taping up colored paper ornaments and a shining yellow star. They have saved a little money for food, so dinner tonight will be ham, with sides of cornbread, collard greens and candied sweet potatoes made from "Sister Pamela's Soul Food Cookbook," a 25-cent find at a used book sale. 
 A year ago, they weren't doing as well. Ms. Bowman, 26, was living in Brooklyn with six housemates, earning her keep by having conversations with male callers to a telephone sex line. Catey was living in an unofficial foster home in Pittsburgh under the care of a woman she called Aunt Cindy.
The new year began tumultuously, when Ms. Bowman fell into a paranoid depression on Jan. 10. It was sparked, she said, by two puffs from a cigar wrapper filled with marijuana. She spent 17 days in the psychiatric ward at Harlem Hospital. It was an odious experience, she said, except for one moment of clarity in which she decided to become a photographer.
February was filled with errands -- buying a camera, going to therapy, compiling a portfolio, applying for public assistance and filling out an application for the two-year photography program at Parsons School of Design. She gave up drugs, alcohol and sex.
"From the minute I hit the street from that hospital, I have not stopped," Ms. Bowman said.
Her ambition unnerved her housemates, who were unemployed actors and writers and designers. She said they took her jewelry and clothes and then kicked her out, leaving her furniture on the sidewalk and defacing it with personal insults. In desperation, she moved in with a friend from high school, but he molested her, she said.
"I spent the whole month there scheming how to get out," she said.
She made her break in the middle of March, taking only her camera, her photographs and two pairs of underwear. For the next three nights, she slept in a chair at a drop-in center for the homeless in downtown Brooklyn. On the fourth morning, Ayn Steele, the director of a center for mentally ill homeless women, spotted Ms. Bowman.
"She looked so lost with those big glasses, and she was so thin," Ms. Steele said. "She was at sea."
Ms. Steele saw something hopeful and tragic in Ms. Bowman and invited her to live at the transitional living center in East New York. The center, one of five in New York City, is run by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. For Ms. Bowman, rallying back from mental illness, the center was a stable, nurturing place.
"She said, 'If I don't do something now, I could just end up spiraling down and down and down,' " Ms. Steele said. "And she was right. She needed to get a grip."
Ms. Bowman's drive impressed the center's staff, and they made special allowances for her, letting her keep a camera in the dorm so she could build her portfolio.
When Parsons accepted her in April, Ms. Bowman cried for 10 minutes. She called her daughter, who had made up her mind to come home. Ms. Bowman promised an August reunion.
By May, she had found a subsidized apartment in Harlem -- two rooms and a kitchen for $215 a month -- but a snag in her benefits prevented her from moving out right away.
She stayed at the center and commuted to Parsons for a summer program, where she learned how to draw, sculpture and talk about art. As a final project, she stayed up until 3 A.M. designing a wire mask and covering it with scraps of fur and cloth that she found around the shelter. By morning, her fingers were blistered and bleeding.
It was August. Ms. Bowman felt secure and confident and ready to leave. She told the center's staff. "We can't let you go," she remembers them saying. "You don't have any benefits."
"Don't worry," Ms. Bowman said. "Something will happen. That's the way this year has been."
The center gave in, and they paid her first month's rent. "She asserted herself," said Arlan Dean, the center's housing coordinator. "She made it work."
Then came a $3,000 windfall from the Internal Revenue Service, which had finally verified her earned income tax credit. Catey came home on Aug. 21, and Ms. Bowman gave her a brush and paints and told her to decorate her bedroom. She made a mural of butterflies and fish. Ms. Bowman splashed her own walls with a pattern of yellow, orange and red brush strokes.
School began in September. Ms. Bowman paid the $8,550 tuition with loans. She was given a work-study job for $5 an hour. Besides food and rent, the tax refund went toward mandatory art supplies for herself and books and school fees for her daughter, who enrolled at an experimental public school near Parsons.
October was tough. The tax money was gone, and Ms. Bowman said welfare workers told her that anyone who could afford to attend Parsons could also buy food. They were wrong, she said, and she and Catey went hungry. The contents of their refrigerator dwindled to a vegetable or two. Catey was sometimes given meals from strangers who passed through the student lounge, which had become her second home. Once, a school friend took Ms. Bowman to the supermarket and bought her $60 in groceries.
November was better because the emergency food stamps finally came through, and they celebrated with a Thanksgiving dinner that could not be beat.
A few weeks ago, Ms. Bowman's teachers critiqued her first semester work. They praised her creative eye and assured her that once she had mastered the techniques of the darkroom, her photographs would be good enough to sell.
"I should be pretty proud of myself," Ms. Bowman said. "From January to now, I said what I was going to do and I did it, and I'm good at it and I love it and I got my kid back and I have an apartment."
Sometimes it doesn't seem real. But it is, and Ms. Bowman knows how to prove it.
"Mookie," she said, using her daughter's nickname. "Get my portfolio."

HEADLINE: Digital Studios: It's the Economy, Stupid;
George Lucas Sees Technology as a Wondrous Tool and a Cost-Cutter

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: NICASIO, Calif.

 BODY:
When George Lucas began the movie industry's love affair with computer technology on his first "Star Wars" adventure in 1977, Hollywood seized on the notion that computers, like the Force, would eventually make just about anything possible.
Now, after a series of major technological improvements, the fully digital studio has finally arrived. But for Mr. Lucas and other technology experts, the new equipment is still not being used to its full potential: bringing visual wizardry to the silver screen while reducing Hollywood's bloated budgets. 
 Most of the big movie companies use digital technology either just for editing or to create dazzling but extremely expensive special effects.
In Mr. Lucas's view, the studios have missed the point. In his eyes, digital technology, by reducing the need to shoot on exotic locations, build expensive props and film certain scenes over and over, is a practical tool, a means of telling stories on as grand a scale as a director wants, but on a reasonable budget.
"They don't get it," Mr. Lucas said of the big studios. "They're about five years behind. I don't think they understand what I do here."
Sitting amid the Victorian charm and powerful technology of his Skywalker Ranch here, he added: "The idea is not creating the perfect environment. It's creating the illusion of one."
The promise of the new entertainment technology is no different than in Henry Ford's Detroit in the 1920's. Computers, Mr. Lucas said, can give assembly-line efficiency to the business of illusion and entertaining audiences.
What Mr. Lucas is suggesting, in short, is that Hollywood go back to the future. Mr. Lucas says the model on which the digital studio is based is essentially the model of the studio that created "Gone With the Wind."
Before World War II, movie companies usually filmed against the backdrop of ersatz reality created in backlots from painted mattes. In the 1960's, films were increasingly shot on location to create greater verisimilitude. A movie was no longer a series of optical tricks that created an image of Africa, but actual images of Africa. In the process, movies became extraordinarily expensive one-of-a-kind endeavors.
Computers may be bringing back the old days. But this time the scenery will come not from a set department filled with mattes of different landscapes, but from disks on which scenery of everything from European cities to Asian villages will be stored digitally. An actor gesticulating against a blue screen at a lot in Los Angeles will eventually become a young man shaking hands with President Kennedy. The next Tara might be an antebellum mansion kept on a laser disk file indexed under the heading "Plantations," and the next Atlanta (pulled from a file labeled "Cities: 19th Century") might burn in the cold light of digital flames.
Currently, the greatest use of digital technology is not at the big studios but at specialized production houses like Pixar, Digital Domain and Industrial Light and Magic, a unit of Mr. Lucas's privately held Lucas Digital.
No big studio today, for instance, could create the computer-generated dinosaurs in "Jurassic Park," which were created by Industrial Light and Magic about three years ago.
But Hollywood is catching up, spending hundreds of millions of dollars to develop in-house digital capabilities. For instance, Silicon Graphics, whose work stations are frequently a component in the digital studio, has seen the percentage of its revenue -- $1.6 billion in 1994 -- from the entertainment industry grow from 5 to 15 percent in the last five years.
"I think it will eventually become the way almost all movies are made," said Thomas Pollack, the vice chairman of MCA Inc. and a former head of MCA's Universal Pictures. "You will be able to create just about all your backgrounds on the computer."
The newest studio attempting to create both a real and digital backlot is Dreamworks SKG. It has hired some of the most experienced computer experts in Hollywood to build what will be one of the best digital studios around, and a big part of the expense will be not just generating images, but storing them.
"We're putting heavy emphasis on storing images so they can be re-used, like an old studio with a costume and set library," explained Rob C. Hummel, one of the people creating the Dreamworks digital studio. "That's a big part of what the technology is all about. The model is very old-fashioned."
For Mr. Lucas, the best proof of Hollywood's tardiness in understanding the technology was "Waterworld," the futuristic seaborne epic that reportedly cost nearly $200 million to make. He said the movie could have been filmed at about half the cost by using digital technology and manufacturing many of the elaborate battle scenes flawlessly on terra firma rather than aboard wind-tossed ships. And, he suggested, the digital version would have looked better.
"There is no aesthetic advantage whatsoever" in shooting an action movie on location anymore, Mr. Lucas said. "The issue is economics."
Robert Sullivan, a vice president at Avid Technology, the maker of one of the most widely used digital film-editing machines, said: "Hollywood is a lot like Detroit. It's probably a 60- to 70-year-old business and it still sticks to a certain way of making its products."
Sony Pictures has worked harder than most movie companies to develop technologies, and a few months ago it hired Ken Ralston, one of Mr. Lucas's experts, to build an in-house digital studio. The company has committed itself to installing 100 computer work stations; the combined hardware and software cost for each runs about $200,000. The total cost will be at least $20 million.
Still, Sony officials agree the industry has a long way to go.
"In a fundamental way this is an industry that hasn't changed the way it does business in 70 years or so," said Kenneth S. Williams, an executive vice president in charge of Sony Pictures's computer technologies. "There was surprisingly little impact by technology on the way you assembled a movie until recently. Even now half the film editors don't know how to use this stuff."
The old process of making a movie has not been replaced by new digital technology, just changed incrementally. Scenes are still shot for the most part on 35-millimeter film with traditional optical cameras, which are regarded as a superior means of capturing images. But immediately after that, the film is put through what is called a telecine, a device that puts the image into digital form.
All subsequent editing and mixing of disparate landscapes and other elements takes place on computers, including the creation of digital characters like the T-1000 robot in "Terminator 2." An editor or director can instantaneously call up multiple takes of a scene, mix together different backgrounds or special effects and combine them with the ease of someone editing sentences on a word processor.
In the end, the final "cut" is still made on film, since that is how theaters exhibit movies.
Ed Granlund, post-production supervisor for Lucasfilm, Mr. Lucas's movie-making company, recently showed how the company was using digital technology to save time and costs.
He was editing a shot for an episode of "The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles," a television series produced by Mr. Lucas. The show has not been a great ratings success, but it has been a laboratory for Lucasfilm's techniques.
In one scene, Mr. Lucas wanted to show a troop ship unloading doughboys at a quay in Africa. The shot began with something that looked ridiculous: several men dressed in World War I garb, standing on a scaffold in the middle of an empty field near Prague, where the company happened to be doing some filming.
Then a troop ship was created using computer graphics. Some shabby storefronts, filmed at a museum, were put in place digitally; clouds and crates were painted in by computer artists. A shot that would have taken days to construct, if not weeks, took 12 hours and less than $10,000, about a tenth of the cost of live-action shooting, Mr. Granlund said.
One of the first full uses of the new technologies may be the new "Star Wars" trilogy Mr. Lucas is producing, as well as a special edition of the original trilogy of films.
In the special edition, Mr. Lucas said, he will resolve some long-standing irritations by using today's superior technology to produce scenes as he had originally envisioned them. For instance, when Luke Skywalker and his friends enter the desert city of Mos Eisley, the vistas will be far broader and the streets more detailed.
In the new trilogy, Mr. Lucas will still use 35-millimeter cameras to shoot most scenes and real actors will still play the key roles.
Mr. Lucas boasted that his new "Star Wars" movies would have an epic quality but cost $60 million to $70 million each, relatively modest sums by Hollywood standards.
But digital does not always mean economical. Since digital has become a buzzword in Hollywood, many producers have demanded digital effects even when they are more expensive than traditional techniques.
"One of my favorite words is techno-lust," Mr. Hummell of Dreamworks said. "It's one of those hype things. People want digital everything even if the old methods work just as well at less money."
And there are some directors and producers who argue that actors cannot perform as well talking to the air against a blue screen than on location. Mr. Lucas disagreed.
"Actors are paid to act," he said. "That's part of the job. It's not as emotionally satisfying, but it's more the way it was done in the early '30's. I'm going back to that earlier style."

HEADLINE: Coming Soon to Computers Everywhere, a World's Fair

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
It's hard to say no to Carl Malamud.
The 36-year-old Washington-based economist has successfully pushed, prodded, wheedled and occasionally even begged powerful corporate executives, Clinton Administration officials and foreign leaders to support his crusade to transform the Internet computer network into a combination of a global Main Street and digital Library of Alexandria.
Earlier this year Mr. Malamud's nonprofit research group, Internet Multicasting, pushed the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Patent and Trademark Office -- both kicking and screaming, initially -- into establishing public records distribution sites on the Internet.
Now that both sites are considered strong successes -- the S.E.C. system distributed more than two million documents in its first month of operation -- Mr. Malamud has set out on a much more ambitious effort to extend a high-speed, multimedia version of the Internet into more than 100 countries. The first step is to begin on New Year's Day, when he will open the first Internet world's fair, to be followed in February by the start of what he is calling the Internet railroad. (A preview of the fair can be seen at the World Wide Web site http://park.org/fair.) 
 The fair itself will be a digital exhibition set up on a vast global "farm" of computer disks located primarily in Tokyo, San Francisco, Washington and Amsterdam, and created by people in more than 60 countries during the next year. Besides offerings like an interactive history of wind energy at the Netherlands' national site, and other downloadable multimedia material specially designed for the fair, there will be recorded and live events like an interview with the Dalai Lama in early January and video coverage of the 25th anniversary of the Kennedy Center in April.
"The impact of the fair is huge in Japan," said Joichi Ito, a Japanese business executive who is helping organizing the fair there. "We have everyone focusing on it."
The railroad is actually an ambitious effort to create a globe-girdling digital pipe to carry the digital world's fair, fast enough to transport multimedia information -- sound, full-motion video and computer data. While the fair is scheduled to last only through the end of 1996, Mr. Malamud hopes the railroad will become a transport medium that endures into the future.
In the last year Mr. Malamud has circled the globe seven times himself, logging 250,000 air miles, meeting with government agencies, telephone company and computer executives and raising $100 million in contributions of technology and service to start the fair.
In Japan, for example, industry and government have contributed two high-speed digital backbone networks, two terabytes of computer disk space and an I.B.M. supercomputer to help turn the Tokyo neighborhood of Harajuku into a digital city, where people on the scene can tap into the Internet from cybercafes while people around the world can log in for interactive events.
Mr. Malamud has seized on the idea for the first Internet world's fair and the global railroad as an information-age analogy to the way world fairs in the earlier, industrial era helped to usher new technologies into widespread use.
The traditional world fairs "taught people about the world around them, but they also challenged engineers," Mr. Malamud said. "Most importantly, the world fairs, because of their scale and scope, proved to business and home consumers that the technology had a place in their lives."
As he prepares to put the fair -- the Internet 1996 World Exposition -- on line, he has assembled a dedicated chain of high-speed fiber-optic links capable of sending data at speeds as high as 155 million bits a second in an arc stretching from Taiwan, Korea and Japan in Asia to Finland, Sweden and Russia in Europe. By the end of 1996 Mr. Malamud hopes to stretch the Internet railroad fiber around the entire world. Along the way he has assembled endorsements from presidents including Bill Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin and has occasionally left some of those who have suffered his prodding a little exasperated.
"I've ended up doing more lobbying for Carl Malamud than I have for some heads of state," said a Federal official who has been called on repeatedly to help gain commitments for the project.
In an era when the Internet has become synonymous with commercialism and instant fortunes, Mr. Malamud's commitment to public service has set him apart.
"This is an individual moving companies and countries by the strength of his will and the obvious goodness of his ideas," said Larry Landweber, a computer scientist who is president of the Internet Society, an international organization that oversees the Internet's standards. "He's an evangelist."
For Mr. Malamud it is all part of the work that has been his passion since the early 1980's when he was first introduced to computer networking while studying economics as an undergraduate at Indiana University, where he subsequently got an M.B.A. A decade later he became an early volunteer helping to create the Interop conference, a computer-networking industry trade show that was one of the first venues to demonstrate the potential of the Internet.
With the financial help of Dan Lynch, an Interop founder, Mr. Malamud set out in 1991 as a self-described "Official Internet Explorer," physically traveling around the world three times in his quest to visit as many nodes on the Internet as possible and meet as many of the people who were building the network infrastructure as he could.
That project led to his 1992 book "Exploring the Internet: a Technical Travelogue," a chatty account of the then-little known elite that built the Internet, before it became a household word.
The idea of a cyberspace world's fair was hatched in late 1994 when Mr. Malamud was talking with Vinton Cerf, a designer of the original technical protocols -- communications software standards -- for the Internet. Inspired by the idea, he immediately hopped on a plane to persuade two Internet experts, Jan Murai of Japan and Rob Blokzijl of the Netherlands, whom he had met on his original global tour, to sign on to the idea.
Today Mr. Malamud maintains that there are still two ways to build the Internet. One is the high-stakes, high-visibility route of initial public offerings in the stock market, the money-raising approach being pursued by people like Netscape Communication's founders, Jim Clark and Mark Andreeson. The other route, Mr. Malamud maintains, is by soliciting funds and building viable public works projects that benefit the common good.
Mr. Malamud takes pains to point out that he hasn't organized the fair by himself. There are now hundreds of people working on the project around the world, including some of the Internet's best technical experts.
Chris Swanson, a technical advise from SSDS, a network consulting firm in Englewood, Colo., is global project manager on a piece of the project known as the World's Central Park. Marten Tepstra, a special-projects engineer from Bay Networks Inc., is global project manager on the Internet railroad, responsible for installing and maintaining the router computers that will keep the global traffic flowing over the railroad.
The effort, Mr. Malamud said, did not compete with the current rush to commercialize the Internet. "People don't move to towns without parks and roads and schools," he said. "It's a viable part of the global business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carl Malamud is a man on a mission: preparing for the Internet 1996 World Exposition. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Essay;
And on Earth, Freedom

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"Peace on Earth" cannot be achieved until the other part of the Christmas message comes to pass: "good will toward men."
I read that last phrase -- with the translation of "men" dutifully updated to "one another" -- in its broadest modern sense, to mean "an embrace of the yearning of the human spirit for freedom." 
 The blessing of liberty is what a minority of Russians are reaching for today. If democracy holds its own, bringing prosperity in its wings, that lesson cannot be lost on China, redoubt of repression. But if freedom loses, Cold War III will begin.
That's what makes the Russian presidential election of 1996 even more important to Americans than our own Presidential election.
Last week, in a kind of primary, candidates of the Communist Party and its agrarian ally won almost a third of the seats in the legislature. That was more than expected, though not all that surprising, given the ire of 30 million inflation-wracked pensioners and a government fighting inflation by delaying checks to pensioners and workers.
The rest of the new Duma is divided among three groups: (1) Zhirinovsky nationalists, whose percentage was halved; (2) Yeltsin government supporters led by Chernomyrdin, vaguely reformist but more interested in retaining the presidency, and (3) reformers led by Grigori Yavlinski, the only outspoken democrat whose party is left standing.
What did last week's preliminaries augur for Russia's coming presidential campaign?
The field is narrowed to four probable candidates: the two Z's (the communist Zyuganov and the nationalist Zhirinovsky); either Yeltsin if he decides to run or his Prime Minister, Chernomyrdin, and Yavlinski.
Which two will make it to the runoff? With three movements (communist, nationalist, reformist) and four candidates, you don't have to be a Russian pollster to figure out the morning line: Yeltsin or Chernomyrdin will splinter Yavlinski's reformist vote, leaving the two Z's running in the final round.
That would face Russians with a terrible choice: backward to Lenin or further backward to the Tsar.
How can the hugely unpopular Yeltsin avert this?
One way is to follow the legislative election returns away from the privatization of land, and toward the Communist platform. "Last time, Zhirinovsky's strong showing led Yeltsin into war in Chechnya," says Grigory Yavlinski. "This time, if the Communist showing leads Yeltsin's government away from reform, that would be economic disaster for Russia."
Another way to stop the two Z's would be to postpone elections. But democracy cannot be preserved by dictatorial means. Russian voters, who turned out in greater percentages than Americans, deserve the right to make their own mistakes.
Another way to avert the two-Z choice would be for Yeltsin to decline to run, take Chernomyrdin out, and embrace Yavlinski. But that would be the kiss of death for the reformers, who must keep their distance from the regime so despised by voters angry at the predations of the government's botched reform.
The only other way I can see for Yeltsin to steer his country between the Scylla of communism and Charybdis of nationalism is to subtly help the reformers not tainted by service in his government. Reformers say that government powers in last week's election were used far more against them than against the two Z's.
A Yeltsin decision to help rather than hinder reformers would require a new fairness in coverage on government TV and an end to the relentless harassment of party organization -- as well as a way of executing new communist legislative acts so as to make the communists look foolish or dangerous.
But Yeltsin, though cunning, is hardly subtle. He is more likely to run as a semi-communist making nationalist noises, and lose, than to quietly slip the torch to reformers unable and unwilling to associate themselves with his economic failures.
That's why peace on earth faces a political test half a year ahead: its precondition, freedom for the human spirit, is in danger of a setback in Russia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Capitalists in China, Hand Over Fist

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Tomorrow night's two-hour visit to what the producers title "The Wild East" concentrates on the new capitalists who are running amok in Communist China. For this very small but growing group of entrepreneurs and operators -- someone calls them former Red Guards in Armani suits -- life seems to be fun and games and moneymaking. The wisecrack going around Beijing is that the Forbidden City has been turned into the for-business city. Mao Zedong, still an icon, must be spinning wherever the spirits of Chinese Marxists spin.
It's a somewhat unfocused tour, venturing here and there through time and space as if the producer, Peter Kaufman, were having difficulty filling up his own time and space. The program is most pointed when Mr. Kaufman's Chinese acquaintances tell of the persecution of the educated class during the Cultural Revolution and speculate gloomily on the consequences of the capitalist revolution. 
 Attention is drawn to old-fashioned but still current Government repression, to up-to-date forms of corruption, to the unemployment that has turned millions into itinerant job hunters and to the industrial pollution that is being permitted to foul the air in the service of development. Inhabitants of Hong Kong, which is to return Chinese rule in 1997, voice their special worries, and ethnic and religious stirrings, especially among China's big Muslim population, portend other troubles.
Yet "The Wild East" diverts as it moves somewhat eccentrically between dire news and cheery travelogue. You can see Mongolian women on horseback slam-dunking in an exhibition of horse basketball, and hear from Russian women of the night who have been imported for the pleasure of the new Chinese millionaires. You can also listen in on a discussion among young Chinese women about the virtues of sex before marriage.
Flourishing enterprises -- restaurants, stock exchanges, private clubs, religious temples, discos -- are seen in action. And in a change of pace, there is a time-warped pop singer, who learned his craft from Crosby-Hope and Astaire-Rogers movies, crooning "On a Slow Boat to China."
 
Nova
Can Buildings Make You Sick?
PBS, tomorrow, 8 P.M.
(Channel 13 in New York)
Does being at work give you a headache? Don't rush to blame the boss or the annoying person in the next cubicle.
Tomorrow's offering from "Nova" tells how brick-and-mortar sleuths go about detecting the causes of employee weariness, respiratory ailments, eye trouble and all-round malaise in new offices and hospitals. Is it the air-conditioning? The ventilation? The lighting? The acoustics? The fireproofing? Bugs in the ducts?
The program is a gift for people who need one more thing to worry about. Season's greetings from PBS.

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Schools for Budget Pinch;
Plight of the City

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross (Op-Ed, Dec. 18) makes statistical comparisons that present a distorted picture of educational financing in New York City from 1980-1993. 
 To justify cuts in state education spending, Ms. Ross blames the misuse of public funds for the problems in our schools. She claims that school spending increased from 1980 through 1993, while enrollment remained steady. New York City spends $3,500 per pupil less than surrounding suburban districts.
It is not an accident that Ms. Ross selected 1980 as the base year for her analysis. In 1980, New York City was still suffering through a major fiscal crisis that produced sharp cuts in its education budget. Within the next few years, as the economy improved, school spending returned to more normal levels; capital improvements and routine maintenance were resumed and teacher salaries unfrozen. She represents this restored budget as if it were a funding increase.
In addition, her comparison of 1980 and 1993 hides the actual pattern of change in school enrollment. Instead of remaining steady, enrollment declined from 1980 through 1990 and increased by more than 6 percent after 1991.
Ms. Ross ignores the large amount New York City is required to spend on remedial and special education programs. Sixty percent of the educationally disadvantaged youth eligible for services in the state live in New York City. Also, the number of children in special education programs, which cost nearly five times the amount spent on regular education students, doubled between 1979 and 1994.
 
ALAN SINGER
Hempstead, L.I., Dec. 18, 1995
The writer is assistant professor, department of curriculum and teaching, Hofstra University.

NEW YORK CITY
 
Is It a Taxi or a Bus?
To ease traffic congestion between 30th and 60th Streets in Manhattan, the Giuliani administration is planning to designate specially marked taxi stops as the only places for cabbies to pick up and drop off passengers between 10 A.M. and 4 P.M. on weekdays. The change could permanently alter a cherished tradition of to-the-door taxi service for many New Yorkers, though some questioned how readily it would be accepted. [Page 41.]
 
Bronx Democrats End Feud
The public end of the feud last week between Representative Jose E. Serrano and Roberto Ramirez, the State Assemblyman who is also the Democratic Party leader in the Bronx, is seen as an important step in uniting the Bronx Democratic Party as its favorite son, Borough President Fernando Ferrer, prepares for a possible challenge against Mayor Giuliani in 1997. The yearlong feud splintered the borough's Hispanic political leaders and left the Democratic Party in the Bronx in turmoil. [41.]
 
A Subway Fable, Set to Music
The experts say that David Allakhverdov is not quite ready for Carnegie Hall, but that was not the verdict of the subway commuters passing through Grand Central Terminal on the way to the shuttle. What is certain, however, is that David, who came to New York from Tashkent, Uzbekistan, 14 months ago, is on the upward arc of a remarkable odyssey. [41.]

2 Are Shot Dead at a Party
Shots rang out at a 15th birthday party in a church hall in Manhattan, leaving two men dead. Alma Miranda, who was celebrating her coming out party, said that she did not know the victims, nor had she invited them to her party. [43.]
 
Mother Held in Son's Beating
The mother of a 3-year-old boy was arraigned yesterday on charges she abused the child by beating and burning him. The mother, Judith Frade, 34, was arrested Saturday after she took her unconscious son to the emergency room of St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx and told doctors that the boy had accidentally drunk her supply of methadone, the police said. But doctors said the boy had black eyes, burn marks on his buttocks and arms and "numerous scars from past assaults." [43.]
 
Questions Resurface on Paint
A high-ranking Fire Department official said four months ago that layers of old paint thought to have contributed to a rash of stairwell fires in housing projects should be removed -- a recommendation the city rejected in favor of covering it with a fire-retardant coating. But Fire Commissioner Howard Safir has acknowledged that removing the old paint might turn out to be necessary. [43.]
 
A Supermarket Lures Crowds
The Fairway supermarket in Harlem has been luring crowds from around New York since the warehouse-style grocery opened on Dec. 19 at 133d Street and 12th Avenue. A visit provided a glimpse into just who the megamarket's customers are: many of them are from other parts of Manhattan, and relish the chance to have the best of suburban shopping a short car or subway ride away. [44.]

A Culture at a Turning Point
From New York to Los Angeles, Japanese-Americans, the most integrated of Asian-American groups, are at a turning point in their century-long history in the United States. Many fear that their culture -- which has the highest intermarriage rate of any ethnic group in the country -- is dying and that there will never be enough new immigration from Japan to reinvigorate it. [1.]

If, for many, the Christmas season is a marathon -- an overtime-working, airline-queuing, all-day-shopping, hot-stove-slaving test of endurance -- then yesterday was the final sprint. By noon, the aisles of department stores were beginning to resemble rush-hour subways in places, and many a caterer was mired in giant mounds of mashed potatoes, but the sense that the relaxation of Christmas Day was just around the corner made it all more bearable for many. [1.]

Hardened shoppers, perpetual sales and a snowstorm that blanketed the Northeast in the crucial final week of Christmas shopping combined to give retailers their worst holiday seasons in years, analysts, economists and other retail experts said. And things won't get better for retailers, many experts said, until more go out of business, reducing the competition. [1.]

It was the week before Christmas, and at the Coreglia Studios in North Bergen, N.J., the saints -- in 12-inch, 18-inch, 24-inch and 32-inch varieties -- were marching out. Walter Baldaccini's small, family-run company, which specializes in plaster and concrete statues of saints and other religious figures, has been doing a robust business in religious statuary this year. "We got grottos, we got angels, we've got just about every saint there is," Mr. Baldaccini said. [1.]

The arrival in Bosnia and Herzegovina of 17 soldiers from the Second Brigade went off without a hitch. On this day that celebrates a miraculous birth, Pvt. HEADLINE: Change in Census Survey Definition Could Halve the Number of U.S. Farms

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
The nation could lose nearly half its farms before the year 2000 -- on paper at least.
Because Congress cut its budget, the Census Bureau has made plans to survey far fewer farms when it draws its next detailed profile of American agriculture, in 1997. 
 The plan, which would be part of an appropriations bill, would have the bureau count only farms that sell $10,000 or more of crops or livestock a year, up from $1,000 now. The number of farms would plunge from 1.9 million to one million as a result. Farming would be measured only as a business and not as a way of life.
But more is at stake than mere numbers. Universities receive Federal research and extension dollars based in part on the number of farms in their states. A cutoff would fall particularly hard on the Southeast. West Virginia would lose close to 80 percent of its farms, and Tennessee nearly 70 percent. The Middle West would lose the fewest farms, with the number in Iowa and Nebraska dropping by 20 percent each.
"It will have an impact bigger than just the cost savings of increasing the size of the farms," said Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman.
Backers say the new threshold makes economic sense -- the 900,000 farms consigned to statistical oblivion do not add that much to the farm economy. The farms, averaging 136 acres, accounted for only 2 percent of all agricultural sales in 1992, the last survey year. Most ran at a loss. Many kept horses and raised hay, more hobbies than real enterprises.
"Many of these places are not farms in a commercial sense, but rather the rural residences of people who work at nonfarm jobs," the bureau said in a paper listing the pros and cons of the change.
Although the change looks drastic, it is not really revolutionary. Counting for inflation, the $10,000 threshold would come close to the $500 set in 1890, backers say.
Selling three feeder steers or maybe a dozen hogs would push a farmer over the $1,000 edge, depending on prices and weights. The corn off five acres would do the same.
The vanishing farms add to family earnings and food supplies in many poor parts of the country, counters Ronald C. Wimberley, a rural sociology professor at North Carolina State University and member of an outside committee that advises the Census Bureau.
The farms sell important shares of some goods while buying lots of supplies and equipment. They sold 1 percent of corn and less than 2 percent of wheat and soybeans in 1992. But they raised nearly 8 percent of the tobacco, 19 percent of blackberries, 4 percent of cattle, 8 percent of sheep and lambs, 30 percent of pecans and 38 percent of persimmons. They kept more than half the horses and ponies while raising 10 percent of the hay and silage.
Agencies and researchers would have a harder time figuring out whether farms may be adding to pollution, Mr. Wimberley said in a letter to the Democratic staff of the House Agriculture Committee.
About three-quarters of farms owned by blacks would be written out of existence, the number dropping to 4,567. Farms run by women would drop to 50,292 from 145,516.
The bureau is seriously considering the proposal because Congress gave it $10 million for its farm survey in 1996, when it must start designing forms and mailing lists for the 1997 farm census. The bureau had received $13 million for 1995. Using the $10,000 threshold would save up to $3.6 million, the agency said. But the census language is in a Commerce Department spending bill that President Clinton vetoed last week, so decisions are not final.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Second Phone Lines A Sign of the Times
In the days when keeping up with the Joneses required a high-capacity station wagon, not a high-speed modem, having a second telephone line at home was a luxury, necessary only if a family had several teen-agers.
But this year, in the biggest single-year increase in new residential phone lines in the United States since the end of World War II, seven million households have had additional lines installed, as several information-age forces have ignited into a social phenomenon. And now it is often the parents who are tying up the lines, and propelling demand. [Page A1.]
 
Changes in Electric-Car Rule
California is backing away from a requirement that in about two years, 2 percent of cars sold there must be electrically powered. Critics are calling the move a capitulation to the automobile and oil industries. But some auto experts said the change was a practical one because today's technology cannot produce an electric vehicle that customers would want to buy. [A14.]
 
Russian-Italian Deal Founders
Russia's biggest privatization deal involving a foreign company stalled when the Government said that Stet, an Italian state telecommunications company, had pulled out of an agreement to buy a 25 percent stake in Svyazinvest, a Russian phone company. [D3.]
 
A Faster Youth Lane at Toyota
Toyota has abolished rules that specify how long an employee must stay in one job before a promotion. The move, intended to make it easier for young staff members to rise to junior management positions, foreshadows a possible change in the way the company chooses senior executives. [D3.]
 
Gambling Jobs in Atlantic City
As the 20th anniversary of New Jersey's vote to legalize gambling approaches, the industry's big promises -- that the casinos' wealth would spill over, enriching residents -- are beginning to become a reality. And while Atlantic City has hardly been converted into a utopia, there are now many jobs available for high school graduates. [A1.]
 
Machine-Tool Orders Rise
Orders for American-made machine tools, the devices that cut and shape metal for products ranging from toasters to tractors, fell for the first time in two months. The sharp decline suggested further weakness in American manufacturing. [D2.]
 
Not Exactly A Signature Move
With print ads for the Bradford Exchange promising that its commemorative plate honoring Michael Jordan will be "graced by a facsimile of Michael Jordan's autograph," will the next Bradford plate be covered in genuine imitation leatherette or swathed in 100 percent acrylic? It's time to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Relief in Sight?
After surging to heady heights through the first three quarters of the year, the shares of securities firms have fallen. They are now trading at close to the same prices they commanded at the end of September 1993, forcing investors to reach for their Alka-Seltzer. Market Place. [D4.]
 
Coca-What?
Russia has its vodka, Germany has its beer, France has its wine, but Peru has Inca Kola -- a fruity, greenish-yellow carbonated drink that many Peruvians savor almost as much as many Britons enjoy their afternoon tea. [A4.]

Bed, Bath and Beyond
Frequent travelers, used to finding the Gideon Bible in hotel rooms, are encountering a number of other religious texts as well these days, like the Book of Mormon and the Teachings of Buddha. [A14.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Jobless Rate in Japan Reached A Record of 3.4% in November

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 26

 BODY:
Japan's jobless rate jumped to a record 3.4 percent in November, the Management and Coordination Agency said, the highest since it began collecting unemployment figures in 1953.
The number of unemployed rose 17.8 percent on the year, to 3.3 million, the agency said. The nationwide labor force shrank three-tenths of 1 percent in November from a year earlier, to 64.39 million. 
 Economists polled by Bloomberg Business News had expected November's unemployment rate to stay at 3.2 percent, where it had remained for the last five months.
As in past months, the greatest job losses came at manufacturing companies and among young people and middle-aged men.
For those younger than 25, some 6 percent were without jobs, and for men between 55 and 64, 5 percent were unemployed, the agency said.
Manufacturers are cutting costs to offset weak demand, falling prices and the still-strong yen. Small manufacturers unable to cope are going out of business, forcing workers out of jobs.
The jobless figures cast a shadow on recent signs, ranging from profit growth to rising capital investment, that Japan's economy is recovering after a four-year slowdown.
The report showed that compared with a year ago, some 380,000 manufacturing jobs were lost, a decline of 2.5 percent to 14.62 million, the agency said. Agriculture lost some 100,000 workers, down 3 percent from a year earlier, to 3.20 million.
The service industry, by absorbing many of those workers, has become Japan's biggest employer. Service job growth slowed to an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent on the year to 15.50 million. In October, service job growth was 1.3 percent.
Employment in the construction and retail-wholesale industries -- the remaining two broad categories in the report -- also rose.Retail and wholesale employment rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 14.63 million. Construction jobs rose 2.3 percent, to 6.77 million, the agency said.
Among women, the jobless rate was 3.3 percent, unchanged from October. Among men, it rose to 3.4 percent from 3.2 percent.
By Western standards, Japan's jobless rate is extremely low. The United States, for example, is running a 5.6 percent unemployment rate. In Germany, the rate is 9.3 percent, and in Canada, the rate is 9.4 percent.
Japan's low rate is partly due to the nature of the Japanese labor market and a narrower definition of unemployment. Jobless workers not actively looking for work are not counted as unemployed. And those who have worked for even one hour during the month are considered employed.

HEADLINE: Elderly Couple Die in a Fire In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
For four days, with ice clinging to their window sills and no heat in their apartment, an elderly couple in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, resorted to a space heater to survive the winter chill. Early yesterday, fire officials said, that Hobson's choice killed them.
Florian Teraskiewicz, 75, and his wife, Irene, 69, died when a three-alarm fire raged through their apartment, burning their bodies so badly that at first, firefighters said, it was impossible to tell their age or sex, much less who they were. Inspectors said the blaze began about 2 A.M. with a faulty wire in the electrically powered oil-filled heater that the couple were using to ward off the raw cold. 
 Other residents in the building at 43d Street and Eighth Avenue, who were forced to flee into the snow-piled street before Christmas Day had dawned and were left temporarily homeless by the fire, said they had been without central heat since Thursday. They said they had been unable to reach their secretive landlord -- a man whose last name they did not know, who accepted rent payments only in cash and who, they said, had repairs done badly, if at all.
"He doesn't care if there's no heat," said Sixto Rivera, 54, one of the tenants. "He just cares if he gets paid."
There were other fire victims around the city yesterday, including an unidentified woman who was killed in what fire officials labeled a suspicious blaze in a vacant building in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. And another fire damaged an apartment house on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
The Sunset Park fire, at 807 43d Street, was first reported at 2:08 A.M. and was not brought under control until 3:34 A.M., said Firefighter George Semidey, a Fire Department spokesman. Before it was over, he said, 21 units and 160 firefighters were involved in the fight.
While the fire did not spread beyond the top floor of the three-story building, a river of water from firefighters' hoses soaked much of the building, particularly a vacant unit directly below the one that burned. The water knocked out electrical power, forcing residents to move in with friends and relatives.
Neighbors said that Mr. and Mrs. Teraskiewicz, a friendly but private couple, had lived quietly in their two-bedroom, third-floor apartment for more than 40 years, raising children there, including a son, Al, who lived with them. In a working class neighborhood that is now heavily Hispanic and Chinese, they were holdovers from a time when Sunset Park was largely Scandinavian, Polish and German.
The family had been touched by tragedy before, neighbors said, with the deaths in recent years of two of the Teraskiewicz's grown children. They said the elder Mr. Teraskiewicz, known as Terry, could barely walk.
It was the Teraskiewicz's son who alerted the others in the building yesterday, including the Riveras, whose Christmas Eve party was just winding down.
"He came down and pounded on our door and yelled: 'Fire! Fire! Get out!," said Mr. Rivera, a doorman at a Manhattan apartment building who lives on the second floor with his wife, Miriam, and the youngest of their six children, William, 19.
His son Sixto Jr., said, "He said, 'My parents are up there.' He said he couldn't get them out."
The elder Mr. Rivera said he ran up to the Teraskiewicz apartment and opened the door, only to be driven back by a gale of heat and flame.
The younger Mr. Teraskiewicz was taken to Maimonides Medical Center and was treated for trauma, then released. A Fire Department lieutenant was treated at the same hospital for a cut on the nose.
Residents said the building was bought five or six years ago by a man they knew only as David, who refused to give them his telephone number and whom they saw only every few months. They said they could contact him only through a clerk at Economy Discount Wines and Liquors, on the ground floor of the building. When they complained that there was no heat, they said, the store clerk told them, "Call David," and refused to contact the landlord for them, even when they protested that they did not have his number.
The tenants said they paid their rent, in cash, to the liquor store clerk, who has never given them his name. The store was not open yesterday.
Yesterday morning, the landlord appeared at the building after the fire, but left quickly when confronted by Mr. Rivera about problems in the building.
Mrs. Rivera said that when she reported the lack of heat to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the operator said city records still had the previous owner listed as the landlord, with no mention of the mysterious David. Department officials could not be reached yesterday for comment.
There was a minor electrical fire in the building two weeks ago, and residents said it was caused by an contractor renovating the vacant apartment. "Every time we have a problem with the building, the landlord gets unlicensed people to work on it," William Rivera said. "He doesn't want to spend any money to get professionals to do it."
Hours after the fire, Mr. Rivera stood outside, still wearing the double-breasted suit he had donned for the party, his shoes crunching glass from windows that were broken by firefighters, and examined a soggy pile of debris -- mattresses, lamps, clothes -- that had been thrown from apartment windows. His own apartment, he said, would be fine with a little work. "We got lucky," he said.
The Crown Heights fire, in a vacant, three-story brick building at 1092 Pacific Street, near Franklin Avenue, was being investigated by fire marshals, who called it suspicious. The two-alarm blaze was reported at 9:18 A.M. and brought under control at 10:46 A.M.
A woman in her 40's, whom firefighters found in the building, was taken to Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, where she was pronounced dead.
Earlier, a three-alarm fire struck a five-story brick apartment building at 180 West 81st Street, at Amsterdam Avenue, in Manhattan. It started in the ceiling above a restaurant on the ground floor, but the cause was not clear, Firefighter Semidey said. The fire, reported at 12:21 A.M. and brought under control at 1:58 A.M., damaged only the first floor and caused no injuries, he said.

HEADLINE: Big Bang Hits the Johannesburg Stock Exchange

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
Probably no bourse in the world is quite as naked about money worship as the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. Where others have a bell or a clock, it has two huge, bejeweled chalices modeled on those in the temple of Moneta, where Rome's money was stamped. Between them is a wall of stained-glass windows representing mining, transportation and the other industries that make this the richest country in Africa.
Soon all this medievalism will be gone, though, replaced by the 21st-century version of the same cathedral: an exchange in a mainframe presiding over a far-flung congregation of computers. 
 Twenty years after Wall Street and 10 years after London, the world's 12th-largest stock exchange is in the middle of its own Big Bang.
Some critics have dismissed it as the Little Whimper, but others say that even though the changes may not be original or earth-shaking, they signal some big shifts in one of the world's most insular economies. Eventually, South Africa may be changed economically as much as it has been politically, entering the world of free-market capitalism from which it was long largely excluded.
Phase One of the Big Bang began last month, when foreigners and South African banks and insurance companies were allowed to buy seats on the exchange, no longer forced to go through the clubby group of 46 brokerage houses.
Eleven of those houses, eager to protect themselves in the free-wheeling world to come, have already allied themselves with local banks or been bought by American, British or Swiss institutions. Merrill Lynch now controls the Davis Borkum Hare brokerage. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the Equitable Companies' securities unit, and Doley Securities of New Orleans have made overtures to others.
The more important Phase Two is scheduled to begin on March 1 with the abolition of fixed commissions. Commissions and taxes on buying and selling a 10,000-rand block of stock -- about $2,800 worth -- now add up to about $126. That will be negotiable, and discount brokers will presumably spring up.
Disclosure requirements are to be strengthened, though they won't be nearly as tough as in the United States.
And most important, the exchange floor itself, where each deal is recorded on chalkboards and scribbled down on scrip, will be replaced by a computer.
Now, "you go stand under the board and scream the name of your stock as if it were fruit and vegetables," said Colin Goldstein, a trader for Cahn Price Shapiro.
That's part of what makes the market feel like a boys' schoolyard. The cork wall tiles are a porcupine of paper airplanes. On a recent trading day -- just before the 1 P.M. lunch break -- a few brokers with ties as loud as their voices were crying their wares. A few more were squinting at the chalkboards through binoculars. But the biggest bunch was glued to television sets -- a cricket match against England was on.
Maurice Fisher, a 16-year veteran with Frankel Pollak Vinderine, said he would miss the camaraderie. But Mr. Goldstein, a trader for only two years, looks forward to computer trading. Now, he said, "a seller -- and some of them are idiots -- can mess you around. He can give his friend more than he gives you, even if you were first."
But these changes are only cosmetic if they don't lead to bigger things. The officials who run the economy are hoping the changes will lead to a more liquid market, less secrecy and more foreign capital.
Right now, nearly 80 percent of the stock of exchange-listed companies is in the hands of five conglomerates: Anglo American, the Sanlam Group, the Rembrandt Group, the Liberty Group and S A Mutual. Individual investors are rare. Most buying is done by banks, by pension funds and insurers -- which are part of the conglomerates -- and by mutual funds. There are only 70 mutual funds -- called unit trusts -- versus about 5,300 in the United States.
"The big institutions don't sell," Mr. Fisher said. If they did, he said, it could take three or four years to unwind such major positions.
In fact, South Africa's market is less liquid than most stock exchanges its size. Judging by market capitalization, South Africa ranks near Hong Kong and Australia, but based on the value of stocks that are actually traded, it ranks among such small exchanges as Austria and the Philippines.
The market's concentration, said Beth Mandel, director of Morgan Stanley's operations here, can be seen in how her firm adjusts its value. The exchange says the total value of all the companies it lists -- normally a simple figure to calculate -- is $270 billion. But because so many companies own big chunks of one another, Morgan Stanley's emerging markets index pegs its value at only about $108 billion.
This concentration has several causes. After harsh exchange controls were put in place when capital began fleeing after the 1961 Sharpeville Massacre, foreign investors, unable to take profits out, shied away. South African companies -- already big because mining has high fixed costs -- had no outlet for profits except to buy up other South African companies.
"The Big Bang is pretty marginal until you get other reforms like relaxing exchange control," Ms. Mandel said. "But it's unfair to call it the Little Whimper. It's one sign that the economy is aligning itself with international norms. Given their history, I think it's incredible how quickly things are changing."
The exchange was under reform pressure from several fronts:
*Nervous foreign investors, realizing that the nation is held together by more than baling wire and Nelson Mandela's halo, are showing more interest. Emerging-markets mutual funds, in particular, are buying South African stocks. The entire continent of Africa accounts for only about 2 percent of the world's market capitalization, but the Johannesburg Stock Exchange accounts for about 95 percent of that.
*Exchange controls are slowly loosening and were dropped entirely for foreigners in April. The central bank now allows locals to do "asset swaps" in which, for example, a South African trades stock in Anglo American to an American who has stock in I.B.M.
*Three years ago, the country's banks, frustrated over exchange rules, threatened to set up a parallel exchange rate. Now seven banks have bought into brokerages or set up trading arms.
*Nearly 90 exchange-listed companies are traded in London or through American depository receipts, so local brokers risked being outflanked and forgotten.
Brokers like Lance Coogan, asked why the changes took so long, tend to shrug and answer: "Hey -- we're in Africa."
But Roy Andersen, the exchange's president, wants a "formidable total package" of changes to be carefully managed. The advantage of being late, he said, is that "we're cherry-picking the best out of various baskets.
"We commissioned Ernst & Young to research 31 exchanges -- not only the big, sexy ones, but more relevant ones like Malaysia," he said. "Our rules for disclosure are basically London's. Our capital requirements are the European Union's. And our automated system was created by the Chicago Stock Exchange and is used by Manila and Bangkok."
Asked if he thought Wall Street and London traders will move in with sharp elbows, Mr. Andersen said, "Look -- the reality of the matter is that South Africa has to compete in world markets. I hate to use this analogy, but just as our sportsmen are learning to be world champions, our members will, too."

HEADLINE: Heroin Route Via Africa A New Worry

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Drug Enforcement Administration has agreed to help South African authorities choke off a new drug pipeline in their country created by Nigerian narcotics traffickers who want to make South Africa a transit point for Asian heroin destined for the United States.
Thomas Constantine, the agency's administrator, said he will visit South Africa in January to discuss the cooperation, which was requested by the Government of President Nelson Mandela. 
 Until now, the Drug Enforcement Administration has only monitored drug trafficking in Africa out of its office in Cairo. But Mr. Constantine said in an interview that he wanted to set up another office in Johannesburg to give technical assistance to the South African police.
"We can put people in there," Mr. Constantine said. "We can give South African narcotics authorities access to virtually all our information."
Mr. Constantine said South African law enforcement officials expressed concern about an influx of as many as 50,000 Nigerian immigrants into their country, some of whom, he said, "had a long history of running heroin in Nigeria."
During the decades of white minority rule, South Africa kept out most other Africans, with conspicuous exceptions like migrant miners from Lesotho and Mozambique. Since the dismantling of apartheid, thousands of other Africans, taking advantage of the new nonracial hospitality, have flocked into South Africa looking for economic opportunities.
Asked whether any heroin had arrived in the United States via South Africa, Mr. Constantine said there had been "nothing significant" yet. "I haven't seen any major shipments show up," he said.
Neels Venter, the head of South Africa's police anti-narcotics operation, told a local reporter back in July 1994 that South Africa was becoming a transit country for heroin smuggled to the United States and Europe.
Mr. Constantine said Nigerian gangs account for a growing share of the heroin smuggled into the United States. He described some of the couriers as "swallowers," who swallow condoms filled with heroin and regurgitate them after clearing airport customs. But he said the gangs were also hiring Eastern European and American women, who are less conspicuous, to sneak packets of heroin into the United States.
A background paper produced for a recent United Nations conference on crime prevention acknowledged the problem. "South Africa's status as an international model of political reconciliation and the new engine of economic growth for Africa is in jeopardy due to penetration by Lagos crime groups," it said.
Lee P. Brown, who resigned earlier this month as the President's director of drug-control policy, visited Nigeria and South Africa in September to discuss the flow of narcotics with officials in both countries.
"South Africa has the potential of becoming a significant transit country for Southeast Asian heroin en route to the United States," Mr. Brown reported when he returned. "Drug traffickers are taking advantage of the country's new openness to transit drugs through its poorly controlled borders, air and sea ports."
Mr. Brown said President Mandela and his ministers "fully appreciate the seriousness of the drug-trafficking threat and are already addressing it in their Cabinet meetings. They understand that once South Africa becomes a major drug-transit country it will also become a major drug-consuming country."
Until recently, drug use in South Africa was generally limited to dagga, the local marijuana, and to mandrax, a stimulant smuggled in pill form from India. Since the fall of apartheid in 1994, police officials have run into increasing amounts of heroin, crack cocaine and other drugs that were previously rare.
The South African Narcotics Bureau reported earlier this year that it had identified about 150 international drug syndicates operating in the country.

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Fall, New Hint Of a Slowdown

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools fell in November, the first drop in two months, an industry trade group said yesterday, in a report that suggested further weakness in manufacturing.
Last month's orders totaled $317.15 million, down more than 35 percent from October and 26 percent from November 1994, according to a monthly report by the Association for Manufacturing Technology. 
 For the first 11 months of 1995, the orders totaled $4.471 billion, 8 percent more than in the corresponding period in 1994.
Orders of machine tools, which are used to cut and shape metal for products ranging from toasters to tractors, are an indication of whether manufacturers are confident enough about demand to refurbish and expand their factories.
The weakening demand for machine tools is consistent with other recent evidence of a slowing economy. Government figures on demand for durable goods from American manufacturers have also shown recent declines.
Domestic orders for machine tools fell in November to $261.40 million, down 38 percent from October and 34 percent from November 1994, the trade organization, which is based in McLean, Va., said.
Foreign orders fell to $55.75 million last month, 17 percent lower than in October, but almost double the level of November 1994.
Shipments of machine tools totaled $522.85 million in November, up 4 percent from October and up 55 percent from November 1994.
For the first 10 months of 1995, the shipments totaled $4.39 billion, 28 percent more than in the same period last year.
The backlog of orders was $2.17 billion at the end of November, down from $2.38 at the end of October and $2.13 billion at the end of November 1994.
