HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Smite The Gate Closers

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Take in the stranger, care for him. The major religions of the world all teach that. At the time of holidays -- holy days -- that might be worth thinking about.
The above paragraph is a blatant attempt to use religion, the holiday season, emotion, compassion and sentiment in the cause of a generous American immigration policy. 
 Yes, and it is an unashamed effort to call down the words of Jehovah, Jesus, Allah, Krishna, Buddha and the great Sikh gurus to smite and warn American politicians who fight to keep narrowing the opening in the gates of America.
They struggle, with all their sour passions, to treat legal immigrants as a special caste to be deprived of rights and privileges for the offense of being foreign-born.
Well -- I really do not expect religion to move American politicians and their propaganda mentors who want to create America in their image -- America the Mingy, mean from shore to shining shore.
But when the strangers set immediately to build cities, take in crops and strengthen the country with their skills, culture and genius, we get that lovely combination -- virtue and responsibility coming together to promote our self-interest. That is what generous immigration gives us, a thought that might move Americans who sit by, not noticing its approaching demise.
As a holiday gift, I give you three particularly useful recent pieces on immigration.
Julian L. Simon, a professor of business at the University of Maryland, has put the essence of his noted immigration studies into 51 pages -- "Immigration: the Demographic and Economic Facts."
Here's a taste, backed by statistics, to answer the charges made by the gate narrowers en route to their goal of gate closing:
Despite the propaganda about America being overwhelmed with immigrants, the rate of immigration is about one-third what it was at the beginning of the century. Immigrants do not increase the rate of unemployment among native-born Americans. Total per capita government expenditures on immigrants are much lower than those for the native-born. The education levels of immigrants have been increasing every decade. Natural resources and the environment are not at risk from immigration -- in fact, they are helped by the technical knowledge it brings.
You can get this report from the Cato Institute, a conservative think tank, at 1000 Massachusetts Ave. N.W., Washington, D.C. 20001. It is excellent for smiting.
But the immigration issue is not just about statistics. Without immigration, America would not have long existed. Now, without immigration it cannot exist as a world power. Immigration helped create the weaponry and technology, from the atom bomb to the cruise missiles of the Persian Gulf war that empowered America militarily.
Today, immigrants of genius are essential to American industry and to high standards of American life. One-third of all American Nobel winners are foreign-born and judging by mathematical doctorates, science degrees, patents, prizes and publications, one-third of American geniuses are foreign-born.
Those conclusions come from "Geniuses from Abroad" in the Wall Street Journal of Dec. 18, by George Gilder, a fellow of the Discovery Institute in Seattle.
It would be handy if the U.S. could just pick up geniuses full blown, rejecting all others at the gate. But geniuses have a way of arriving in America disguised as little kids. Or they come from the wombs of non-genius immigrant mothers. That's the way it works.
But when an immigrant or immigrant-family genius does flower, he turns out to be thousands of times more productive economically than ordinary people -- a reality ignored by too many economists.
Then, for an idea how gate closers are endangering immigration and perverting the Constitution, read the analysis of the anti-immigration measures now pending in Congress. Get it from National Immigration Forum, 220 I Street N.E., Suite 220, Washington D.C. 20002-4362. Then have a chat with your local Congress member, a lot of chats.
I wish I had a pulpit to instruct the anti-immigration types that their defiance of the religious commandments on the stranger weakens their country and, incidentally, endangers their immortal souls, but a column will have to do.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mr. Hollings Saves the Phone Bill

 BODY:
House and Senate conferees seemed ready to negotiate a damaging telecommunications compromise until Senator Ernest Hollings of South Carolina, the chief Senate negotiator, altered that destiny last week. Wielding the threat of a filibuster and a deft legislative hand, he rescued the best parts of flawed House and Senate bills passed earlier, added some good new ideas and threw out most of the rot.
His draft bill could spark innovation and set off consumer-friendly competition among television, cable and telephone companies. Its biggest flaw is a heavy-handed and probably unconstitutional effort to ban "indecent material" from the Internet. 
 The original bills sought to break down barriers that keep media companies from entering each other's markets. But three mistakes were made. The bills would have deregulated cable rates before competition by other video companies could protect customers from price-gouging cable operators. Local phone companies would have been allowed to enter the long-distance market before they faced competition from cable or other companies. Worse still, the bills would have allowed broadcasters, cable operators, telephone companies and newspapers to merge too easily. That could expose consumers to a frightening concentration of information sources.
Mr. Hollings, with the help of key Republicans like Senator Larry Pressler, fixed most of these flaws. His draft bill would hold up entry of local phone companies into long-distance service until the Federal Communications Commission says O.K. after giving weight to an antitrust review by the Justice Department. The bill leaves it up to the F.C.C. to set reasonable guidelines for mergers. It would put off deregulation of most cable rates for three years -- enough time for phone and satellite services to take on cable operators.
The one serious error is a prohibition against transmission of allegedly indecent materials over the Internet -- the network of millions of on-line computer subscribers around the world. The indecency standard is probably unconstitutionally vague and restrictive. The standard is also unnecessary. The law already forbids sending obscene materials by computer. To protect children, parents can buy easy-to-use programs that block indecent materials from any source. The draft bill threatens to trigger further Government control of electronic communication -- which has blossomed so far precisely because Government has stayed on the sidelines. Fortunately, Republican leaders like Speaker Newt Gingrich are troubled by the indecency standard. There is a good opportunity to knock the provision out before Congress takes a vote.
Some Republicans, miffed when Vice President Al Gore declared the draft an Administration victory, threatened to withhold support. But telecommunications, the heart of a high-tech economy, is too important for small-minded sparring. Congress should take up the draft bill, remove the indecency provision and put Mr. Hollings's good deed into law.

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK: John Henry Holland;
Searching for Simple Rules Of Complexity

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE 

 BODY:
HE'S the man who taught computers how to have sex. And now, for an encore, he's working on a theory to explain the complexity of life and its myriad manifestations on planet earth.
In so doing, John Henry Holland poses metaphorical questions that he likes to ponder while taking his morning shower or during hours spent alone in his office. How is an economic system like an immune system? How is an anthill like the brain? How is evolution like learning? 
 If there are plausible answers to these questions, Dr. Holland is likely to find them. The 66-year-old computer scientist from the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor is legendary for having invented genetic algorithms -- lines of computer code that simulate sexually reproducing organisms. This powerful technique is being used to redesign factory assembly lines and in attempts to predict stock market fluctuations.
Nowadays, Dr. Holland has turned his attention to the nascent field of complexity. "Many of our most troubling long-range problems -- trade balances, sustainability, genetic defects, mental health, computer viruses -- center on systems of extraordinary complexity," said Dr. Holland. "The systems that host these problems -- economies, ecologies, immune systems, embryos, nervous systems, computer networks -- appear to be as diverse as the problems."
But there may be some hidden order, some fundamental characteristics and common interactions inherent in all these systems, Dr. Holland said. More than the sum of their parts, each of these complex systems has, in his view, the ability to anticipate the future, learn and adapt in ways that are not yet understood.
Complexity, for all its youth and growing pains, is a highly controversial field. Some critics call it a sham. One skeptic recently mocked claims for the new discipline by asking if a cure for AIDS was more likely to emerge from the mathematics and computer modeling of complexity science than from the nitty-gritty bench-top work that led to the discovery of the AIDS virus.
Complexity theory may never produce a cure for the acquired immune deficiency syndrome but it can generate theories that help direct experiments, Dr. Holland said. "Theory and experiment go hand in glove and this is where we might make a major contribution," he said.
This year's top accolade in epidemiology, the Timmons award, went to three researchers who used complexity theory to model the spread of AIDS, Dr. Holland said. They showed that the virus is most infectious in the first few weeks of incubation and not, as is widely believed, later on when it multiplies within its victims.
Other critics say that complexity is no different from a number of other scientific fads like chaos, cybernetics and catastrophe theories. "People say these were flashes in the pan but in fact if you look at each, they have contributed healthily to the way scientists look at things," Dr. Holland said. "To say cybernetics failed is to ignore that the fact that feedback in living systems is now accepted as received wisdom in many scientific fields."
Another criticism is that complexity theory is built on computer models that have little to do with the real world. But models lead to genuine insights, Dr. Holland said. For example, before James Clerk Maxwell developed his famous equations describing electromagnetism, he built little gears that floated in water. Maxwell studied the gears' interactions to build up his field theories, Dr. Holland said.
Like Maxwell, Dr. Holland uses models to search for mathematical equations. His goal is to find fundamental rules of nature that he believes drive all complex adaptive systems. "This is more than the search for a terminology," Dr. Holland said. "It signals our intuition that there are general principles that govern all complex adaptive system behavior, principles that point to ways of solving the attendant problems."
For the last 400 years science has advanced by reductionism, Dr. Holland said. "The idea is that you could understand the world, all of nature, by examining smaller and smaller pieces of it. When assembled, the small pieces would explain the whole." Moreover, mathematical laws could predict all natural phenomena.
"In a general sense there is nothing wrong with this approach," Dr. Holland said. "It has led to tremendous successes." But reductionism and the linear mathematics on which it relies, he continued, have hit some serious snags in the last 100 years. The first blow came when scientists like Kurt Godel proved that mathematical systems are always incomplete and cannot be relied on to describe nature.
Then scientists began to take a closer look at nature itself, Dr. Holland said. The world is filled with complex phenomena that do not behave in a linear fashion and that cannot be explained by reductionism, he said. "We can't add up the parts and understand the whole, for that does not give a good picture of what the system does," he said. "The interactions are just as important as the parts." A different kind of mathematics, using nonlinear approaches, is needed.
Scientists from many disciplines are fascinated by complex adaptive systems, Dr. Holland said. He spends time each year at the Santa Fe Institute in New Mexico where scientists from different disciplines meet to discuss complex phenomena in nature and technology. "I go there to think and cross pollinate ideas," he said.
Dr. Holland said that his basic strategy is to look for common properties and mechanisms in various complex adaptive systems. "A feature that is obvious in one system can be recondite and hidden in another," he said. "If I look at arms races between nations, certain features and motivations seem fairly clear. In ecosystems, there are similar arms races between organisms."
For example, a flowering plant might evolve a toxin that fends off a moth and in turn the moth might evolve an enzyme that renders the toxin harmless, Dr. Holland said. Further mutations might take place in a kind of arms race between the two organisms.
Dr. Holland likes to work alone. "I find most scientific meetings a waste of time," he said. "I read Science, Scientific American and the American Scientist and follow up on references for things that seem relevant. I enjoy learning as much as I can about different fields." He has three offices -- one at the university, one at home and another at a summer home on Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Each hideaway is strewn with books on every conceivable subject and many, such as E. O. Wilson's "The Ants," show signs of having been read more than once.
But as more and more information gets absorbed, Dr. Holland faces his ultimate challenge -- abstracting the information, deciding what to keep in his models of complex adaptive systems and what to toss out.
"This is a matter of taste," he said, "not unlike an art form. It is based on metaphors and analogies." For inspiration, Dr. Holland often talks with a poet, Alice Fulton, who also lives in Ann Arbor. "We discuss creativity in science and poetry," he said. "Our purposes are similar, to find the right phrases, right words, right rhymes. The feeling of rightness is critical to what I do. It's a matter of intuition, of judgment, of style. I look at big, buzzing complex systems and ask what mechanisms and properties seem central."
For one thing, every system has agents. Economies have business firms. Brains have neurons. And anthills have ants. The agents -- business firms, neurons, or ants -- interact on the basis of very simple rules that can lead to complex behavior, Dr. Holland said. An individual ant has a small number of rules. If it finds food, it lays down a scent. If another ant detects a scent, it follows the trail. A dozen or so simple rules used by single ants result in an ant colony that exhibits surprisingly complex behavior, Dr. Holland said. It looks intelligent as it puts out probes to exploit its environment, defends itself and lives far longer than any individual ant. The same goes for neurons. Each cell follows a few dozen simple rules but taken together you get the conscious human brain.
One system may also use building blocks from another system in new ways. The internal combustion engine is composed of parts used in earlier technologies, recombined in a way that led to a whole new transportation system.
Another common trait is that agents form aggregates. In a tropical forest, trees and parasites like Spanish moss collectively retain nutrients in a way that neither the tree nor the parasite could do alone. The first business firm, described by Adam Smith, is another example, Dr. Holland said. Straight pins used to be made by individual craftsmen who could produce only so many pins per day. When the workers formed an aggregate, with one person drawing the wire, another clipping it and another putting on the pinhead, he said, production went up by a factor of 10 and the price of straight pins dropped.
While such aggregates seem obvious, Dr. Holland said, "we still don't understand the mechanisms by which they come about," adding: "What triggers them? Why do they stay together? In modeling aggregates, no one has been able to show how this transformation occurs." Eventually, the interactions between aggregates produce larger systems, he said.
The challenge is to build a computer model that explains both protein folding and international finance, Dr. Holland said.
"We're a long way from achieving this," he said. But the payoff could be enormous bcause complex adaptive systems have lever points. A small perturbation can have far-reaching results. Vaccines are an example. A small injection can make a huge, trillion cell organism immune to measles.
These kinds of lever points abound in natural systems, he said. "We just don't know where to look for them," he said. "But it's possible that a small intervention could make an enormous difference in solving inner-city problems. Good mathematics would suggest where and how to look for them."
Dr. Holland recently wrote a book, "Hidden Order, How Adaptation Builds Complexity," published this fall by Addison Wesley. He is now working on a book called "Emergence," about the relationship between metaphors and computer models and innovation.
"I like to hang out with artists and musicians," for inspiration, said Dr. Holland, who does not look the Bohemian part in his conservative suits and dark ties. "Basically I prefer to work alone," he said. "Spending time alone thinking is critical. I don't remember ideas from sleep but I do get many of my best ideas while in the shower." He smiled, recalling that he was in the shower when, three years ago, the phone rang with news that he had won a MacArthur genius award.
"I've had good luck in the shower," he said. "I should keep a pad of paper closer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. John Holland, at one of his favorite workplaces -- his home office. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Creatures of the Deep Find Their Way to the Table

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
DWELLING in darkness, little known or understood, the animals of the deep sea are traditionally thought of as mysterious or monstrous. But that is changing. Increasingly, commercial fishermen are scouring the global deep to catch them by the ton. Creatures of the abyss, frequently grotesque by human standards, are being carefully prepared and marketed to hide their murky origins when sold in stores and restaurants.
Scientists worry that the rush for deep-sea food is beginning to upset the delicate ecology of some of the sunless regions that cover more than half the planet, threatening to tip the evolutionary balance. But chefs and fishermen are eager to probe the new frontier. Deep harvesting, they say, can be prudent and the results quite tasty. 
 "They're an incredible hit," Michael Stafford, the chef at the Captain Daniel Packer Inn in Mystic, Conn., said of the giant deep-sea shrimp he has started to serve. They are known as Stonington Reds and Royal Scarlets and are sometimes as large as lobsters. "They're tender and sweet, and they cook really quickly," he said. "They sell themselves."
Other deep creatures now being harvested or targeted as seafood include rattails, skates, squid, red crabs, orange roughy, black oreos, smooth oreos, hoki, blue ling, southern blue whiting, sablefish, black scabbard fish and spiny dogfish.
The search for palatable fare in the sea's depths is partly fueled by fishing wars and the collapse of such shallow fisheries as the Grand Banks off Newfoundland, where the search for wholesome food and short-term profit has driven such popular species as cod and haddock to the verge of commercial extinction. Worldwide, after centuries of steady growth, the total catch of wild fish peaked in 1989 and has subsequently declined.
Foraging deeper is often a survival strategy for fishermen forced out of traditional grounds by government regulators and pressed by creditors to make payments on expensive boats. In the United States, the investigation of deep fisheries is encouraged by the National Marine Fisheries Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, a Federal agency that aids such exploratory work with millions of dollars in grants. The exact amount of the catch from the deep seas is not known.
But scientists and environmental groups warn that so little is known about deep-sea creatures that some face ruin. Animals that inhabit the icy depths, experts say, often grow and reproduce very slowly, making their populations particularly vulnerable to disruption. Scientists recently discovered that the orange roughy, which dwells up to a mile deep off New Zealand and has been heavily exported to the United States for a decade, reaches sexual maturity in its 30's and lives to an age of 150 years or more.
"Deep fisheries can provide a pulse of good fishing but they're often not sustainable," said Dr. Jack Sobel, a senior scientist at the Center for Marine Conservation, a private group in Washington.
The problem is illustrated by orange roughy, whose principal stocks around New Zealand recently collapsed. "They never should have been exploited at all," said Mike Hagler, a fisheries expert in Auckland, New Zealand, for Greenpeace International. "People wouldn't eat rhinoceros or any other land creature that they knew was threatened by extinction. But they're eating fish like orange roughy without a clue to what's happening."
Peter J. Auster, science director of the National Undersea Research Center at the University of Connecticut in Avery Point, said knowledge and moderation were essential to avoiding trouble. "Some of these fisheries might be sustainable with a five-boat fleet but would be rapidly depleted if 15 or 20 boats decided to go after them," he said.
"The attraction is understandable. For the individual fisherman trying to pay off the boat or put his kid through school, and facing Draconian rules to reduce pressure on over-exploited stocks, this is a wide-open area. It's a place to go and use your wits and knowledge to try to make a living, which is what fishermen have been doing for centuries."
Bruce Morehead, an official of the National Marine Fisheries Service, said his agency was aware of the risks that accompanied deep fishing and was working closely with commercial fishermen to strike a balance between exploitation and conservation. "If you don't accurately assess the stocks," he said, "you can accidentally kill them off."
Although limited commercial fishing of the deep has been practiced for decades around the globe, new sciences and technologies are rapidly making it more practical and efficient, even as its allure grows because of the worldwide depletion of shallow stocks. Hauls that once took days can now be done in minutes.
From the start, the main tool has been a long steel line and a stout net or baglike trawl, which can be dragged through the midwater or across the dark bottom, its way eased by rollers and wheels. Now ships are bigger and faster, lines are thinner and stronger, and winding drums are wider. Most importantly, the maws of trawls can be enormous, often hundreds of feet wide.
Former military technologies are helping the hunt, including radars that let boats navigate in dense fogs, sonars that locate deep schools and navigation satellites that pinpoint locations so vessels can return to rich locations.
As a result, the bottoms of many continental shelves and shallow seas have been scraped repeatedly in the hunt for deep seafood. Increasingly, the action is moving into the inky depths.
Recently, fishermen have begun pinpointing zones of deep fertility by studying maps based on formerly secret military data, which reveal hidden sea-floor features. For instance, a map made public in October by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in one step doubled the number of known undersea mountains, which often are associated with upwellings of deep, nutrient-rich water and dense aggregations of sea life.
Deep creatures hauled up as commercial seafood include deep-sea red crabs found off the northeastern United States and southwest Africa, according to Dr. John D. Gage and Dr. Paul A. Tyler, authors of "Deep-Sea Biology" (Cambridge University Press).
In the North Atlantic, Russians pioneered the harvesting of rattails, a ubiquitous deep fish with big eyes and a long tail that swishes back and forth in a sinuous motion. This fishery, which at its peak produced more than 80,000 tons a year, is now in decline. "Whether this has been caused by too-intensive fishing" or natural shifts is unclear, the scientists say.
In the Pacific, the sablefish, or blackcod, is fished at depths of up to a mile, and recent research suggests that individuals can live up to 70 years. Anxious over its slow rates of reproduction, Dr. Gage and Dr. Tyler warn that "the stock could become quickly depleted" unless deep fishing is carefully regulated.
A best seller from the depths has been orange roughy, a pug-nosed warrior that feeds on prawns, squid and fish, living on deep banks and around sea mounts near New Zealand. Trawlers in their heyday could sometimes catch 50 tons an hour. But after a gold rush that resulted in the export of hundreds of millions of dollars a year in orange roughy, the New Zealand fishery recently collapsed to a tiny fraction of its former size.
Now the industry is seeking to develop fisheries for alternative deep species such as black oreos and smooth oreos.
"In deep water you get high costs, high technology, high finance, and consequently, the pressure is on to heavily exploit the stocks," said Mr. Hagler of Greenpeace International. "You're up against the wall, which pushes fisheries beyond the limits of economic sustainability."
Scientists say the collapse of deep stocks such as orange roughy can have all kinds of hidden implications because they are apparently preyed on by such large animals as sperm whales and giant squids. Their disappearance, experts warn, could disrupt delicate food chains.
Off the United States, the National Marine Fisheries Service is helping industry explore fisheries for deep shrimp, rattails, chimeras, orange roughy, smoothheads, slackjaw eels, blue hake, skates and dogfish, which the National Fisheries Institute, an industry group, in an effort to improve their marketability, has renamed cape shark.
"We're excited because these may open up an avenue to try something new and relieve the pressure on cod, haddock, some of the flounders and other species that are depleted at this point," said Kenneth L. Beal, a manager in Gloucester, Mass., with the northeast regional office of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
One pioneer deep shrimper is Capt. Bill Bomster, who with his three sons runs the 100-foot "Patty Jo" out of Stonington, Conn., and sells his catch to the Daniel Packer Inn in nearby Mystic. He has plied the edge of the continental shelf from Block Island to Virginia, dragging the bottom with a 200-foot-long trawl whose mouth is 3 feet high and 150 feet wide. The trawling is done at depths of up to a half mile.
"What's nice is that the water is very cold and exceptionally clean," he said. "That makes the catch far superior to gulf or farm-raised or any other shrimp. Some of the damn things are 10 inches long."
As stocks of better-known fish shrink and international quotas tighten, experts say the deep will increasingly be targeted as a source of seafood, which is fine with Mr. Stafford at the Daniel Packer Inn.
One of his deliveries of deep shrimp was accompanied by a strange kind of crawfish that nobody could identify, even his friends who are marine biologists.
"One of the arms was really long," Mr. Stafford recalled, adding that the exotic crustacean went into the pot along with the big shrimp.
"It was really tasty," he said.

HEADLINE: THE PROMISE OF GAMBLING: A special report.;
After 20 Years, Atlantic City Starts to Reap Casinos' Benefits

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
Ask Michelle Barnes what her future would look like without the casinos here and she cannot even imagine.
"I don't know," she said. "I guess I would be working at, McDonald's?" 
 Unlike many high school seniors these days, Miss Barnes is not worried about finding a good job when she graduates. She is one of 50 members of the class of 1996 from Atlantic City High School, an urban, largely minority school, who have lined up full-time jobs at the casinos here with starting pay close to $20,000 a year plus benefits and promotion opportunities.
Miss Barnes was born in 1976, the year New Jersey residents voted to legalize gambling in hopes of rejuvenating this decaying honky-tonk resort and restoring some of the economic power that it formerly had in southern New Jersey. Now, as the 20th anniversary of the vote approaches, the gambling industry's big promises -- that the casinos' wealth would spill over and enrich the community as a whole -- are finally beginning to become a reality.
While it has taken longer than anyone expected, and this city of 38,000 has hardly been converted into a utopia, there are now many jobs available for high school graduates and thousands of new units of moderate-priced housing, as well as a new supermarket, airport and minor league baseball team. A new convention center is under construction, along with a big noncasino hotel aimed at attracting tourists who want to do more than gamble.
"This is my future," Miss Barnes said of her $300-a-week after-school job as an assistant cash manager at Claridge Casino restaurants. "I have friends who graduated two or three years ago, and they have houses and cars and babies now. So this is what I'm striving for, to work here until I retire."
Even gambling's defenders, like Atlantic City's Mayor and school leaders, concede that the high-blown promises made during the 1976 referendum campaign are still far from fulfilled. (And in other towns where casinos want to gain a foothold, like Bridgeport, Conn., opponents repeatedly recite the bleak side of the Atlantic City story.)
Homelessness was a problem here 20 years ago, and it still is -- but only about half as bad, according to shelter officials. Unemployment, at 14.9 percent, is still high, but it is an improvement from the 18.2 percent rate in 1976 and not as bad as in Camden, where the rate is 18.4 percent.
And there have been losers in the long, slow development process. Retailers along Atlantic Avenue were among gambling's most ardent promoters 20 years ago, and -- except for the pawn shops -- were repaid by being all but wiped out by the casinos, which deliberately maintain their own restaurants, entertainment and shopping areas as a way of keeping as much tourist money as possible within their own walls.
In one of the most positive signs of a business turnaround, construction is almost complete at a retail complex that includes a Thriftway, the city's first new supermarket in decades.
Crime is down in cities across the country, but in Atlantic City the drop has been sharper than elsewhere. Both violent and nonviolent crime have dropped by half since 1990, helped by the greater availability of jobs -- jobs for which a police record is an automatic disqualifier.
 
Making Progress
Promise of Jobs Motivates Students
Atlantic City High School's dropout rate was 24 percent as recently as 1990. Now it is 13 percent, compared with a statewide average of 16 percent.
"It's still too high, but we're making progress," said William Steel, the principal. He credited, in part, the new $1.2 million high school building -- paid for with casino taxes -- and the lure of casino jobs after graduation.
"You can work part time while you're still in school," said Mark Mangel, the school's job-placement counselor, "but you need a diploma afterward if you're going to go anywhere."
Tonya Maniscarco, a 1990 Atlantic City High graduate, is in her fourth year as a promotions representative at Trump's Castle Casino Resort. "To the kids in school," she said, "the casinos are an adventure, a new kind of life, and there's always advancement. Everybody talks about being a dealer when they're in high school."
Ms. Maniscarco lives with her twin sister, Sherene, who works at the Trump Taj Mahal. She declined to say how much she earns, but said she does not regret having skipped college.
"I make a good salary. They take good care of you medically. If you have children, they cover them, too. So I'm just going to stay."
James Hughes, dean of planning and public policy at Rutgers, says casino gambling is "providing a type of opportunity that is equivalent to the manufacturing jobs we once had."
Dr. Hughes -- who with George Sternlieb wrote a book in 1983 on the ups and downs of the casino industry titled "The Atlantic City Gamble" -- still finds much to dislike about the gambling industry here. The dislocation created in the early days, when homes and businesses were knocked down in anticipation of investment that never came, put a blot on gambling's record that is still seen in the blighted streets along the approach to the city from the Atlantic City Expressway.
But in the 12 years since he wrote the book, he said, the city's economic health has improved.
"You now have more than $3 billion worth of new property to tax," Dr. Hughes said, "and no other urban center in New Jersey has had investment comparable to that. Today, the police are well paid and well equipped, you have a good civil-service staff that was just starting to take shape in 1983 and is now solidly in place. The schools are on solid fiscal foundation."
"And clearly," he added, "the employment opportunities are greater than in any other urban area."
All this has been helped by the strong run the casinos have been experiencing -- 19 straight months of record income growth.
Still, Dr. Hughes said, there are limits. "The notion of taking large numbers of people who were in urban poverty and lifting them into mainstream America, that has not happened. But that is also an impossible standard to hold the city to."
The city's strengths are cited in a Salomon Brothers market analysis headlined "Atlantic City: Worthy of a Second Look." The trends have been bolstered by more investment coming in, including the following:
*A $270 million convention center, the largest between New York and Washington, is under construction, paid for by the state's Sports and Exhibition Authority. It will be linked to a new 500-room, $87 million Headquarters Hotel, Atlantic City's largest nongambling investment in years, intended to widen the city's appeal.
*A $1 billion two-casino complex is planned by Circus Circus and Mirage Resorts, whose chairman, Steven A. Wynn, left Atlantic City in a fury eight years ago over what he called incompetent and meddlesome state casino policy.
*The $225 million Corridor Project, to widen and remake the Missouri Avenue approach to the Boardwalk area, will rebuild the old ocean front convention hall, home to the Miss America pageant.
*Seven casinos are spending $580 million to add 3,000 hotel rooms and build new parking and retail space.
*A new airport has just been completed, and a minor league baseball team has been signed.
The new investment will add thousands of jobs to an industry that has already created 44,000 jobs, more than the city's entire population of 38,000. Nearly half the existing jobs are filled by women and members of minority groups.
 
Recognizing Limits
Some Urban Woes Defy Resolution
One reason the Atlantic City experience has been seen as a failure by many, says Mayor James Whelan, is that high unemployment, poverty and welfare dependence coexist with so much opportunity.
Mr. Whelan, a Democrat, considers Atlantic City a lesson in the limits of trickle-down capitalism.
"The problems that exist in the culture of poverty are not solved by providing jobs," he said. "Casinos do not solve hopelessness, they do not stop kids from dropping out of school, they do not stop kids from getting pregnant. If a teen-age boy does not have a father, getting his mother a job is not going to provide a role model for him."
Although the casino operators deny it, many Atlantic City leaders maintain that the houses, as the casinos are sometimes called, turned their backs on the city in the early years. The managers were from Las Vegas and felt little kinship with the city.
But in the last six years, as industry leaders grew worried about the negative accounts of Atlantic City's gambling experience, the casinos became more community-minded. Some trace the turnabout to 1990, when the casinos embarked on a campaign to have sports betting legalized and sought to win support by showing themselves off as concerned members of the community.
The sports betting effort failed, but today one would be hard-pressed to find a school, club or social service agency that has not received support from the casinos.
"I think what has happened was that the brain trust that is part of the casino industry said, 'We are available now to help,' " said Barry Durman, president of the Atlantic City Rescue Mission, a refuge for the homeless.
"I remember how it happened in 1989," Mr. Durman said. "We had a severe financial crunch, we really needed the help, and I spoke with the Trump organization about it. That Christmas they handed me a check for $10,000, and the next year Trump's Castle called and said, 'We're going to send you 300 entrees every day for the rest of your life.' "
Last year, the Rescue Mission served 208,468 hot meals and distributed 23,526 food baskets, and did not pay for a single one.
In 1991, the Rescue Mission provided 70,850 nights of lodging to homeless people, and that figure has declined each year to 50,589 last year, partly because the city's economy is improving, Mr. Durman said, and because the mission is taking a harder line in excluding men who refuse help getting back on their feet.
Donald Bailey, 28, was one of the men waiting for a meal and a cot recently. He said he shunted laundry carts in a casino for three months until he hurt his foot and is now homeless. Yet, he said, his 25-year old brother Dennis is making $22,000 a year at a laundry service for the casinos.
"The casinos have been good for a lot of people from around here," Mr. Bailey said. "They just haven't been much good for me."
Each year, Harrah's Casino pays for a formal sit-down dinner for parents of honor-roll students at the Uptown Elementary School. Most casinos provide scholarships for graduates of the city's high school.
"Every school has a casino as a partner," said Ernest L. Harper, the Uptown principal, "and it's more than just an adopt-a-school program. They pay for job fairs at the state colleges. They put up smoke detectors for us."
This year, 289 students from the high school are working in the casinos, earning an average of $8 per hour busing tables, cleaning floors and acting as greeters. Typically, between a quarter and a third of graduating seniors work at the casinos. "The casinos have always liked to promote from within, so there is upward mobility," said Mr. Mangel, the job-placement counselor.
Mr. Mangel's son Greg spent two summers at Resorts Casino while he was attending college. At 24, he is now the casino's food and beverage accounting manager.
 
Changing Fortunes
Deregulation Bill Spurs Investment
Perhaps nothing better illustrates Atlantic City's changing business fortunes than the planned return of Mirage Resorts, eight years after Mr. Wynn angrily sold the Golden Nugget casino and swore never to return, saying the city government was corrupt and incompetent, the state overzealous in its regulation.
"Things are so different in Atlantic City today compared to then that I don't know if it's possible to state the differences loudly and clearly enough," said Alan M. Feldman, a Mirage vice president. "But the No. 1 change has been the change in regulatory attitude and emphasis by the Governor and by the Mayor."
On Jan. 25, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a casino deregulation bill into law that ended state supervision over hundreds of nongambling functions.
"We now confine ourselves to keeping the games honest and making sure the state gets the share of revenues that it is due," said Bradford S. Smith, director of the State Casino Control Commission.
That share is 8 percent of total gambling receipts, good for $263 million last year, that goes toward programs for the aged and the disabled throughout the state.
The law also requires casinos to invest an additional 1.5 percent of all revenue in local nongambling development. This money, more than $50 million a year, has underwritten the construction of new housing at the northern Inlet Section.
The housing, on land cleared of old buildings, was built with special attention to insure that original residents would not be displaced involuntarily, said Susan L. Ney, assistant deputy director of the Redevelopment Authority. Owners were bought out at market rates and given temporary shelter. Renters in the old housing were also placed in rental housing, and the difference in rents subsidized.
New units were offered for sale at heavily subsidized discounts, Ms. Ney said, and renters were provided apartments in new high-rises.
Houses that sold for $63,000 to $69,000 to outsiders went to previous owners from the neighborhood for $50,000 -- the typical buyout price for one of the old houses. The Redevelopment Authority used some of its casino revenue to subsidize mortgage rates.
When the first phase of new houses was offered, there were few takers because few trusted the authority. As successive phases opened, more owners and renters signed on. Today, the authority estimates that more than 90 percent of the people living in the new housing are former residents.
Ralph Brown, a retired middle school student counselor, is one of them. He used to own a three-story frame house at 110 Adelphic Avenue. Now he lives with his wife and child in a three-bedroom town house a block away.
"When they tore down those old wrecks," he said, "they ran off all the squatters that were living in them, and they were causing the crime. No old houses, no crime now."
But Mr. Brown said he paid only $720 a year in taxes on Adelphic Avenue, and his condo, bought for $55,000 last year, cost him $2,300 in taxes and association charges. "Before, I was living mortgage free. Now, I got a mortgage, but I'm living a lot better."
Dr. Hughes has thought a lot about whether gambling has been good for Atlantic City.
"We can tear ourselves apart arguing about whether it's been good or bad," he said. "The fact is, it's there, it exists, and the question now is, how best do we reshape it so that Atlantic City will be viable in the long run. To me, the new housing, the baseball stadium, the corridor project and the convention center are the kinds of things Atlantic City will need to survive in the next century."

HEADLINE: THE CONTENDERS;
Phil Gramm's Offbeat Charm As a Persistent Conservative

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Dec. 21

 BODY:
There is a kind of offbeat charm in the roguish self-deprecation of William Philip Gramm, the Texas Senator who wants to be the next President of the United States.
Campaigning in Phoenix recently, Senator Gramm was introduced to 2 1/2-year-old Leah Clark, a dazzling little towhead, by her proud parents. "I had a girlfriend once named Leah," drawled Mr. Gramm, tickling the toddler under the chin. "She dumped me!" 
 Phil Gramm's style may or may not captivate the voters. But for the most part, Mr. Gramm, who a colleague once said was "charismatically challenged" and whom Texas Monthly magazine described as a man with "the round, wizened face of a snapping turtle," never planned to win the Presidency with a charm offensive anyway.
Instead, Mr. Gramm has tried to storm his way to the Republican nomination with the twin bludgeons of an unbendingly conservative economic message and an enormous campaign war chest. Now, though, with the 53-year-old Senator having clearly failed to build any air of inevitability about his own nomination, his campaign emphasizes a less ambitious proposition: that there is nothing inevitable about the nomination of the Republican front-runner, Bob Dole.
"We're where we want to be," he insisted in an interview. "I said at the outset of the year that the point was to establish Phil Gramm as the viable conservative alternative to Bob Dole. We have achieved that."
But several state and national polls suggest that at least three other Republican challengers can lay claim to the mantle of Mr. Dole's chief rival or, perhaps more accurately, that none of them can. Mr. Gramm is stuck in a crowd.
So, rather than dueling with Mr. Dole head-on, the Texas Senator rattles off the reasons that he should be taken more seriously than the rest:
*Lamar Alexander, former Governor of Tennessee: "No money; no message."
*Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire: "People are not going to vote for Forbes; he's not plausible."
*Pat Buchanan, the political commentator: "He's a protest vote against Dole. If I convince people that I have a chance of beating Dole, they'll desert Buchanan in droves."
The essence of Mr. Gramm's strategy remains unchanged: finish close enough to Senator Dole in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary to establish himself as the prime alternative, then overpower Mr. Dole in a string of more conservative Southern and Western state primaries that follow.
Mr. Gramm dismisses his standing well below Mr. Dole in a variety of state and national public-opinion polls, insisting that they are largely based on name recognition and that a truer reflection of the race is his victories in straw polls of party activists, events on which he has lavished far more money than any other candidate but which he says demonstrates the grass-roots strength and organization of his campaign.
Still, by this point in the campaign, Mr. Gramm had clearly hoped to be spending most of his time building the case against Senator Dole, not against the lesser-knowns. In fact, by declaring early and raising $20 million, far more than any other candidate except Mr. Dole (though Mr. Forbes is a wild card because he is spending his own money), Mr. Gramm wanted the race to be a two-man duel by now.
That it is not raises questions not about his fund-raising ability or his organizational skills, but about his message and his fundamental appeal as a President. His conservative themes are solid, but he has not electrified crowds and he has also had some embarrassing stumbles.
Asked by Larry King if he would consider a female running mate, Mr. Gramm quipped, "Sophia Loren is not a citizen," a remark that many did not find endearing. His small investment 20 years ago in a soft-porn movie project, "Beauty Queens," did not go over big in conservative Christian circles.
 
Unusual Boast About Money
And he may well have undercut himself with his boasts about his remarkable fund-raising prowess, as if that, as opposed to his vision for the country, amounted to his chief political asset.
The night before he formally announced for President, Mr. Gramm spoke to a glittering crowd in a Dallas hotel where he took in $4.1 million and set a record for the largest amount raised in a single campaign event. He told the crowd: "Thanks to you, I have the most reliable friend you can have in American politics, and that's ready money." (Mr. Gramm says now that criticism over the remark was unwarranted because he was just humorously paraphrasing a Benjamin Franklin quipp that the three most "reliable friends" in the world were "an old wife, an old dog and ready money.")
But if Mr. Gramm is waging an uphill fight for the nomination, few people count him out altogether. Richard Murray, a professor of political science at the University of Houston who has closely followed Senator Gramm's political career, said that while "it doesn't seem like he plays well on the Presidential stage," Mr. Gramm has a history in Texas of winning races in which people did not take him seriously at first.
In fact, the only race he ever lost -- long before he switched from the Democratic to Republican Party -- came when he tried, as an obscure 33-year-old professor of economics at Texas A&M University, to wrest the Democratic nomination for the Senate from a popular incumbent, Lloyd M. Bentsen, in 1976.
"Phil Gramm is just so easily underestimated," Mr. Murray said. "He's smart. He's tough. He's determined. He's resourceful."
Mr. Gramm has a history of shrewdly seizing the political advantage. Running behind in a race for the House of Representatives two years later, Mr. Gramm seemed headed for oblivion until the retiring Congressman in his district, at a news conference to endorse Mr. Gramm's opponent, falsely implied that Mr. Gramm and his wife, Wendy, had a child out of wedlock. Mr. Gramm masterfully seized on the aspersion, using it to build both voter attention and sympathy, and he narrowly won the race.
And in perhaps the most legendary incident of his career, Mr. Gramm appeared to have violated all political decorum in a 1982 fracas. As a member of the Democratic-controlled Budget Committee in 1982, Mr. Gramm, according to an account by President Ronald Reagan's budget director, David Stockman, provided the White House with secret information about the Democrat's budget strategy.
Mr. Gramm was booted off the committee for his heresy. But rather than atone, he committed apostasy.
He resigned his seat, immediately declaring for the vacancy as a Republican and telling the voters: "I had to choose between representing Tip O'Neill or y'all, and I chose to represent y'all." He won smashingly, and the next year he won the statewide election to the Senate.
He has survived ethics scrapes ranging from the arguable use of his Senate staff for campaign activities to a controversy over a Dallas savings and loan operator's paying almost half the $117,000 in building expenses on Mr. Gramm's vacation home on the Maryland shore. Mr. Gramm said that the man contracted to do the work and that the money represented a cost overrun.
Senator Gramm's tenacity is well-documented in everything from his political campaigns to his courtship of his second wife, Dr. Wendy Lee Gramm, whom he married in 1970 and with whom he has two sons, Marshall and Jeff. Both Mr. Gramm and his wife say her first response to him was: "Yuck!"
That was when Mr. Gramm was on a recruiting trip for Texas A&M, which was ready to offer a job to Ms. Lee, herself an economist. "As a single member of the faculty," Mr. Gramm's future wife recalled him telling her, "I'd be very interested in having you come to Texas A&M." The remark rather than landing Mr. Gramm a sexual-harassment lawsuit landed him a wife.
 
A Budget Pledge Close to His Heart
Mr. Gramm cites the evident affection of his wife -- as well as that of the many long-serving members of his staff and of his dog, a yellow Labrador named Gus -- to counter a recurring description of him as "mean."
"I think that when you say, No, in Washington, it makes you mean," Mr. Gramm said, as a turboprop airplane passed over the crimson rock canyons of central Arizona. "But people forget that when you say, 'No,' in Washington, you're making it possible for families to say, 'Yes,' around their kitchen table."
Mr. Gramm's pre-eminent campaign pledge is to balance the Federal budget in four years, and not to run for re-election if he fails to do so. And in recent weeks -- perhaps in response to a memo from his own pollster, Linda DiVall, who warned that the Gramm campaign "offers pain and hard choices, no optimism" -- Senator Gramm has been trying to stress his plan's positive aspects.
"All we hear from Washington is the sacrifice involved in balancing the Federal budget," he said at a construction site in Phoenix. "We don't hear anything about the benefits."
To that end, he produced 27-year-old Ty Brewster, a struggling computer programmer with his wife, Lisa, and two young daughters, Morgan and McKenzie. "This is something we'd like to do if we could just get a little more of our tax dollars back," Mr. Brewster said, gesturing at a house in the making.
Mr. Gramm, projecting that a balanced budget would cut interest rates by two percentage points, rattled off figures about just how much money "average Arizonans" could save on home mortgages or car loans.
To the builder of a master-planned community here in Flagstaff, Mr. Gramm was even more blunt: "I'm gonna make you rich by balancing the Federal budget!"
Mr. Gramm is often given credit for preaching much the same economic message from the beginning of his career or, as he often puts it: "I was conservative before conservative was cool."
Drawing a contrast with Mr. Dole, whom he described as "a politician in search of a consensus" and someone who was "clueless" about the real meaning of last fall's election, Mr. Gramm said: "Party activists know that Senator Dole for 35 years has basically been, in the context of the modern Republican Party, a moderate. His hallmark has been cutting political deals and I think if there's ever been a time where the public is not inclined to go with a deal cutter, it's now."
Then, he quickly added: "Now I know him well. I like Senator Dole. I'm an admirer of his."
Mr. Gramm does have a talent for offering conservative positions in clear, colorful terms. "The social safety net has become a hammock," he says, or: "We must stop building prisons like Holiday Inns."
Mr. Gramm is occasionally compared in style and determination to another Texan, Lyndon B. Johnson. And a central question is whether he will forge a path, like Mr. Johnson, to the White House, or if he will wind up like another Texan, former Gov. John B. Connally, who created a $12 million juggernaut in the 1980 Presidential campaign to wind up with only a single delegate to show for it.
Mr. Gramm's chief strategist, Charles Black, said the big breakthrough would probably come just after Iowa and New Hampshire, in places like Arizona, whose primary comes one week later.
"Iowa's really Dole's best state in the whole country," Mr. Black said in an interview. "New Hampshire, that's a northeastern, New England state -- you've got to expect Dole to win those. Then, the calendar gets much more Gramm-friendly."
The Senator agreed: "One clear advantage I've got right now is that the people that are for me are for me. They have been for me when they have read every day that I was losing. They have for me under the worst of circumstances and they are not going anywhere. And if we begin to win, they're going to get very, very enthusiastic about it. And that's a strength."
NEXT: Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan Changes Regulation Of the Nation's Banks
 Japan's Ministry of Finance announced sweeping changes in the way it manages the country's banks, in hope of ending a series of financial disasters. The measures are intended to allow the banks to thrive or fail by market discipline. The Finance Minister said the package "will fundamentally change Japan's financial policy." 
 Banks will be required to bolster their internal inspection systems and develop more complete risk management. The new guidelines follow the Daiwa Bank scandal, in which unauthorized trades in New York led to losses of $1.1 billion. [Page A1.]
 
The Politics of Averting a Default
 As Federal departments remained unfinanced and some closed, the Clinton Administration prepared new fiscal steps to avoid default, and a Republican committee chairman talked of a "constitutional crisis." [A1.]
 
Ways to Stabilize A Racing Heart
 The F.D.A. approved the use of two heart defibrillators, which are implanted devices that deliver a jolt of electricity to stabilize a racing heart. The makers are Guidant and Ventritex, which will compete against the market leader, Medtronic. Guidant appeared to have an advantage over Ventritex in how its device can be marketed. [D2.]
 
Stocks Edge Higher
Stocks advanced broadly, but in unusually slow trading. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks rose 12.29 points, to 5,110.26, and broader measures also went up modestly. The regional Bell stocks and oil shares were among those rising, but many cyclical stocks weakened. [D8.]
 
Bond Prices Also Climb
 Treasury securities rose in thin volume, as the market waited for fresh news about the budget talks in Washington. Signs of weak retail sales lifted prices. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.03 percent, near a two-year low. [D15.]
 
Dissidents Challenge Tesoro
 Dissidents who own 5.7 percent of Tesoro Petroleum are trying to take over the company by replacing five directors. Tesoro stock rose 37.5 cents, to $9.375. [D2.]
 
China's Miracle Misses Millions
 China's economic miracle is improving lives along the coast, but is leaving behind millions of people in the interior. Increasingly, they are expressing anger over the disparity. [A1.]
 
In Mozambique, Hope vs. Reality
 Mozambique, one of the world's poorest countries, has a valuable natural-gas preserve, which the Enron Corporation plans to develop. It intends to build an 800-mile pipeline into the South African market, provided it can find a customer. But Enron may have alienated South African corporate buyers. [D4.]
 
A Tougher Year for Frequent Fliers
 Next year could bring less generous frequent-flier program awards, less flexibility to make plans, and increasing charges for flights, hotels and rental cars. Business Travel. [D7.]
 
Almost-Ads on Public TV and Radio
 Public radio and television stations have begun to stretch the boundaries of corporate underwriting. The radio spots are being dressed up with corporate jingles and toll-free numbers. And the TV spots are adding flashy logos and graphics. Advertising. [D2.]
 
Heating Oil Prices Rise
 Extended cold weather lifted energy prices further. January heating oil gained 0.41 cent, to 60.50 cents a gallon. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Budget Leader In House Fears Crisis on Debt

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration prepares another wave of fiscal maneuvers to avoid national default during the budget impasse, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee warned today that the Administration was courting a "Constitutional and legal crisis" by usurping Congress's right to control the national debt.
The accusation by Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, came as the partial shutdown of the Government entered its second full week, with no prospect that Federal workers would be back at their jobs until after the new year. 
 Moreover, three-quarters of a million Federal workers faced the prospect of getting hit in the pocketbook soon, receiving half their normal paychecks next Tuesday.
To the disappointment of Republicans, the shutdown has created little political pressure for a quick budget settlement. Mr. Archer's warning today, in fact, seemed part of an effort by the Congressional leadership to switch horses, hoping that the prospect of default, if the Administration's fiscal juggling is blocked, might work better in forcing President Clinton to accept their priorities for balancing the budget.
Republicans had tried to use the Government's debt ceiling as such a lever back in November, when borrowing approached the statutory limit of $4.9 trillion. But Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin managed to put off any debt crisis through the end of the year.
In a letter sent today to Mr. Rubin, Mr. Archer did not advocate default but said "it is increasingly unclear what legal actions remain open to you," and appeared to be laying the groundwork for a court challenge to any new steps the Administration takes. So far, the Republicans have avoided that route, after their lawyers concluded that Mr. Rubin acted within his authority in November by withholding interest payments to two huge Government trust funds.
In a statement today, the Treasury Department said that it was Mr. Rubin's "duty and intention to take all legal steps necessary to assure that the nation's financial obligations -- obligations already approved by Congress -- are honored."
Mr. Rubin has argued that he has been driven to take "extraordinary measures" because of Congress's refusal to approve an increase in the debt limit. Even the Republican budget, if adopted whole, would require a huge increase in that cap on Federal borrowing.
The accusations and counteraccusations today sounded a bit empty in downtown Washington, chiefly because the combatants were nowhere to be seen. Mr. Archer was home with his family in Texas, Mr. Rubin was in New York and only their fax machines seemed busily at work. In fact, the combined effects of holiday vacations and the partial Government shutdown made Washington seem as empty as Paris in August or Tokyo at New Year's.
Meanwhile, Federal workers were beginning to show the first signs of fraying tempers.
At the Social Security Administration's headquarters in Woodlawn, Md., about 100 furloughed employees held a peaceful protest to express frustration at their inability to work. Some carried signs that read "Furlough Newt," a reference to Speaker Newt Gingrich.
In fact, 56,000 of 66,000 Social Security personnel around the country are on the job. But Joseph Flynn, vice president of the local union representing the protesting workers, said workers were angry that furloughed employees, along with those on the job, were only going to receive paychecks for half their normal pay on Jan. 2.
Paychecks for most workers cover work performed before Dec. 15, when the Congressional approval expired to pay 280,000 furloughed employees at Federal agencies that have not already had their budgets passed and signed into law by the President.
These people face getting one week's pay instead of the normal two on Tuesday, as do an additional 480,000 who have been working because they are considered essential but cannot be paid yet because budget bills covering them have not yet been approved.
The Federal Government has a legal obligation to pay the employees who have remained on the job, and Mr. Gingrich has promised that the furloughed workers will also be fully paid later, at the cost to the Government of about $40 million a day.
But while the furloughed workers are a potent image for television cameras, the debt limit -- a subject so complex that most lawmakers here were only vaguely aware of its details until a month or so ago -- has once again become the centerpiece of political maneuvering.
When Congress refused to extend the borrowing limit, Mr. Rubin first said that default was "unthinkable" and insisted that even the threat of failure to pay America's debts could raise interest rates on Federal borrowing. Several major credit-rating agencies agreed, putting the United States on a version of "credit watch," warning investors that the country's political willingness to pay its lenders, as opposed to its ability to pay, could be in jeopardy.
In fact, interest rates have dropped, in part because Mr. Rubin has poured so much effort, and in some cases considerable imagination, into techniques to keep the country afloat.
In November, he announced that the Treasury would no longer invest the assets of two trust funds in Government securities that generate the interest that keeps the funds growing in size.
By turning those Treasury securities into cash, he reduced the Government's outstanding debt by billions of dollars, creating more room for it to borrow funds on the open market and pay Social Security checks, interest on Government bonds and other expenses.
But it is a game Mr. Rubin can play only briefly. Those two funds are covered by Congressional legislation that requires the Government to reimburse any lost interest. But in one of the oddities of Government accounting, those I.O.U.'s do not count against the debt limit.
On Friday Mr. Rubin will try another twist: he will forgo crediting $14.5 billion in a semiannual interest payment to the Civil Service Retirement Fund, essentially issuing another I.O.U. That savings will get the Government through January, and perhaps into the beginning of February. But after that, he told Congress recently, he will have to take other steps that he has refused to disclose publicly, apparently for fear that it will give Republicans time to try to head off the maneuvers.
Whatever the Treasury does next, it will almost certainly be open to legal challenge. Mr. Archer pointed out in his letter today that the House has already passed a nonbinding resolution calling for the current debt limit to be enforced. And he warned that "the Constitution is clear on this point," citing Article I, section 8, which reserves to Congress the power to "borrow money on the credit of the United States." Sidestepping that constitutional provision, Mr. Archer argued, would "undermine the constitutional balance of power."

HEADLINE: BellSouth Seeks to Ease Curbs on Profit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 26

 BODY:
State regulators in South Carolina are about to decide whether to remove the profit restraints on the BellSouth Corporation. In return, the phone company said it would not raise rates for homes or small businesses until 1998.
BellSouth said it needed the freedom from regulation to help it prepare for competition. Consumer advocates, however, say the utility could earn higher-than-normal profits for some time before it faced true competition for its 1.2 million South Carolina customers. 
 The state Public Service Commission is scheduled to consider the matter Wednesday.
BellSouth, which is based in Atlanta, said that being allowed to keep as much as it could earn, with some limits on rate increases, would be an incentive to become more efficient, not increase rates.
Consumer advocates are skeptical. South Carolina's telephone market "is not even remotely competitive on the local level," said Elliott Elam, a lawyer who specializes in utility regulation for the state Consumer Affairs Department.
BellSouth wants to change rates for large business customers and for special services, like call waiting, as often as needed to attract customers. It would keep rates for residential and small business customers the same for three years and then tie rate increases to the inflation rate.

HEADLINE: Stocks Climb In Unusually Light Trading

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
On the day after Christmas, the stock market climbed in unusually light trading, and analysts were left with little to analyze.
"The strength was in the blue chips," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers. "Institutions were dressing their portfolios for the year-end." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks rose 12.29 points, to 5,110.26. The big gainers included Coca-Cola, up 2 7/8, to 74 5/8; Merck, up 1 3/4, to 66 3/4; and DuPont, up 1, to 69 7/8.
Among the broader-based indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 2.34 points, to 614.30, and the Nasdaq composite index increased 2.48 points, to 1,049.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 2.22 points, to 543.77. Some 14.5 million shares changed hands on that exchange to push its annual trading above five billion shares for the first year ever.
With many traders staying home after the three-day weekend, turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was the lowest for a full day of trading since the July 4th period. A total of 217 million shares changed hands, compared with 289.6 million shares on Friday. Advances exceeded declines on the Big Board, 1,272 to 1,034.
The budget standoff in Washington, where the White House and Congress will not resume talks until Friday, added to the sluggishness of the market. "A growing contingent of investors are sitting on their hands," Mr. Stovall said. "It's a good reason not to do anything."
Regional Bell telephone stocks rallied after the companies helped to defeat a provision in the final version of the telecommunications-overhaul bill that would have delayed their ability to sell both local and long-distance services. Nynex rose 1 5/8, to 51 3/4; Bell Atlantic increased 1 1/4, to 66 7/8; and US West advanced 1, to 35 5/8.
Oil issues soared as cold winter weather helped to raise heating oil and natural gas prices. Royal Dutch closed at 140 3/8, up 1 1/2; Amerada Hess closed at 52, up 1/2; and Chevron closed at 52 1/2, up 3/8.
Some of the technology stocks were strong on expectations of above-average earnings. Texas Instruments jumped 2, to 53 1/2; Hewlett-Packard climbed 1, to 85 5/8; and Compaq added 1/8, to 49 7/8.
However, many of the cyclical stocks -- which tend to fall quickly when the economy turns down -- demonstrated weakness, apparently due to slowing earnings growth. Alcoa dropped 1 7/8, to 51 1/2; Caterpillar slipped 1 1/2, to 59 3/8; and Phelps Dodge declined 1 3/4, to 61 1/4.
With the release yesterday of the Johnson Redbook report that retail sales at chain and department stores slumped 2.4 percent in the four weeks ended last Saturday, some retailing companies were hard hit. Sears, Roebuck closed at 38 3/8, down 1 1/8; Gap closed at 41 3/8, down 1 7/8; and May Department Stores closed at 41 1/2, down 7/8.
Most of the European markets were closed for a holiday. But in France, the CAC-40 index fell 6.70 points, to 1,866.67.
